HEADLINE: President Of Albania Is Rebuffed On Charter

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania

 BODY:
The voters in what was once the most rigidly Communist country of Europe have dealt a sharp rebuff to their President, to whom they handed a landslide victory in their first democratic elections in 1992.
As a result, Albanians and diplomats fear that the infant democracy has lapsed into a deadlock that puts at risk the political and economic gains achieved since Communism began to crumble in 1991 in Europe's poorest country. 
 Early in November, Albania's voters rejected by 54 percent to 42 percent a draft constitution that President Sali Berisha had placed before the electorate. Dr. Berisha circumvented the Parliament, where approval by two-thirds would have been required, and chose a referendum in the belief that he was sure to win a majority.
The defeat is seen here as the low point in a steady decline in affection for the once hugely popular leader of the Democratic Party, not for what he has done but for how he does it.
Albania was repressively ruled by Enver Hoxha and his chosen successor, Ramiz Alia, from 1944 until the 1992 landslide by the party of Dr. Berisha, a cardiologist of boundless energy and impatience. For too many Albanians, Dr. Berisha resembles his dictatorial predecessors in style, although not in content.
Even leaders of the largest opposition party, the Socialist successors to the Communists, grant that the President has effectively led the transition toward democracy and a market economy. "The Democratic Party and Berisha have played a positive role," said Luan Hajdaraga, a vice president of the Socialists.
Mr. Hajdaraga and Arta Dabulla, a member of the party presidency, said the referendum showed that early Parliamentary elections were called for to reflect the present mood of the country. Parliament elects the President.
Dr. Berisha's disregard for Parliament, where defections from his own party have deprived him of the two-thirds majority he had obtained in the elections, and the one-man character of his referendum campaign proved counterproductive.
"Albanians were not against the constitution but against the style of the propaganda," said Ismail Kadare, a writer. "The television propaganda was frenetic. It recalled the days of Communism."
By all accounts, the President totally identified himself with the constitution, although it was drafted by a parliamentary committee with advice from Western experts. He campaigned for it with the same vigor and disdain for opponents that characterized his presidential race.
"He signed autographs on the constitution, as though it was his personal property," said Agim Isaku, director of the Open Society Foundation, which is financed by George Soros, the American financier.
Opposition politicians criticized the draft as giving too many powers to the President, but even they said the voters rejected the President's style rather than the charter.
In an interview, Dr. Berisha vigorously rejected all criticism, while still reflecting his personal identification with the charter, which he referred to as "my constitution."
He said there was no question of calling early elections or submitting a new draft to Parliament. In a round table with party leaders, he proposed that Parliament should name a new drafting committee. As alternatives, he suggested a non-Parliamentary group of experts or the adoption of a constitution modeled on that of one of the countries of the European Union. He excluded the French Constitution, which provides for a strong President.
"Berisha has a clear desire for a democratic society and a market economy," one ambassador said. "But does he know what these things mean?" He answered his question by recalling that like all Albanians, the President is a product of a system that denied its people any knowledge of open societies.
Mr. Kadare, the writer, said he saw a silver lining in the referendum: "It showed the people have truly progressed. Despite the frenetic television propaganda, the people calmly said no."

Ex-Leader's Sentence Reduced
 TIRANA, Albania, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today reduced the nine-year prison term of the former President, Ramiz Alia, by three years, but gave no reason.
Mr. Alia is to be released in September, taking into account two years he spent under house arrest, reductions of his sentence by an appeals court and an amnesty announced on Sunday, court officials said. The Supreme Court also substantially reduced the sentences of other former top officials.
Mr. Alia was convicted of abuse of power in 1992 along with nine other members of the Politburo.

HEADLINE: Trade Talks In Miami: Momentum Isn't There

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The Administration raised the prospect of big things when it announced a summit meeting of the hemisphere's leaders last year, including a possible agreement on a trade zone embracing North and South America within 10 to 20 years.
But when leaders from 34 nations meet next week in Miami, the results will be far from bold: the leaders are not expected to agree on a firm plan or date for a trade area. 
 In a briefing today, Administration officials sought to put the best face on the talks, saying the leaders, from every nation in the hemisphere except Cuba, for the first time will call for setting up a trade zone from Alaska to Argentina.
Some Latin American and Caribbean officials are disappointed that the meeting will not accomplish more; but, showing how much expectations have dropped, many leaders say the most important thing is that the meeting will improve United States ties with Latin America, which has felt neglected by President Clinton, partly because he has not visited it as President.
"It's important for upgrading the political linkages between two areas that are so important to each other," said the Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, Paulo-Tarso Flecha de Lima.
Administration officials insist that the summit meeting, the first since 1967, will not yield just photo opportunities and hollow oratory. They say the leaders will plan high-level meetings over the next 15 months to explore how to remove trade barriers and how to harmonize rules in areas like foreign investment and telecommunications.
"This is not a trade summit," Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the senior White House counselor, said at a briefing. "It is an overall summit. It will focus on economic integration and convergence."
Peter Hakim, president of Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington research center, said: "As it stands now, the agreements that they're going to reach just aren't very inspiring. Nonetheless there's no sense that the summit will fail, because expectations have been falling."
For the Administration the summit talks, Dec. 9 through 11, have proved to be a headache. Brazil and Mexico have complained about the date because both countries have recently elected new Presidents.
Many countries have grumbled that having the meeting in Miami will force Cuba onto the agenda. Cuban-American groups are threatening protest marches to press for a condemnation of Fidel Castro and to urge President Clinton to admit 23,000 Cubans being held at Guantanamo Bay Naval Station.
The summit meeting has crystallized another set of tensions for President Clinton. Latin American nations want to use the talks to push for increased access to the huge United States market just when President Clinton is under fire on several fronts for opening the door too wide to low-priced imports.
Some Latin leaders are upset that the meeting is not expected to set a date for a trade pact even though the United States and 17 other nations in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum have set 2020 as the goal for their pact.
But United States officials played down the lack of a date. "The question of date is rather a subsidiary issue," said the deputy United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky. "It's the view of many countries that a date becomes rather superfluous" because "there is so much substance and direction with respect to both the vision and the manner" of moving to a trade zone.
Argentina wanted the leaders to agree to sign an accord by 2000 that would set up a trade zone by 2015. But that move was opposed by Brazil and several other nations, which fear that moving toward a hemisphere-wide trade zone would distract them from developing smaller trade areas like Mercosur, which includes Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay.
"Some countries think that if you set a date that's just a short time away, it's unrealistic, and some think that if you set a date far away, it's too diffuse," said the Argentine Ambassador to the United States, Raul Enrique Granillo Ocampo. "We have decided on an agenda of concrete steps to move in that direction."

HEADLINE: Senate Seems Set to Approve Trade Accord

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today received commitments from several key Senators to support the overhaul of a 124-nation free trade pact, and both Democratic and Republican leaders said they were now certain the Senate would pass the accord in a vote scheduled for Thursday night.
Working to build on their victory on Tuesday in the House of Representatives, President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and several members of the Administration spent all day cajoling the dozen or so senators still undecided. 
 By the end of the day their initial fear of falling just short of the needed votes had melted away. A simple majority of 51 is sufficient to pass the legislation to implement the agreement, but first proponents must get 60 votes to waive the budget rules that apply to any action that would increase the Federal deficit.
"We're in the mid-60's now, I think," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is the floor manager of the bill. "I'm beginning to feel more comfortable."
Tonight, White House officials were feeling confident enough to tell some senators that as long as they voted in favor of waiving the budget rules -- a separate issue that will come to the floor before the actual General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- they were free to vote against the accord itself if they needed political cover in their constituencies.
In London, Senator Bob Dole, the future majority leader, who endorsed the accord last week after reaching a compromise with the White House, said, "I feel confident we have the votes."
The White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, predicted that "by the time the vote is cast tomorrow, we will have the votes."
Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, decided tonight to vote for the pact after long talks with Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. "I don't want to see a single job lost in this country, especially to nations with low-wage workers," he said. "But with or without GATT, we face that reality."
Senator Lautenberg said the Treasury Department had told him that the agreement would create 18,000 jobs in New Jersey, though outside experts said they were mystified about how the Administration was making such calculations.
GATT, the most radical change in trade policy in 40 years, would lower American tariffs by about a third and submit American laws to review by a new trade-policing body, the World Trade Organization.
In several hours of debate today, senators described two very different visions of the nation's economic future. Proponents painted a future in which expanded free trade bolsters American exports around the world. Opponents predicted that cheap imports would drive more American blue-collar workers out of their factories, and that the World Trade Organization would become a huge, all-powerful bureaucracy, dictating changes in American worker safety and in environmental laws.
Mr. Moynihan mocked those who contend that the World Trade Organization will become "some kind of world government."
"To those who think it is a behemoth, consider this," Mr. Moynihan said. "The GATT," which is an organization as well as an agreement, "has 450 employees. The World Trade Organization is scheduled to increase that number by 15. That will bring it to roughly one-third the size of the Capitol police force."
As the Senate vote has neared, major American business groups have been lobbying heavily to win approval of the pact, arguing that a vote against GATT is a vote for isolationism. They have sponsored a series of advertisements carrying pictures of Senator Reed Smoot and Representative Willis Chatman Hawley, the authors of the Tariff Act of 1930, a law that many historians said contributed to World War II.
Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who is the Senate's most vocal opponent of the pact, said: "That's a bum rap! Don't give me that war argument and Smoot and Hawley."
Mr. Hollings is from a textile manufacturing state, which will be hard hit by the pact's reduction in tariffs. But over the past few days he has been outnumbered by senators who have concluded that their states will gain more by exporting wheat, airplane parts or software than they will lose as aging industries fall by the wayside.
Senator Patty Murray, a Democrat from Washington, the home state of the Boeing Corporation, said, "My friends and family understand that international commerce is the lifeblood of our economy."

HEADLINE: Salinas Sunset: Triumphs, Setbacks

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Barely a day before he is to resign his presidency, Carlos Salinas de Gortari was striking his usual poses on the television news: In one state, he was cutting ribbon on a new bridge; in another, a new hospital; in a third, a new subway line.
"He is working as though it were his first day!" the pro-Government anchor marveled for anyone who might have missed the message. 
 What could be said as easily, however, is that after six busy years in an office to which Mexico allows no re-election, there is still no end to the campaign for political legitimacy that followed a vote that many Mexicans thought Mr. Salinas won by fraud. The fact that he may stand as the man who most changed this country in the second half of the century has somehow seemed to get lost on the 46-year-old leader's way to his last inauguration.
With the striped sash he will hand over on Thursday to his chosen successor, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, 42, Mr. Salinas will deliver a restructured and strengthened economy, a political system in the throes of democratization, a society that overcame two centuries of nationalistic mistrust to join the United States and Canada in the North American Free Trade Agreement.
But as Mr. Salinas has prepared to leave office, he has been haunted by reminders of the challenges he sought to avoid.
While he has hurried around the provinces, the central square of the capital has filled with angry leftists camped out in protest against what they contend have been fraudulent state elections. Members of the federal elections board have joined the opposition in complaining that the last-minute reforms by the Government to the political system that its party has dominated for six decades were too little and too late.
In one Mexico City suburb, the young lawyer who quit last week as Deputy Attorney General was still railing today that corrupt old-guard leaders of Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party had blocked his investigation into the murder of his brother, the party's reform-minded secretary general. (The main target of his accusations, Ignacio Pichardo, the party president, was named today as Energy Secretary in Mr. Zedillo's new Cabinet.)
Brokers in the gleaming downtown stock exchange worried about a possible devaluation of the peso, which has come under renewed pressure as political uncertainty and a sluggish economy have slowed the flow of foreign capital needed to cover the huge deficit in Mexico's current account.
And across the city, politicians worried about Chiapas, the southern state where rebels claiming fraud in local elections there are threatening turmoil if the Governor-elect tries to take office as scheduled, seven days after Mr. Zedillo.
In Tabasco, another southern state, earlier this month, a thoughtful laid-off oil worker named Alejandro Padron summed up the Salinas administration's contradictions.
Wearing the black boots he worked in until his 11-year job became one of 100,000 sacrificed to modernize the inefficient state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, Mr. Padron, 30, said he understood the need for the economic overhaul and could imagine other bright futures for himself and his family. In a year of searching, however, he had been able to find none in Tabasco.
"It has not been the success they say on television," he said of the upbeat advertisements that the administration often used to extol its triumphs. "He is leaving, but we remain. The problems remain."
Against what sometimes seemed this year like great odds, Mr. Salinas succeeded in consolidating the power of a new political generation.
The Cabinet that Mr. Zedillo unveiled today was filled with faces from the United States-trained ranks of the Salinistas. Jaime Serra Puche, 43, the Trade Minister who led the campaign for Nafta, won the post of Finance Secretary. The President's chief of staff will be a 36-year-old economist trained at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Throughout what has become a bitter political battle over Mr. Salinas's legacy, there has been little challenge to the notion that the new team will receive a far healthier economy than its predecessors did.
More than 1,000 state companies have been sold off or closed. Enterprises ranging from bus transportation to road construction have been deregulated. Debt payments have been slashed, the budget has run a surplus for the first time in memory, and inflation has plunged.
With Nafta as a glimmering lure, foreign investors have poured in $50 billion in six years. Each year, lists of the world's billionaires show more Mexicans.
But the latter fact has come increasingly to symbolize something gone badly wrong. While the richest fifth of the population has grown richer, getting more than 54 percent of the nation's income by 1992, the poorer half drew only 18 percent.
Mr. Salinas sought to ease the social and political impact of his austerity with a $4 billion-a-year antipoverty effort, the National Solidarity Program. But as late as the end of 1993, he did not plan significant political changes to meet swelling demands for greater democracy.
Even his sharpest critics, however, did not imagine the hundreds of peasants who marched into four provincial towns in Chiapas just as Nafta was taking effect with the New Year. Nor were they less than shocked by the still-mysterious assassination of the governing party's first presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, on March 21, or the slaying in downtown Mexico City of another prominent reformer, Jose Francisco Ruiz Masseiu, the party's secretary general, six months later.
In an interview this month, Mr. Salinas disputed the idea that the two assassinations suggested a failure to adequately confront corruption and drug trafficking within the ruling party. "Every time we had information and evidence, we acted," he said.
As for Chiapas, he argued that the proof of change in Mexico was in its ability to withstand the shock.
"If during five years we had not carried out social and economic reforms and made progress on the political side, an event like Chiapas would have become a source of general instability in the country," he said. "We had the means and the space to build a negotiated solution, when in the past the means had always been extermination."

SERBS SPURN U.N. LEADER
The leader of the Bosnian Serbs spurned the United Nations Secretary General, refusing to appear at a meeting at the Sarajevo airport. Secretary General Boutros-Ghali warned that if Muslims and Serbs did not cooperate with the United Nations, he could not keep peacekeeping troops in Bosnia. A1
 

DOLE PRODS MAJOR ON AIR RAIDS

HEADLINE: More Men in Prime of Life Spend Less Time Working

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
By all accounts, Americans are more overworked than ever. Unemployment has dipped to less than 6 percent, overtime is at a record high and many workers are holding down more than one job. So why are so many men -- healthy men in the prime of life -- working less than ever before?
Even as the powerful American job machine has churned out tens of millions of new jobs in the last two decades, a raft of recent studies disclose that men past college age and well before the usual retirement age of the early to mid-60's are working much less than men did 10 or 20 years ago. A rising proportion are neither working nor looking for work. 
 The most stunning change is the shrinking share of men who serve as traditional breadwinners -- the male who works full time, year-round, year in and year out. Among young and middle-aged men, the share performing that basic family role has dropped sharply.
In the decade of the 1970's almost 80 percent of men from 22 to 58 worked full time, year round in at least 8 of 10 years. During the 1980's, however, among that same age group, the fraction working under the same conditions -- call them the hard-core employed -- dropped by nine percentage points, to 70 percent.
Men's experience stands in sharp contrast to that of women, who are working more and for higher pay.
As America's economy increasingly focuses on advanced services and high technology, the growth in jobs that blue-collar men traditionally favored in factories, construction and transportation services has not kept up with the growth in the working-age population. Adjusted for inflation, the wages and benefits such men can command have plunged by as much as one-fifth since the late 1970's.
The result? Those men are not, as popular wisdom would have it, mostly working more to make up the lost pay. Instead, as the rewards of working have shrunk, they are mostly working less.
"It's the Achilles' heel in the American job success story," said Richard B. Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard University and editor of a book of articles, "Working Under Different Rules." "This is one of those long-term big shocks to the whole society."
The decline in work among men has worrisome implications, both liberal and conservative economists agree. All too often, the only available alternatives to steady, full-time work are off-the-books employment or even crime. The young, the poorly educated, school dropouts -- the same demographic group that is working less and whose opportunities and pay have contracted -- is the group most likely to get into serious trouble.
Indeed, the number of men in prison, on parole or probation now exceeds the number counted as unemployed. In 1993, according to Government data, there were 4.6 million adult men under such state supervision compared with the 4.2 million who were out of work.
"The equivalent of the long-term European unemployed who are on the dole is the U.S. prison population," Professor Freeman said. "They give them welfare and we put them in prison with free housing, food and TV. We haven't escaped the problem."
Indeed, the decline of work among men is not limited to the United States. European men are working less, too.
In contrast to the European situation, however, the American decline in men at work does not appear to have been caused by welfare payments, unemployment checks or disability payments that are so generous they tend to discourage employment, researchers say. Such alternatives to a paycheck have, if anything, become leaner and harder to get in the United States since the early 1970's. Instead, the drop is a result of lower pay and fewer opportunities for the kinds of jobs less-educated men have long filled.
By and large, the rise of a sizable nonworking class -- along with an even larger group of prime-age men who are frequently unemployed, work part time or do temporary work -- is concentrated among academic underachievers. Men with high school degrees or dropouts are being pushed out or are opting out of steady full-time work.
"There's been a huge decline in work for prime-age men," said Lawrence F. Katz, a labor economist at Harvard and the former chief economist of the Labor Department, "and it's concentrated among the nonwhite, less-educated and men whose pay is below the average."
So what is going on? Think of these men as the counterparts of the farmers who left the country for the big cities, starting at the turn of the century and stretching well into the 1940's, 1950's and 1960's. What makes this transition so much more traumatic is that factories and services no longer provide plenty of jobs for blue-collar men.
Today, most of the new jobs for people with less education and experience are considered "women's work:" clerical, sales, personal service. A new jobs study by McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm, found that in the 1980's the United States created 27 clerical, sales and service jobs per thousand working-age Americans. At the same time, 16 production, transportation and laborer jobs per thousand working-age Americans disappeared.
Women with relatively little education and low pay have not experienced the same sharp pay declines that men have faced. And they are actually working more, not less.
But men, with rare exceptions, have not joined women in these growth sectors. The fraction of men who have moved into so-called pink-collar jobs like practical nursing or clerical work remains negligible. It is not just that women's work generally pays less or that it may require greater skill with numbers and words, men are often loath to take pink-collar jobs, regardless of the appeal, and employers are equally unwilling to hire them.
"For men, whether black, Latino or white, there are strong cultural and social norms about what is appropriate work," said Rhonda M. Williams, an economist at the University of Maryland. "Given the changes in the occupational and industrial distribution, there are clearly groups of men who are going to suffer more from adhering to those norms."
The decline in men's work requiring more brawn than brains is quite drastic. A recent study by Stephen J. Rose at the National Commission for Employment Policy, a Government study group in Washington, tracked the careers of a large number of prime-age men through the 1970's and 1980's. In the 1970's, 68 percent of men with less than a high school education, who make up 15 percent of the male work force, worked full time, year round in 8 of 10 years. By the 1980's, that fraction dropped to barely half the group, 51 percent.
The deterioration for black men was similarly startling. For that group, the proportion of "hard-core employed" dropped from 73 percent in the 1970's to 51 percent in the 1980's.
Other measures tell a similar story.
Since the end of the 1960's, the share of prime-age men who are not in school, on the job or looking for work has tripled, from 3 percent to 9 percent, according to Robert H. Haveman, an economist at the University of Wisconsin. He also found that in 1992 one-quarter of high school dropouts had no official job at all, not even for a single week.
For those with high school degrees, one of 10 white men did not hold a job last year, compared with only one of 50 at the end of the 1960's. Among nonwhites, 17 percent reported they had no job, compared with 3 percent 25 years ago.
In the meantime, the stereotypical overworked middle-class white-collar male, particularly the man who commands a sizable paycheck, is coming home late for dinner just as often as he ever did. Men with college degrees and those with more advanced education worked longer hours in the 1980's than in the 1970's. A solid 79 percent worked full time, year-round during most of the decade versus 77 percent in the 1970's. Men in the top 40 percent of wage earners -- those paid an average of $19 an hour or more -- also worked more.
Nor are women and minorities, the beneficiaries of more than a decade of affirmative action in the workplace, crowding this kind of male worker out of good jobs. That is true even though it is this relatively affluent male, not his blue-collar counterpart, who is far more likely to have a substantial cushion of savings to support early retirement if he wants. And many such men are married to professional women, whose commitment to working has grown the most and whose salaries might be thought to allow such men to take it a little easier.
There are some signs that younger men are responding to the travails of their fathers and older brothers. High school graduation rates for young black men are up. And college enrollment rates for males are at a record high.
But few economists are sanguine that the decline in wages at the bottom of the pay scale is over or that men will not continue to respond by working less.
"I don't see much," said Chinhua Juhn, an economist at the University of Houston and the author of two influential studies on the topic, "that indicates that technology is going to shift back in favor of less-skilled people."

HEADLINE: 3,000 Nurses Are Expected To Lose Hospital Jobs by '97

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
A new study of health-worker employment forecasts an accelerating decline in jobs in the next three years in New York City, even as the health-care system grows.
The study, prepared for the Bureau of Health Resources Development of the State Department of Health, predicted that about 3,000 registered nurses would lose hospital jobs between 1995 and 1997. Of these, the report said, 2,000 are likely to find work in nursing homes or in home care. But new nurses, arriving in the work force through graduation, would increase the surplus of registered nurses to 1,800. 
 "Our general conclusions are that hospital-based employment in New York City over the next three years will decrease substantially, with most of the decrease coming from registered nurses, laboratory technicians and food-service workers," the report said. "We cannot make predictions for overall hospital employment since we have not studied all hospital-based occupations, but we anticipate a decline in the demand for hospital workers roughly 10 to 15 percent over the three years."
The report said that as of November 1993, there were 291,800 private-sector health jobs in New York City, with 157,200, or 53.8 percent of them, in hospitals. Other jobs in nursing homes, doctors' offices and home health care, as well as 60,000 jobs in government agencies, brought the total to 350,000, or 12 percent of the 2.9 million jobs in the city.
The study was conducted under the supervision of Prof. Howard S. Berliner, the chairman of the department of Health Services Management and Policy of the New School for Social Research and Christine T. Kovner, a professor in the Division of Nursing at New York University.
The report also predicted that there would be an increased demand for nurse's aides, physical therapists and physician assistants; weak growth in demand for licensed practical nurses, and a decline of perhaps as many as 2,000 jobs for food-service workers.
"The major factor that will affect the health-care system in New York City is the downsizing of its acute-care hospital capacity, which will directly lead to a reduction in the number of people working in hospitals," the report said. "The reasons for the downsizing of hospitals include the growth of managed care, attempts by insurance companies to reduce expensive hospital use and changes in technology that allow more medical procedures to be done in office and clinic-based settings."
The report said, "Although the number and size of hospitals in New York City have been declining over the past decade, we expect this process to accelerate markedly over the next few years."
The study forecast that 2,000 to 4,500 acute-care hospital beds, or 7 to 15 percent of total capacity, could close in the city by the year 2000. "This decline in acute-care capacity will be accompanied by a reduction in the hospital work force," it said.
But, it continued, the health-care system in the city will be growing and providing new jobs. The report forecast growth in office jobs, in ambulatory and primary-care clinics and in the home health-care industry.

The Economy
 
The percentage of men working has declined in the United States -- to about 70 percent from 80 percent in the 1970's, at the same time as the number of jobs available to the less educated has fallen. [Page A1.]
 
The economy expanded at a 3.9 percent annual pace in the third quarter, pointing to a strong holiday shopping season. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Stocks Flat Despite Data On Economy

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For once, good news on Main Street did not automatically lead to bad news on Wall Street. But yesterday's relative tranquillity, which may have been attributable to technical factors rather than real market sentiment, could give way to a more pronounced selloff of stocks by tomorrow, when job-growth figures are released.
The stock market closed mixed yesterday, despite evidence of an unexpectedly strong economy, slowed only slightly by the Federal Reserve's tightening of interest rates this year. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.68 point, to 3,739.23, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 1.48 points, to 453.69. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 1.16 points, to 750.32.
The Commerce Department's second of three estimates for third-quarter gross domestic product, released yesterday, showed the economy growing at a robust annual rate of 3.9 percent. Private economists had expected only a slight increase, to 3.5 percent, from the initial estimate of 3.4 percent. That compares with 4.1 percent in the second quarter.
Business inventories were also revised down, probably signaling robust consumer demand and indicating further potential for inflation.
The renewed fears of higher inflation and the resulting plunge in stock and bond prices that typically follow such news of robust economic growth did not materialize. Even the dollar, which typically would have fallen, was relatively steady.
"What stocks benefited from is that bonds rallied despite the strong figures for the economy," said Gregory A. Nie, senior vice president, technical analysis, at Kemper Securities.
Bond traders seemed to be unconcerned about the strong economy. Bond prices rose slightly. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 8 percent, from 8.03 percent.
Tomorrow the Labor Department is scheduled to report November unemployment as well as changes in nonfarm payroll jobs. Some analysts say that if unemployment is low and job creation sufficiently high, those numbers may prompt a selloff in stocks.
Six stocks advanced for every five that fell on the New York Stock Exchange, with rising stocks outnumbering falling stocks by 1,263 to 1,011 Eighty-eight stocks established new lows, and 22 established new highs.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.49 point, to 248.41, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.77 point, to 433.86.
Some stocks rose. The Apache Corporation, an oil and natural gas developer, bought some Texaco oilfields for $600 million. Apache rose 2 7/8, to 28.
Others stocks fell. Applied Materials, a developer of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, dropped 4 5/8, to 47 7/8, after the company said that production bottlenecks might hurt profits.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Deal Is Set On American Brands Unit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
American Brands Inc. will sell its insurance unit to the American General Corporation for $1.17 billion, the companies announced today. They disclosed earlier in the week that they were negotiating a sale.
American General will buy the Franklin Life Insurance Company of Springfield, Ill., from American Brands. Analysts said American Brands, with assets of $45 billion, could afford both Franklin and Unitrin, a Chicago-based insurance company that is another planned acquisition, as long as the company did not take on too much debt. Unitrin's board has rejected American General's $2.6 billion offer as too low. 
 The A. M. Best Company and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which rate insurers on their claims-paying ability, placed their top-notch ratings for Franklin under review today for possible downgrading.
The Franklin acquisition would mark further concentration by American Brands, based in Old Greenwich, Conn., on name-brand consumer products like Jim Beam and Old Grand-Dad bourbon.
The company also plans to sell its United States tobacco business. But its plans met a setback in Washington today when the Federal Trade Commission followed through on its promise to challenge the proposed $1 billion purchase of the American Tobacco Company by B.A.T Industries P.L.C. of London.
The commission voted 3 to 0 to file an administrative complaint that contends that the buyout would reduce competition in the cigarette industry in violation of antitrust laws. A hearing must now be held before an administrative law judge.
The planned sale of Franklin Life is the second time this month that a nonfinancial services company has said it is getting out of the insurance business, where values have been battered by rising interest rates.
"It takes a different set of skills for a nonfinancial services company to run an insurer that has to compete against banks, mutual funds and other insurance companies," said Michael Albanese, vice president at A.M. Best in Oldwick, N.J.
If the deal is completed, American General, based in Houston, will get a solid insurance company and become one of 10 biggest publicly held life insurers in the country.
The companies said they expected to complete the Franklin transaction in the first quarter of 1995.
"Franklin is an outstanding company, but it doesn't fit in with our products," an American Brands spokesman, Roger W. Baker, said, adding that American Brands might use cash from the sale to buy other consumer-products makers.
American General stock rose 25 cents, to $26.25, while shares of American Brands rose 87.5 cents, to $35.25, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Yearning for Yemen, Dying in Brooklyn;
Stray Bullet Breaks a Cycle of Work, Saving and Trips Home

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
He kept to a dichotomous, back-and-forth regimen, and it was the same way with his Arab friends. He would work behind the counter in one of the storefront Brooklyn delis, squirreling away money that he would mail to his expanding family in Yemen. When the separation would nag at him, he would return home for a few months. Then he would start the cycle all over again.
Some of his friends could endure years between visits with their families, but Nagi Al Qotaini would brood and could not go that long. Sometimes, he would last only four or five months. He had been doing this for nearly 12 years, since he was 18, but it never got any easier. 
 In the last go around, he arrived in Brooklyn in the middle of July and might have been ready to visit Yemen in a few months. As it turned out, he made his final trip home on Tuesday night in a casket. Today, he is being buried.
He was earnest and was hoping very much to make more of himself in the United States, but he ended up one of those freakish New York tragedies. He made news because he was hit by a bullet intended for someone else.
Last Friday evening, while walking down a bustling Crown Heights avenue to fetch fruits and vegetables for his dinner, he was struck in the upper chest by a bullet that the authorities believe was fired by a police officer. He was dead by the time he got to a hospital.
The officer, who was standing about 160 feet from Mr. Al Qotaini, was actually shooting at Keith Richardson, who the police said was reaching for a handgun tucked in his waistband. Mr. Richardson was also killed. The police said the weapon he was carrying was a BB gun.
The police said Mr. Richardson, 34, had been arrested numerous times since 1977, including on charges of armed robbery, rape, burglary and drug possession. He was convicted of one drug charge and a number of minor offenses and has spent time in jail on several occasions, they said. He was shot just outside the Flavor for Ya pool hall, one of his favored haunts.
Friends knew Mr. Al Qotaini as a serene man with classic aspirations that never shrank in scope. Like other immigrants, he was passionate about doing well enough so that his children would live a more satisfying life. He had four young children and his wife is pregnant with a fifth. They live in Bedin, Yemen, which is where Mr. Al Qotaini was born 29 years ago.
The lonely, cross-ocean life was imbued in him by his father, Abdo. In Yemen, the elder Mr. Al Qotaini has a small farm, where his wife and some of his 12 other children live. For 22 years, he has been working in delis and food stores in Brooklyn, most recently at the A & A Grocery on Kingston Avenue. About three years ago, he brought his wife to Brooklyn to see if she might want to live here. She stayed a few months but did not care for the city and went back.
Nagi Al Qotaini married when he was 14, and four years later he came to New York, full of raw energy. He found companionship among the dozens of Arabs from Yemen who live and work in and around Crown Heights, mostly in the jumble of delis and candy stores.
During interludes between shifts, when he sat and bantered with friends, he sketched out the high hopes he harbored.
"He always dreamed to live good, to have a nice business and a nice house," said Feisul Selah, a friend who worked near him at the Prospect Deli and Grocery. "He always dreamed for his children to go to good schools and to be a doctor or something like that. He always dreamed a big, good dream."
He added: "He hated problems. When he saw problems, he walked away. When he saw an argument, he would walk away."
Mr. Selah also lives the dual-continent life. In his case, he has not been home to Yemen to see his family for two years. "Nagi could never go that long," he said. "He was crazy for his family."
Mr. Al Qotaini and his friends came here to bring an upward spiral to their lives. "Everyone dreams to come to America," Mr. Selah said. "America is the best country. The land of opportunity."
But Mr. Selah said that it was hard for their children to go to American schools and they felt the neighborhoods they lived in were too dangerous for young children. So their families would usually remain overseas at least until the children were older. Mr. Al Qotaini talked of bringing his family over here at some point.
He worked at various delis, subject to their shifting economic circumstances. Two weeks ago, he started at the Taiz Supermarket and Deli on Nostrand Avenue. It is a narrow storefront grocery, like so many others spaced along Nostrand. On one side is the shuttered Superior Market and on the other is the Beauty Corner. The front window is ornamented with prices of sale items. Inside, there are the newspapers up front next to two-liter bottles of soda, a rack of bread, an ice cream case and a cold cuts cabinet.
George Maflahi, his boss, paid him $4.25 an hour, and he would work different shifts, eight hours a day, seven days a week. Mr. Maflahi said he was here legally and had a green card. He would operate the cash register, stock shelves, make sandwiches -- the deli life.
He shared Mr. Maflahi's apartment next door to the store. "He only worked and went home and slept," Mr. Maflahi said. "He was a nice, honest man, working hard like the other Arabs do."
Mr. Maflahi, who has been in America since he was 14, also has a wife and four children back in Yemen. He sees them sporadically, calls and writes as often as he can. "If you visit every two years, it's not a problem," he said. "That's life."
As it got past 7 that Friday evening, Mr. Al Qotaini was still on duty at the deli. He told Mr. Maflahi, "I'm going to get some fruit and vegetables." It was common for them to cook vegetables in the back of the store for their dinner. It was about 7:25 when he stepped outside the door. Carol James, who works at a nearby pharmacy and had just bought some food at the deli, walked along with him.
They strolled south down Nostrand toward a Korean grocery. They got to the Nostrand Travel Bureau, and that was as far as they would go. Shots rang out, and Ms. James cowered next to the wall. Mr. Al Qotaini dropped to the ground. When the shooting ceased, she told him it was safe to get up. Then, she realized he had been hit. She began screaming.
"I heard the shots," Mr. Maflahi said. "I was behind the cash register, and I had a lot of customers. One customer came back and said, 'Your friend got shot.' I went outside, and it was true. I saw my friend laid down."
On Tuesday afternoon, it was mild and sunny. Shortly before 1 P.M., a gray and black hearse backed up to the At-Taqwa mosque on Bedford Avenue. The light gray casket containing Mr. Al Qotaini's body was gently carried inside. About 50 people had shown up to pay their final respects, their shoes stored on racks at the door.
A short prayer was said, while the hearse waited outside. Then the casket was loaded back into the hearse and the driver headed off to Kennedy International Airport, so the body could be flown to Yemen to be buried today in Bedin.
Outside the mosque, Abdo Al Qotaini was morose and he was quiet. He did not have much that he wanted to say. He was traveling back to Yemen with the body. He was not sure when he would return. He said he was still trying to understand all this.
"What can I say?" he said. "He was a good son. A good person. What can I say?"

HEADLINE: G.D.P. Growth Is Raised To 3.9% for 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The economy grew faster during the summer than had been previously estimated, pointing to a strong holiday shopping season, fresh Government figures showed today.
Total output of goods and services expanded at a 3.9 percent annual pace in the third quarter as business investment boomed in the face of progressively higher interest rates. A month ago, the rise in gross domestic product for the July-September period was put at 3.4 percent. 
 "This momentum is self-sustaining," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, noting that today's revision showed a bigger contribution from business investment and personal consumption and no longer any contribution from goods moving into inventory.
A buildup of inventories, which helped drive G.D.P. during the first half of the year, typically represents a borrowing of activity from future periods when factories slow while stocks are pared.
Inflation associated with the G.D.P. accounts was revised slightly higher -- to 3.4 percent from 3.2 percent as gauged by the fixed-weight index of domestic prices -- but neither economists nor the bond market expressed anxiety.
In its initial tally of corporate profits for the quarter, the Commerce Department said profits from current production had climbed 2 percent, or $10.7 billion. While this was much less than the second-quarter surge of 7.5 percent, the earlier period benefited substantially from a rebound following the California earthquake in January. First-quarter profits slumped 4.8 percent.
In a separate Government report, a Federal Reserve revision showed American industry operating a bit further below inflation-threat levels than previously thought. Factories, mines and utilities ran at 84.6 percent of capacity during October -- still the highest since April 1989 -- instead of the 84.9 percent reported two weeks ago. A utilization rate above 85 percent or so is considered in the danger area for accelerating inflation.
As part of scheduled revisions of capacity and production data, the Fed said production was stronger in 1991 and 1992 than previously reported but slower in 1993 and 1994. The Fed also raised capacity growth for 1991, 1992 and 1993. But none of the changes significantly altered prospects for the economy, analysts said.
Two other reports today, from corporate purchasing managers in two regions of the country, showed rising cost pressures similar to those found recently in other areas but which have yet to be much reflected at the consumer level or in wages.
Purchasing managers in the Chicago area reported that the prices-paid component of its index had jumped to 79.4 from 72.5, while New York managers said the component there jumped to 77 from 70, nearly twice the average rise in the three preceding months.
Still, it was the surprisingly large upward revision of G.D.P. that captured most of the attention today.
For analysts, the 3.9 percent annual rate of expansion confirmed economic strength they had suspected. But the data also implied that vigorous growth would continue, and possibly accelerate, before higher interest rates take their toll on the economy in 1995.
"The numbers make me feel more confident about our 4 1/2 percent G.D.P. forecast" for the fourth quarter, said Michelle C. Laughlin, economist at Sanwa Securities in New York.
The biggest upward revision was in fixed investment other than housing, which soared $11.2 billion, to a 14.4 percent rate of gain instead of the 7 percent initially estimated.

HEADLINE: For the Toy King, New Challengers

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
At least 21 cents of every dollar spent on toys this holiday season will end up in the coffers of Toys "R" Us -- and many analysts suspect that the reigning titan of Toyland is really raking in more than that.
But a swarm of potential challengers are nipping at the toy industry's 800-pound gorilla. There's Noodle Kidoodle, Zany Brainy, Learningsmith and Baby Superstore, to mention a handful of nascent retail chains trying to nibble on Toys "R" Us's slice of the toy market. 
 At that suggestion, Michael Goldstein, the Toys "R" Us chief executive, waved his hand as if brushing aside a gnat. "Most of them will fail," he predicted.
He is less dismissive of more rapacious rivals like Wal-Mart Stores, the Kmart Corporation and Target Stores. "Five years ago, there were several toy supermarkets, and now there's just us," he said proudly. Then, his face clouded slightly as he added: "And the major discounters, of course."
The competition is getting fiercer just as the company's rate of growth is decelerating. For most of the 1980's sales at Toys "R" Us, which is based in Paramus, N.J., grew at a compound rate exceeding 20 percent, but between 1988 and 1993, the pace slowed to about 11.2 percent, according to Goldman, Sachs & Company.
With 618 stores scattered around the country, there are few new domestic markets to conquer. But since the United States stores account for roughly 80 percent of its operating profits, the company is looking for ways to increase their sales. "The most important challenge for us is to wring more productivity out of existing stores," Mr. Goldstein said. "That's what's driving us, not the competition."
For all Mr. Goldstein's sang-froid, it is clear that Toys "R" Us has not turned a blind eye to its competition. The special merchandise "boutiques" it has opened in some stores are a clear reaction to the lively ambiance of most of the new toy chains that have sprung up. The boutiques soften the warehouse atmosphere of Toys "R" Us stores and help make them easier to shop.
In the same way, the company has deployed coupon "catalogues" as a response to the cutthroat pricing of the big discounters. Just today, the stores will begin distributing a 32-page book with $500 in coupons for the season's most popular video games and electronic toys, which will also be distributed in 61 million newspapers this weekend.
Making these strategies work is even more important because the company's overseas expansion has proven more difficult than expected. Last year, operating profits at the 293 foreign stores rose a scant 1.8 percent, to $102.9 million, falling almost $50 million short of the company's goals as recession ate into sales in Japan and Germany. Analysts are confident the overseas operations will meet this year's objective of $150 million in operating profits, but they doubt those returns will ever equal the profitability of the company's North American and British stores.
Mr. Goldstein is not worried. "When you look back at Toys 'R' Us, the profitability was O.K. but it wasn't great," he said. "The surge in profitability came later, and it will come later over there, too."
Toys "R" Us has revved up its business before. A couple of years ago, as Wal-Mart and Kmart got more aggressive about toys, its sales per square foot slipped. But the company has fought back with low prices -- and sales per square foot have rebounded to the 1989 level of $220.
Discounters have managed to slow Toys "R" Us's market share expansion, though, and it now seems less likely that the company will ever live up to founder Charles Lazarus's dream of controlling 40 percent of the toy-retailing business.
And if the new rivals that have popped up in malls around the country do gain a toehold in the market, they will likely hurt Toys "R" Us before they hurt the discounters. Their stores are loaded with colorful fixtures, interactive displays and helpful sales people, in marked contrast to the no-frills ambiance of the typical Toys "R" Us store.
Several of those chains are already trying to chip away at pieces of the company's business that are most vulnerable to competition -- educational toys and software. Kids Source Inc., for example, does about one-quarter of its business in toys that Roy M. Cohen, its founder, calls "playthings with a purpose."
"We built Kids Source as a 'mom's needs' store, not a 'child's want' store," Mr. Cohen said. "There's no doubt that Toys 'R' Us is the child's want store in America, and no one is ever going to take that away from them."
But Toys "R" Us is not interested in sharing Mom with anyone, either. She, after all, is the one who makes the purchase.
To that end, the company has begun testing an educational boutique devoted to toys and software that promote learning. Like the Books "R" Us shops the company has opened in more than 300 stores, the educational boutiques have replaced floor-to-ceiling shelving with lower display fixtures for easier access, and the shop is staffed by a trained sales clerk. Tot-sized tables and chairs with computers invite children to test the software.
Educational software and computer games is a new category for the company -- but a critical one. "Of all the tests they're doing now, that's the most important," Sean McGowan of Gerard Klauer & Mattison said.
Mr. McGowan expects software to gradually supplant the video game business, which makes up about 13 percent of Toys "R" Us's sales. Additionally, if the company cultivates its young software customers, who now buy from traditional software retailers, it may be able to retain them as they get older and more affluent, he said.
Mr. Goldstein said the company was still trying to determine how big a market educational toys and software will be. But he issued a subtle warning to his new competitors: "Eventually, we're going to be in that business in a big way."
The company has also committed itself to putting boutique shops devoted to Lego and stuffed animals in more of its stores. The Lego store, in particular, brings a bit of F.A.O. Schwarz, the fabled premium toy-store chain, into Toys "R" Us, with interactive trains and planes built of brightly colored Lego blocks that tiny shoppers can operate with a control pad.
And a specialty shop featuring "plush" toys, industry jargon for stuffed animals, has even enticed upscale manufacturers like Dakin and Gunds, which would never sell to Toys "R" Us before. Those toys command hefty profit margins, too.
That is welcome, because the in-store shop concept does increase the company's costs. The shops must be kept neat and will require additional, better-trained staff, but Mr. Goldstein is hoping that the extra sales they generate will more than offset the higher expenses.
Not every boutique concept works: a Parties "R" Us shop was deemed a failure. But analysts consider the shops a must. "Even if the sales response was not sufficient justification, the emergence of capable new competitors may render such a remerchandising effort necessary for defensive reasons," David A. Bolotsky, a retail analyst at Goldman, Sachs, wrote in a report on the company.
Mr. Bolotsky estimated that a Books "R" Us shop increases book sales by 200 percent, which in turn raises the sales of stores in which they operate by about 2 percent. The Lego and plush shops will probably have more impact, he said, and over all, the three concepts could add 5 percent or more in sales to their host stores.
That may well accelerate growth. And the Toys "R" Us catalogues are a way of maintaining sales in the face of the discounters.
Last year, the company's coupon-filled "Big Toy Book" Christmas catalogue led to near-riots in stores as customers fought to get them.
This holiday season, the company came out swinging in October with a preview catalogue featuring $300 worth of coupons. That was followed by an even bigger catalogue with $600 in coupons in November.
The company now offers customers $500 worth of savings on video games and electronic toys that are good until Dec. 15. The hope is that the new catalogue will prod lagging sales of video games. Analysts say it will be hard for consumers to resist Super Nintendo and Sega Genesis cartridges, which usually sell for between $40 and $55, at $19.97.
The catalogues are clearly a message to Toys "R" Us rivals that the industry's giant is not sleeping. "We're trying to be aggressive like everyone else out there," Mr. Goldstein said. "This is our business."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A venerable peanut subsidy may be a target of Republicans.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE new Republicans are on the prowl for spending cuts. And since some of the juiciest targets -- notably Social Security -- have been ruled off limits, they are making no secret of their wish to save billions on farm subsidies.
Once that political door is opened, though, it is likely that many farm programs will be challenged, including many that offend free marketers more than they drain the Treasury. And one of them, the half-century-old peanut program, could prove vulnerable once Congress takes aim at higher profile subsidies. 
 Talk, of course, is cheap. Votes against a program that diverts roughly $500 million a year from consumers to a few thousand well-connected land owners are not. But opponents of the peanut program, who include Dick Armey of Texas, the Republican House majority leader in waiting, may be on the verge of assembling a coalition strong enough to support the rhetoric.
Like most farm programs, peanut subsidies date from the New Dealers' response to the Great Depression. But over the years its original purpose -- to stabilize the incomes of small farmers -- was quietly laid to rest in the murk of interest group politics.
Each year, the Agriculture Department estimates the quantity of peanuts needed by makers of peanut snacks, peanut candy and peanut butter, and guarantees a minimum price (currently 34 cents a pound) for this tonnage. Since growers would be delighted to sell far more at the mandated price, quotas for sales at 34 cents a pound are parceled out to peanut growing states, thence to counties and individual growers within counties based on historical benchmarks.
To prevent the Government from ending up with millions of tons of unsold peanuts, imports are effectively barred. (Substantial quantities, though, are likely to come in from Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement. More about that later.)
It is not surprising that the peanut lobby has been able to brush aside efforts to trim back the largess over the last decade. The program costs the Government very little -- just $40 million this year -- making it an unworthy target for budget cutters on the lookout for heftier game. Food processors all face the same artificially high price, and can thus treat the program as a cost of doing business like sales taxes. Consumers, for their part, never know why a jar of Jif costs, say, $3 rather than $2.60.
By contrast, beneficiaries of the program know exactly how their bread is buttered and by whom. Quotas, freely tradable within counties, can be leased for cash. And most are: just one-third of the peanuts sold under quota were actually grown by the quota owner. Indeed, just 409 growers produced 665 million pounds of peanuts in 1991, fully 19 percent of all the peanuts marketed under the system.
Why, then, is there any reason for believing that the attack planned for next year will succeed?
For one thing large numbers of producers don't see a penny from the program since roughly a third of all the peanuts grown in America are sold at unprotected world market prices. Much of this surplus is exported; the rest ends up as oil or animal feed. And while jealousy alone might not motivate the growers of so-called "additionals" to lobby effectively against the program, they are convinced that the free-market price is depressed by overproduction on quota-protected acreage.
For another, the North American trade accord opens a hole in the wall against imports. Mexico is currently a minor producer of peanuts and peanut butter. But under the agreement, restrictions on the peanut trade are being phased out and will disappear entirely by the middle of the next decade.
The Department of Agriculture estimates that by 2000, 14 percent of the peanuts eaten by Americans will be imports. If, as many expect, Mexico invests heavily in modernizing agriculture, the figure could be much higher. And this raises the prospect that the Government will be forced to buy peanuts that cannot be sold at the minimum quota price.
Last but not least, peanut processors are becoming more militant. While they have never been thrilled to pay more than necessary for the raw material, they now fear being priced out of the snack market. Sales of peanut foods, which peaked in 1989, are down about 10 percent -- with most of the loss in peanut butter.
What form might the reform take? A coalition of peanut processors and peanut growers lacking quota rights wants to cut the price support to 25 cents a pound -- a price that would put very few peanut farmers out of business yet keep America competitive with Mexico.
Mr. Armey would prefer the reform to be short and, for those who share his perspective, sweet: his bill, introduced in February, would simply wipe the peanut program off the books.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds, Municipals Post Gains

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday for the first time in three days as inflation concerns eased.
Municipal bonds staged their biggest rally in more than a week amid buying by insurance companies, mutual funds and other investors attracted by higher yields. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32 , pushing its yield down 3 basis points to 8 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"Inflation is fairly well under control," said Jim Fields, who helps manage about $3 billion at Wright Investors in Bridgeport, Conn. By the end of 1995, "we'll get a 100-basis-point drop" in bond yields, Fields said.
The Government revised its overall gross domestic product estimate up to 3.9 percent yesterday from 3.4 percent. More important, it said its price deflator, a broad measure of inflation that is a component of the G.D.P. report, grew at a revised 1.9 percent pace in the third quarter, up from its initial estimate of 1.6 percent, but down from the second quarter's 2.9 percent rate.
A firm dollar also helped lift bonds, traders said.
In the municipal market, "we've finally got to levels where people want to put money to work," said Richard Visconti, senior vice president at W. R. Lazard, Laidlaw & Mead Inc.
Tax-exempt bonds as measured by the Bond Buyer Municipal Index of 40 bonds rose 1 3/32 , or $10.94 per $1,000 face value of bonds, to yield 7.73 percent, 18 basis points lower than Tuesday. That was the biggest gain since Nov. 23, when municipal bonds as measured by the index rose 7/8 of point to yield 7.93 percent
Most investors were interested in new bonds sold by states and state agencies, traders said. In yesterday's largest sale, California sold $146 million in revenue bonds. Strong demand helped California lower yields by as much as 15 basis points.
Some investors have been unloading their mortgage securities in the last few days, either to raise cash before the end of the year or to allocate more money to Treasuries, traders said. By now, yield spreads widened enough to make mortgages attractive again, according to some investors and traders.
"At this point it's probably a better time to buy," said Michael Kennedy, who manages the $300 million Stein Roe & Farnham Intermediate Bond Fund. "We've seen some widening of spreads in the last few days."
Government National Mortgage Association 9 percent passthroughs delivered in December were up 3/32 at 100 13/32 for a yield of 9.01 percent, or 1.10 points more than the 10-year Treasury note, down from 1.11 points Tuesday.
In the corporate market, Eli Lilly & Company sold $450 million of notes in connection with its $4 billion acquisition of PCS Health Systems Inc.
Some corporate bond investors said they were not interested in the Lilly offering because the the company's decision to finance the PCS purchase partly with debt could prevent the new bonds from appreciating much and increase the risk its debt ratings would be cut.
"Whether the rating agencies will let them keep the double-A rating depends on how much debt they sell to finish this deal," said Barbara McCue, who helps manage about $11 billion at Keystone Fixed Income Adviseors.

HEADLINE: Mexico's President-to-Be Names Free-Market Cabinet

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30

 BODY:
On the eve of his inauguration, President-elect Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon today named some of the prime movers of the outgoing administration to significant posts in his Cabinet, sending a signal of stability and continued Mexican Government commitment to a market economy.
Financial analysts reacted positively to the announcements, but investors seemed to have anticipated the moves over the last few days and decided to take some profits today. American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, this country's benchmark stock, fell $1.375, to close at $52.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 The market here, the Bolsa, dropped 0.19 percent, to close at 2,591.34. In the four previous trading days, the Bolsa rose more than 7 percent.
Lawrence B. Goodman, vice president for emerging markets research at Salomon Brothers in New York, said the recent rise was "clearly a reflection of a market view that the Zedillo administration is going to pave the way for capitalizing on the substantial economic reforms" of the administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who gives way to Mr Zedillo on Thursday.
Jonathan Heath, director of Macro Assesoria Economica, a consulting firm, took a more cautious view of the market's strength. He said the national development bank had probably intervened in the last few days, buying stocks in timely fashion. "They're trying to to show the market that everything is fine," Mr. Heath said. "That's not bad; it's just a little dressing-up factor."
Mr. Zedillo's Cabinet contains names familiar to many United States investors. One of the most important positions, Finance Minister, will be filled by Jaime Serra Puche, an economist educated at Yale University, who was Mexico's point man for the North American Free Trade Agreement. Mr. Serra, a strong free-market advocate, oversaw many attempts to deregulate and change Mexico's economy during the Salinas administration, including the creation of a Federal Competition Commission.
Another Nafta team member, Herminio Blanco, will fill the critical job of Minister of Commerce and Industrial Development, which Mr. Serra held in the Salinas Cabinet. Mr. Blanco handled detailed talks for Mexico and like Mr. Serra believes in vigorous competition.
Guillermo Ortiz, now Deputy Finance Minister, takes over the Communications and Transportation Ministry, which is expected to make some important policy decisions during Mr. Zedillo's six-year term. The ministry will oversee the end of Telefonos de Mexico's long-distance monopoly and the entrance of competitors, probably including AT&T, MCI and Sprint, into the Mexican market.
A name absent from Mr. Zedillo's list was that of Pedro Aspe, the current Finance Minister, who has been a favorite of international investors. Mr. Aspe has said that he wants to leave public life. Until the last few days, he had been considered a candidate for any number of positions in the Zedillo administration.
Analysts noted that Mr. Zedillo fulfilled a pledge to include the political opposition in his Cabinet. He named Antonio Lozano, a member of the conservative National Action Party, as Attorney General.
A sour note for reform advocates was the inclusion of Ignazio Pichardo, president of the long-ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, as Energy Minister. Mr. Pichardo, a powerful politician, is a member of the party's old guard. Under a proposed reorganization, his Energy Ministry could assume control of Pemex, the state oil monopoly.
A week ago, Deputy Attorney General Mario Ruiz Massieu accused Mr. Pichardo of blocking the investigation into the assassination in September of his brother, the party's Secretary General, Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu. The day he made the charge, the Mexican stock exchange dropped sharply until the development bank intervened. Mr. Pichardo has sued for defamation.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Silver Near Low for the Year As Inflation Concerns Abate

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Silver prices fell to their lowest levels in nearly a year yesterday as rising interest rates and waning inflation fears hurt the market.
Gold prices also fell, although not so sharply. Precious metals are often considered a hedge against inflation. 
 Silver led a broad decline in commodity prices that lowered the Commodity Research Bureau's index by 1.36 points, to 229.23. Hogs, soybeans, natural gas and orange juice were among the other losers. Wheat futures rose sharply.
Silver for delivery in December dropped 14.9 cents on the Commodity Exchange of New York to settle at $4.896 an ounce, the lowest daily settlement for a near-term futures contract since last Dec. 7. Gold for December delivery fell $1.30, to $380.70 an ounce.
The plunge in silver represented the market's third consecutive daily decline. The selloff followed a Government report on the gross domestic product that showed little inflation in the third quarter.
"Although the economic numbers showed the economy is strong, they also showed that inflation was certainly contained," said Peter Cardillo, research director for Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York. "As a result of that, there was no reason to hold the precious metals any more."
An analyst at Smith Barney, David Rinehimer, said easing inflation concerns had reduced speculative demand for silver.
A stronger economy could increase industrial demand for the metal, but supplies are ample. Warehouse stocks of silver registered with the exchange stood at 265.7 million ounces yesterday, up from 250.7 million at the end of February.
Analysts said the selling accelerated when the December delivery price fell below $5 an ounce, an important psychological barrier.
On other markets, hog futures fell sharply, reflecting large supplies of animals. The Agriculture Department estimated yesterday's hog slaughter at 366,000, about 3,000 above trade estimates. Live hogs for December fell 0.90 cent, to 30.67 cents a pound, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange; frozen pork bellies for February fell 0.40 cent, to 36.25 cents a pound.
Near-term hog delivery prices are poised to drop below 30 cents a pound for the first time since Oct. 18.
Wheat futures rose strongly amid speculation about a possible Chinese purchase of American wheat. December wheat rose 7.75 cents, to $3.7225 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Steady on Report Of U.S. Economy's Strength

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed yesterday, consolidating its recent gains on fresh evidence that the American economy is healthy enough to warrant higher short-term interest rates in the near future.
"The tide has shifted in favor of the dollar," said the chief economist at BankAmerica, John Wilson. "There is no reason for the dollar to remain as weak as it has been, given the strength of the economy." 
 The Commerce Department raised its estimate yesterday of the gross domestic product, the broadest measure of the goods and services output in the United States, for July to September. It said the third-quarter G.D.P. expanded at a strong pace of 3.9 percent, or a half-percentage point higher than the first estimate.
Also, final sales, a component of the G.D.P. on which economists focus because it shows what Americans actually spent, was revised even higher, to a gain of 4.2 percent, from 3.1 percent.
Mr. Wilson said the dollar was also helped by a growing market perception that the Federal Reserve was ready to tackle inflation pressures.
"There are expectations the Fed needs to tighten further," he said. "But certainly, the situation looks a lot better than it did in the middle of summer."
The dollar was depressed last summer by a trade dispute between the United States and Japan at a time when the Fed left monetary policy on hold for three months.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5710 German marks, compared with 1.5703 marks late Tuesday. The dollar ended unchanged at 98.97 Japanese yen.
The chief economist for Mellon Bank, Richard Berner, said global investors were looking favorably at the United States now that short-term interest rates were higher than those in Germany, and should remain that way for the near future.
Helmut Schieber, a Bundesbank director, said in an interview that "it's more difficult to see a scenario that would cause us to react with a rate increase," because he estimated that the German recovery was "two years" behind those in English-speaking countries.
