HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Confidence Meter Frowns on Clinton and Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence is reported to be sharply higher. That sounds good, but if history is any guide, the latest readings from the Conference Board survey may be a bad omen for both stocks and President Clinton. That is because consumers' views of the future are significantly less optimistic than their views of the present. And in the past, such a divergence has been a negative indicator for the stock market.
Had someone bought and sold the stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average based on an indicator derived from the consumer confidence data since 1969, the portfolio would now be up 515 percent. By contrast, a buy-and-hold investor would have gained 313 percent. And with this week's results, the indicator has issued its first sell signal since June 1987. 
 Looking only at the indicator in the survey closest to midterm elections, it has been a perfect forecaster of the results of the next Presidential election. If consumers felt the future looked better than the present, as they did in 1970, 1982 and 1986, they went on to re-elect the incumbent President, or his party's candidate if he did not run.
And when consumers felt the other way, as they did in 1974, 1978 and 1990, they voted the incumbent out of office two years later. It is that unfortunate group that Mr. Clinton is in danger of joining.
The latest poll by the Conference Board, which was released on Tuesday, produced an overall level of consumer confidence of 101.3 for November, the highest since July 1990, just before a recession hit the country, and up sharply from October's 89.1.
But the surge came mainly from very optimistic views of the present situation, which registered at 108.3, also the highest since mid-1990. The outlook for the next six months was only 96.7, less than it was just after Mr. Clinton was elected two years ago.
It makes sense that people would put more money into stocks when they think the future is better than the past, and would grow cautious when they fear the future will be worse. And it turns out that consumer confidence has been a fair indicator of the stock market.
The rule, first discussed in this column two years ago, is that if the expectations index is at least nine points below the index of current conditions, a sell signal is created. That signal continues until the expectations index is at least nine points higher than the current index, when a buy signal is given. That range keeps the indicator from flipping over on small changes.
When the Conference Board began its poll of consumers in February 1969, they were less optimistic about the future than the present, and so an investor would have stayed out of the stock market. By August 1970, when the future looked better, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 15 percent from where it had been when the first measure was taken. Over the succeeding years, the indicator would have called for selling at the end of February 1973, buying in December 1974, selling in May 1978, buying in June 1980 and selling in June 1987, shortly before the 1987 crash.
That crash shook consumer views of the future, and it was not until February 1991, well after the stock market had made up the losses from the crash, that it provided a new buy signal, which remained in effect until this week.
For purposes of computing the history, all buy and sell signals were considered to be executed on the last day of the month in which confidence moved past the trigger for buying or selling. Because the Conference Board sometimes revises its figures a month after they are released, it is possible that some of those signals were given a month later than indicated.
The figures for performance do not include dividend income, nor do they take into account the costs of moving in and out of the stock market. They also ignore the money that could have been made in Treasury bills while an investor was out of the stock market.
The Conference Board figures for November are preliminary, and will be revised next month. It is possible, although unlikely, that both the stock market and President Clinton's prospects might look better after the revision. There is, of course, no assurance that any indicator will work as it has in the past.
President Clinton might be pleased to learn that the overall consumer confidence index, at 101.3, is higher than at any previous midterm election. But history indicates that the more relevant factor for electoral success is the relative level of the current and expectations indexes.
The second highest overall level of confidence at midterm came in 1978, when the figure was 96.5 but the future appeared dimmer than the present. Two years later, Jimmy Carter lost his bid for re-election.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Consumers Send a Sell Signal" tracks the Conference Board index of consumer expectations about future conditions, minus the Conference Board index of consumer attitudes about present conditions, plotted in index points. The resulting figure shows when consumers think the future will be significantly better than the present, or when the opposite is true. A difference of 9 points or more sends a signal to buy or sell stocks. The closing Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks is given for the month of each signal; for sell signals, the Dow's change since the last buy signal is also given. For both confidence indexes, the 1985 average equals 100; figures are six times yearly before July 1977 and monthly since then. (pg. D1)
 
Table: "Midterm Forecast"
 When it comes ot anticipating the next Presidential election, the overall level of consumer confidence in the middle of a president's term is not a reliable omen, but its components are. Only when consumers have felt better about the future than the present has the President's party kept the White House in the next election.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Salary Cap Taken Off Immediate Agenda

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LEESBURG, Va., Nov. 30

 BODY:
The mediator whom the Clinton Administration sent to save Major League Baseball from itself is viewed by labor negotiators as a master of good timing, and today Bill Usery Jr. put that talent to use.
At Usery's urging, the owners' negotiating team agreed to postpone a meeting next Monday in Chicago, where the owners had been expected to declare an impasse in negotiations and implementing their salary-cap proposal. 
 "I've asked the owners to put off the meeting, and they've agreed to do that," Usery said a little more than six hours after the two sides began meeting at the Lansdowne Conference Resort. "I've asked the owners to withdraw the threat of implementation and they've agreed to do that. It's in everybody's interest to change those deadlines and continue negotiating."
At the same time, Usery was persuading the owners to postpone implementation, he was working on the players' negotiators to develop a counterproposal at the union's executive board meeting in Atlanta next week.
"It's our intention to come out with one," Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, said. "I can't say more than that."
The two sides agreed to meet in Rye Brook, N.Y., on Dec. 9. John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, the owners' chief labor spokesman, said the owners would meet Dec. 15 or 16 at a site to be determined.
A key element of Usery's success was in inducing the owners to agree to postponement without a guarantee of a new proposal from the players.
When Jay Bell of the Pittsburgh Pirates, the National League player representative and a member of the union's negotiating subcommittee, left the meeting early, just before 6 P.M., he was asked about the players' plans.
"Whether we come out of there with a counterproposal or not I don't know yet, but that's something we need to discuss at the board meeting," he said. "We've been asked by our board members to negotiate, but because the board meeting is so close from now, we want to go there and caucus with them."
Asked if Usery was trying to persuade the owners to postpone their meeting, the shortstop said, "Yes, that's basically what he's doing."
As Bell headed for the door, Usery was meeting with the owners' negotiators to pin down their pledge to delay what would be the most critical step in the labor dispute since the players struck Aug. 12.
The agreement also involves postponement of one other date -- Dec. 7. That's the deadline for clubs to offer salary arbitration to their free agents to retain rights to them.
Harrington had said the clubs needed to implement their new economic system before that date. He said Tuesday night the clubs would consider postponement of the Dec. 7 deadline "under certain conditions," one of those presumably being the players' promise of a counterproposal.
The two sides agreed to put off the arbitration-offer deadline until Dec. 17. The deadline for response from players who receive offers was postponed from Dec. 19 to Dec. 23.
"I think this is a positive note for our negotiations," Harrington said. "I'm pleased we're agreeing to meet again."
The agreement to postpone could not be taken as a sign of progress, but as an effort to keep the talks going without disruptive actions. "If there is a window, both sides found a way to keep it open a few days more, and that's very important," said Lauren Rich, a union lawyer.
A 10-day delay in the owners' meeting would be enough time for the players to formulate and present a counterproposal and for the owners to decide if the approach would be worth pursuing.
If they saw no promise in the proposal, the owners would presumably act on impasse and implementation at their rescheduled meeting.
Another deadline, Dec. 20, was not discussed. That's the date by which clubs must tender contracts to the approximately 900 players who aren't signed for 1995. Neither side apparently wants to change that deadline.
Usery's plan to postpone implementation and give the players time to give a counterproposal makes eminent sense.
When the owners set their Chicago meeting, they knew the players' executive board was meeting the same week but gave no indication of a willingness to wait to hear what the union had to say before declaring an impasse. Usery could have tried earlier to get the owners to wait, but he obviously felt that he had a better chance of succeeding in his quest if he waited until after the two sides exhaustively discussed the new tax proposal that management made Nov. 17.
Members of the union and management staffs held several technical question-and-answer meetings on that proposal, in person and by telephone, between the series of bargaining sessions in nearby Herndon and this series. Full negotiating committees further discussed the plan for several hours Tuesday.
Upon reconvening today, they held a discussion of a different kind. Doyle Pryor, a union lawyer, said they were discussing "the gulf between us and how to bridge it."
The gulf is gaping and would grow wider with the owners' implementation of the salary cap they want. At the same time that they placed the tax proposal on the table, they gave the players a revised salary-cap proposal that they intended to implement as baseball's new economic system.
Implementation would trigger an arduous legal fight before the National Labor Relations Board and most likely in United States District Court. Both sides would concentrate their energies on that element of their dispute, and they would most likely have little time for the bargaining table.
The owners would also proceed with plans to open spring training camps and start the season with replacement players if necessary.
"We want to make a commitment to the fans that we're going to play the 1995 season with some caliber of professional baseball player," Harrington said Tuesday night. "We believe it will be entertaining and we believe that's what the fans want. The fans want baseball with the best quality player we can put out there. Our preference is to put major league players out there, but if they're unwilling to play, then we'll have to go with someone else who's willing to play."
Fehr, the union leader, said Harrington has said the same thing about replacement players in negotiating sessions. "Such comments do not make the process more simple," Fehr said. "They have the opposite effect."
Gene Orza, a union lawyer, said the idea of replacement players is "internally inconsistent because only major league baseball players can play major league baseball. In the absence of an agreement on opening day 1995, major league players will be on strike."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Players Hoping Tour of Europe Will Jar Owners

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 30

 BODY:
The effects of hockey's labor predicament will flare on two fronts Thursday as the lockout of players begins its third month.
Across a conference table in Chicago, negotiators for the National Hockey League and the N.H.L. Players Association will argue again over terms of a collective bargaining agreement in an attempt to end an impasse that has postponed the start of the season for 61 days. 
 If no deal is reached by the end of December, it is possible that the entire 84-game regular season, plus the Stanley Cup playoffs, could be canceled. Such a meltdown would be unprecedented in professional sports and could lead to the splintering of a major league that has survived for eight decades and seemed, until this fall, on the brink of an explosion in popularity.
Meanwhile, on the ice, in a suburb north of Detroit, a group of N.H.L. stars, led by Wayne Gretzky, will play an exhibition game against a minor league team. The match is a warm-up for a six-game tour of Finland, Sweden and Norway, which begins on Friday, but which would end immediately if a settlement is reached.
Officially, the trip is for goodwill and charity, but its larger agenda is much more complex and controversial.
"We're hoping the lockout ends and maybe this tour will put a little pressure on somebody to get it to end," said Gretzky, who has chartered an airplane for the tour. "Maybe it's showing that players can get out there and work and do some good things for the sport of hockey. I get mad when people say we're on strike. We're not on strike. We're locked out. Big difference."
Among those touring with him are some of the elite of the league, including Mark Messier of the Rangers, Brett Hull of the St. Louis Blues and Sergei Fedorov of the Detroit Red Wings. Although the N.H.L. has expressed its unhappiness with the plan, the cable television network ESPN2 announced today that it would carry two games of the tour, on Dec. 9 and 10, from Sweden.
Fedorov, last season's most valuable player, is one of three Detroit players who will voluntarily miss Thursday night's game, to be played at the Palace of Auburn Hills, Mich. He, Steve Yzerman and Paul Coffey are deferring to Mike Ilitch, the owner of the Red Wings.
Although Ilitch is among the owners supporting the lockout, the players are reluctant to offend him by playing in his market in a rival building. The Palace is operated by Bill Davidson, owner of the Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Association, whose organization competes with Ilitch's Joe Louis Arena for sports and other entertainment shows.
Yzerman, the Detroit captain, seemed ill at ease today when trying to explain why he won't wear the union jersey alongside the rest of "Wayne Gretzky & Friends" Thursday night.
"No matter which way we go, we're going to get some criticism and some pressure," Yzerman said, after a practice in Fraser, Mich. "I think the majority of people understand, maybe not necessarily agree. We just think it's the right thing to do. It's not the N.H.L. Players Association against the Detroit Red Wings on this issue. It's a separate issue, which I don't want to get into."
He referred to Ilitch and his family as "our bosses" and said "we've been treated extremely well." A request for comment from Ilitch wasn't returned.
"It's been indicated to us that they wouldn't appreciate us participating," Yzerman said. "In the best interest of when the lockout is over, and we go back to play for the Detroit Red Wings, we want to go back to the atmosphere we had before."
For that to happen, the bargainers must settle at least three major issues: an entry-level salary structure, a reformation of arbitration rules and a restructuring of the formula for free agency.
Also looming over the talks is the possibility of a "luxury tax" to punish high payrolls, a concept the players say they won't accept because it is a salary cap in disguise. All changes are sought by owners to create a "drag" on salary inflation.
League lawyers and union officials met today with Gretzky and his teammates. They traveled to Chicago today. Someone with knowledge of their position said the union's offer to management on Thursday will be comprehensive, geared toward ending the lockout. Some players, including Jeremy Roenick of Chicago, have charged that the union has already conceded too much after first offering to play the season under a no strike/no lockout pledge.
On the management side, several owners have voiced anxiety about the length of the lockout. Bill Wirtz, the Chicago owner, said last week that Commissioner Gary Bettman needs to have a deal by Dec. 1. Joe Cohen, part-owner of the Los Angeles Kings, said Bettman's luxury tax "is the last thing we should be talking about."
Neither Bettman nor Bob Goodenow, the executive director of the Players Association, were available for comment today. Gretzky was, and he said only the luxury tax stands in the way of a deal.
"If they would eliminate that, every other issue is pretty much negotiable," he said. "I think the players have proven they are willing to bend on everything. Guys like Messier and myself, this whole thing has nothing to do with our life. We're never going to feel the effects of this.
"What we're talking about here is guys like Robbie Blake, guys like Brian Leetch, the up-and-coming superstars. The last thing we want to have happen is 10 years from now, those guys turn to us and say, 'You know what, guys like Gretzky and Messier sold us down the river.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wayne Gretzky, who will lead some N.H.L. stars on a European tour, scans a newspaper sports section at a recent practice in Fraser, Mich. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Gingrich's Politics Didn't Follow Fashion

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Gingrich's Life: The Complications and Ideals" (front page, Nov. 24) leaves the impression that early in his political career Newt Gingrich abruptly shifted his ideological posture from "liberal" to "conservative" because it became fashionable to do so. In fact, Mr. Gingrich is a classic neoconservative whose entry point into conservatism was via the "Kemp wing." It should be recalled that Ronald Reagan himself was a trade-union liberal Democrat who switched parties as the Democratic party moved leftward. 
 In his first two tries for a House seat, in 1974 and 1976, he was still in the liberal "Rockefeller wing" of the party. Between '76 and '78 Jack Kemp emerged in the House as a champion of supply-side economics, devoted to entrepreneurial capitalism, with government relegated to maintenance of the social safety net created by Democrats and approved by the neoconservatives.
As an editor at The Wall Street Journal between 1976 and 1978, I became aware of Mr. Gingrich's enthusiasm for this new movement, as he sent me campaign material he used in his successful 1978 race that reflected his own conversion.
In all the Gingrich profiles I've seen since the Nov. 8 earthquake, none have mentioned the most important event of his career, his 1990 decision as House minority whip to oppose the budget deal between President Bush and the Democratic Congressional leaders. It was that deal, which raised the income tax rates that President Reagan had lowered, that broke President Bush's "read my lips" 1988 campaign promise.
Mr. Gingrich was vilified by the Bush team for killing the budget the first time around. It was that act of political daring and principle, in a losing cause, that cemented Mr. Gingrich's hold on the hearts of the party faithful and the backbenchers of the House.
At a time of political realignment, Mr. Gingrich's beginnings as a liberal have been a source of great strength to him. He still has in his intellectual experience a liberal's appreciation of human weakness and our collective responsibility to leave no one behind in the kind of general economic advance supply-siders envision.
 
JUDE WANNISKI
Morristown, N.J., Nov. 24, 1994
 
The writer is a political and economic consultant.

HEADLINE: Ending Bosnia's Endgame

BYLINE: By George Kenney; George Kenney resigned from the State Department in August 1992 to protest Bush Administration policy in the former Yugoslavia.

DATELINE: STEYNING, England

 BODY:
I never imagined I would find myself defending Serbian conquests. Yet the choices the United States and NATO have made throughout the Bosnian conflict have been so bad that there are no good choices left. It is better to end the carnage, even on unfair terms, than to have it continue for what could be a decade or more. The Europeans are right. The West should make the Bosnian Government settle against its wishes.
After the humiliation surrounding the Muslim defeat in the struggle for Bihac, the United Nations is deadly serious about withdrawing its peacekeeping troops, perhaps even this winter, unless the warring parties agree to a cease-fire across Bosnia and a new round of talks aimed at ending the war. The risks of withdrawal would be great, since NATO forces -- presumably including American ground troops -- would have to provide escort to retreating U.N. personnel. 
 Until his policy shift this week, President Clinton had been halfheartedly pursuing a strategy that did nothing to end the war while raising tensions with Britain and France: arguing for lifting the arms embargo against Bosnia, unilaterally ending American enforcement of the embargo and pressing for more NATO air strikes against Serbian positions. Finally, Mr. Clinton has backed away from these efforts now that Western forces have failed to stop the Serbs in Bihac. Now, the strategy should be formally dropped.
Despite the Muslims' recent losses, there are worrying signs that they are preparing another large offensive -- this time in central Bosnia. Such a move would be another fiasco. In the past, faint American encouragement has led to gross Muslim overconfidence. But has the White House learned not to underestimate the Muslims' irrational and dangerous belief that the West will eventually come to their rescue?
The last two winters in Bosnia, fighting abated. This winter, it may escalate as Muslims, Serbs and Croats anticipate the U.N.'s withdrawal and the possibility of capturing equipment left behind. In the last week peacekeepers have been de facto hostages of both Muslims and Serbs, while European governments insist that they will pull their troops out of Bosnia if the fighting escalates.
And what happens if the U.N. leaves Bosnia? Humanitarian aid will end. The Serbs will shut down Sarajevo. There will be no passage by road in or out; no electricity, no gas, no water. There will be violent shelling. The Serbs will no doubt grab all of eastern Bosnia and what's left of the Bihac pocket. The Muslims can maintain a stronghold in central Bosnia, but if they ever seriously threaten Serb-held areas, Bosnian Serbs can rely on allies in Serbia and Croatia to back them up.
If the U.N. pulls out, my guess is that the Muslims will surrender within six months, with less land than they have now. Bosnia would disappear, carved up between Serbia and Croatia. This scenario might improve somewhat if the Muslims got outside help, but the Bosnian Serbs would find benefactors, too. Jingoistic Russian legislators, for example, have said that Russia will arm the Serbs if the arms embargo on Bosnia is lifted. The Muslims, in short, have no winning strategy. Like it or not, they are looking at the war's endgame.
Before the Muslims' recent devastating setbacks, there was reason to believe that the Bosnian Serbs were ready to sign a deal -- one quite close to the plan the five-nation "contact group" proposed this summer. Although senior Clinton Administration officials dismissed this possibility, conversations I have had over the last two months with diplomats close to the negotiations have convinced me of the Serbs' genuine desire to end the fighting.
The Serbs' recent successes have shifted the terms in their favor, but their interests in a settlement remain the same. They don't want all of Bosnia; they know they couldn't control it. And they want to support the efforts of the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, to get international economic sanctions lifted from Serbia and Montenegro.
The Bosnian Serbs flatly refused the contact group plan for several reasons. They want to keep their northern corridor connecting Serb-held territory in eastern and western Bosnia at its current two-and-a-half mile width, rather than narrow it to one-and-a-half miles as the plan provides. As a military calculation, that logic is reasonable. They would trade Muslim-held land in eastern Bosnia, which the plan leaves with the Muslims, for Serb-held land around Sarajevo. The exchange carries both advantages and drawbacks for the Muslims, but also seems negotiable. The Serbs want most of the Bihac pocket; thanks to Sarajevo's intemperate, failed offensive, they are taking it.
Finally, they want the same rights of confederation with Serbia that the Bosnian Muslim-Croat federation enjoys with Croatia, a proposal that now seems to be on the table. Outsiders should note: the U.S.-brokered constitution of the Muslim-Croat federation gives no explicit rights to Serbs living in federation territory, whereas it does explicitly protect Muslims and Croats. (American officials privately admit that the arrangement was too hastily put together, and they are working to fix the problem.)
Uncritical condemnation of the Serbs and uncritical support for the Bosnian Muslims must be re-examined. Much has changed since the outbreak of violence in Yugoslavia in July 1991. What was once a clear-cut war of aggression -- some call it genocide -- gradually turned into the civil war many incorrectly thought it always was. What was once a genuinely multiethnic and legitimately elected Bosnian Government turned into a hard-line, anti-democratic Muslim entity.
Now we find ethnic cleansing by Muslims alongside that of the Serbs, and the senseless determination of President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia to wage war against his longtime rival, Fikret Abdic, the dissident Muslim leader of northwestern Bosnia, thus shattering the one region spared from earlier fighting.
It's all understandable, but it isn't right. In August 1992, when I resigned from the State Department, I said the West had a brief window of opportunity to intervene. Well, it shut a long time ago.
The clique of nationalist politicians around President Izetbegovic -- particularly hard-liners like Ejup Ganic, the Vice President -- don't want to admit that they will never govern all of the former Bosnia, because doing so raises questions about their legitimacy. Nor can they clearly explain what is to be gained by further fighting. These men -- inexperienced, corrupt, unable to fathom international politics -- hardly warrant U.S. support in a civil war that would destroy their country in order to save it.
I don't believe morality has an existential reality independent from the world: arguing that we must lift the arms embargo so the Muslims can defend themselves ignores the brutal consequences of arming them. In Bosnia, we have to recognize that the good is the enemy of the least bad, however tragic that may be. If there is anything to be salvaged from this debacle, Mr. Clinton must work more closely with the Europeans, not against them.

HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES PACT TO EASE TRADE CURBS; A VICTORY FOR CLINTON

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The Senate tonight approved American participation in the most ambitious global trade accord reached in four decades.
Approval of the 124-nation pact, by a far wider margin than expected, ended a dozen years of negotiations over the lowering of tariffs and the creation of the World Trade Organization, a new international body designed to police commerce among nations. 
 After two days of heated Senate debate, the broad expansion of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, passed by a wide margin, 76 to 24. Earlier in the evening, a crucial procedural vote to waive Senate rules against any bill that adds to the Federal deficit passed 68 to 32, eight votes more than necessary. The trade accord will cost several billion dollars in tariff revenues.
The House of Representatives approved the agreement on Tuesday by an even wider margin, 288 to 146.
Final passage of the accord, nearly a year after the world's trading nations initialed it, was the last action of the 103d Congress and the last business before Republicans take over both houses of Congress next month.
The passage of the pact also is a major victory for the Clinton Administration, building on the narrow margin by which the North American Free Trade Agreement passed last year. Since January the White House and the nation's biggest businesses and agricultural groups have pressed for the accord, warning that its defeat would jeopardize America's efforts to lead the world economically at a time when the nation's military power is diminishing in importance.
The Reagan Administration started negotiations on the accord, and it was supported by former President George Bush as well.
Appearing on the South Lawn tonight with Congressional leaders, including Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas and the incoming Senate majority leader, President Clinton went out of his way to praise Republican leaders for saving the accord. He called the vote "a bipartisan victory that really, really gives our country the boost we need to keep moving forward toward the 21st century to create more high-wage jobs for the American people."
"We said loud and clear that America will continue to lead the world to a more prosperous and secure place after the Cold War," he said. "Let's make the GATT vote the first vote of a new era of cooperation."
The outgoing Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, who was defeated in the Republican landslide last month, declared that the much-criticized 103d Congress was "the most important congress in trade liberalization in decades."
GATT's supporters acknowledged that the pact falls far short of heralding an era of free trade. It fails to address many trade issues crucial to American business, including trade in most financial services.
"But we should not measure this trade agreement against a perfect and unrealizable ideal," Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the retiring majority leader, said in his last appearance in the well of the Senate. "These are the only trade partners we have. We don't trade with Mars; we don't trade with the moon; we don't trade with countries made in heaven."
Senator Dole sealed the pact's fate last week when he reached a compromise with President Clinton on a mechanism to involve Congress in abandoning the agreement if the new World Trade Organization acts unreasonably in actions against the United States. But today, Mr. Dole sounded like one of the pact's biggest supporters.
"Let's face it," he told his colleagues. "We're the big beneficiaries, the United States of America, any way you cut it."
Congress' action, taken in a lame-duck session called to approve the accord, clears the way for America's largest trading partners, including Japan and the European Union, to take similar actions in the coming weeks. They have refused to consider the agreement -- and to endure the wrath of their farmers and manufacturers who will be hurt by the gradual phasing out of many protections -- until Washington acted.
In the end, the United States, which had pressed harder than any nation for the accord, threatened to become the greatest obstacle to its adoption. An alliance of consumer groups, environmentalists and conservatives mounted a major campaign against the accord, arguing that the World Trade Organization would become an all-powerful bureaucracy, able to undercut American sovereignty by allowing panels of foreign judges to rule on whether Federal and state laws constituted impediments to trade.
Their arguments found an audience in recent weeks as callers flooded talk shows, saying that the issue should wait until the newly elected Congress could deal with it. Some callers were inspired by Ross Perot, Patrick J. Buchanan and Ralph Nader, all of whom called for the accord's defeat.
Such objections led many Democrats and Republicans to abandon their leaders on the vote, arguing that American workers would be undercut by more imports from countries that pay a fraction of American wages, and that the United States was signing away its sovereignty to the new trade organization without understanding the true scope of that organization's powers.
Thus, Senator James Jeffords, a moderate Republican from Vermont, declared from the Senate floor early this afternoon that while free trade was an admirable goal, it was not worth threatening the livelihood of his state's dairy farmers. "All protection for dairy farmers is eliminated," Mr. Jeffords argued. "We cannot abandon the American farmer."
In fact, the changes for most farmers will be gradual, and more will benefit than be harmed.
Until yesterday, it was unclear whether the Administration could garner sufficient votes, and as late as this morning President Clinton was cajoling wavering Senators over breakfast.
Under the accord approved tonight, tariffs around the world will be reduced by more than $700 billion over the next decade. Those cuts include ones relating to farm products, which raises an issue so politically sensitive in almost every nation that it was never covered in past trade agreements. New protections are afforded to intellectual property, including patents and copyrights.
In both chambers of Congress, the debate has really been over two differing views of the American economy: linking the future to exporting to developing markets in Latin America and Asia or nurturing traditional American industries and stemming the loss of jobs to foreign lands.Which members of Congress hold those views had more to do with where they come from than their party.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Appearing on the South Lawn of the White House, President Clinton, third from right, listened as Senator Bob Dole, at lectern, praised the approval of GATT. Others, from left, were the trade representative, Mickey Kantor, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Representatives Robert Matsui and Sam Gibbons, Senator Bob Packwood, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and Senator George J. Mitchell. (Marty Katz for The New York Times) (pg. A22)
 
Chart: "HIGHLIGHTS: The New Trade Pact"
 
CREATES A NEW TRADE OFGANIZATION -- The agreement will replace the 47-year old GATT organization with a new umbrella group, knownas the WTO, with the power to enforce the new trade accordand assess trade penalties against nations that violate the accord. The United States has pressed for greater enforcement power for years, but in recent months environmentalists, comsumer advocates and conservatives have charged that the WTO's panels of foreign judges could order changes in American law. Congress or the states would have to enact those changes, however, and any country can withdraw from the WTO with six months notice.
 
REDUCES TARIFFS -- All countries have agreed to reduce their tariffs by an average of one third. Agricultural tariffs are included in the agreement for the first time since the initial GATT round in 1948. Because American tariffs are already relatively low, other nations will be forced to reduce their taxes more dramatically than the United States will, when measured in dollar terms. The Clinton Administration estimates that the tariff reductions will amount to $744 billion.
 
ELIMINATES QUOTAS -- The agreement bars countries from placing limitson the quantity of imports. Japan, for example, will have to end its ban on rice imports; the United States will have to end its quotas on peanuts, dairy products, sugar, textiles and apparell. The quotas will be replaced with tariffs, which will be reduced gradually over a number of years. The agreement also bans the widespreadpractice of requiring high local content for products like cars.
 
PROTECTS INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY -- For the first time, the new world trade accord requires all signatories to protect patents, copyrights, trade secrets and trademarks, which Washington hopes will curb piracy of movies, compact disks, computer software and presecription drugs.
 
ISSUES NOT ADDRESSED -- There was no agreement on limiting government subsidies to civil aircraft makers, on distributing movies, music and other cultural products in Europe, or on opening markets to most financial services. Shipping, steel and telecommunications are also largely exempted. (pg. A22)

HEADLINE: Mexican, Taking Office, Pledges To Fight Poverty and Corruption

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, a politically inexperienced economist thrust by tragedy into the leadership of Mexico's long-governing party, took office as President today, promising a new fight against poverty, "definitive" steps to democracy and sweeping changes in the corrupt justice system.
"Many have not benefited from the fruits of progress," Mr. Zedillo, 42, said in an inaugural address that was filled with implicit criticism of the previous administration's failings. "Now that we are able to build a more prosperous Mexico, we must -- and can -- make it a more just Mexico." 
 Standing before a vast audience of politicians and foreign dignitaries in the lower chamber of the congress, Mr. Zedillo paid a warm but brief tribute to his predecessor and political mentor, Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Then he immediately recalled the assassination that turned him from novice campaign manager into candidate.
Acknowledging widespread dissatisfaction with the Government's investigations into the murders of the governing party's first presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, and another party leader, Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, Mr. Zedillo pledged to "significantly intensify" efforts to solve them.
He also held out a conciliatory hand to peasant rebels in the southern state of Chiapas who have vowed to prevent the scheduled inauguration next week of a ruling-party Governor whose election they maintain was fraudulent.
Reiterating his call for new peace talks with the rebels, Mr. Zedillo said the Government troops surrounding them would not break the cease-fire that has held since Jan. 12. But he also signaled that he would reject demands for new elections in Chiapas, insisting that the law must be upheld.
Underscoring the conflicts left unresolved by Mr. Zedillo's easy victory in the Aug. 21 election, dozens of people were reported injured this afternoon when left-wing protesters hurling bottles and stones set on riot policemen blocking their way to the central square where Mr. Zedillo was greeting well-wishers after being sworn in. A police car and a truck bearing advertising for the governing party were set on fire by protesters.
For the most part, however, the occasion was yet another lavish exercise in renewal for the party that has dominated Mexican political life since its founding in 1929.
The green, white and red that have blended the identity of the Institutional Revolutionary Party with that of the state were everywhere in the colonial heart of the city. Companies of soldiers in long coats and busbies goose-stepped around the central plaza.
The inaugural drew heads of state from throughout Latin America, including Presidents Fidel Castro of Cuba, Alberto Fujimori of Peru and Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina. Vice President Al Gore headed the delegation from the United States.
Mr. Zedillo's chest swelled beneath his new sash as he looked on from a balcony of the National Palace. The bespectacled, sometimes awkward, technocrat of the campaign seemed to begin giving way to the kind of commanding political presence that Mexican presidents have usually attained.
Among the many doubts that have been raised about Mr. Zedillo's ability to lead a country racked by social tensions and political turmoil, the questions of his authority and skill as a politician remain central. Despite the enormous challenge Mexico faces in creating millions of new jobs, revitalizing small and medium-sized businesses and sharing its wealth more equitably, his abilities as an economist have gone virtually unquestioned. Mr. Zedillo, who received a doctorate from Yale University, served in the last administration as Minister of Planning and Budget and of Education.
Members of Mr. Zedillo's own, deeply divided party have worried that he will never wield the extraordinary power that Mr. Salinas consolidated in the name of change.
But throughout a campaign largely focused on the authoritarian practices rooted in Mexico's one-party past, opposition leaders clamored for a greater balance among governmental powers, and Mr. Zedillo embraced the idea as his own.
Today he repeated his campaign vows to end the Government's traditional support for the Institutional Revolutionary Party, to cede budgetary oversight powers to the legislature, and to allow greater autonomy to state and municipal governments, which were long treated as executive pawns. He said again "emphatically" that he would renounce the traditional prerogative of the President of running his party and choosing its candidates for high office.
In describing a "definitive reform" of the political system, Mr. Zedillo said it must address a series of issues that he had only a few months ago described as settled: regulations on political party financing and campaign expenditures, fair access to the news media for all parties and fuller autonomy for electoral authorities.
"Mexico demands a reform which, based on the broadest political consensus, will eradicate the suspicion, recrimination and distrust that mar the electoral process," he said.
"Electoral democracy can no longer be at the core of the political debate or the cause of dispute or division," he went on. "We must resolve, in keeping with the most advanced practices worldwide, each and every one of the issues still causing dissatisfaction in terms of democracy."
Mr. Zedillo was not specific in his prescriptions for the country's final democratization, and the Government's critics were quick to note that the promises, the optimism and the sincerity of a new administration all rang familiar.
"He has good aims, and there are commitments there that are significant, but we have heard speeches like this before and they have disappeared into the air," Jesus Ortega, a leading congressman from the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party, said in an interview today.
Like other opposition leaders, however, he noted a different tone. Throughout most of his administration, Mr. Salinas often sought to flatten the leftists who questioned his legitimacy. Mr. Zedillo has moved quickly to take a different approach.
Last Thursday, he met with Mr. Ortega and other members of his party. Where Mr. Salinas filled many key posts with figures of the ruling party's old guard, Mr. Zedillo named a young congressman from the right-of-center National Action Party, Antonio Lozano, as his Attorney General.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Ask Billions More In Spending for the Military

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Trying to quiet Republican criticism that the military is underfinanced, President Clinton held a Rose Garden ceremony today to announce that he would seek a $25 billion increase in military spending over the next six years.
With Defense Secretary William J. Perry and the Joint Chiefs of Staff at his side, Mr. Clinton outlined plans to improve readiness and to support military personnel. Among the purposes of the new money, he said, will be the troops' annual cost-of-living pay increases that Congress has already authorized into the next century. 
 In addition to that $25 billion, Mr. Clinton said, he will ask Congress for an emergency increase in this fiscal year's Pentagon budget to help cover the costs of operations in Haiti, in Kuwait, in Bosnia and off the Cuban coast. Administration officials said later that this emergency request would total about $2 billion.
Senior Administration officials said Mr. Clinton's plan was recognition of a need to improve the readiness and the quality of life of military forces, which have been stretched so thin that the Pentagon last month conceded that 3 of 12 Army divisions were not at peak readiness levels.
But the Administration officials also acknowledged that the timing and the staging of today's event reflected a view that Mr. Clinton must do more to head off what has been a strong line of Republican attack: that cuts in military spending since he took office almost two years ago have left American forces incapable of carrying out their declared mission of fighting two major conflicts at once.
"We ask much of our military," the President said in presenting his initiative, "and we owe much to them."
Republican Congressional leaders described the plan as a welcome and important first step. Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who is among his party's most influential figures in military matters, called it "the first sign of recognition on the part of this Administration that this nation's military readiness and ability to defend its vital national interests in the world is in question."
But Senator McCain and his fellow Republicans said the initiative was insufficient to heal what they called deep wounds in American military might. They said they would fight to halt the decline in the Pentagon budget, which has plunged to $252 billion a year from $281 billion since Mr. Clinton took office and would decline further, even under the President's new plan, before spending rises again later in the decade.
"This is a hemorrhage that needs a tourniquet," said Senator Robert C. Smith, a New Hampshire Republican who is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, "and the President is offering a Band-Aid."
The $25 billion in new spending that Mr. Clinton called for today would not reverse the current decline in the military budget until the 1998 fiscal year, a turnaround point he had previously set. It would postpone its largest budget increases until the turn of the century, and over the next four years would provide only $2.5 billion a year -- about 1 percent of the Pentagon budget -- over existing plans for military spending.
At a White House briefing after the announcement, Deputy Defense Secretary John Deutch pronounced the plan sufficient to allow the Pentagon to close a budget shortfall that had threatened to force deep cuts in weapons systems.
But Republicans immediately questioned Mr. Deutch's arithmetic. They said that even if his assumptions of low inflation were correct, and even given weapons systems cuts that he said still lay ahead, it would be impossible to make up a budget gap that the Administration estimates will total $48 billion over the next six years.
"We have a readiness problem now, and we will have a readiness problem after the President's initiative is implemented," said Representative Floyd D. Spence, the South Carolina Republican who is preparing to become chairman of the House Armed Services Committee in the new Congress.
A promise to restore military spending is a central feature of House Republicans' "Contract With America," which they have pledged to carry out once they take control next month. Representative Newt Gingrich, set to become Speaker of the House, has led a chorus of Republican attacks accusing Mr. Clinton of cutting military spending too deeply.
But Mr. Clinton, who has sought for the last two years to hold the line against the deeper military cuts sought by some Democrats, said today that it was "not right" to see his request for an increase in spending as an acknowledgement that his critics were correct.
"We have seen the military, frankly, have to deal with an amazing number and variety of unanticipated challenges," he said. "They have done so with great skill, but now they need the support that I think we ought to give them."

HEADLINE: Derivatives Loss Jolts Stocks; Dow Off 38.36

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock prices, already falling because of gnawing inflation fears, were staggered yesterday by a surprise -- that a wealthy Southern California county was facing a loss of $1.5 billion, in part because of buying risky investments known as derivatives.
The loss by Orange County, Calif., is the largest attributed to derivatives by an institutional investor this year. The disclosure hurt Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest securities firm, in particular, because it has dealings with Orange County. 
 Stock traders spread rumors, denied by Merrill Lynch, that the brokerage house had itself lost more than $1 billion in related actions, such as a stock margin call or a derivative linked to municipal bonds. Merrill Lynch stock dropped 1 1/2, to 36 1/2, in unusually heavy trading of 1.8 million shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 38.36 points, or 1.03 percent, to 3,700.87. The broader stock indexes fell, too, with the Standard & Poor's 500 dropping 1.05 percent and the Nasdaq composite index falling 1.29 percent.
"Orange County was the straw that broke the camel's back today," said Harrison Roth, senior options strategist for Cowen & Company. "Tomorrow might bring an even bigger straw."
The Orange County news weakened prices in advance of today's closely watched employment figures, which traders use to guide their decisions on buying or selling stocks and bonds. "As I tell all my traders," said Anthony P. Conroy, managing director in charge of trading at Mabon Securities, "those are the most important numbers this week."
Traders use derivatives to bet on the performance of indexes or other investments, including stocks, bonds, options and loan swaps. The derivatives are used to mitigate, and sometimes profit from, swings in interest rates or other shifts in market conditions.
But because of derivatives' complexity, and the occasional use of huge sums of borrowed money, large losses can also occur. Some corporate clients have lost millions of dollars and sued brokerage houses that arranged the investments for them.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, which had been quiet for most of the day, spiked in the last 15 minutes, as traders struggled to assess the implications of the loss by Orange County, the fifth-largest county in the country, with more than 2.4 million people.
By day's end, however, volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 288.3 million, about equal to the daily average for the year.
On the Big Board, two stocks fell for every stock that rose, with 1,553 issues declining and 692 gaining. Only 9 stocks established new highs, while 126 established new lows.
The market had been flat for much of the week, but began to turn down yesterday morning, with reports from the Commerce Department that Americans' incomes as well as personal spending had risen. Such reports suggest a potential for inflation that could lead to the Federal Reserve's raising interest rates, which in turn could hurt stocks and bonds.
At 12.4 million shares, Intel was the most active stock yesterday, declining 1/2, to 62 5/8, on traders' continuing concerns that the company may have to recall millions of flawed Pentium computer chips. In addition, stocks of many computer makers that use the chip in their machines were dragged down, a development that hurt the Nasdaq averages. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 9.71, to 740.61.
Then, when Orange County officials said about 2 P.M. Eastern time that they planned a statement by day's end disclosing their losses, the stock market turned down in earnest.
Along with the 38-point fall in the Dow, the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 4.77, to 448.92.
Best Buy, an electronics retailer, was one of the sharpest decliners yesterday, with shares dropping 11 3/8 to 32 7/8 after it predicted weaker-than-expected profits. J. C. Penney, the department store chain, established a 52-week low of 41 7/8 before closing at 42 1/2, down 3 1/2, also on traders' worries about its retail sales prospects.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 2.37 points to 246.04 and the American Stock Exchange market value index dropped 2.67 points to 431.19.
Of the Dow industrials' 30 component stocks, 23 fell, led by International Paper, which lost 1 3/8 to 70 1/8. Of the S.& P. 500's component stocks, 365 fell, led by Wal-Mart, which dropped 3/4, to 22 1/2.

HEADLINE: Paris Meeting Backs U.N. Program to Combat AIDS

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Recognizing that the global fight against AIDS has so far been largely ineffective, 42 countries pledged today to throw their political weight behind a new United Nations program to step up prevention campaigns and to fight discrimination against victims of the disease.
At a so-called AIDS summit meeting on World AIDS Day, a dozen prime ministers and other senior officials also agreed to work more closely with AIDS victims and carriers of the human immunodeficiency virus. Those who are infected often say their opinions and experience are ignored. 
 Yolanda Simon, an H.I.V. carrier from the Caribbean, told delegates today: "We're tired of the lip service we feel you have been paying to our communities. Why must there always be confrontation between us? Why not work in a spirit of partnership?"
Outside the conference hall, there were also signs of skepticism that today's meeting could make much difference. About 50 members of the militant group Act Up blocked traffic along the Champs-Elysees this morning to protest the gathering.
But the chief American delegate, Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the meeting had placed the AIDS crisis "higher on the world agenda." She added: "We're talking about a whole new partnership with non-governmental organizations and with people with AIDS."
In her address, she stressed that fundamental human rights were at stake. "The battle against AIDS is also a battle against racism, sexism and homophobia," she said. "As leaders, we must fight to protect the rights of people with H.I.V. and AIDS while we fight against the virus that is killing them."
Richard Burzynski of the International Council of AIDS Service Organizations, who also spoke today, denounced laws denying H.I.V. carriers the freedom to cross borders.
"This means that laws which criminalize or discriminate against homosexuals, drug users, migrants, refugees and sex workers must be abolished," he said.
This position was echoed in a final declaration that emphasized the rights of those with AIDS to health care, employment, education, travel, housing and social welfare.
The United States is among a score of countries that restrict the entry of AIDS victims or carriers of H.I.V. Inaugurating today's meeting, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France said, "It would be an illusion to think that certain countries can protect themselves alone by closing their borders."
Prominent in the plan adopted today was recognition of the special vulnerability of women to AIDS and the need to eliminate social, economic and cultural factors weakening prevention programs. "The pandemic is now spreading faster among women," warned Hiroshi Nakajima, Director General of the World Health Organization.
The main thrust of today's declaration, though, was for governments to recognize their responsibility to fight AIDS and to work more closely with one another and with a new United Nations program that aims to coordinate the activities of all international bodies.
But in a pessimistic review of efforts to date, the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, asked, "Why has our mobilization against AIDS borne so little fruit?" All too often, he said, there has been no linkage between global and national strategies, and at times there has even been rivalry.
"Given this situation, it is essential that we rethink our action and improve our coordination," he said.
Noting that 17 million people have so far been infected by H.I.V., he said that "the poorest people in the poorest countries" were the natural targets, with 70 percent of the infected people living in sub-Saharan Africa. "There is thus an obvious correlation between AIDS and underdevelopment," he added.

International
 The Senate approved the new global trade accord, ending years of GATT negotiations with more than 100 nations over the lowering of tariffs, and also creating a World Trade Organization. [A1.]
 

The Economy
 One of the biggest losses on investments known as derivatives was reported by Orange County, Calif. The county fund's $1.5 billion loss, caused by rising interest rates, is expected to focus more attention on such highly volatile investments. [Page D1.]
 Holiday sales are off to a relatively modest start, with the big retail chains reporting only moderate gains for November. [D1.]
 Politically sacred payments could consume the entire Federal budget by 2030, according to a computer war game from a Washington panel on reducing entitlements and the deficit. [D1.]
 Americans' incomes surged 1.4 percent in October, and consumer spending rose. Other reports pointed to a robust economy. [D2.]

Companies

HEADLINE: Cuban Exiles Raise Cash To Resettle New Refugees

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Frustrated over Government delays in releasing Cuban refugee families held in detention camps at the Guantanamo naval base in Cuba and in Panama, Cuban exile groups are getting pledges to privately finance the transportation and resettlement of about 8,000 refugees in this country.
The money would also pay for schooling for more than 2,000 children. 
 Representatives of an ad hoc committee that has been pressing the Clinton Administration to release the families said they undertook the effort because they feared that costs of illegal immigration in Florida and an anti-immigrant mood in the country have delayed for weeks a Federal announcement on when the refugees could come to the United States. That announcement is now scheduled for Friday by Justice Department officials, an Administration official said.
"They're very generous," the official said of the Cuban-Americans' offer to underwrite the relocation. But the official added, "This is not going to turn on whether it's a burden to the state, but on humanitarian concerns."
But the cost factor has been an issue for Gov. Lawton Chiles, who has sued the Federal Government to get it to pay expenses associated with illegal immigration into Florida. Mr. Chiles ran for re-election, and won, stressing his success in keeping more than 30,000 Cuban refugees away from Florida last fall.
To appease the Governor and Federal officials worried about anti-immigrant sentiment elsewhere, Cubans in South Florida have been lining up help in the past few weeks to avoid a drain on public money.
They said they already had commitments from private institutions, corporations and individuals to cover at least half of the estimated $15 million needed to relocate the refugees. The pledges include free flights from a volunteer aviator group, scholarships from Christian schools and about 9,000 sponsors willing to take in families and guarantee that they will not become a public charge for at least a year.
The Cuban refugees have been held in detention camps since last August, when the Administration ordered their interception after thousands set out in boats and rafts for the United States because of worsening economic conditions in Cuba. The detentions marked the reversal of longstanding American policy of granting entry to refugees fleeing the Communist Government of Fidel Castro.
Although Cubans in the United States have always played a major role in the economic assimilation of each new wave of immigrants from Cuba, the plans for the Guantanamo refugees are the most ambitious and broad-based to date. That they even tried, some experts in Cuban affairs say, attests to the exile community's organizational and financial capacity, and its impatience with American policy on Cuba.
"It's almost an embarrassment for the Cuban community that Castro and divided families continue to be a major public policy issue," said Mark B. Rosenberg, acting dean of the College of Urban and Public Affairs at Florida International University. "The result is that the community tries to come up with its own solutions."
Last month Administration officials said they were leaning toward releasing the families on the ground that keeping children in Guantanamo for months was inhumane.
On Friday, Justice Department officials are expected to list the conditions under which the families would be granted entry. An Administration official said humanitarian need, as measured by the age and health of the child, among other things, would be determined case by case before anyone was allowed in.
Administration officials said the decision on the Cuban families was an expansion of a policy announced in October to allow the humanitarian parole into the United States of unaccompanied children under 18 in the detention camps, as well as the elderly and those with urgent medical needs. Already, more than 400 Cubans have been flown in and relocated by voluntary relief agencies under this policy.
Francisco Hernandez, president of the Cuban-American National Foundation, said the ad hoc committee lobbying for the release of the families has secured pledges to help pay for about $2.5 million in transportation costs and about $12 million for initial resettlement costs, including education, health insurance, food and housing.
Mr. Hernandez said about 9,000 people, mostly relatives or friends of the refugees, have applied with the foundation to sponsor the families. About 30 percent of them are expected to move to Cuban communities in New Jersey, New York, California and other states.
Most contributions are needed in Miami, which even Cubans who settle elsewhere eventually choose as their permanent home. Tom Willey, the South Florida director of World Relief, a service arm of the National Association of Evangelicals, said the agency was urging Christian schools in the Miami area to donate scholarships.
Mr. Willey said that one school had already agreed to take five students, and that he expected many others to follow suit.
The volunteer search-and-rescue group Brothers to the Rescue has committed its donations to fly the children in. Little Havana Activities and Nutrition Centers of Dade County, which finds jobs for immigrants in the health care and service industries, says it believes it can place most of the refugees.
Interest in helping the refugees has also come from commercial carriers like United Airlines and from the newspaper El Nuevo Herald and Roman Catholic schools, Mr. Hernandez said.
He also said his group had offered to pay for the 1,500 Haitian children who are being held in detention camps in Guantanamo. A Federal judge ruled last month that these children should be allowed into the United States in the same way that Cuban children are, but the Government has appealed that decision.
"Our purpose is to show that this is something that can be done," Mr. Hernandez said. "We're prepared to hold their hand for a year or a year and a half."
A spokesman for Mr. Chiles said the Governor had insisted that families be allowed entry only on four conditions -- that they also resettle in other states, that they have sponsors, that the Federal Government take full financial responsibility for them and that the group is counted against the 20,000 visas the United States has agreed to grant annually to Cubans who want to come to this country.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cuban-Americans are collecting pledges to privately finance the bringing to this country of 8,000 refugees being held at camps at Guantanamo Naval Station and elsewhere. Many refugees, like this girl, live in tents. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 11-Year Sentence for Chief of Failed S.& L.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 1

 BODY:
David L. Paul, chairman of the failed Centrust Bank, was sentenced today to 11 years in prison and ordered to pay $65 million for his part in the $1.7 billion collapse of the savings and loan institution.
Mr. Paul, 55, was convicted of 97 counts of racketeering and fraud in connection with the 1990 failure of Centrust, the fourth-biggest banking collapse in United States history. 
 The prosecution had recommended that Mr. Paul serve 17 to 22 years in prison, and the defense proposed a three-year sentence.
Judge Donald Graham of Federal District Court split the difference, citing Mr. Paul's abuse of trust, his central role and planning in the crimes, and the jeopardy to Centrust's financial soundness that his actions caused.
Although prosecutors strongly disagreed, Mr. Graham also concluded that Mr. Paul had accepted responsibility for his crimes, despite expressing concerns earlier in the day about Mr. Paul's attitude.
Along with the prison sentence, Mr. Paul was ordered to pay $60 million in restitution and a $5 million fine. He must report to prison in 30 days and wear an electronic monitoring bracelet until then.
Whether Mr. Paul can pay his restitution and fines is in doubt. After the bank's collapse, Mr. Paul pleaded poverty and his wife has filed for bankruptcy protection.
Regulators had attacked Centrust's extravagant spending on artwork and other luxuries.
Mr. Paul showed no reaction as he was sentenced. But later he said: "You take each day in stride. Right now I'm taking each day in stride."
His lawyer, Benson Weintraub, said, "I do think the sentence was excessive, but it was a very difficult sentencing decision for the judge,".
The prosecutor, Allan Sullivan, said after the sentencing that Mr. Paul "believes in his heart that he is an innocent man."
Judge Graham tentatively set a dollar loss of $62 million from the crimes committed in the 1980's when Mr. Paul was running Centrust, the biggest savings and loan in the Southeast, and hobnobbing with celebrities and politicians. The amount is the starting point for determining the length of a prison term in fraud cases.
The defense says the bank had $938 million in revenue when it was seized in 1990, while the prosecution has calculated a $371 million loss on junk bonds that were sold by regulators after the bank failed.

HEADLINE: Ex-Television Evangelist Bakker Ends Prison Sentence for Fraud

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HENDERSONVILLE, N.C., Dec. 1

 BODY:
Five years and two months after he went to prison for bilking thousands of contributors to his PTL ministry, Jim Bakker, the former television evangelist, became a free man today.
But Mr. Bakker, now 54 and divorced from his wife of 30 years, Tammy Faye, stayed out of sight in the modest ranch-style house he has been renting for the past three months while under house arrest. 
 He has refused all requests for interviews. On Tuesday he called the sheriff to have television camera crews removed from his property on the outskirts of this Blue Ridge city of 7,380 people.
"He's waited five years to gain his freedom," said Chris Nichols, a lawyer whose firm represents Mr. Bakker, "and a few extra days of waiting in the house for the press to leave won't hurt him."
A statement released by James H. Toms, a close friend and also a lawyer for Mr. Bakker, only hinted at the future. "Jim looks forward to rebuilding his life and being of useful service to others," it said. "He will remain in western North Carolina."
Friends who have spoken to Mr. Bakker in the last few days said he was overjoyed about his new status. He must still report periodically to probation officials.
Some friends said he was working on a book about his life. Others said they were urging him to return to the ministry in some form, even though he is barred by the terms of his sentence from conducting a ministry on television.
Mr. Bakker has reportedly told these friends that prison has been a humbling experience, one that has given him insights he wants to share.
Some who say they were victims of Mr. Bakker's excesses in his ministry are feeling charitable now.
"I was hurt like many others -- beside myself with anger and dismay," said Don Edwards Jr., a resident of Heritage USA, the 2,300-acre Christian-oriented retreat and entertainment complex in Fort Mill, S.C. Mr. Edwards became president of PTL Ministries after Mr. Bakker found himself facing Federal fraud charges.
"But I have healed," Mr. Edwards added. "He is most welcome in our home any time."
Others have found it harder to forgive. "It's a shame that anybody who took millions of people's savings should get off so easy," said Charlie Truax, 68, a retired postal worker. "I don't think he has paid his debt to society."
Mr. Bakker was convicted in 1989 of 24 counts of mail and wire fraud in bilking 116,000 supporters of $158 million they had contributed to buy shares Heritage USA.
Adding to the financial collapse of the ministry was the shock of the disclosure that Mr. Bakker had a sexual encounter with a church secretary, Jessica Hahn, and had diverted some $265,000 of church money to buy her silence.
Mr. Bakker was originally sentenced to 45 years and fined $500,000, but an appeals court reduced that sentence twice, first to 18 years and then to 8 years.
Many people here are still skeptical about Mr. Bakker.
Rebecca Castroman, a hostess at the Po'Folks Restaurant, recalled the Bakkers in their heyday, when they stopped here while traveling to one of their vacation homes in Tennessee and posed with big smiles for a photograph in the local newspaper while standing in front of their Lincoln Continental under a sign that blazed "Po'Folks.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Ebb; Buyers Await Data on Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were slightly lower yesterday in moderate trading, in advance of the important monthly employment report due today.
The benchmark 30-year bond fell 6/32 , to 946/32 , which pushed up its yield to 8.01 percent from 8 percent on Wednesday. Rates for shorter-maturity bills also increased as prices, which move in the opposite direction, were lower. 
 The market limited its losses despite a barrage of data showing strong economic growth -- the sort of news that has depressed bond prices out of fear of inflation. The reports were all close to expectations, and many traders awaited today's November employment figures.
Manufacturers reported brisk growth and higher prices last month, spurring concern that interest rates would go up. But sales reported by the nation's big retail chains were considered somewhat disappointing.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said yesterday's data showed that the economy was continuing to grow more strongly than desired "and put more pressure on the Fed to firm policy further."
She said she expected the Federal Reserve to next raise short-term interest rates at the Jan. 31 meeting of its rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee, but she did not rule out an increase at the committee's Dec. 20 meeting.
Other data released yesterday included October construction spending, up nine-tenths of 1 percent, which was higher than expected. But strong October personal income and spending, and weekly jobless claims, had only moderate effects on the market. The weekly jobless claims fell to 317,000 for the week ending Nov. 26, compared with 329,000 for the previous week. Separately, the Conference Board said its help-wanted advertising index rose in October, suggesting that the demand for new workers had not slowed.
An increase in manufacturing, as seen in a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management, underscored previous strong momentum in that area. The association's index rose for the 15th consecutive month to its highest level in 10 years. The gains were led by new orders and production, with employment edging up slightly.
Construction activity outpaced expectations in both September and October. But a rapid shift in construction activity, from housing to commercial and public building, is likely to have a negative effect on the fourth quarter's gross domestic product and probably on that in the first quarter of 1995, too. Some economists foresee that residential construction will fall at a 9 percent rate in the fourth quarter, while commercial construction surges 16 percent and state and local government spending remains strong.
But the most eye-catching news yesterday, traders said, was the surge in the Conference Board's help-wanted index for October, up 11 points to 128. The strength of the report stoked fears of a stronger-than-predicted employment report today.
Ms. Schaja said she expected the nonfarm payroll to show an increase of 250,000, with unemployment unchanged at 5.8 percent.
Also weighing on prices early yesterday were comments by the president of Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, Cathy E. Minehan, who said on a Boston radio program that a tight labor market could spur inflation and that the economy was showing "very strong growth." Ms. Minehan is to become a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee at the January meeting.
Among traders in the corporate bond market, the reaction was similar to those dealing in Treasury securities -- a refusal to succumb to the stronger-than-expected consumption and personal-income data. October's income data indicated rises in both salaries and hourly wages.
Prices of municipal securities were little changed as investors vied for a limited quantity with relatively higher yields.
Last month, states, localities and agencies sold $12.1 billion in new securities, including negotiated and competitive ones, according to Bloomberg Business News.
The total amount of debt sold in November was slightly higher than in October, with $7.1 billion of municipal issues sold by negotiations with underwriters and $4.996 billion through competitive bidding.
