HEADLINE: Pataki Warns Of Painful Cuts In State Aid To Close Deficit

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Governor-elect George E. Pataki said today that closing a projected $5 billion budget deficit while keeping his campaign pledge to cut taxes would involve more pain than he expected, and he suggested that to do it, he might have to break another campaign pledge: protecting state aid to local schools and governments.
On a day in which he was either meeting with jubilant Republican lawmakers or hunkering down with budget advisers, Mr. Pataki repeatedly said that he "had ruled out nothing" to close next year's projected deficit, except raising taxes. He said his options included laying off workers, consolidating agencies, slashing welfare and freezing or cutting state aid to schools and local governments. 
 During the campaign, Mr. Pataki, a Republican, said he could pay for his plan to cut state income tax rates by 25 percent over four years without laying off state employees. He also said that he wanted to safeguard aid to local schools and governments. "I would like to see education aid increase," he said on Oct. 3.
Today, that position shifted sharply. Mr. Pataki said he had won a mandate from voters not only to cut taxes, but also to cut spending.
"Until we have the courage and the commitment to take the action necessary to not just solve one year's problems but to break that structural imbalance, we'll have this problem," he said. "We want to take actions in 1995 that, for once and for all, control the spending that has been the problem for this state government."
Mr. Pataki began his day in the capital with an hourlong meeting with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, their first face-to-face session since the election. During the campaign, the two men did not debate, never crossed paths and essentially limited their dialogue to acrid exchanges via spokespersons.
But today, they were all smiles and kind words after a private meeting in Mr. Cuomo's conference room that was also attended by their closest advisers. During the meeting, which their aides called friendly and cooperative, Mr. Cuomo promised to make himself available at any time to help Mr. Pataki. Then, for the benefit of news photographers, he gave Mr. Pataki a brief tour of the ornate ceremony room adjoining his office, which is decorated with a 12-foot-high Christmas tree and a collection of wooden rocking horses.
Noting that he was feeling a little wistful at leaving the office he has held for 12 years, Mr. Cuomo, while standing at Mr. Pataki's side, said: "Of course, I would have wanted to win. And I regret that I didn't. But I'm very eager to see George Pataki succeed as Governor Pataki. He is Governor right now as far as I am concerned."
Asked if he felt he was leaving the state in capable hands, Mr. Cuomo, who during the campaign accused Mr. Pataki of dishonesty, said: "Oh yes. This is a great, great state. It survived me. It should do very well with Governor Pataki."
In an afternoon news conference, Mr. Pataki elaborated somewhat on their meeting, saying that he reiterated his request that Mr. Cuomo freeze state hiring and delay signing unessential contracts before Jan. 1. He said Mr. Cuomo did not commit to the freeze, but promised to try to reduce spending.
Mr. Pataki also said that Mr. Cuomo seemed to agree with him that an employee buyout program by the State Power Authority was too generous. Later, Mr. Cuomo released a letter sent by his counsel to Power Authority officials saying that the program might violate an executive order which, among other things, requires all compensation programs to be reviewed by Mr. Cuomo's budget division.
A spokesman for the Power Authority, Stephen Shoenholz, said he had not seen the letter and could not comment on it.
Mr. Pataki also hinted that he may not move his family from their large Victorian home in the Putnam County town of Garrison to the Governor's Mansion in Albany next year.
"We want to be as less disruptive as possible to our kids' lives," said Mr. Pataki, who has four school-age children. "We are leaning very strongly now toward having them continue the balance of this school year in the schools where they are. But even beyond that point, we haven't made any final determination."
Between his meetings with Mr. Cuomo and budget advisers, Mr. Pataki met with the Republican's two leading legislators, the new Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and the Assembly minority leader, Clarence D. Rappleyea. He also addressed a meeting of the Assembly Republicans, receiving a rousing ovation from colleagues with whom he served for eight years.
After the meeting, one of Mr. Pataki's leading budget advisers, Assemblyman John J. Faso, said the projected $5 billion budget gap was mostly the result of increased spending, not anticipated tax cuts or declining revenues. For that reason, he said, Mr. Pataki should be able to fulfill his campaign pledge to cut income taxes rates by 25 percent in four years, a plan which would reduce state revenues by $5.6 billion per year by 1999.
Later, Mr. Pataki reinforced his intention to cut taxes. "The people of this state voted for change, and it's not simply enacting the tax cuts that we talked about during the course of the campaign, it's controlling the spending which has driven us to where we are: the highest taxed people in America," he said.
Mr. Pataki also said that before Election Day, he did not think layoffs would be necessary to produce a balanced budget. "But I don't believe anybody was talking about a budget deficit of the magnutude of four-and-a-half to five billion dollars prior to the election," he said.
Throughout the campaign, Mr. Cuomo charged that Mr. Pataki's tax-cut plan was economically unrealistic and that the state would be unable to pay for it except by reducing aid to local governments -- a move that could force towns and cities to increase property taxes.
But Mr. Pataki said that he would not allow that to happen, contending that he viewed the property tax as "the worst tax" because it can force people to give up their homes.
Yesterday, Mr. Pataki also announced the formation of a 15-member task force that will study ways to reduce utility costs for the customers of the Long Island Lighting Company. The group will be led by State Senator James L. Seward, a Republican from Oneonta, and Frank Zarb, an investment banker and former energy adviser to President Nixon.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Governor-elect George E. Pataki spoke with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday in the Governor's ceremonial office in the Capitol, after their first meeting since the election. The Governor said he was "very eager to see George Pataki succeed as Governor Pataki. He is Governor right now as far as I am concerned." (David Jennings for The New York Times)

FEBRUARY 1994: The state budget division projects spending will outpace revenues by $1.43 billion in the 1995-96 budget year, because of a slower economy and higher health care costs.
 
June 1994: The Legislature passes the 1994-95 budget, and in doing so, increases the deficit for the following budget year in two ways: by approving $635 million in business tax cuts for the 95-96 year, and by adding 1.2 billion in new spending in the 1995-96 budget. That puts the projected deficit to $3.27 billion.
 
FALL: New problems have arisen. The budget division projects that personal income tax revenues for the 95-96 year will be $500 million less than projected, and that revenues from a hospital tax will fall by $267 million. At the same time, prison costs are expected to rise an extra $75 million because of more inmates, school aid costs are estimated to go up by $47 million and other programs are projected to grow faster than expected, increasing costs by another $100 million. That brings the projected deficit to 4.25 billion.
 
DECEMBER: Governor-elect George E. Pataki says the cost of an income tax cut in the 1995-96 budget year would be about $800 million. Add that to the budget deficit and the shortfall hits $5.05 billion.

HEADLINE: Republicans Vow Dismissals, Audits and Reshuffling of House

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The House Republicans said today that when they take over next month they will dismiss hordes of Capitol functionaries, reshuffle all their offices, audit everything, hire more waste-and-fraud watchdogs and make all decisions of any note in the light of public scrutiny.
They said this would save the Government money, though they could not yet say how much, and they said it would make for a leaner bureaucracy, though they allowed that 1,500 people who were told today that they would be dismissed could apply for their old jobs and that some might be hired back after some re-education. 
 The remainder will be let go without severance pay, a decision the supervisor of the Republican takeover, Representative Jim Nussle of Iowa, said was deemed "appropriate" by the party's leaders.
Such changes would amount to nothing less than a revolution in the House, a place which, despite its $728.5 million annual budget, operates more like a cross between the sitcom town of Mayberry and a Chicago alderman's ward. Push-button elevators are staffed with elevator operators, ice is delivered to every office every working day and politics -- Democratic politics, for the last 42 years -- dictates not just all action, but all inaction, too.
Denouncing Democratic "arrogance" and brandishing a plethora of flow charts and press releases, Mr. Nussle said those days were over, or would be on Jan. 4. He said notices of impending unemployment were sent out today to those who basically kept the House running -- janitors, cafeteria workers, accountants, doorkeepers and so on -- so they could have a month to decide whether to reapply for their jobs.
"We want to make sure that these people are dealt with as fairly and as quickly as possible," he said.
Democrats are incensed.
"What they are causing is going to be a major disruption," said Representative Benjamin L. Cardin of Maryland, a senior member of the House Administration Committee, the closest thing to a city council in this legislative company town. "This is an unfair thing they are doing."
Among other things, the Republicans propose to abolish the Administration Committee, which controls countless internal matters like the awarding of food-service contracts that bore voters stiff but interest House members intensely.
The Republican overhaul would replace the Administration Committee with a new Oversight Committee that would confine itself to broad questions of policy. Control over contracts, money and other meat-and-potatoes matters would fall to a new chief administrative officer of the House, to be appointed by the Speaker-to-be, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia. The proposal would concentrate virtually all day-to-day House operations under the new administrative officer, from printing to computer operations to janitors and the post office.
Mr. Nussle said Republicans would increase the House inspector general's staff to 11 workers, from 3, forward its findings to the Oversight Committee and the Justice Department when proper and give it control over outside audits of all House operations. Those audits and, probably, reports by the inspector general will be made public, he said.
He said public accountability would be the hallmark of the Republican "open House," in contrast to what he said were decades in which Democrats denied Republicans and voters information about the most basic House matters. That secrecy, he said, bred the corruption that came to light this decade in scandals involving the House bank and post office.

HEADLINE: $1.5 Billion Loss Seen For County

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Orange County, Calif., one of the wealthiest counties in the nation, is facing one of the biggest investment losses ever -- $1.4 billion -- from purchases of highly volatile investments known as derivatives, which have fallen in value as interest rates have risen.
The Orange County loss appears to be the largest by an investment fund, either corporate or municipal, from these complex instruments. And it overshadows such well-publicized problems that derivatives have caused at Procter & Gamble, the investment firm of Piper Jaffray and, just last week, the Mellon Bank. 
 In a statement announcing the losses yesterday, Robert Citron, the Orange County treasurer, said they were still only on paper. But critics of Mr. Citron's investment policy assert that many of the securities may never recover in value. They estimate that the losses could rise to $2 billion or more.
"Orange County has joined the ranks of these problems in a big way," said Richard Y. Roberts, a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission. "It's worrisome to the S.E.C. These securities, which were dreamed up more in a boiler room than a conference room, are sold to a broad range of investors and re sprinkled around the country."
Orange County is one of hundreds of municipalities, mutual funds, colleges and corporations that tried to increase their investment returns by buying highly complex securities that were, in effect, high-risk bets on the direction of interest rates. As interest rates have risen since earlier this year, the value of these instruments have tumbled in value.
Derivatives are securities that are linked to underlying assets, either stocks and bonds or financial indexes. The gain or losses on the derivatives depend on the performance of the underlying asset. Derivatives can result in losses that investors may never have imagined.
The $20 billion Orange County fund included some $8 billion in reserve money for future needs from more than 180 municipalities in California and $12 billion in borrowed funds.
The largest investors in the fund are the county itself, the county transportation authority, sanitation districts and California cities outside the county.
Mr. Citron, who did not respond to requests for comment, took some $8 billion in the money of these municipalities, borrowed some $12 billion more, and used it to buy a wide variety of securities that go by the name of floating-rate derivatives and reverse repurchase agreements."
As of August, $5.7 billion was invested in floating-rate instruments that decreased in value as interest rates rose. Also, about $7.5 billion was invested in government-agency four-year notes, which have also fallen in value. And some $12 billion was borrowed, in the form of reverse repurchase agreements, which added a high amount of leverage, or risk, to the portfolio.
The borrowed money, which was pegged to rising short-term interest rates, was used to buy the longer-term government agency notes, according to those who have seen the portfolio.
"All these securities have lost value and are not worth what they paid for them," said Joseph Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer, an industry newsletter. "This county has taken a market hit. And then they borrowed to do that, so it's even worse."
Mr. Citron, in his statement, defended his actions. "In my 21 years of managing this fund, I have dealt with bear markets and bull markets, and am confident that we can deal with this situation," he said.
The county said it was assembling a team of county executives and securities consultants to develop a strategy to resolve the fund's problems.
Mr. Citron's actions came under sharp fire in June when he was challenged for the county treasurer's post. He won. But his opponent, John Moorlach, a Costa Mesa, Calif., accountant, made Mr. Citron's investments a campaign issue, calling them "junk." Following yesterday's announcement, Mr. Moorlach said: "The good news is that I was right. The bad news, too, is that I was right. Rising interest rates are the kiss of death for this investment strategy."
Merrill Lynch & Company sold Orange County many of the securities in the fund. A spokesman said the firm would experience no losses as a result of the Orange County problems. Merrill Lynch sharesfell by $1.50 to close at $36.50 in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
The exact impact of these potential losses on the operations of the 180 municipalities and agencies that put their money into this fund is unclear. The most vulnerable are school districts, including Orange County schools, because they could have more immediate needs for the money.
Nearly 60 percent of the money was put in on an involuntary basis, and the largest amount came from the county's transportation authority. Mr. Citron's office said yesterday that a number of the municipalities that voluntarily put their reserve money into the fund would continue to do so, although nine said yesterday that they were reviewing this situation.
The Orange County Sanitation District, which has $400 million in the fund, said it would stay. "It's not a problem for us," said Steve Kozak, the district's financial manager. He said the district has no upcoming needs for the money.
The fund is not intended to cover continuing municipal expenses. Instead, it is an investment pool where municipalities put their extra cash in order to earn more.
Karen S. Krop, an assistant vice president at Moody's Investors Service, a rating agency, said that it was having "ongoing discussions" with Orange Country officials to review the situation. It is too early to determine, Ms. Krop said, if the agency will downgrade the county's rating as a result of yesterday's announcement. The county's current rating is Aa1, just below the top rating.
Most of the county's debt is made up of general obligation borrowings, which are backed by the tax payments of county residents.
John L. Schiavetti, an analyst at Fitch's Investment Services, another rating agency, said that municipalities like Orange County are ill-equipped to make the complex financial analyses required to understand derivatives.
A warning to this effect was recently issued by the Government Finance Officers Association. "It's difficult to analyze such high-risk securities," Mr. Schiavetti said. "It takes a lot to understand these things and lots of municipalities simply don't have the expertise."

HEADLINE: Mammogram Interpretation Is Questioned

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
A new study has raised serious questions about radiologists' reliability in reading mammograms and making recommendations about what to do when a suspicious lesion is found in the breast.
The study, by researchers at the Yale University School of Medicine and published yesterday in The New England Journal of Medicine, found that radiologists who read mammograms can vary considerably in their interpretations of the X-ray films and in the advice they would give to women. 
 Where one radiologist might recommend an immediate biopsy, another looking at the same mammogram might suggest a repeat X-ray in three months, and still another might suggest waiting a year to do another mammogram.
The study, directed by Dr. Joann G. Elmore, an assistant professor of medicine at Yale, involved the reading of 150 women's mammograms, originally taken in 1987, by 10 radiologists from New York and Connecticut. Though all the radiologists were trained and experienced in reading mammograms, they disagreed on the diagnosis more than 20 percent of the time and disagreed even more often as to whether a biopsy should be performed.
In interpreting the mammograms of women who, in fact, had cancer, the radiologists' recommendations to do a biopsy ranged from 74 percent to 96 percent. And among the mammograms of women who did not have cancer, recommendations for an immediate biopsy ranged from 11 percent to 65 percent. In addition, in some cases the radiologists disagreed as to which breast should be biopsied.
The study does not question the value of mammography in detecting early cancers or the quality of the X-ray equipment used. It does suggest that it may be necessary to have more specific criteria for radiologists to use in interpreting the X-rays and in making decisions about what to do next. It also suggests that the training given to radiologists in reading mammograms might be improved.
In an editorial accompanying the report, however, a leading radiologist at Harvard Medical School took issue with the study's design and conclusions. The radiologist, Dr. Daniel B. Kopans, pointed out that the sampling of mammograms used in the study contained an unusually large proportion of "ambiguous" films. When these same mammograms were originally read in 1987, he wrote, "almost 30 percent of the cancers were incorrectly categorized."
He added that "mammography is not an accurate diagnostic test because there is a considerable overlap in the appearances of benign and malignant lesions on mammograms."
Dr. Kopans also suggested that the findings emphasized several well-known facts about medical practice, among them that even the most expert doctor will occasionally overlook an important abnormality and that doctors vary in their willingness to recommend additional procedures based on a single suspicious test result.
Among radiologists reading a mammogram that hints of an abnormality, some might suggest a repeat mammogram in three months while others, looking at the same X-ray, might suggest an immediate biopsy.
Dr. Kopans questioned whether this decision should be made by the radiologist alone. He suggested instead that the woman "certainly should be given the option" of deciding whether to have a biopsy if there is a 10 percent chance or even a 1 percent chance that a mammographic lesion indicates a malignancy.
The study's findings also raise an important economic issue. At a time when health care agencies are striving to reduce medical expenditures, the study suggests that the price of greater accuracy in detecting cancers through mammography may be to perform a larger number of breast biopsies, more of which will turn out to be benign.
In the study, the radiologist who detected the most breast cancers did so because he recommended biopsies for mammographic lesions that other radiologists chose to ignore or watch with repeat mammograms. This radiologist, however, also had a high rate of biopsies of lesions that turned out to be benign. On the other hand, the radiologist with the lowest rate of cancer detection had a very low rate of negative biopsies.
Dr. Kopans suggested that "since observers differ in what they miss," improved cancer detection through mammography could be achieved less expensively and certainly with less trauma to women by having two radiologists read every mammogram. He cited high-quality Swedish screening programs for breast cancer, which showed that "even among highly expert radiologists, double reading increases the rate of cancer detection by 15 percent."

HEADLINE: Maryland County Embroiled in Voting Rights Suit

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: POCOMOKE CITY, Md.

 BODY:
The flat, featureless countryside around here is dotted with the chicken farms that have brought economic renewal to Worcester County. To the northeast at the tip of the county sits Ocean City, a boardwalk isle that serves as a summer draw for the Middle Atlantic States.
But the county may soon become known throughout the nation for something else: It is becoming a prime legal battleground in the war over how to apportion political power fairly between whites and blacks. 
 The weapons have included the esoteric theories of C. Lani Guinier, President Clinton's onetime choice to be the nation's civil rights chief, as well as the threat of impatient civil rights leaders to hold Ocean City's tourist dollars hostage to their vision of justice.
The current round began in 1992 when some local black political figures, backed by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the American Civil Liberties Union, brought suit in Federal court charging that the county's electoral system discriminates against blacks in violation of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
The case has since bounced back and forth between a Federal court in Baltimore and a Federal appellate court in Richmond, and will almost certainly end up in the Supreme Court.
Two of the principal adversaries in the case, one white and the other black, live a few blocks from each other in this small town at the southern end of the county. John (Sonny) Bloxom is a white member of the Worcester County Commission and a defendant in the suit. The principal black plaintiff is Honiss Cane Jr., who runs several small businesses and as such has used Mr. Bloxom as a lawyer.
At the bottom of the dispute is a divergent view of how the races get along in Worcester County.
Asked recently about race relations locally, Mr. Bloxom replied: "I think they're very good. But this suit is the kind of thing that brings lots of difficulty, lots of polarization."
To the same question, Mr. Cane said: "They are simply real bad. I couldn't survive here without relying on the black community for my businesses." The lawsuit, he said, could hardly damage race relations because "a huge polarization already exists."
Worcester County, which is on the Delmarva Peninsula and has been a government entity for more than 250 years, is bounded on the north by Delaware and on the south by Virginia. Blacks constitute about 21 percent of the population of 35,000.
The five county commissioners are elected in a system called post-at-large, which used to be common in the South but has become archaic because of extensive voting rights litigation. Worcester County has never had a black commissioner.
Post-at-large works this way: The county is divided into five districts and candidates run as the representatives from those districts. But every voter in the county gets to cast a ballot in each of the five districts. That means each voter gets to vote five times, once in the voter's own district and once for each of the other four districts.
Last January, Judge Joseph H. Young of Federal District Court ruled that the system diluted blacks' voting strength in violation of the Voting Rights Act. In April, he ordered the county to remedy the situation with a system of "cumulative voting."
Cumulative voting is an idea mainly associated with Ms. Gunier, a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania whom Mr. Clinton nominated to head the civil rights division of the Justice Department, only to withdraw her name in June 1993 in the face of mounting opposition over her views on how black voters could increase their influence in elections. Cumulative voting has been used in settling some voting rights suits, but it has never been imposed by a judge.
In Worcester County, it was supposed to have worked this way: All candidates would run at large. Each voter would get five votes, which could all be cast for one candidate or divided among as many as five candidates. That means, for example, that black voters could concentrate all their votes on one black candidate, overcoming their numerical minority in the county.
Mr. Bloxom said he thought there were no elected blacks because no one had tried hard enough to win election. He said he himself had to run three times before being elected; no black, he said, has run for office more than once. He is deeply resentful of the suit, he said, because "they're saying they can't get elected without special treatment."
Mr. Cane, the plaintiff, said that without black commissioners, blacks got shut out not only from decision-making but also from patronage, the jobs and contracts the commissioners can dole out.
In September, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, upheld the ruling that Worcester County violated the Voting Rights Act, but said that cumulative voting was not acceptable either because it did not take into account local officials' desire to insure a system with regional representation. Under a cumulative voting plan, all the commissioners could come from one part of the county.
The likely result now is that the court will impose new regional boundaries to create a new district with a majority of black voters, a position supported by the Justice Department. The Supreme Court has been wrestling for two years with how far to go in creating special districts for blacks. A narrowly divided Court last year said in a North Carolina case that black majority districts with especially odd configurations could be unconstitutional.
If the Court imposes new boundaries, Worcester County would have a district that cuts across the county, picking up black neighborhoods in three towns. A map of the district would resemble a skinny dinosaur on its hind legs.
This fall, the commissioners began considering whether to appeal to the Supreme Court that part of the ruling they lost -- that there was a violation of the Voting Rights Act. They were suddenly confronted with a threat from the N.A.A.C.P. to organize a boycott of Ocean City on Memorial Day.
Edward H. Hammond, the lawyer for the county commissioners, said it was appalling that civil rights leaders would try to threaten the merchants of Ocean City to force the county to forgo its right of appeal. "We respected the plaintiffs' right to bring the case, they ought to respect our right to have our day in court," he said.
Mr. Cane said he saw nothing wrong with the boycott. "If they can use our taxpayers' money to work against the interest of the black community, we should be able to use a portion of strength, our economic power," he said.
The boycott threat has proved to be a clumsy tool, and the evidence of that came in October, when the county commissioners took up the issue of whether to proceed with the appeal. They voted unanimously to defy the threat.

HEADLINE: Republicans Elect Bruno Senate Leader

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 1

 BODY:
In a changing of the guard in the State Senate, Republicans formally elected Joseph L. Bruno of Rensselaer County as their new majority leader today.
"The people on Nov. 8 dictated to the people of this state that there be change," Mr. Bruno said at a news conference, where he was surrounded by his Republican colleagues. "The people in our conference recognized that call for change and have consequently supported me." 
 Mr. Bruno, a 65-year-old 18-year veteran of the Senate, pledged to work closely with his former Senate colleague, Governor-elect George E. Pataki, who held a round of meetings in the Capitol today with legislative leaders, budget officials and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. But Mr. Bruno offered few suggestions about how Mr. Pataki should restore the state's fiscal health, saying only that it was clear that the state had taxed and spent itself into an economic hole.
Instead, Mr. Bruno focused on the changes he would like to bring to the legislative process. He said he would ban the Senate's infamous all-night sessions, in which deals are cut and bleary-eyed legislators vote on bills they have never read. The Senate recessed last June at 11:20 A.M. after one such session, when a number of important bills died in the final hours.
Mr. Bruno also pledged to start Senate sessions and closed-door caucuses on time, a novel concept in his chamber. But he said he has not yet decided whether to propose to cut the legislative budget and staff, both of which are the largest of any state in the county.
Mr. Bruno's election was insured last Friday, after three days of furious lobbying, when he collected commitments from a majority of the 36 Republicans in the 61-member house. In doing so, he overthrew Ralph J. Marino, a Long Island Republican who had been majority leader since 1989 but who had opposed Mr. Pataki's candidacy earlier this year. Mr. Marino did not attend the closed-door session today at which Mr. Bruno was selected.
The full Senate is expected to confirm Mr. Bruno's election in a vote on the floor when it convenes next month.
Mr. Bruno said it was clear that New York has overspent and overtaxed, although he conceded that he voted for this year's budget, which he called "unconscionable" because it raised spending in the general fund by more than 6 percent over the previous year.
"It was the only document on the floor," he explained. "And if I'd had a choice my vote would have been otherwise."
Mr. Pataki was the only Republican senator who voted against this year's budget, which was negotiated by Mr. Marino, Mr. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.

HEADLINE: New Video-Game Challenge: Cut the Budget, if You Dare

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Call it the political equivalent of "Mortal Kombat." It's the Government's budget game you can't win without spilling the blood of millions.
The lesson of the computer game released today by a Presidential panel on entitlement spending is that there is no easy way to keep these politically sacred payments -- Social Security and Medicare, in particular -- from consuming the entire Federal budget by 2030. 
 Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat who is chairman of the Bipartisan Commission on Entitlement and Tax Reform, said "There will be a certain explosive nature" to the proposal for a cure he intends to submit next week.
Although budget specialists have long contended that that these giant programs will have to be curbed, the panel's much-heralded distribution of its interactive computer game dubbed "Budget Shadows" -- a model of policy options -- followed an election season in which virtually all candidates not only disavowed the notion of cuts but refused even to discuss the subject of Social Security.
"With the first keystrokes, people will confront the long-term fiscal imbalance caused by simple demographic forces: more people tapping entitlement programs with fewer working people to pay for them," said John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican who is retiring from the Senate and who serves as the commission's vice chairman. "And they will see that the Social Security and Medicare trusts are on a course toward future insolvency."
The game, to be widely distributed on computer networks and on diskettes, does not even strictly aim to balance the budget. Instead, the goal is simply to hold the deficit to the same share of national output as at present, about 3 percent of gross domestic product.
And the game's implacable scorer gives zero points for many politically appealing items, like slashing Congressional retirement benefits.
But keeping a lid on the deficit is not easy. It takes 100 points to win "Budget Shadows," a point being roughly equal to 20 billion of today's dollars. But while the panel expressed some anxiety that the game was "too easy" -- that is, you can win with a heartless flick of a finger -- real-life budget analysts who played at the request of The New York Times this afternoon showed it to be quite difficult when the potential human toll was taken into account.
"What I could stomach added up to 41," said Max B. Sawicky, public finance specialist at the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal-oriented research organization, when asked for his list of options to reach a score of 100. Scott A. Hodge, principal budget analyst for the conservative Heritage Foundation, did produce a list that added up to about 100, though not before complaining about a paucity of options.
Mr. Sawicky, who wrote a paper earlier this month declaring that reducing the deficit "is neither as important nor as urgent as is commonly believed," scored 17 points by only allowing deductions to be itemized at the lowest tax rate of 15 percent. He also scored 14 points for savings in health care -- 12 by lowering payments to doctors and hospitals and 2 by imposing a cap on spending for the acutely ill.
The rest of his points came from removing the Social Security wage base cap for employers (5), taxing Social Security like a private pension (3), and taxing capital gains at death (2).
The game allows tax increases related to specific programs -- but not income taxes -- and makes no allowance for options that would alter general economic or demographic conditions.
Mr. Hodge, though lamenting the absence of such options as the use of vouchers for medical care that he said would introduce needed market discipline, reluctantly met the game's 100-point goal.
Among his choices were to means test Social Security (9 points), raise the Social Security retirement age to 70 (5), require currently exempt state and local employees to join the Social Security system (2), raise eligibility for Medicare to age 70 (11), reduce payments to health providers (14) and both change the way various programs are indexed and the calculation of the Consumer Price Index itself.
"Budget Shadows," designed for people with minimal familiarity with computers, runs on personal computers with Microsoft Windows, version 3.1 or later, and Lotus 1-2-3 for Windows, version 4.0 or later. It will not run on Macintosh computers. Copies can be downloaded from the Internet.
The telephone number of the commission, which disbands around the end of the year, is (202) 224-2300.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Is Proposing A Toll Freeze For a Year

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey proposed a 1995 budget yesterday that would keep tolls on Hudson River bridges and tunnels at $4 for at least one more year. But officials said an increase is possible in 1996.
Stanley Brezenoff, the executive director of the authority, said losses at the New York City bus terminals and on the PATH train line would cause a $100 million deficit in the 1996 budget. If other revenues remain flat, Mr. Brezenoff said he saw no way to close the 1996 shortfall without raising tolls or the PATH fare, which is now $1. 
 "There is no place that I can see at this point where we can identify a large spike in revenue," Mr. Brezenoff said. "I don't see at this juncture how we close this gap in 1996."
The tolls on the Hudson River crossings were last raised in 1991, when they went from $3 to $4. An increase of a dollar would produce about $120 million more in revenue for the authority, officials said.
The $2.7 billion budget for 1995 calls for a slight increase in spending of $78 million to keep up with inflation. The authority's board of commissioners will vote on the plan on Dec. 15. The governors of New York and New Jersey can veto the plan.
"From our perspective, this is another hold-the-line budget," Mr. Brezenoff said. "Spending is at the same level as it was last year."
Still, officials said they had cut about $46 million worth of programs and delayed some capital projects to keep spending at a relative standstill. Mr. Brezenoff said the agency would continue cutting its staff next year by about 1 percent to bring the payroll under 9,000 jobs for the first time since 1986.
The budget contains $1.6 billion in operating money, a rise of about $100 million above this year's plan. That increase is fueled by inflation and by the reopening of the New York Vista Hotel, damaged in the February 1993 terrorist bombing of the World Trade Center. The authority owns both the center and the hotel. The spending plan also contains $669 million for capital projects at New York and New Jersey airports, port facilities, river crossings and the World Trade Center.
Among the $360 million in improvements to airports will be an extension to runways at La Guardia Airport and the completion of a monorail linking terminals and parking lots at Newark Airport. The agency also will continue planning rail links to all three area airports.
The authority also plans to spend $70 million renovating public spaces in the World Trade Center and $45 million on improvements to the marine terminals in Port Newark.
Despite spending cuts in recent years, officials said the agency has continued to lose about $265 million a year on its rapid transit trains and its two bus terminals, at 42d Street and the George Washington Bridge. So far, those losses have been offset by profits at the airports and from tolls.
Mr. Brezenoff said that if the authority seeks a toll increase in 1996, it would also seek to raise the fare on PATH trains.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A building products distributor opens doors with acquisitions.

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado 

 BODY:
A CONSOLIDATION in the building products distribution industry has brought Cameron Ashley Inc. to the attention of Wall Street professionals.
The company, based in Dallas, has quietly become prominent in the distribution of residential building materials like roofing, millwork, vinyl siding and insulation. In Florida, its Ashley division is the dominant distributor of pool and patio construction wares. 
 The company went public in March at $12 a share. Its shares closed yesterday at $16 in Nasdaq trading, down 25 cents for the day and $2.75 below their high on Nov. 4. Nearly 70 percent of the stock is still held by management and directors.
Although new home construction is expected to ease because of higher mortgage rates, about 55 percent of Cameron Ashley's business is in the remodeling market. When interest rates rise, this market tends to grow because homeowners who are unable to sell often elect to build additions or to renovate.
But it is a growth-through-acquisition strategy that has raised investor interest in Cameron Ashley. In the last three years, the company has bought 12 new distributors for its system and plans to acquire 2 others. The company now has 67 distributors, with a goal of 160 by 1997.
"Cameron Ashley is well on the way to becoming a national factor in the building products distribution business through an aggressive acquisition program," said John H. Diffendal, an analyst with J. C. Bradford & Company in Nashville, the co-manager of Cameron Ashley's public offering.
A confluence of factors is spurring consolidation in the highly fragmented, $22 billion industry. Many proprietors of mom-and-pop shops, who already have trouble competing with the purchasing power of larger companies, want to sell their operations before their retirement. In addition, sophisticated management-information systems have given Cameron Ashley and other companies a big lead in on-line communication with customers, analysts say.
"The smaller distributors typically do not have the capital or management to develop these systems," said Wyatt A. Williams Jr., an analyst with William MacKay Jordan & Company of Houston. "Cameron Ashley has been very successful in acquiring smaller distributors and almost immediately improving their profit margins."
The company's most substantial acquisition has been the building products division of the Bird Corporation. The deal, completed in August, gave Cameron Ashley 12 locations in four new markets: Arizona, Kentucky, New England and the New York metropolitan area.
"I'd rather acquire a company in a new location, than in a market where we already have a presence," said Ronald R. Ross, chairman of Cameron Ashley.
Because of the company's broad product line, the new distributors could have an advantage in attracting new accounts. Cameron Ashley's customers include building developers, professional contractors, lumber yard proprietors and some home center chains.
Volume purchasing, firm pricing policies and tight cost controls have enabled the company to achieve operating profit margins of about 6 percent in an industry where the range is usually 3 to 4.9 percent, Mr. Ross said.
Analysts expect the company to earn about $1.30 a share in its fiscal year ended Oct. 31, compared with $1.13 the previous year. They expect $1.66 a share next year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Some Strength Against the Mark and Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened against most currencies yesterday, jumping to a 13-week high against the German mark.
Steady in London trading, the dollar climbed against the mark and yen, some currency dealers said, after the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of manufacturing activity rose to 61.2 percent in November from 59.7 percent in October, the highest since 1984. 
 The manufacturing index is the latest in a series of reports indicating that the American economy is growing fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to control inflation, dealers said. While rising rates have hurt the American bond market, dragging down the dollar for most of the year, higher rates, in theory, make dollar-deposits more attractive.
"People are much more optimistic about the dollar right now," said Tom Benfer, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal in New York. "Psychology is changing."
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5768 marks, the highest level since Sept. 2, before settling at 1.5735 marks, up from 1.5710 marks on Wednesday. The dollar rose to a seven-week high of 99.48 yen, before settling at 99.35 yen, up from 98.97 yen on Wednesday.
Since Nov. 15, when the Fed raised short-term interest rates for the sixth time this year, positive economic reports have helped the dollar rather than hurt it, dealers and analysts said.
"People didn't expect the dollar to keep going up like this," said Joe Francomano, a trader at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. "We'll probably see more fireworks tomorrow." The Labor Department is scheduled to release the November employment report today.
But signs that Germany's economy is accelerating kept the dollar from rising further against the mark yesterday, traders said. Industrial production in western Germany rose a bigger-than-expected 1.6 percent in October, prompting speculation that the Bundesbank will soon raise rates to control inflation.
Andrew Hodge, a vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert, said the Bundesbank was poised to raise rates. "That would be a negative for the dollar," he said. The German discount rate on direct loans to banks is 4.5 percent, compared with 4.75 percent in the United States.

HEADLINE: New Reports Show Strong Economy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Incomes are growing so rapidly that free-spending Americans are not keeping up -- and therefore the savings rate is improving -- new figures showed today.
A flurry of reports pointed to a remarkably strong economy with "no dark clouds," said Eugene Sherman, an economist for M. A. Schapiro & Company, a Wall Street firm. 
 The fourth quarter got off to a quick start, according to data released today by the Commerce Department. On Wednesday, the Government reported that the economy expanded in the third quarter more rapidly than estimated earlier.
Income surged 1.4 percent in October, the biggest jump in eight months and the ninth straight gain, the department said. With millions more Americans employed and being paid more, analysts expect a strong Christmas shopping season.
Spurred by a big gain in average hourly earnings and bonus pay for auto workers, the income advance easily outpaced consumer spending -- which rose seven-tenths of a percent in October for its strongest showing since a rise of nine-tenths of a percent in August.
"These are very strong numbers," Mr. Sherman, the economist, said. "It's a very positive figure on the income side, so much so that people saved more money."
"Everything is doing remarkably well," he added. "There aren't any dark clouds."
These were among several reports showing a stronger economy:
*Construction spending rose nine-tenths of a percent in October, the second straight gain, although the advance was limited to nonresidential and government spending. The Commerce Department said residential construction spending, nearly half of construction outlays, fell.
*The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing the first time for state unemployment benefits dropped last week to the lowest level in two months.
*American manufacturing surged in November to its strongest level in 10 years; it was the 15th straight month of growth, according to a widely followed survey by the National Association of Purchasing Managers.
The Commerce Department said the income gain was the largest since it rose 1.7 percent in February.
Disposable income -- income after taxes -- also climbed 1.4 percent in October.
Americans' savings rate -- savings as a percentage of disposable income -- rose to 4.7 percent in October, from 4.1 percent in the previous month. The new rate is the highest since it reached 5 percent in April 1993.
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's gross domestic product, was up for the sixth straight month.
On Wednesday, the Government reported that the economy expanded at a 3.9 percent annual rate in the third quarter despite rising interest rates.
"The current quarter is off to a brisk start, and fourth-quarter consumer spending could rise at around a 3.5 percent rate," Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch & Company said. But, he added, "that pace is unsustainable."
Private wages and salaries, the most closely watched component of income, increased at an annual rate of $45.6 billion in October, more than double a rise of $18.5 billion in September.
The Commerce Department said incomes in October were also lifted by a big jump in subsidy payments to farm owners. But even excluding that factor and the bonus pay in the auto industry, personal income rose 1 percent.
The income and spending figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, disposable incomes rose 1.3 percent in October, while spending was up six-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: ON PRO BASKETBALL;
Knicks' Future Is Now, As in Now or Never

BYLINE: By Harvey Araton 

 BODY:
Pat Riley gets a front-row look tonight at the players who are bound to beat his brains in, should he stick around a few more years with his future Eastern Conference also-rans.
That's the Knicks, in Orlando tonight to continue what's looking more and more like a mighty struggle to keep their dubious future from spilling into their promising present, from giving Riley good reasons to wonder if signing a rich contract extension is such a smart idea. 
 The Magic was supposed to be another year away from intruding on the Knicks' Atlantic Division dominance, from being any kind of playoff threat, especially since they've never won a playoff game.
Tell that to their last eight opponents, all thoroughly whipped by the frightening Shaquille O'Neal and the emerging Penny Hardaway. Tell that to them.
"Our guys want the Knicks to know they've arrived," said Brad Ceisler, the Westchester-based Orlando scout who spent part of last summer devising ways to help O'Neal diversify his offensive game.
"What's happening now is that Penny is taking over games when he sees that Shaq isn't able to," Ceisler said. "The night we were in Boston last week, Shaq got hit in the throat. The next night, in Milwaukee, he can't really get into it. Penny was unbelievable, 35 points, triple-double. He just took over, and that's something he never did last year."
The Magic won 50 games last season, when O'Neal was more interested in bending rims than baby hooks, when Hardaway was chronologically a college junior, when Horace Grant was a rebounding Bull. Without a minute's contribution from the 3-point specialist Dennis Scott, Orlando has vaulted to the top of the Atlantic, and this is only the start.
It is the making of the dynasty at Disney World. The New Wilt. The Next Magic. Grant and Nick Anderson in their primes. Three future Golden State first-round draft picks Chris Webber won't be devaluing, now that he's come east to bang with Shaq.
Like Danny Manning in Phoenix, Brian Shaw took less money to play in Orlando because, inside the arena and out, the forecast is sunny. With the exception of league-leading scoring aspirants, who wouldn't want to play there?
Even the comparative economics are bleak for the Knicks, who will be stuck making huge payoffs to aging stars while Orlando becomes pro basketball's Magic Kingdom. Scott's $3.5 million dollar salary cap slot will open up next year. The Magic will target some classy small forward, maybe even Manning, to complete what will be a Boston/Los Angeles 1980's vintage starting five.
Forget, for the moment, Webber in Washington, Alonzo Mourning in Charlotte, Grant Hill in Detroit and the swarm of aggressive Pacers in Indiana. Riley and the Knicks have to know that soon, if not now, all Eastern roads to the finals will go through Orlando.
Maybe that's what Riley is thinking as negotiations to extend his contract beyond next season drag on. Maybe he senses the smart thing for him would be to see if the Knicks can complete his perfect painful progression, eke out that elusive Patrick Ewing-era title. Then Riley would be king of New York, in position to demand the skyline, live off his championship as the team retools.
If the Knicks don't win, maybe he decides he's done all he can here, and looks for something more compatible for the Winner Within.
"I haven't gotten anything like that in the many conversations I've had with him," said Dave Checketts, the new high chieftain of Madison Square Garden. "I don't sense he's delaying anything. I think it's been more a matter of timing than anything else."
Riley has tunnel vision, an obsessive nature once the games begin. Even he, though, must occasionally sneak a peek at the Knicks' big picture. Ewing shooting jump shots on achy knees and Charles Oakley grimmacing on misshapen feet may be temporary setbacks this season, but that's what's in store the next few years.
The Knicks have no young superstars, discounting infrequent ascensions to that level by John Starks. They haven't had an impact draft pick since Ewing in 1985. They have traded a batch of future first-rounders. No one knows if their new owners will throw money around the way the previous one did. And, of course, the N.B.A. has helped shroud their immediate future by turning thumbs down on their hands-on defense.
A few weeks ago, Riley said he couldn't fathom why people doubted his team had another good championship run left in it, or if it could even take another season of him.
"I agree that after seven or eight years, sometimes a team has had enough and it's time for a coach to move on," he said. "But not after three."
Unless, of course, it senses that opportunity has passed it by, that the new bully on the block is much too strong. Then it becomes easier to ask: What's the point?
The Knicks are thus advised to come to play tonight. This is much more than one game in December.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Coach Pat Riley has been around for the rise of the Knicks. But will he be on the sideline for the fall? (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Players' Union Is Discouraged After Meeting Adjourns

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 1

 BODY:
As the National Hockey League season slid one day closer to cancellation, league and union negotiators broke off talks early tonight after nearly eight hours of bargaining that offered no palpable hope for the future, except that the two sides would resume meeting Friday.
In fact, on Day 62 of the lockout, when the main action was expected to be the league listening to a counterproposal from the union on such issues as a rookie salary cap, arbitration and free agency, the N.H.L. came up with new wrinkles to its own plan that were not bound to please the players. 
 According to people familiar with the talks, union officials were discouraged when the talks broke up. The people said that the N.H.L. proposal today called for an entry-level salary structure for rookies that would pay a first-round draft choice no more than $700,000 a season, a second-rounder no more than $400,000 and a third-round draft choice no more than $250,000.
In addition, the league said it wanted to raise the age of free agency eligibility from 28 to 31. Part of new concept was supposed to have been unfettered free agency at 28.
"We exchanged proposals and we'll have working sessions tonight and there may be communication between both sides," said Bob Goodenow, the union's executive director.
"We met for eight hours, we're not going to characterize any progress," said Arthur J. Pincus, the N.H.L.'s director of public relations.
Both the league and the union are trying to salvage the remainder of the season, with a 50- or 60- game schedule before the playoffs.
The lockout has caused 20 layoffs in league offices in New York, Toronto and Montreal, which went into effect today, as did a 10 percent salary cut for all remaining employees, including Commissioner Gary Bettman.
For now, the league's proposal to create a "luxury tax," a penalty that would be levied on high team payrolls, is not on the table.
Players have called the tax a deal-breaker, and a salary cap in disguise.
One person familiar with the management position said the tax may be unnecessary if agreement on the other three issues produces the "drag," or slowing of salary inflation, so desired by owners, who claim that revenues are not keeping pace with soaring payrolls.

HEADLINE: Senators Cool to Pact With Koreans

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Democratic and Republican Senators alike gave a frosty reception today to the Administration's agreement with North Korea to halt its nuclear program, saying it had made too many concessions and might encourage other nations to engage in nuclear blackmail.
With some Republicans threatening to block the agreement, several members of the Senate Subcommittee on East Asia told the Administration's chief negotiator on the accord that it was unwise to promise North Korea $4 billion in new atomic reactors when North Korea would not permit inspections of some of its nuclear sites for five more years. 
 Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who is in line to head the subcommittee next year, faulted the agreement because it does not require immediate inspections of all the sites where officials say there is evidence that North Korea has extracted plutonium to make nuclear weapons. This, he said, allowed the North to shirk its obligations under international treaties.
"Why didn't we insist that they come clean?" Mr. Murkowski asked. He and several other senators said this delay left the world vulnerable to the one or two nuclear weapons that some Administration officials say North Korea has developed.
Robert L. Gallucci, who worked out the accord in October, defended the agreement, saying it rightly focuses on denying North Korea the ability to make nuclear weapons in the future.
But Charles S. Robb, the Virginia Democrat who heads the subcommittee now, said "we will be well down the road of providing economic incentives" to the North "before we have the ability to confirm anything about North Korea's true nuclear weapons capability."
Mr. Robb called the hearing because the agreement was reached in late October, after Congress had recessed for the election campaign.
In return for North Korea's promise to freeze and eventually dismantle its nuclear weapons program, the United States has agreed to arrange for several nations, led by South Korea and Japan, to build two light-water reactors for the North. It is harder to extract weapons-grade plutonium from such reactors than from North Korea's current ones.
Senator Larry Pressler, a South Dakota Republican, said the agreement might encourage nations like Iran to copy North Korea and bar nuclear inspections unless the West agrees to furnish new power plants.
Mr. Gallucci said the accord calls for North Korea to do far more than it is obligated to under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. He said the North had promised to dismantle its reactors, to freeze construction of two large reactors, not to reprocess 8,000 spent fuel rods and not to refuel an existing reactor.
He said the freeze on its nuclear program would prevent it from building new reactors that could have produced enough plutonium to construct 30 bombs a year.
The International Atomic Energy Agency, he noted, has inspectors in North Korea who said this week that the North was complying.
Mr. Gallucci emphasized that to press North Korea to make good on its promises, it would not receive the nuclear components to start its light-water reactors until it allowed all the nuclear inspections sought by the Atomic Energy Agency.
"The agreement provides that before they get anything of significance, they have to come clean," he said. North Korea has refused to allow international inspectors to visit two waste sites that are believed to contain evidence that it has extracted weapons-grade plutonium.
Although Mr. Murkowski has threatened in the past to try to overturn the accord, he said today that he was not calling for canceling it. But Mr. Pressler said he was not convinced by Mr. Gallucci and that he would vote to overturn the agreement if given a chance.
Some Republican leaders have suggested that it would be politically dangerous to scuttle the agreement because that could revive tensions on the Korean Peninsula and the Republicans might be blamed for creating a new crisis.
Under the accord, the United States is to provide 50,000 tons of heavy oil to North Korea over the next three months as part of a long-term program to provide it with fuel until the new reactors are built. Mr. Gallucci said the Department of Defense would use $5.5 million in discretionary funds to buy this oil and would not need Congressional approval to do so.
But he acknowledged that the Department of Energy would probably have to go to Congress to reappropriate $5 million to $10 million to handle the North's spent fuel rods. That could become a vehicle for the Republicans to block the accord.

HEADLINE: Plan for Toxic Dump Off Coney Island Defies Common Sense

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Nov. 25 news article on the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's plan to dump toxic harbor dredgings in shallow ocean water only one-half mile off Coney Island beaches: The agency appears callous and unconcerned about the public's health and safety in defending its plan. An official says, "We must not allow a dispute over trace levels of contaminants to jeopardize a project of great significance to the Port of New York and New Jersey." 
 While harbors must be dredged to remove accumulated sediments in order for shipping and commerce to take place, disposal of dredgings contaminated with dioxins and polychlorinated biphenyls should not create economic or environmental problems elsewhere.
The dioxins originated from past industrial discharges in Newark and Kingston, N.Y., and are continually being washed downriver into Newark Bay and into New York Harbor. The PCB's emanated from discharges in Schenectady.
Near-shore dumping of harbor dredgings over several decades six miles from beaches at Sandy Hook, N.J., induced the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to close that site to dredgings containing highly toxic substances because of significant ecological degradation. It defies logic and common sense now to consider dumping toxic dredgings even closer to public beaches where swimming and fishing would be more severely affected.
The Port Authority says that local residents will not be directly exposed to dioxins, considered the most toxic chemicals ever manufactured, because the dredgings will be capped with sand. However, dioxins and PCB's could escape the Coney Island dump site as they did from the Sandy Hook site, both during and after the dumping operations, before the cap could be deposited about four weeks later.
The presence of dioxins and PCB's in fish taken from the Sandy Hook area may be further explained by dissolved toxins migrating through the permeable sand cap at the present dump site, which could also occur at the Coney Island location.
Since extraction of toxins or land disposal of the contaminated dredgings is not feasible because of the large volumes involved (up to seven million tons annually), the most suitable alternative is offshore dumping into the Hudson Submarine Canyon, 150 miles from land, where the ocean is two miles deep. This enormous underwater gorge is larger than the Grand Canyon and extends from the edge of the Continental Shelf for almost 1,000 miles out into the three-mile-deep ocean abyss.
Toxic harbor dredgings dumped 150 miles out in 10,000-foot depths where wave action is in effect nonexistent would tend to migrate downslope and farther from land rather than upslope to the shelf, where most commercial fishing is done.
 
JULIAN KANE
Professor of Geology
Hofstra University
Hempstead, L.I., Nov. 25, 1994

HEADLINE: Chemical Banking to Cut 3,700 Jobs

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
To cut costs, Chemical Banking Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate 3,700 jobs, or 9 percent of its work force, underscoring the continuing profit pressures on big banks in New York and elsewhere in the country.
Chemical's action, one of the biggest single employment cutbacks in New York in recent years, highlights the large loss of jobs among money center banks, including Citicorp and Chase Manhattan. In metropolitan New York, fewer people now are employed by banks than on Wall Street. And further steady reductions in banking employment are still expected to come. 
 While most Wall Street analysts reacted favorably to Chemical's announcement, its stock fell 87.5 cents a share, to $40.75, in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
About 2,000 of the jobs to be lost are in New York City and its suburbs, with most of the layoffs likely to hit bankers dealing with corporations and people working in the bank's computer operations areas.
The bank also plans to sell its banking operations in New Jersey that are outside the New York metropolitan area.
Around the country, most banks are having trouble generating new sources of profits. But New York banks, in particular, are saddled by bad loans for real estate and to developing countries and cannot afford to move into other areas. Banks are turning more and more to cost cutting because investment banks, mutual funds and other new competitors are siphoning off an increasing share of the nation's savings and lending. And experts say there are still too many banks in this country.
Some fast-growing regional banks, such as Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C., and the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis, have been able to expand by ruthlessly eliminating duplicate costs in a buying spree of banks and nonbanking companies alike.
In 1992, Chemical merged with its Park Avenue neighbor, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, eliminating 6,000 jobs and closing 130 branches.
But those cutbacks were not enough to keep costs from starting to rise again. Meanwhile, Chemical's revenues have fallen recently because of the slowdown in trading for bonds and currencies, resulting in a 9 percent drop this year in the value of the bank's stock.
"In 1994, the whole industry has had somewhat of a revenue challenge," said Walter Shipley, the bank's chairman, "which has been exacerbated by those of us who had large capital markets and trading activities."
Wall Street analysts said Chemical had little alternative to the drastic staff cuts.
"There is a lot of pain associated with this," said Thomas Hanley, a bank stock analyst with CS First Boston. "You've got to give them credit," he added. "They sat back, studied their problem and they bit the bullet."
In addition to the job cuts, Chemical plans to save money by negotiating lower prices with its suppliers and by selling some operations and bad real estate loans. The bank will take a charge against earnings of $260 million in the fourth quarter to cover the costs of severance pay and closing facilities.
In total, Chemical said its new plan would reduce its annual costs by $440 million in 1996. Given inflation and increased spending in some area, it expects its total expenses to remain constant at about $5.2 billion, while revenues are now expected to grow under its old target of 6 percent.
Chemical, which bought Horizon Bankcorp of East Brunswick, N.J., in 1989, making it the fifth largest in that state with 140 branches and $5 billion in assets, never acquired enough heft to compete effectively. With New Jersey banks drawing attractive offers, Chemical decided it would rather sell its operation in the southern part of the state than invest to expand there. Similarly, Chemical said it would try to sell its 40 percent state in the CIT Group, a commercial finance company. It sold a 60 percent stake in 1989 to Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan. And Chemical has designated $950 million in bad real estate loans to be sold quickly.
"This signals a new thinking that they are willing to dispose of businesses that don't meet strategic or financial return goals," said Ronald I. Mandle, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
The single largest source of savings will be $125 million, from negotiating better prices from everything the bank buys from computers to paper clips. The bank will also eliminate duplicate computer systems.
Despite the cutbacks, Chemical plans to increase spending by $180 million a year in certain areas, including credit cards, mortgage lending, private banking and the trading of securities and derivatives.
The 3,700 jobs will be eliminated over the next year, partly through attrition and partly through layoffs. In its branches, many of the layoffs will hit clerical workers. In corporate lending, by contrast, the bank will eliminate the jobs of many of its professional banking executives.
Another 10 to 15 branches will be closed next year as part of a program to cut 50 branches that was announced last spring.
Other banks are undergoing similar squeezes. Since 1990, Chase has reduced its employment to 34,000 from 42,000, but it will add another 4,200 jobs because of recent acquisitions. The bank just announced an early retirement program for which 2,600 people are eligible.
Citicorp has also cut jobs since 1990, reducing its staff in the United States to 39,000 from 52,000.
Elsewhere in the country, several regional banks have instituted even more drastic staff cutbacks. Fleet Financial Group in Rhode Island recently said it would eliminate 25 percent of its jobs. And First Interstate, in Los Angeles, said it would cut employment by 11 percent.
Chemical said it wanted to reduce its expenses to 57 percent of its revenues. This widely watched indicator in banking, known as the efficiency ratio, is currently about 61 percent at Chemical, compared to about 50 percent for the best managed banks.
To further increase the company's stock price, giving it leeway to expand into other operations, Chemical said it would buy back up to 6 million of its shares on top of a recent buyback of 10 million shares. Analysts said that if Chemical were able to sell CIT and the New Jersey operations, it would buy even more shares.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 3, 1994, Saturday

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about plans by the Chemical Banking Corporation to eliminate 3,700 jobs misstated the company's stock price. The stock closed on Thursday at $36.625, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Finance Arm To Take Over Italy's Tessile

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The creditor banks that took control last year of one of Italy's largest, most innovative and most indebted textile groups, Gruppo Finanziario Tessile S.p.A., agreed today to make the company available to Gemina S.p.A., a finance and investment group.
The announcement by Gemina ends a drawn-out feud for control of the Turin-based textile company, which almost alone brought the Italian designer-fashion craze to the United States in the 1980's. For Italy's textile industry, shaken by recession and disclosures of financial misdealings, the transaction represented a successful effort to keep the Tessile group in Italian hands. 
 Gemina, whose holdings include the sportswear maker Fila, said it had reached an agreement to acquire a majority of Tessile's shares. Details of the agreement will be worked out with creditor institutions led by Mediobanca of Milan.
Bankers who confirmed some details said that Gemina, under a complex arrangement, would pay at least $103 million for a controlling stake in Tessile, depending on which of the creditors chose to remain as stockholders. They said that Gemina also agreed to purchase $37.5 million of fresh shares in Tessile, increasing its capital base. For their part, the banks were said to have agreed to restructure roughly $275 million of Tessile's short-term debt.
Led by the Rivetti family, the Tessile group saw its American sales balloon to $304 million in 1989 from $7 million in 1980, with licensed designer names like Armani and Valentino. But by 1993, the growth had stopped and the company was saddled with $250 million in debt. A consortium of banks took over, reducing the Rivetti family's role.
The decision to offer the Tessile group to Gemina, which is controlled by an Italian building contractor, Giampiero Pesenti, came as a surprise to some because it passed over an attractive counteroffer by CVC Capital Partners, a unit of Citibank. CVC had proposed to absorb most of the bank liabilities. But this proved to be a negative feature, given the desire of some credit institutions to retain links with the Tessile group.

HEADLINE: Luther Foster Jr., 81, Dies; Leader of Tuskegee Institute

BYLINE: By J. MICHAEL ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Luther H. Foster Jr., who headed Tuskegee Institute for 28 years, died on Sunday at the South Fulton County Medical Center in East Point, Ga., while on his way home from vacation. He was 81 and lived in Alexandria, Va.
The cause was a heart attack, said his daughter, Adrienne Foster Williams of Iselin, N.J. 
 Dr. Foster was president of Tuskegee, a 113-year-old historically black college in Tuskegee, Ala., from 1953 to 1981, a tenure that included the civil rights and antiwar movements. Tuskegee's current president, Dr. Benjamin F. Payton, said his predecessor's "quiet but firm" hand had been a stabilizing influence on the campus during those tumultuous years. During that time, the institute grew to more than 3,500 students from about 2,000. In 1985, it was renamed Tuskegee University.
After retiring, Dr. Foster devoted his time to working with educational and other organizations. At the time of his death, he was chairman of the Academy for Educational Development, a Washington nonprofit organization that promotes educational programs in more than 80 American communities and 100 countries. He was a board member and former president of the United Negro College Fund and was a director of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies.
Dr. Foster was born on the campus of St. Paul's College in Lawrenceville, Va., where his father was an administrator. He earned undergraduate degrees from Virginia State College in 1932 and from what is now Hampton University in 1934. He received a master's degree in business administration from Harvard University in 1936 and a master's degree from the University of Chicago in 1941 and and a Ph.D. in 1951.
He joined Tuskegee as business manager in 1941, and in 1953 he became its fourth president.
In addition to his daughter, he is survived by his wife of 53 years, Vera Chandler Foster; his mother, Daisy P., of Petersburg, Va.; a son, L. Hilton, of Washington; two sisters, Virginia Hendrick of Petersburg and Mary Allen Burleigh of Clarksburg, W. Va., and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Now, for the Fruits of Freer Trade

 BODY:
The trade treaty's surprisingly easy approval in the Senate -- 76 to 24 -- is testimony to the good that Congress can do when its leaders stop squabbling and start legislating. Freer trade, by steering workers into high-paying exports jobs, could add as much as $1,700 to the typical family's income over the next decade. That gain was at risk until Senator Bob Dole, the next majority leader, took responsibility for bringing wavering Republicans in line behind President Clinton's legislation.
The House also approved the agreement by a large margin. Now that the political drama is over, Americans can look forward to reaping the benefits. They are not hard to locate. 
 Workers and exporters in the pharmaceutical, computer software, book and movie industries win big because the agreement will prevent trading partners from pirating intellectual property. Exports of agricultural products will rise as Western Europe and Japan lower quotas and tariffs. America will sell a lot more construction and medical equipment as its largest trading partners eliminate tariffs on these products. The jobs to be had in many of these export sectors are among the highest-paying in the economy.
U.S. consumers also win. The price of farm goods -- including sugar and dairy products -- will eventually tumble. So too will the price of children's clothes and consumer electronics. The important point here is that many of the goods that will enter the country at reduced or zero tariffs, like toys and furniture, account for a sizable part of the budgets of low-income families. The trade treaty will act like a tax cut stacked in favor of the poor.
Unfortunately, it will also cause disruptions -- though there will be surprisingly few because the U.S. made so few concessions. Textile and apparel workers in the South are most vulnerable to losing their jobs in the face of increased imports of sweaters and the like from parts of Asia and other developing countries.
Even here, though, the changes will be phased in slowly. If the Federal Reserve Board manages to keep the economy humming along near full employment, the prospect that job losers can find work at comparable pay will remain bright. Still, some will suffer; it is thus imperative that the Republican-led Congress not trim Mr. Clinton's proposals to upgrade retraining assistance to displaced workers.
Constructive bipartisan negotiation broke the trade logjam. It is to be hoped that the episode foreshadows fruitful compromise on other keys to robust growth -- health care, welfare reform, worker training and education.
