HEADLINE: The G.O.P. Contract Is Too Timid

BYLINE: By Paul Craig Roberts; Paul Craig Roberts, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in 1981-82, is a fellow of the Cato Institute.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Liberals and conservatives alike regard the Republicans' "Contract With America" as a bold venture, though liberals complain it goes too far. In truth, it is a timid measure that even if carried out will leave the U.S. a handicapped player in the global capitalism of the 21st century.
Make no mistake: a capitalist revolution is sweeping the world. Communist central planning is no longer throttling the production and productivity of 1.2 billion Chinese people. Development planning is no longer stifling Latin America. 
 Latin America has a potential market twice the size of the U.S., and China four times as large. We know that these new players on the world scene are serious when the Chinese Communist Party uses its power to create stock markets and protect entrepreneurs, and when former socialist states like Chile and Argentina privatize social security and national health. In 25 years, according to World Bank projections, China will have the largest economy, with the U.S. a distant second.
In a global economy, capital will flow to areas where returns are highest and away from those where it is savaged by taxes, regulations and tort liabilities. So the U.S. has no choice but to stop building welfare and entitlement dependencies it can no longer afford, and to return to the small-government era that permitted wave after wave of penniless immigrants to be absorbed into the economic life of a thriving nation.
The Republican contract takes steps in the right direction, but they are a baby's faltering steps, not the strides of confident leaders. Even Republicans are too imbued with guilt over inequality to permit our country to really compete on the world stage.
If the U.S., a welfare state grown soft and fat, is to survive in a competitive post-socialist world, it must privatize Social Security and health care, abolish welfare and cease to tax human and physical capital. Above all, we must return to equality before the law and terminate the emerging legal system -- a throwback to feudal times -- in which people have differing rights based on their status, in this case race and sex.
Privatizing Social Security is an urgent matter of survival. The viability of a pay-as-you-go system that transfers money from one generation to another depends on a high ratio of workers to retirees. This is no longer the case in the U.S., and the system is already reneging on its promises by taxing Social Security benefits.
Privatization will be financially challenging. Large amounts of general revenue would have to be used to support those in retirement and near-retirement while younger workers are moved into I.R.A.'s and similar plans. These revenues can be made available only by curtailing functions of government that are inconsistent with a self-reliant people.
As Western Europe has discovered, a welfare-dependent population is a disadvantage in global competition. Only disciplined people with high saving rates to cushion themselves against uncertainties will successfully make the adjustment to the new world order. The economic cost of a government-supplied safety net is exorbitant, and its perverse incentives are socially debilitating. A new social safety net will have to be constructed, using a combination of lower taxes, expanded I.R.A.'s, medical savings accounts and charitable activities.
Nor can the U.S. afford the antipathy to meritocracy that suffuses its economic and social policies. Capitalism depends on the recognition and reward of merit, but American law now demands advancement by race and gender quota. A country bent on equality of result at all costs has no prospect of success in the emerging world capitalist order.
When multiculturalists demand the demolition of traditional academic standards even for the training of scientists, one must wonder whether the 21st century will find the U.S. engaged in the dismantling of modernity while our competitors become modern states. The cost of such a disastrous course cannot be offset by any economic policy.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Bond Swaps Ease Pain Of Big Declines in 1994

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
SEASON'S greetings from the I. R. S.! That's what the tax break known as a bond swap amounts to -- a year-end gift of otherwise-Federal dollars. But if investors tie the ribbons on this nice present wrong, they may wind up saying "Uh oh" instead of "Ho ho."
 Bond owners can surely use a Santa this year. "There are plenty of losses out there -- many of 20 percent or more," said Jim Lebenthal, a New York bond trader. 
 But as bonds fall, bond swaps have more appeal. "I expect to do four, five times as many swaps this year as usual," said Peter Quick, president of Quick & Reilly Group.
 The boom arises because large bond losses mean large tax savings. In swaps, investors sell losing bonds or bond funds to offset capital gains or ordinary income, and then buy replacements with the proceeds.
 Imagine an investor who, last January, bought $25,000 of New York City general obligation bonds, yielding 5.625 percent and maturing in 2012. Today, those bonds would bring $20,000. At the 28 percent maximum Federal tax rate on long-term capital gains, that $5,000 loss means a tax savings of $1,400. And at 39.6 percent -- the top rate on ordinary income -- the savings are a jolly $1,980. Add state and local taxes and the gains are even more.
 Moreover, with Republicans ascendant, lower tax rates are in the air. That means tax savings could be smaller in future years. The $5,000 loss that saved $1,400 at a 28 percent tax rate is worth just $1,000 at 20 percent. Thus, some say, swap while the swapping is good.
 What is the price of these nice tax breaks? Befuddlement over complex rules, for one. An investor taxed at 39.6 percent on ordinary income would want to apply any losses to that income first; each $1 saved from taxes is 39.6 cents in the pocket. But while short-term capital losses -- on property held a year or less -- can be written off this way, long-term losses must first be applied to long-term gains. Even at the top rate of 28 percent on those gains, a tax break buys just 28 cents for each $1.
 Then comes the $3,000 rule. After applying capital losses to capital gains, taxpayers may use leftover losses to reduce ordinary income -- but only up to $3,000. The rest must be banked for the future.
 Still, tax breaks bring good tidings. By saving $1,400 in taxes, the New York bond investor shrank his 20 percent decline to 14.4 percent.
 What about the other half of the swap -- the replacement bond? In theory, the new bond should mimic the old one in maturity, coupon rate, credit rating and tax traits. "That way, you can create a loss and not alter your portfolio," said Thomas Ochsenschlager of Grant Thornton.
 But swapping like-for-like assumes a well-tended portfolio. Many portfolios are weedy, though, with too many high-yield bonds or low credit quality. For them, "use swaps to rebalance the portfolio and buy what makes sense now," said Lyle K. Benson, a Baltimore planner.
 James F. Lynch, who edits the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory newsletter in New York, recommends that swappers lengthen maturities. "The yield on 15-year bonds is much greater than in January," he explained. Conversely, Mr. Benson said, "rising short rates may mean investors should put more in C.D.'s and T-bills."
 As for income, rising rates will help swappers maintain their yields. To replace the $25,000 of New York bonds sold for $20,000, Mr. Lebenthal suggested $20,000 of another New York City issue, yielding 7.52 percent and due in 2019. Despite the smaller face value, the new bonds yield $1,450 in tax-free income yearly, while the old ones paid $1,405.
 But swaps do have flaws. For one, they seal a loss. "If Grandpa holds those $25,000 in bonds until maturity, he'll get $5,000 more than if he sells now," Mr. Lebenthal said.
 And watch fees. Because bond fees are not flagged as stock commissions are, "many investors don't realize they pay fees on bond deals," Mr. Benson said. True, a 1 percent fee may be small if the swapped bond lost 20 percent. But if $25,000 in bonds lost 5 percent and the fee was 2 percent, at the 39.6 percent rate an investor would pay $475 to save $495 in taxes. Fund fees must also be factored into swaps.
 A final danger is the "wash sale" rule: If investors sell at a loss and buy substantially identical securities 30 days before or after the sale, the I.R.S. will disallow the tax gain.
 The rule -- which deters investors from selling securities they like just for tax losses -- is easily applied to stocks. Equities from the same company are substantially identical.
 But "wash sales are vague in bonds," Mr. Lebenthal said.
 The variety of practices prove it. "I've read that two elements must be different," Mr. Lebenthal said, like the maturity and the coupon rate. At Coopers & Lybrand, Vincent Vaccaro, a partner, said, "We say if it isn't exactly the same bond issue, the rule isn't violated." Other advisers have still other rules of thumb.
 But, in truth, the Government pays little attention. "I've never heard of the I.R.S. pursuing this," Mr. Benson said. Investors can also skirt the rule by sitting out 60 days, though at some market risk. Nor does the rule apply if, for portfolio reasons, they buy a different bond than they sold.

HEADLINE: THE 104th CONGRESS: NEW LEADERS;
Senate G.O.P. Elevates Dole But Ousts Ally From 2d Spot

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Senate Republicans re-elected Bob Dole as their leader today and then undercut him by dumping his assistant leader, Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming.
They replaced Mr. Simpson with the more confrontational Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, who had campaigned hard on his connections to Newt Gingrich, who will soon become Speaker of the House. 
 Mr. Lott was strongly supported by Senator Phil Gramm, the Texan who is expected to compete with Mr. Dole for the 1996 Presidential nomination. But he insisted today that Presidential politics had not played a part in the race, and said he would be Mr. Dole's completely loyal subordinate. Mr. Dole was elected without opposition.
While the Republicans were, like their voters across the nation, sounding a theme of change, the Democrats sent a less certain message.
They chose as their new minority leader Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, a cautious, low-key protege of the departing leader, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine. But Mr. Daschle said today that he represented "real change."
Mr. Daschle, a die-hard battler for President Clinton's health care legislation this year, defeated Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, a late entrant whose backers argued that he was the combative sort the party needed to confront both the Republicans and, at times, the President.
Mr. Daschle insisted at a news conference that he planned to lead Senate Democrats down their own path. "To the extent that we can, we want very much to work with the White House," he said. "We will not be led by them; we will not view ourselves as an extension of them."
While Mr. Daschle was striving to portray himself as an independent agent, Mr. Lott was taking the opposite tack. "I'll be working with and for Bob Dole," even if Mr. Dole goes off to run for President, he said in reply to a question. "There won't be a new agenda," he continued. "There won't be a separate agenda. It will be our agenda, his agenda. He will be the leader."
Later he returned to the same point on his own initiative, protesting: "I'm going to ride shotgun for the leader. I want to help him. I want to protect him. I want to do his bidding on behalf of our conference. And sometimes, I'll take some slings and arrows and spears, if necessary, for the leader."
His victory was a surprise to Mr. Dole and Mr. Simpson, who had both told friends on Thursday they had firm commitments for Mr. Simpson from 30 Senators, when 27 were needed for victory. Mr. Simpson had held the position for a decade, working closely with Mr. Dole, who campaigned for his re-election.
But Mr. Lott, too, said he had more promises than the 27 votes he received in the secret balloting. He quoted Mr. Daschle, a former colleague in the House, as saying of any campaign for a Senate leadership post, "It's kind of like trying to put bullfrogs in a wheelbarrow."
Each contested race was decided by a single vote, and there were no major ideological differences in either contest, though in each contest the younger man won and had more open support from newer Senators. Mr. Lott, 53, and Mr. Simpson, 63, are both quite conservative, though Mr. Simpson favors abortion rights and Mr. Lott does not. Mr. Daschle, 46, and Mr. Dodd, 50, are both fairly liberal.
The results seemed to set the stage for a harder edge to party relations in the Senate than has existed between Mr. Dole and Mr. Mitchell for eight years, and to push Mr. Dole toward being more aggressive.
But even though he does not have the history of good relations with Mr. Daschle that he enjoyed with Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Dole visited the Democratic caucus to assure members that he planned to deal as fairly with them as Mr. Mitchell had with him.
Then Mr. Dole, who is 71, told the Democrats that he planned to keep the Senate in session in January, a month when it usually does not do anything after formally convening in the first week. Mr. Gingrich has already announced that the House will start legislating the day the new Congress convenes, on Jan. 4.
The Republican race ended with smiles, and two joint news conferences involving Mr. Simpson and Mr. Lott. Mr. Simpson came before the television cameras to say, "I'm going to break a little protocol to speak first." Referring to Mr. Lott,he said, "I pledged him my total support in whatever role he would ask me to do."
He said he personally would now concentrate on immigration legislation, which will come out of a Judiciary subcommittee that he will head, because "this is a huge bipartisan issue, and we either do it right, or else it will be tainted with racism and bigotry, and we can't allow that to happen."
The lanky Wyoming Senator said he had been reassured by the Mississippian that he, too, did not believe in "saliva tests" of Republican purity.
Mr. Lott, who had campaigned hard for the job and contended that he would bring a fresh energy to it, said he would be seeking Mr. Simpson's advice and was "honored by his support." And he added "There is no saliva test."
Asked why he thought he had won, he stressed his ties to the House, where he had risen to deputy minority leader before running for the Senate in 1988. He said, "I do have a personal friendship with them that I hope will be a constructive thing in making sure they understand we have a job to do over here, too."
The Senate Republicans' task would be harder, he said, because in the House the majority party controls the Rules Committee, and if "you control the rules, you control the world." But in the Senate, he said, "there's only one rule, unanimous consent, and maybe exhaustion."
The Democratic race appeared to end with less geniality. Mr. Dodd did not join in Mr. Daschle's news conference after the South Dakotan's 24-to-23 victory. Mr. Daschle said, "I'll be asking Senator Dodd for his counsel and help very often," and called him "my good and longtime friend." But it was clear the race had strained the friendship.
In the caucus, Mr. Daschle's backers urged his election because they said he stood for change. Mr. Dodd's supporters stressed both his experience and combativeness.
Mr. Daschle had campaigned to succeed Mr. Mitchell ever since the Maine Democrat decided in March not to run again. Before the Nov. 8 election, he was in a close contest with Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, whom Mr. Dodd was supporting. When Mr. Sasser was defeated for re-election, several of his supporters urged Mr. Dodd to step forward, and he did, but in the end Mr. Daschle's lead was too much to overcome, though votes were switching back and forth as late as Thursday.
The assistant Democratic leader will be Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, who was re-elected to the post without opposition.
Mr. Daschle promised that as Democratic leader he would try to work with Republicans to avoid gridlock. But he said, "We stand ready to offer vigorous opposition to extreme proposals that threaten economic security or our nation's economic future. We will fight against proposals that are mean-spirited." He said he hoped "our mutual goals are the prosperity and security of working people."
He cautioned, "This is not the time or the place to be talking specifically about our agenda." But he cited the same sorts of economic concerns that House Democrats have been concentrating on lately, saying "America's families need a thriving economy to produce the job security that is the heart of personal security."
Senator Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland was elected secretary of the caucus, the highest leadership position a Democratic woman has held.
Although Mr. Dodd was not there, Mr. Daschle surrounded himself with a leadership group that except for Mr. Ford, a Senator since 1974, included no one who had been in the Senate for more than 10 years.
Mr. Daschle, whom Mr. Mitchell put in charge of the Democratic Policy Committee, said that position would go to Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, one of his allies in this contest and another battle for health care legislation.
He appointed Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana to the position of chief deputy whip, a job Mr. Breaux had held in the outgoing Congress.
What had been the Democratic Steering Committee, a body whose main role has been to recommend senators for committee positions, was renamed as the Steering Coordination Committee, and Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts was named to head it.
Senator Byron Dorgan of North Dakota, entering his third year in the Senate, was named assistant floor leader.
Mr. Daschle said he would ask the caucus to create a committee, on technology and communications, and said he would name Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia, a close friend and ally on health care, to head it.
But while the Senate Democrats were announcing new positions and committees, Senate Republicans announced a plan to eliminate entirely the 200-person Office of Technology Assessment, which helps members understand technical issues, and to cut the $450 million budget of the General Accounting Office, an investigative agency, by at least 25 percent.
They also announced a plan to reduce Senate committee staffs by 15 percent, to 815 members from 955. Almost all of those to go would be Democratic aides.

HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE FELL AGAIN LAST MONTH TO A 4-YEAR LOW

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Surpassing nearly all expectations, the job market posted exceptionally strong gains in November as payrolls swelled by 350,000 and the unemployment rate fell to a four-year low of 5.6 percent, the Government reported today.
The improvement in the economy embraced broad sectors of business and nearly all population groups. Indeed, the growth last month was so vigorous in the face of persistent efforts by the Federal Reserve to slow the economy to a more sustainable pace that analysts now say another rise in short-term interest rates is all but certain. They predict that a rate increase could come possibly before the end of the month but is more likely at the end of January. 
 Several times earlier this year, evidence of a strong economy, like that in today's job report from the Labor Department, has spooked the inflation-sensitive bond market. Bond investors tend to fear that vigorous growth will lead to inflation, which would erode the value of their fixed-income investments.
But such fears were not in evidence today. Instead, long-term rates fell back below 8 percent, and the dollar rose in international currency markets to finish above 100 Japanese yen, apparently because investors now anticipate strong early action to resist inflation by a more vigilant Federal Reserve. The stock market also rallied, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 44.75 at 3,745.62. [Pages 39 and 40.]
The economy also looked remarkably well balanced. Relishing the latest of a string of strong recent reports, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said the economy was in a "Goldilocks expansion" -- not hot enough to ignite inflation, yet remarkably resistant to the Federal Reserve's attempt to cool it down.
"We have not witnessed in this country in a generation the same combination of low inflation and job creation," Mr. Reich said in a telephone interview.
For those fearing inflation, analysts said, one of the most reassuring elements of today's report was that average hourly earnings declined by 2 cents, after an October surge that was initially put at 8 cents and now revised to 7 cents. By far the biggest portion of business costs are accounted for by wages, and inflation is not likely to become worrisome unless wages rise significantly.
Despite the robust conditions reported today, there are some signs pointing to a slackening of economic growth next year. Interest-rate increases, six so far this year, may finally be starting to pinch. After the holidays, consumers may also pull back on the borrowing spree that has helped sustain the vigorous expansion.
Indeed, the Commerce Department reported today that its index of leading, or predictive, indicators edged down in October, the third essentially flat reading in the last four months.
The decline in the index, although a minimal one-tenth of 1 percent, was the first negative move since July 1993. September's reading, initially reported as unchanged, was revised to show a gain of one-tenth of a percent.
Still another report today found that orders to the nation's factories fell four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the first decline in three months.
But it was the buoyant job data for November, the first broad-gauged tabulation of economic performance for the month, that commanded most attention. Laurence H. Meyer, an economic consultant in St. Louis, said the unemployment report showed that economic activity had become so "steamy" that he decided to raise his forecast of fourth-quarter growth by about a percentage point, to an annual pace between 4 and 4.5 percent.
On Wednesday, the Government raised its estimate for the third-quarter growth rate to 3.9 percent from 3.4 percent, well above the roughly 2.5 percent increase many economists think is about the most that can be sustained without driving up inflation.
"Today's employment report," Mr. Meyer advised his clients in a report, "dramatically increases the probability that the Fed will move again to raise rates before the end of the year." He previously anticipated that the central bank would wait until its policy meeting at the end of January to make it more expensive for banks to borrow short-term funds.
The economy has defied expectations all through 1994, proving to be surprisingly strong. Analysts now attribute the vigorous performance this year, at least in part, to the delayed effects from the low interest rates of 1992 and 1993. Those rate declines were engineered by the Federal Reserve to kick-start the economy out of an extended period of so-called jobless recovery that followed the recession of the early 1990's.
Interest rates were so low in 1993 that homeowners went on a mortgage-refinancing binge, which added billions of dollars in spending power to American households. Federal Reserve officials and other analysts now express surprise that consumer spending has been so strong amid relatively stagnant growth in incomes.
Booming capital investment by business has been a second major source of economic strength. But the substitution of machines for labor did not prevent employers from adding 350,000 workers to their payrolls last month, about 100,000 more than most analysts had expected.
One of the biggest contributors to the increase was a jump of 71,000 in construction industry jobs, aided by mild weather in much of the country that extended the building season and by the return of some workers in the Southeast who had been idled during prolonged October rains.
There were 51,000 more factory jobs last month, on top of a gain of 42,000 in September. That powerful two-month surge lifted factory jobs to a level more than 250,000 above their September 1993 low.
Some analysts, including David B. Bostian Jr., a New York consultant, contended that the demise of the Clinton Administration's health care program was also a significant incentive to hiring. Many employers had feared that the program would raise their costs for workers' health care benefits. Once that concern was lifted, he said, "a lot of people started putting on workers they'd been thinking about hiring for a year or more."
The length of the average workweek in the private sector declined last month, the job report also showed, while the length of the factory week and hours of factory overtime were unchanged at recent very high levels.
The Labor Department's survey of households echoed the payroll numbers; 372,000 new jobs were created, and only 100,000 more people joined the work force, which cut the unemployment rate by two-tenths of a point. At 5.6 percent, the jobless rate has fallen half a point since August and is at its lowest level since August 1990.
The jobless rate for teen-agers dropped two points, to 15.3 percent, last month, while the rate for blacks and Hispanic workers each fell nearly a point to 10.5 percent and 8.6 percent, respectively.
Geographically, the biggest decline was in the Midwest, already enjoying the lowest jobless rate of any region. In that area, the November improvement was four-tenths of a point, to 4.6. The unemployment rate in the Northeast edged down to 6.1 from 6.2, while in the South it eased to 5.5 from 5.7. The West was unchanged at 6.7 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Backed Candidate for Trade Post Is Trailing

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 2

 BODY:
One day after winning Congressional approval of a vast global trade accord, the Clinton Administration appears to be losing the first power struggle in the new world trade order.
At issue is who will head the soon-to-be-created World Trade Organization, the agency that is to handle trade disputes and replace the existing Geneva-based bureaucracy of GATT, or the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. 
 The United States has vigorously supported Carlos Salinas de Gotari, the Mexican President who left office on Thursday. Mr. Salinas is seen as a champion of free trade, having led Mexico into the North American Free Trade Agreement, and he is by far the most prestigious candidate for the job.
But he is running a distant second. The European Union, led by Germany and France, is backing an Italian diplomat and trade expert, Renato Ruggiero, who served as the Italian Minister of Foreign Trade from 1987 through 1991 and is well known in European trade circles.
A surprisingly strong third is Kim Chul Su, the South Korean Trade Minister, who has the support of Japan and most Asian countries.
The issue is important because many experts say the World Trade Organization will emerge over time as the most important international economic agency, eclipsing the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in importance, as it carries out the far-reaching changes in trade agreed to under GATT.
According to officials in the GATT building on the shores of Lake Geneva, Mr. Ruggiero has more than 50 percent of the votes of the 123 member nations. And pressure has built over the last week for the United States to persuade Mr. Salinas to withdraw in favor of Mr. Ruggiero.
"Fair is fair," said a European diplomat involved in the closed-door negotiations. "We have high esteem for Mr. Salinas and Mr. Kim, but Mr. Ruggiero has more than half the votes, and a consensus should form around him. It is only appropriate that Mr. Salinas and Mr. Kim withdraw."
In Washington, President Clinton today threw his weight behind Mr. Salinas, saying the former Mexican President would bring to the helm of World Trade Organization "a wealth of experience and important insights from the perspective of a developing country."
Administration officials said they recognized that Mr. Salinas faced an uphill fight. But they said Mr. Clinton had decided to issue the unusual endorsement because he believed that Mr. Salinas would bring with him the kind of political influence the new organization will need.
At minimum, the officials said, the endorsement would put Mr. Clinton in common cause with the Latin American leaders with whom he will meet next week in Miami at the Summit of the Americas.
Officials of GATT would like to resolve the dispute by Thursday, when the members meet to approve the startup of the World Trade Organization so that on Jan. 1 the agency will begin with a new director general, replacing Peter Sutherland, who was the managing director of GATT.
But so far, GATT diplomats say, none of the three sides is budging.
Many insiders say they cannot remember when the normally collegial body of bureaucrats has been as deeply divided, and they fear a long, messy internal debate.
What they hope at all costs to avoid is a potentially divisive public vote. GATT officials pride themselves on working by consensus.
For those who have criticized the World Trade Organization and its authority to rule unilaterally on trade disputes, the leadership struggle may confirm their worst fears.
Most of Mr. Ruggiero's votes come not from the major nations in Europe, but from the smaller African, Caribbean and Pacific countries that are either former European colonies or major trading partners with the European Union. Since each member has one vote, major powers like the United States and Japan have no more voting power than many tiny nations.
But the current debate is not really between large and small countries; it is predominantly between Europe and the United States, and underscores a growing economic rivalry. Europe has been slow to create new trade links outside its borders, as the United States has with Mexico. And many European governments were shaken last month by the prospect -- though admittedly distant -- that the United States would form a giant free trading bloc with the Pacific basin countries.
To be sure, both the Europeans and Americans have strong arguments for their candidates. Mr. Salinas's supporters say his presence would lift the stature of the agency and insure an audience with other world leaders at critical times.
But that is just what many in Geneva do not want. In addition to a fear that it would concentrate too much power in the hands of the Americans, anti-Salinas sentiment stems from a belief that a low-profile diplomat could accomplish more in the agency than one of Mr. Salinas's stature.
"Ambassadors fear Salinas would be forever going over their heads direct to the heads of states and not working through the existing process," a diplomat said. "This is a relatively informal agency. He wouldn't have the security, the entourage and the kind of office he is used to in the presidential palace in Mexico. What does Sutherland have, a couple of secretaries and an assistant or two? This is a very collegial body, not one of great show."
Since the organization is not about to bring the matter to a public vote, quiet canvassing is being done by Hungary's delegate, Andreas Szepesi, hoping that once one candidate builds a commanding lead, the two others will graciously withdraw.
Though Mr. Szepesi refuses to give interviews, he is making his findings known.
Despite the strong support for Mr. Ruggiero, who is 64, he lacks the backing of the United States, considered essential.
But Mr. Ruggiero is at the same time a friend of the United States, having pushed hard for European governments to support the Strategic Defense Initiative during the Reagan Administration. He has held senior diplomatic posts in Moscow and Washington.
"I think I am in the best position," Mr. Ruggiero said in a telephone interview. "But I need the U.S. support. Certainly without U.S. support, you cannot win."
But it is hard to see the United States so quickly abandoning the 46-year-old Mr. Salinas, who has many years ahead of him in international politics and not that many obvious places to serve.
"Salinas was the Aztec emperor for six years, and he is terribly afraid of suddenly becoming a nonentity and disappearing," said a Latin American official who supports him. "He's got to find some way to stay afloat."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
Job growth accelerated in November. The Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate fell to a four-year low of 5.6 percent. The report showed a well-balanced economy enjoying robust growth. [Page 1.] Job growth in the New York region, however, lagged behind the nation. [48.] 

Many agencies and municipalities that borrowed to participate in the loss-plagued investment fund in Orange County, Calif., may not be able to make withdrawals to pay off their notes without facing heavy losses or risking a run. Separately, S.& P. said it might lower the debt rating of Orange County. [39.]
 
Markets
 
Treasury bond prices surged as investors became convinced that that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again sooner than expected. Short-term issues were weaker. [39.]
Stocks staged a surprisingly strong rally following the jobs report. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 4.38 points. [40.]
The dollar advanced against the yen and the mark, helped by a Japanese trade report and the United States jobs report. [49.]
Energy prices fell sharply after 28 Pennsylvania counties were allowed to pull out of a program using a cleaner gasoline. [49.]
 
Companies
 
General Motors reached an unprecedented settlement with the Government that will permit up to six million pickup trucks that the Transportation Secretary had called potentially lethal to stay on the road without any modification. [1.]
USAir is adding two new steps to its pre-flight refueling procedures to insure that no plane takes off without enough fuel.[1.]
The New York Times Company regained significant control over electronic rights to the contents of The New York Times in a deal with the British-Dutch publishing giant Reed Elsevier. [39.]
Browning-Ferris said it had won Attwoods of Britain in a $615 million hostile takeover, overcoming a last-minute bid. [41.]
The owner of Saks and Gucci bought Prime Equipment, a construction equipment rental company, for $300 million. [41.]
The pricing practices of appliance makers, including Whirlpool, Maytag and Raytheon, are being investigated by the Justice Department. Another maker, G.E., declined to comment. [41.]
A top Federated executive was named to head Bradlees. [41.]
 
International
 
A battle over who will head the World Trade Organization, which will soon be created as a result of the world trade accord known as GATT, is so far running against the United States. [3.]
Former East German chemical plants are being restored by the Government in an effort to save jobs and integrate the industry into the market economy. Dow Chemical plans to buy a majority stake in the Buna chemical complex in what would be the largest privatization of a former East German enterprise. [39.]
Can former Soviet bureaucrats become entrepreneurs? Eight-five Russians wanted to find out, spending a month as interns at small- and medium-sized businesses in 11 American cities. [39.]
 
Your Money
 
With possible tax changes ahead next year, now is the time for a review aimed at minimizing the tax bill due in April. [36.]
Bond swaps have more appeal as bond prices fall. In swaps, investors sell losing bonds or bond funds to offset capital gains or ordinary income, and buy replacements with the proceeds. [36.]
A way to defer capital gains taxes involves borrowing additional shares from a broker and selling them immediately.[36.]

HEADLINE: THE 104th CONGRESS: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Hints Of a Tax Cut As He Meets G.O.P. Chiefs

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
As he met for the first time with the new Republican Congressional leaders, President Clinton said today that he would not rule out working with them on a tax cut for the middle class, but he vowed to oppose any proposal that would "explode the deficit" or repeal a ban on assault weapons.
"I hope and believe we can cooperate with the new Congress," Mr. Clinton said, speaking via satellite to delegates at a National League of Cities meeting in Minneapolis. "But cooperation from me cannot mean abandoning principle, abandoning the hard work we have already accomplished together in our fight to restore the economy, our fight against crime, our fight to give this country back to the hard-working people who play by the rules." 
 The remarks about those who play by the rules precisely echoed Mr. Clinton's language in his 1992 Presidential campaign, when he promised a middle-class tax cut. After taking office, he dropped the idea in favor of reducing the deficit.
The President spoke just hours before meeting with Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who will become the majority leader in January, and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who will become Speaker of the House.
After an hourlong session in the Oval Office, both lawmakers emerged in late afternoon praising the meeting. Mr. Gingrich said he had expressed particular optimism to Mr. Clinton that they could work to pass a measure allowing the President to veto individual items in spending bills, make the laws that apply to private citizens and companies apply to Congress as well and pass a law barring the Federal Government from imposing programs on states and local governments without providing money to cover the costs.
Mr. Dole mentioned telecommunications regulation and the environmental legislation as other potential areas of cooperation. Both men said they did not discuss taxes, changes in welfare, health care, details of foreign policy or several other questions.
"We didn't cover everything," Mr. Dole said about tax issues. "We didn't get down to the t's." But, he added, "I think the President understands that we're going to hit the ground running."
Republicans have proposed a $500-a-child tax credit, cuts in capital gains taxes and other tax-relief ideas, but Mr. Clinton has made no mention of what specific ideas he might favor, all the while repeatedly mentioning a tax cut as something he would like to do.
Mr. Clinton's renewed claim to championing the interests of working Americans came a day after his proposal to increase military spending by $25 billion over the next six years. Both matters were part of his effort to stake out the possibilities -- and the limits -- of his cooperation with a Congress itching to challenge him, and to get out ahead of it on what he considers issues of bedrock political concern.
In his satellite talk to the city officials, Mr. Clinton told a Dallas Councilman who had expressed concern about the effect of tax cuts on Federal aid: "While I favor a middle-class tax cut, and I don't rule out working with the Republican Congress on some of their ideas, my standard will be, Will it help increase income for the middle class? Will it promote jobs and growth? And can we pay for it?"
At an economic briefing before Mr. Clinton spoke this morning, Robert E. Rubin, the President's senior economic policy adviser, was asked about prospects for specific cuts. Mr. Rubin drew laughter by saying, "Let me respond in large measure, perhaps, by not responding."
"We are absolutely going to be fiscally responsible," Mr. Rubin continued, "and the judgments that we have to make on the various questions that we need to deal with have not been made yet."
Mr. Clinton, who has struggled since his Presidential campaign to dispel an impression that he is sometimes too ready to compromise, also took pains today to point out the issues on which he would not bend.
"The assault weapons ban that you helped to win stands between the citizens you and I must protect and the gangs and thugs that would terrorize them," he told the city officials gathered in Minneapolis. "I will do all in my power to keep the next Congress from doing anything that will jeopardize the safety of our people. And I truly hope the new Congress understands how important these things are to the American people and to their elected representatives at the grass-roots level."
The President also met today with newly chosen Democratic leaders in both houses, including Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, who will be the Senate minority leader, and Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, who will be the House minority whip.
Afterward, reporters asked Mr. Daschle a variety of questions about his agenda with the White House, to which Mr. Daschle repeatedly replied that it was too early to say.
Mr. Bonior, on the other hand, lost no time in insisting that in contrast to the Republicans, the Democrats "will be taking care of working people" and supporting a tax cut to benefit "middle Americans."
Asked Mr. Clinton's reaction to that idea, Mr. Bonior said, "He was nodding his head in agreement."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton with Republican leaders in the next Congress, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, left, and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, before entering the Oval Office yesterday for a meeting. The Republicans emerged expressing optimism about being able to cooperate with Mr. Clinton. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: THE 104th CONGRESS: BALANCE SHEET;
Analysis Increases the Cost Of Clinton's Welfare Plan

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The capital received another tutorial on the high cost of overhauling the welfare system today when the Congressional Budget Office announced that President Clinton's proposal would cost nearly $5 billion more during the next five years than he had allotted.
With the Clinton plan likely to be a dead letter in a Republican-led Congress, the Congressional Budget Office estimate was less important for what it said about the plan than for what it said about welfare overhaul in general: putting welfare recipients to work will cost money, probably more than the public realizes. 
 Like President Clinton, the Republican leaders want to put time limits on benefits and then enroll recipients in work programs. Although the public tends to think of mandatory work programs as money-saving measures, they are much more expensive, at least in the short run, than simply mailing welfare checks. That is because the Government must hire supervisors, subsidize wages and provide mothers with child care before the women can go to work.
The numbers buried in the estimate from the budget office drive home the point. The average mother with two children receives $4,440 a year in welfare benefits. But the budget office estimated that enrolling her in a work program would raise the figure to $11,440 a year, adding $4,000 for wage subsidies and supervisors' salaries, and $3,000 for child care.
Under Republican plans, those costs could go even higher. That is because the Republicans want to phase in their plans faster and require longer work hours, which would bring higher child-care costs. The Republican work plans have generally acknowledged the expenses involved but pledged to offset them with cuts of tens of billions of dollars in other anti-poverty programs.
Mr. Clinton's pledge to "end welfare as we know it" was among his most popular promises in the 1992 Presidential campaign. He said he would expand the training that welfare recipients received during their first two years, then enroll them in a work program if they remained unemployed.
But the President faced a series of embarrassments last spring as he tried to finance his plan. The Administration considered options that included taxing casinos and taxing food stamps. But news of the strategies leaked, and each met with a public outcry. Mr. Clinton ended up scaling back the plan, with less child care and a slower phase-in than some of his aides had wanted.
When Mr. Clinton presented his bill to Congress in June, he said that it would cost the Federal Government $9.3 billion over five years and that he had found an equal amount of cuts in the budget.
But the budget office, in reviewing the details, estimated that his plan would cost $11.8 billion and that the cuts would save only $6.9 billion. And while the Administration had said the plan would cost the states $1 billion, the budget office placed the figure at $2.6 billion.
The analysis by the budget office emphasized that estimating the costs of large-scale changes was an inexact science because no one knew how recipients would respond. Work programs might deter some women from seeking benefits; expanded training programs might attract others.
The difference in the spending estimates "should be considered small in view of the great uncertainty," the report said.
"You could end up with $7 billion or $14 billion, and both our estimates are in the middle," John Tapogna, an author of the report, said today in an interview.
A year of internal debate went into the drafting of the Clinton plan, but it has been overtaken by the Republican sweep of Congress. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the presumptive Speaker, has pledged to send a bill to the House floor in his first 100 days.
His policy guidebook, the "Contract With America" endorsed by many Republican candidates, calls for enrolling 1.5 million recipients in a work program by 1999, almost four times as many as the Clinton plan. But Mr. Gingrich is also seeking cuts in social programs that could total more than $50 billion.
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington advocacy group on issues that benefit the poor, has estimated that the Gingrich plan would remove from the rolls as many as five million of the nine million children now receiving benefits. Mr. Gingrich has proposed housing some of those children in orphanages.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rates Down Slightly In New York and New Jersey

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Unemployment in the New York region dropped only slightly in November, signaling that the recovery in the local area, already weaker than in most of the nation, may be losing steam.
"What is striking is the contrast between the brisk recovery nationally and what is going on in this region," said Samuel L. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The labor market here has shifted into neutral." 
 The jobless rate in New York City fell to 7.5 percent last month from 8.2 percent in October, but the improvement was accompanied by a decline in the number of New Yorkers looking for work. That means the city's improved unemployment rate masked large numbers of people who, because they had stopped seeking jobs, were not counted.
The rates for New York State and New Jersey were virtually unchanged in November, leaving both states with levels of unemployment that are higher than any of the nation's largest industrial states other than California and Florida.
In New York State, the November rate was 6.3 percent, compared with 6.5 percent in October. In New Jersey, the November rate was 6.6 percent, compared with 6.7 percent in October.
The Federal data for November, reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, covered only the 11 largest industrial states. For that reason, Connecticut was not included.
The rates in New York and New Jersey compared with rates in Michigan, North Carolina and Ohio that were less than 5 percent, and with rates below 6 percent in Illinois, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Texas.
Only California, where the rate was 7.7 percent, and Florida, where it stood at 6.8 percent, had higher unemployment in November than New York and New Jersey.
In New York City, where unemployment has been far higher than the nation for more than four years, the 7.5 percent rate in November was a clear improvement from the first nine months of the year, when it ranged from 8.4 percent to 10.8 percent.
But Mr. Ehrenhalt said the number of people in New York City's civilian labor force -- those employed or looking for work -- dropped sharply in November. The labor force fell last month by 55,000 workers, to 3,236,000, from 3,291,000 in October.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said last month's steep decline suggests that the local economy is weakening.

HEADLINE: Bonds Rally Despite Employment Figures

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds staged a powerful rally yesterday, despite a stronger-than-expected jobs report.
The Labor Department report showed continued robust growth in the economy, convincing investors that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again sooner than expected. 
 Earlier this year, the prospects of Fed inaction had unnerved the bond market, but investors now see the Fed on the offensive over inflation. On Nov. 15, the Fed sharply raised the two interest rates it controls, the sixth rate increase this year, heartening the market. Another increase in the next month would be welcomed as a preemptive strike against an acceleration of inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds.
"The likelihood of further Fed tightening at its meeting on Dec. 20 has certainly increased," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities.
The price of the 30-year bond jumped 1 5/32 , to 95 11/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell below the psychologically important level of 8 percent, to 7.91 percent from 8.01 percent on Thursday. The latest yield was the lowest in more than a month.
Bond prices were also bolstered by a stronger dollar and the covering of short sales by investors who had bet that the market would head lower yesterday and instead were sent scurrying to buy securities to limit their losses. In a short sale, investors sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices, pocketing the difference. But when prices rise, these investors must buy back the securities to limit their losses.
The dollar surged yesterday against the Japanese yen and the German mark, settling above 100 yen for the first time since Oct. 11. A stronger dollar is likely to draw foreign investors back into the market.
James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International, said the prices of short-term maturities came under pressure because of investors' concerns stemming from the $1.5 billion loss reported by Orange County, Calif. The county said the loss was largely a result of purchases of the highly volatile investments known as derivatives. Investors' fears "are that the county isn't the only municipality that has had substantial losses tied to investments in derivatives," Mr. Hale said.
Mr. Fine of Chase Securities said the improvement in bonds yesterday was a result of a number of factors, including short-covering because many investors had positioned themselves for a strong jobs report. The various factors increased expectations that the Fed would raise rates at the Dec. 20 meeting of its policy-making committee. Mr. Fine said he expected the Fed would raise short-term rates by 50 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Other data released yesterday included October factory orders, which showed a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent, pretty much in line with expectations because of the decline in new orders for durable goods reported last week. The durable-goods component was revised to show a 1 percent drop from 1.5 percent, while nondurable orders rose two-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: Waking an Old East German Giant

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SCHKOPAU, Germany

 BODY:
Building after building sits vacant. The rust is everywhere -- on miles of piping that run overhead, on stanchions supporting huge water tanks and on smokestacks reminiscent of the last century.
This mournful site a few miles west of Leipzig is the Buna chemical complex, once the heart of the East German state chemical industry and, more recently, all but destined for the scrap heap. 
 But the European subsidiary of the Dow Chemical Company is betting on the revival of the 1,250-acre plant and its antiquated technology, as Dow makes its boldest move yet into Europe.
Dow Deutschland is expected to pay several hundred million dollars for a three-quarters stake in Buna and two other nearby plants, while the giant Russian natural gas company Gazprom buys the rest. The German Government will bear the brunt of the restoration at Buna with a $2 billion investment that nonetheless could save only 3,000 jobs at the plant, which once employed 18,000. It now has 4,600 workers.
"When we're done, Buna will be possibly the most modern chemical complex in Europe," said its managing director, Bernhard H. Brummer, "There were many in the West who simply wanted to shut us down so they wouldn't have any new competition. But that's not going to happen. Buna will live."
Dow Deutschland is already the dominant American chemical company in Europe, challenging European chemical giants like Bayer, BASF and Hoechst.
If Dow acquires majority ownership in Buna and the two other plants -- a steam cracker in Bohlen for beginning the chemical refining process and a polyolefin producer in Leuna -- it will become the fourth-largest chemical company in Germany.
"The East German operation is, more than anything, a beachhead for exports to Poland, the Czech Republic, the Ukraine and the Baltics," said Elmar J. Deutsch, head of Dow's German subsidiary, in a recent interview with the German business weekly Wirtschaftswoche. Mr. Deutsch declined to be interviewed for this article.
Buna embodies many symbols. For the German Government struggling to integrate east and west, it is by far the largest bailout of a failed East German industry, and, if successfully sold to Dow Chemical, it will be the largest privatization of the 13,000 former East German companies. And for eastern Germans, it represents an assurance that despite the failure of Communism, their chemical industry will not disappear; indeed, it will eventually be able to compete in the next century.
But the decision to invest a vast amount of capital to save a few jobs is also a politically delicate one. Buna will be left with only one-sixth of its former work force. Still, the project is an attempt to salvage at least some jobs in an area where unemployment is running 30 percent and idled workers have little chance of finding new jobs.
Dow has signed a letter of intent with Treuhand Anstalt, the Government agency handling all eastern German privatizations, to analyze the value of the operations at Buna, Bohlen and Leuna. Dow proposes to buy up to 76 percent of the operations and plans to sign a final deal as soon as the end of the year.
Walking through the deteriorating complex here leaves one wondering why Dow would want to get involved. For decades, Buna made its chemicals from coal, an expensive, polluting process that is no longer used. Buna makes fewer than half the 2,500 products that it made five years ago, and many of those products are from synthetic rubber, which Dow does not yet make.
But Mr. Brummer says the chemicals that Buna makes are a good fit for Dow. By 2000, Buna will give Dow a more prominent position in Germany, the largest chemical market in Europe, with close ties to East European governments.
"Many of the managers here were trained or educated in Russia," said Mr. Brummer, who is a former senior executive in Dow's German unit. "They speak Russian. They still have many ties with important people running government and industry in East Europe. More than anything, they know the Russian soul and have a deeper understanding of the Eastern mind."
Buna's move into free-market hands will begin a new era for this complex, which was built by the prewar chemical giant I. G. Farben.
During World War II, Buna made tires for the German war machine. Oddly, Buna was not bombed by the Allies at the end of the war, as were many German chemical plants. Some company officials contend that the Allies did not destroy the plant because they wanted to benefit from its substantial strides in the development of synthetic rubber.
Under Communist rule, Buna provided for the needs of the East German market because the country had little access to Western chemicals and technology. Thus, it developed the coal-chemical technology. Despite the severe pollution that resulted, the technology was studied by other chemical companies in the 1970's after the shocks of the November 1973 Arab oil embargo.
Mr. Brummer notes that coal-chemical technology becomes cost effective once oil prices rise to $80 a barrel -- a long way from less than $18 a barrel at present. "And we know we have much more coal on the planet than oil," he said.
Mr. Brummer, who keeps a color poster of the former East German strong man Erich Honecker as a reminder of the company's past, acknowledges that it is not easy for a Western manager to run Buna.
"There is real resentment here that Westerners have come in and exploited the East Germans," Mr. Brummer said. "East Germans want to run their own destiny now." The tension will worsen because one-third of the 4,600 current employees have yet to be laid off.
Astrid Molder, a public relations employee, acknowledged that she often yearned for the company's bygone days, pollution and all.
"At least we all had jobs," she said. "We were more united. We knew we were suffering from the pollution, but we could suffer together.
"Now with so few jobs, we are fighting each other. I don't know if my job will be eliminated. Now we resent it when we see someone else keeping a job."

HEADLINE: In From the Cold, Ex-Agent Warms to Capitalism

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Nikolai Nazarov has information to offer American businesses interested in investing in Russia. After all, he spent 20 years as a K.G.B. agent assigned to monitor the activities of foreign businessmen there.
"My job was just getting the information," he said in a recent interview. "That is the only thing I was trained to do, the only thing I can do, the only thing I like to do." 
 Making entrepreneurs out of ex-Soviet bureaucrats can be a complicated business, as the case of Mr. Nazarov illustrates.
He is one of 85 Russian business people who have spent a month as interns at small- and medium-sized businesses in 11 American cities. The interns came to America as part of "Business for Russia," a program financed by the United States Information Agency and planned with the help of the Russian Government, which has brought 350 interns to work in the United States since 1993. The cost of the program is about $6,500 an intern, and 1,000 more Russian business people are scheduled to arrive in 1995.
Joseph Duffy, director of the U.S.I.A., said that the program would "allow young Russian entrepreneurs to experience first-hand Western business practices and to see how decisions are made."
 Richard Schreck, the director of international programs at the University of Maryland, was in charge of placing Mr. Nazarov and nine other interns staying in the Washington area with business and home-stay hosts.
"Each of them is put into a business," he said, "either the same business that they're in, or one step upstream or downstream. The intent is that the Russians should learn how it works to run a business in a market economic situation."
Mr. Nazarov, 38, who has the discreet manner of a polished diplomat, spent his five weeks gleaning trade secrets from Prudential Associates Inc., a private investigation firm in Rockville, Md., that provides services mostly for corporate clients. Similarly, Mr. Nazarov's operation in St. Petersburg, Nazarov & Son, provides investigation and consulting services for businesses.
He is clearly pleased about his match, almost as impressed with them as they are with him. For the last five weeks, he has worked and lived with Robert Miller, president of Prudential. Like Mr. Nazarov, Mr. Miller has previous intelligence experience; he is a former intelligence officer for the United States Army.
"The thing I was most interested in was to know the American way of marketing, beginning with targeting the client base and saying 'Hello,' and 'Happy Christmas' and all that kind of stuff," Mr. Nazarov said.
Networking is another concept foreign to the Russians. Every Friday, the interns met at the University of Maryland's University College campus to regroup and attend classes reinforcing what they learned at the office.
"We had somebody come talk to them about networking, which is something else that they're not experienced at in Russia," Dr. Schreck said. "There's much less of a community of trust among business people than here. But they're quite keen to do it."
In addition to developing marketing skills, Mr. Nazarov used his internship to recruit potential clients and investors. While working at Prudential Associates, he pitched his services to venture capitalists, printed business cards, and even incorporated Nazarov & Son as a Maryland business.
"It's a pity," Mr. Nazarov said, "but the Russian market for my services is extremely narrow. So one of the purposes in my coming here is not only to learn the ways" of marketing, "but to examine the American market for my services.
"I consider the enormous, untouched American market to be my target market for investors, American investors, into the Russian economy."
It looks as if it could be the beginning of a beautiful relationship. "I realized what an asset he was, and we've been talking about an ongoing business," said Herb Quinde, director of operations at Prudential Associates. "We spent several hours with a venture capitalist who said he had never considered a business deal that took longer than five minutes to drive to from his office. By the end of the meeting, he was asking Nikolai to pitch him on ventures in Russia."
Mr. Nazarov says he joined the K.G.B. when he was 16, "for the romance, of course." After becoming a senior officer in the analytical department in St. Petersburg, Mr. Nazarov resigned in 1991 when the Communists fell from power. Seeing no other alternative, he plunged head first into capitalism, opening Nazarov & Son. His son, Sergei, is only 10 years old, but Mr. Nazarov says his dream is to have his son join him in the business one day.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Strong Gains, Edging Above 100-Yen Level

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar surged against the Japanese yen yesterday, closing above 100 yen for the first time in seven weeks, in a rally that many analysts said signaled a long-awaited recovery.
The currency was bolstered yesterday by a Japanese trade report and the November employment data in the United States. The dollar also rose to a 13-week high against the German mark and was stronger against most other leading currencies. 
 "We're seeing a fundamental reappraisal of the dollar," said Robert Brusca, chief financial economist at the Nikko Securities Company International. "It's turned a pretty important corner."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 100.61 yen, from 99.35 yen on Thursday; yesterday's was the first New York quote above 100 yen since Oct. 11. The dollar rose to 1.5798 marks, from 1.5768 marks on Thursday. But dealers said trading centered on the yen, which weakened broadly.
The dollar rose in Asian dealings after the Japanese Government reported that the country's trade surplus fell sharply in October, the third consecutive monthly decline, while the economy grew at a 3.7 percent annual rate in the third quarter.
Those numbers suggested a reduction of the huge stockpiles of dollars that Japan earns by exporting goods to the United States; constant selling of dollars for yen by Japanese companies had helped to push the dollar to record lows. In addition, a strong Japanese economy should absorb more imports, which must be paid for in foreign currencies.
The dollar was further bolstered in European and American trading by a stronger-than-expected report on United States employment in November. The Labor Department said the economy created 350,000 jobs last month, pushing the unemployment rate to a four-year low of 5.6 percent.
Receding inflation fears and the higher returns offered on shorter-term United States investments compared with those in Europe and Japan are providing a powerful draw, particularly at a time when Tokyo stock prices seem to have peaked.
"There is a realization in the foreign exchange market of a shifting out of yen-denominated assets and into dollar assets," said Bob Near, a vice president of the Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Price of Crude Oil Plunges; Heating Fuel Drops Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil futures plunged to a seven-week low yesterday after 28 Pennsylvania counties backed away from using a new gasoline aimed at reducing air pollution.
The prospect of reduced demand for the cleaner-burning fuel led to a 6.8 percent drop in gasoline futures and a sharp decline in heating oil, which already is burdened by rising stocks because of the unusually warm autumn weather. 
 "It's just a total panic," said John O'Connell, an analyst for Refco Inc., a futures brokerage firm.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 1.94 points, to 227.71. Cotton futures extended Thursday's gains.
Light crude oil for January delivery plummeted 83 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $16.99 a barrel, the lowest settlement for near-term deliveries since Oct. 14.
January wholesale unleaded gasoline tumbled 3.69 cents, to 50.61 cents a gallon; January wholesale home heating oil slumped 1.73 cents, to 47.02 cents a gallon, and January natural gas fell 1.8 cents, to $1.635 for 1,000 cubic feet.
On Thursday, Gov. Robert Casey of Pennsylvania signed legislation relieving 28 counties of their voluntary agreement to require reformulated gasoline beginning Jan. 1. The counties are not among the 9 metropolitan areas and 40 other communities required to offer the cleaner-burning fuel under Federal or state regulations.
"What this does is eliminate any lingering concern that there might have been for any tightness in reformulated gasoline supplies," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist for Merrill Lynch.
He said traders were worried that the neighboring states of New Jersey and New York might also pull out of the program.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, silver futures dropped more than 4 percent to a 12-month low as rising interest rates fed fears of a stifling of the economy.
December silver fell 21.8 cents, to $4.689 an ounce, the lowest settlement for near-term deliveries since Dec. 2, 1993. December gold sank $3.10, to $375.50 an ounce.
Cotton futures rose sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange, the sixth consecutive day of gains driven by strong export demand. March deliveries rose 1.48 cents, to 82.84 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Time Is Right for a Year-End Tax Review

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Antithetical though it may be to the holiday spirit, a bit of attention to taxes in the final weeks of the year can pay off handsomely. The savings reaped may even cover all those gifts to loved ones.
 Congress has done little to change the tax rules this year, no doubt lulling some people into complacency. Yet nearly everyone can still do something to minimize the bill that comes due in April. 
 One of the most basic moves is to avoid a penalty by making sure quarterly payments and withholding by your employer are sufficient. For most people, that means paying at least 90 percent of your tax liability this year, or an amount equal to last year's bill. If you earned more than $150,000 last year, you have to pay 110 percent of last year's amount to be safe. Another good idea is to pay close attention to the break points where extra income vaults you into a higher bracket, the highest being 39.6 percent.
 To be sure, some of the most rewarding tactics rest on shaky political assumptions, such as whether the new Republican Congress and the Clinton Administration will produce the middle-class tax cut that both sides have said they want. A way to bet on this is to defer income until next year and to accelerate deductions this year, for a lower 1994 tax bill. That can be done by postponing a bonus or making an extra mortgage payment -- only one is permitted a year -- for the additional deduction.
 Anticipating that the bite on capital gains will be eased, taxpayers may want to postpone selling assets at a profit until next year, and to make sure the investments are held long enough to qualify for long-term tax treatment, meaning at least a year and a day. Some market devices can be used to protect gains from evaporating in the meantime (see related article). Another possibility is to structure a profitable sale, of, say, real estate, in installments, with the bulk of the proceeds paid in future years. That way, the gains would be taxed at what is expected to become a lower rate than the rate on the date of sale.
 The Republicans propose to cut the maximum rate on capital gains in half, to 14 percent. (It is possible, though, that individuals who now pay income tax at the top rate of 39.6 percent might pay more than 14 percent on capital gains to make the measure politically palatable.) Whether any change would be retroactive to Jan. 1, 1995, is, of course, unknown.
 Even if you are skeptical about such changes, you may still want to shift income and deductions where possible to keep money in your pocket and out of the Government's for an additional year. The reward is more significant than last year because you can earn higher interest rates on your money.
 Specialists caution, however, that making an early mortgage or state income tax payment to increase deductions makes people more vulnerable to the alternative minimum tax. Those who push themselves into alternative minimum tax territory could "undo the benefits of shifting," said Rick Bobrow, national director of tax services at Ernst & Young, the accounting firm.
 Apart from income shifting, certain maneuvers may help taxpayers in specific situations. If you are selling your home -- and expect to realize a loss -- you may want to delay the closing until next year in case the Republicans push through their proposal to make this loss deductible.
 Another money-saving but decidedly unromantic tactic is for two high-income earners, who would pay higher taxes as a married couple than as singles, to put off their wedding until 1995. This would avoid at least one year of the marriage penalty, which the Republicans propose to relieve.
 Low-income people can also be hit by this penalty. Two people earning $11,000 each who marry would no longer qualify for the earned-income tax credit, perhaps costing them thousands of dollars.
An area where there are some complicated changes in both this year's and next year's law involves charitable contributions. As always, anyone who wants to make a gift to charity and lacks the money can put it on a credit card this month and get a full deduction even if the bill is paid next year.
 And as before, if you want to make a gift of appreciated securities, be sure to donate the stocks, bonds or mutual fund shares instead of selling them and giving the cash that remains after taxes. This has the double-barreled advantage of yielding the charity more, since it pays no taxes, and giving you a deduction for the securities' full market value.
 Time is running out, though, if the recipient is to be a private or family foundation. After Dec. 31, gifts of securities to such groups will be deductible based only on the donor's cost, not on the appreciated value.
 For any gift valued at more than $250, you need a charity's written statement to get a deduction. You also need a statement for all gifts exceeding $75 that came with some benefit, like college football tickets or a dinner, and the statement must itemize the donation and the value of the item given in return.
 Another way to reduce taxes when disposing of assets that have climbed in value is to give them to a child -- or perhaps to an elderly parent -- in a low tax bracket. This person, who must be at least 14 to escape the "kiddie tax," could then sell the asset and pay capital gains taxes at a lower rate than you would. Anyone can give $10,000 to a person a year without worrying about the gift tax. So rather than cashing in company stock to pay a child's college tuition next year, a couple might give the child up to $20,000 in stock.
 Making gifts of company stock is a particularly appealing idea, since it generates a deduction and many people have too much of their worth tied up in a single asset anyway.
 At a less exalted level, donating a hard-to-sell car and promptly deducting its book value may make more sense than spending the time and money to advertise and show the car to potential buyers. Many well-known charities, including the Salvation Army, have programs to handle car donations.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bahrain Investment Group Acquires Prime Equipment

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
Investcorp, the Bahrain investment group that owns Saks Fifth Avenue and Gucci, said yesterday that it had bought the Prime Equipment Company, which rents construction equipment, for $300 million.
Prime, based in Houston, has 74 outlets that deal with contractors and refiners in 11 Sun Belt states. The company is the nation's second-largest equipment rental company behind Hertz and had rental revenue of $113 million in 1993, according to the Rental Equipment Register, a monthly trade publication. 
 Prime, which declined to disclose its sales, also generates some nonrental revenue from servicing leased or rented equipment.
Prime wants to expand in its current markets and add new products and services. Investcorp -- which acquired Prime from the United States arm of Artemis S.A., a French holding company -- said it would put up an unspecified amount of capital to accomplish this.
While best known for its acquisitions of Saks and Gucci, Investcorp, the New York holding company that consists primarily of Arab investors, has recently made more prosaic deals. In September, Investcorp bought a Boston supermarket chain, and in October 1993, it acquired a record retailer. Since its founding in 1982, Investcorp has made 52 investments with a value of $6.5 billion.
Robert V. Glaser, a member of Investcorp's management committee, said in a statement that his company was attracted to Prime because it held a strong position in a growth industry.
Thomas E. Bennett, Prime's president, will remain as chief executive and become a shareholder of Prime as a result of the deal. Mr. Bennett could not be reached for comment, and the size of his Prime holdings were not disclosed.
The equipment rental industry has undergone a resurgence as construction activity has bounced back from recession. Contractors rented less equipment when housing starts and other construction declined around the nation in the early 1990's. Prime saw its revenue drop 18 percent in 1991, to $200 million.
But now, suppliers of rental equipment and the rental outlets themselves "are having a hard time keeping up with demand," said Fred I. Anderson, a spokesman for the American Rental Association in Moline, Ill.
Contractors rely heavily on rental companies for specialized equipment or extra equipment for short periods. Prime's 30,000-piece fleet includes pumps, welders, air compressors and forklifts, but not heavy earth-moving equipment like bulldozers.
The revival in the rental equipment industry may be short-lived, however. New-home construction fell for the first time in four months in October as the housing industry began to suffer from rising interest rates.
Prime, founded in 1962, grew rapidly during the late 1980's through acquisitions of small, independent operators, Mr. Anderson said.
The industry is fragmented among 20,000 companies, only 6 of which generated more than $50 million in annual sales.
