HEADLINE: GARDENING;
Taking a Sharper Look at Lawn Care

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST 

 BODY:
IF the lawn has not had its dose of fertilizer this fall, there is no time to waste. The task should be done promptly. Tradition has it that lawn fertilizer should be spread by the end of November. But the recent spate of mild weather has fooled many gardeners.
Lawn-keeping researchers believe that one late fall application is all that the lawn should need for an entire year. They say that this sort of application economy goes a long way toward lawn health -- but also keeps excess fertilizer out of the water system since less is lost to the environment through runoff. 
 Hopefully homeowners have purchased their lawn fertilizer to date and have just not gotten around to applying it. Otherwise bags of lawn fertilizer may be hard to come by since most of the garden centers have put away garden products to make space for their holiday displays. (Some merchants might be able to haul fertilizer bags out of their storage sheds if they still have some in stock.)
The reason for the late fall application of lawn nutrients is to make the spring greening of grass plants a bigger success and to nourish the grass root system in early spring.
The fertilizer will be absorbed well at this time of year, but because the soil will be cold the nutrients will not break down as quickly. They will remain in position to nourish the roots and grass blades in spring.
Lawn mowers may be cleaned and covered in the back of the garage or toolshed now. But in case not, there is one more task for the lawn: a final mowing. The grass should winter through at a short length. A mowing height of one and one-half inches is about right. This will put the grass in good shape for the winter and encourage a sturdy push of green growth in early spring. The young blades will not have to mush through all that extra growth left over from fall. Also, there is less chance of snow mold developing on a closely clipped lawn.
Of course, the lawn should go into winter free of leaves and other debris. A final raking and cleanup is very worthwhile. Leaves left on the lawn at this time have a tendency to mat, especially after cold weather chills them down. They would adhere to the grass blades and cause more problems in spring.
Next spring if any bare patches occur or there is need for reseeding, be on the lookout for grass seed with endophytes.
These organisms are a form of fungus that repel many of the grass-blade insects like billbugs and sod webworms. This type of grass seed is relatively new and will be found in only a few types on the market, particularly perennial rye grasses and fescues.
Although some of the research is ongoing on the effectiveness of this systemic fungi, this new development in grass culture may prove to be highly worthwhile.
Another facet of lawn care is the trend toward less lawn and more plant diversity, especially those that resemble meadows and contain the old-fashioned close-cropped lawns with English daisies and chamomile.
A rather remarkable book has made its appearance that makes a strong case for rethinking the traditional lawn. "Redesigning the American Lawn, a Search for Environmental Harmony" was published by the Yale University Press and represents a collaboration between the faculty and students of the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies and the School of Art and Architecture at Yale University. The authors were all graduate students at the university and proceeds from the sale of the book go toward fellowships for students in ecology and architecture at the university.
The students make a strong case for changing the traditional thinking about lawns and note that "The American lawn has a long and noble history, and it has won a firm place in our hearts, but there is a darker side to this grassy swath. In our efforts to make it greener, to make it all grass, to keep it closely mowed, and to make it a constant companion of suburban development, we are unnecessarily contributing to some of the most severe environmental problems facing the world today."
The book closes with a chapter on "A New American Lawn" in which several alternatives to the classic lawn are proposed. These alternatives cover a range of options from changing the traditional ways lawns are cared for to more drastic roles of replacing the lawn completely. Although the book presents many challenging viewpoints that might be debated, there is much to be heeded in what is being said.
And since this is such a fine time of year to do some serious lawn-keeping homework, there is yet another book also worth reading: "The Chemical-Free Lawn, The Newest Varieties and Techniques to Grow Lush, Hardy Grass" by Warren Schultz. This tome from Rodale Press advocates the organic point of view on lawn keeping without the use of pesticides, herbicides or chemical fertilizers.

HEADLINE: Black Architects Struggling for Equity

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
COLLEAGUES are few; exemplars and mentors fewer. Business contacts are made in social settings to which one is not always invited. Lacking experience in big projects, one is rarely entrusted with such jobs -- and therefore never gets the needed experience. All told, it is difficult to be a black architect, even in the best of times.
And these are not the best of times. 
 "Certainly, the atmosphere is less optimistic," said J. Max Bond Jr., a partner in Davis, Brody & Associates, whose career spans 35 years. "That seems to be one of the things that has changed -- the feeling in the community as a whole that there was going to be progress, that things were going to change."
Roberta Washington, who began her career in the 1970's, said the outlook may have been better 15 or 20 years ago, when black architects could go into business and get involved immediately with new construction, as opposed to renovation. Today, she said, "I don't see those same kinds of opportunities."
Before the recession, black firms faced white firms of comparable scale and experience when bidding for small jobs or public contracts, said William E. Davis Jr., president of the New York Coalition of Black Architects and a partner in Davis Samuels Architects.
Now, Mr. Davis said, because there is less work to go around generally, well-established offices are competing for smaller projects. "With those firms coming into the mid-size market and the government sector," he said, "it has really made it very difficult for African-American firms to compete."
Paradoxically, progress has been hampered in some cases by programs that set aside a percentage of government contracts for minority-owned companies. To qualify for projects, white-controlled firms will form joint ventures with smaller offices.
"Because of joint-venturing, the range of jobs that minority firms can get has diminished," Mr. Bond said. "Black firms, Latino firms, women's firms are often brought in to fulfill some quota and not because the majority firm thinks they provide value. They don't get a chance to manage a job."
And what about the prospects for individual black architects within larger firms? Ms. Washington worked for several New York offices before setting up her own practice, Roberta Washington Architects, in 1983. "At most firms, I was one of two black people and sometimes the only black person," she recalled.
"When I go to white firms today, I still don't see more than one or two black people," Ms. Washington said. "If it were just skill and something that was judged very objectively -- 'Can you do this?' -- I think there would definitely be more black partners and associates. But it's: 'Do you laugh at my jokes? Do you go to my club? Will we have something to talk about when we get together for the holidays?' If the answer to those questions is no, you never get to the other one."
Although 12.4 percent of Americans are black, only 1.1 percent of members in the American Institute of Architects are black, according to an article in last month's Architectural Record. That is more disproportionate than comparable figures for Hispanic, Asian-American or women architects.
Besides these discouraging statistics, this fall brought more bad news to the black architectural fraternity when Harry Simmons Jr., the founder of Simmons Architects in Brooklyn and a co-founder of the Coalition of Black Architects, was killed when a plane he was piloting crashed in Massachusetts.
Mr. Simmons specialized in housing and churches. His goal, he said, was "to overcome historical conditions by creating physical environments that are oases for dignified, safe, comfortable living." He described his philosophy in "African American Architects in Current Practice" (Princeton Architectural Press, 1991), which was edited by Jack Travis, who also founded JTA Jack Travis Architect.
Kandace Simmons, Mr. Simmons' daughter and the managing director of Simmons Architects, said the firm would remain in business under the architectural leadership of Robyn Fleming, who worked with Mr. Simmons for about nine years.
BUT it was clear from colleagues that Mr. Simmons would be difficult to replace. Mr. Travis described him as "bigger than life" and Mr. Bond said he was an "important symbol."
Mr. Simmons gave much thought to the qualities that distinguish housing for families, Mr. Travis said. One of his ideas was building residential units around courtyards and placing front doors on the yard -- not on the street -- so that front doors could be left open and everyone in the complex could keep an eye out on the children.
Mr. Travis recalled Mr. Simmons saying: "If you think about it, we're extended families. You don't have to go back to Africa to find that; just go back down South. We haven't lost that."
Another feature that Mr. Simmons believed was important in a housing complex was a space near the street for men to gather, particularly since large numbers of them were likely to be unemployed.
"It was a passion with him," Mr. Travis said. "He was really trying to push for these kinds of things to happen. He was, in my opinion, a visionary that way."
Mr. Simmons had another vision: architects should be financially successful. Mr. Travis said Mr. Simmons would make this point to students by finishing his lectures with a slide of his report card -- all A's -- and then slides of his Jaguar and airplane.
"He was fantastic businessman," Ms. Simmons said. "That's why he was able to stay in independent practice for 25 years. There are very few architects -- particularly black architects -- who can say that."
In 1969, the same year that Simmons Architects was founded, Mr. Bond and Donald P. Ryder formed the firm of Bond Ryder & Associates, which came to be one of the most successful and prominent minority architectural practices.
On Mr. Ryder's retirement in 1990, the firm merged with Davis, Brody. Mr. Bond is a partner in that office, with Lewis Davis and his son, Steven M. Davis.
Among Mr. Bond's projects are the new National University of Science and Technology in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, and the Center for Disease Prevention, on St. Nicholas Avenue, between 167th and 168th Streets, which is part of Columbia University's Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Park.
Both at Bond Ryder and Davis, Brody, Mr. Bond has also been involved with designing a laboratory building on the site of the old Audubon Theater and Ballroom, on Broadway between 165th and 166th Streets, where Malcolm X was killed in 1965.
Preservation of the Audubon became one of the first major struggles over a site critical to African-American history. In March 1990, when its fate was still undecided, the Audubon was called "a landmark that is uniquely representative of the African-American experience of struggle" by Michael Henry Adams, a preservationist. "If this building is allowed to go down," he said, "it will be a tragedy."
After a tortuous evolution, the final plan for the new building, the Audubon Business and Technology Center, called for preserving some of the original structure, including parts of the exuberant terra-cotta facade. That plan was approved by the Board of Estimate at its final session in August 1990.
A year later, the 18th-century African Burial Ground was unearthed during excavations for a new Federal office building on a block bounded by Broadway and Elk, Duane and Reade Streets.
Another preservation battle erupted. Federal officials were criticized at first for excavating the site too hastily to permit sensitive archeological treatment of the hundreds of graves that were discovered. Then, the whole notion of disrupting the burial ground was called into question.
"This was a sacred place," William Davis said. "It shouldn't have been disturbed." Besides heading the black architects' coalition, Mr. Davis is a member of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which designated the burial ground in 1993.
In the end, a corner of the development site at Duane and Elk Streets was set aside for a memorial. A design competition was held this year by the African Burial Ground Competition Coalition, headed by Mr. Davis, which includes the Municipal Art Society and Professional Archeologists of New York City. There were some 170 entries.
"Our next step is how we get the memorial realized," Mr. Davis said. The coalition has just published a richly illustrated 91-page book, "Reclaiming Our Past, Honoring Our Ancestors," chronicling the burial ground, its history and the competition.
The burial ground "raised my sense of connectedness to Africa," Mr. Davis said. "No one could ignore it anymore. The evidence was there that these people lived, worked, tilled the soil. There was a real community here. It's almost like they were speaking to us 200-plus years later."
Ms. Washington said the burial ground was "probably the biggest rallier of interest," but noted, as did others, a general increase in historical consciousness.
"There was a time when the black community wasn't concerned with preservation," she said. "They thought it was validating the fact that they only had second-hand things and also, they saw it as something that only people with time on their hands were interested in. But it's changed. In Harlem, there are discussions about getting additional buildings landmarked."
One of her projects is the restoration of the wooden porches in a group of landmark 19th-century houses known as Astor Row, 8 through 62 West 130th Street.
Exploration of cultural history does not stop on these shores.
"An African esthetic has not really come forward," Mr. Travis said. "Now, a handful of people are starting to take a look at the possibilities." He has conducted summer workshops for architectural students in the imagery of sub-Saharan Africa, examining the spaces found in tribal villages and homelands. "We try to take that imagery and forge new imagery," Mr. Travis said.
MARK A. WARREN, of Garrison McNeil & Associates, believes Afrocentric design is concerned with space more than ornamental "applique."
"For instance," he said, "in Japanese architecture they see space in flux and forever changing. Similarly, in African architecture, you would have aspects of inner and outer, meaning that the inside relates integrally with the outside."
While much of the discussion of Afrocentric architecture to date has been theoretical, Mr. Davis has begun exploring it in an actual project: a banquet hall and offices in Hempstead, L.I., for the Nassau-Suffolk chapter of 100 Black Men, a civic group.
"The exterior was your typical, Long Island, neo-Colonial brick face, with broken pediment," Mr. Davis said. "We said, 'That's not the appropriate image. Colonial times were not the best of times for black people. It would be important for you to say who you are from your building.' "
"We looked at their mission, their purpose," he said. "It talked about hard work, ingenuity, commitment. We looked at a series of West African symbols and used those symbols on the face of the building." The facade is still under construction but four pilasters are in place, as is the entablature on which the symbols will be placed.
"We need to look to other cultures and areas, as we have in music, dance, theater," Mr. Davis said. "There are many other areas where African sensibilities and ideas have answered questions that Europeans have been struggling with for years."
Ultimately, however, there may be practical brakes on the development of African forms in American architecture. "A majority of work still has to do with the public sector," Mr. Travis said, "and rules and regulations are going to hamper the energy needed for an Afrocentric esthetic."
The dependence of minority firms on government set-asides is viewed ambivalently. On one hand, the projects can yield needed revenue and invaluable experience.
But if the larger firm is uncooperative, architects in the smaller firm may be shut out of meaningful participation. Also, said Richard H. Franklin, assistant chief architect for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, "because you're tied to government work, it depends on changes and shifts in the political climate."
Ms. Washington's office is involved in several major projects as part of a joint venture, including the proposed 22-story Harlem International Trade Center on West 125th Street (in association with Mitchell/ Giurgola Architects and URS Consultants); the reconstruction of Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn (with Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum and Ellerbe Becket) and the master plan of Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn (with Polshek & Partners).
"I find generally that if architects in both firms really want it to work, they find a way," she said. "We keep trying because, in a lot of cases, it's the only way we can get to do a project that is a lot larger than any we've done before. We couldn't do the Trade Center ourselves. Even if we could, we'd have a hard time convincing the client."
Terrence O'Neal, who began practicing on his own last year after leaving Ms. Washington's office, said: "I am not concentrating on becoming a minority business enterprise and going for the sometimes huge amounts of money that are involved. From what I've seen, it's not even worth it to pursue that kind of work."
Mr. O'Neal's projects include the rehabilitation of two schools in Newark and the design of the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Community Center at 34 West 134th Street.
Kevin F. Barnes, an architect and partner in the firm of BHA Consultants, said that in working for government agencies, "you get smaller contracts, you do the work over and over again until you please them and they won't pay you until you do."
"Quite frankly, I call it welfare architecture," Mr. Barnes said, "and it's nothing that I've ever found attractive." His recent projects include the renovation of 96,000 square feet of office space for Chancellor Capital Management, at 1166 Avenue of the Americas, between 45th and 46th Streets.
Mr. Bond suggested that the process might work better if the smaller firm were selected first and then chose the large office with which it would be associated, thereby gaining greater management experience.
The set-aside provisions tend to discourage the creation of integrated partnerships, Mr. Bond noted. For example, a firm owned equally by one black partner and two white partners would not qualify as a minority business enterprise.
BLACK firms on their own face daunting hurdles. Mr. McNeil's office has several big projects in Harlem, including a Pathmark supermarket on 125th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues and the renovation of the Renaissance Ballroom, at 138th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard.
Nonetheless, he said: "We don't get work below 96th Street or 110th Street. That's not bitter. That's a fact. One day, my 10-year-old daughter asked, 'Why don't you do buildings downtown?' I danced around the question. A day later, she said, 'You don't do work downtown because they won't give it to you, right?' I said, 'That's right.' "
"Race has an effect on the perception of black architects," Mr. Davis said. "That's really where the problem is. It's a subliminal thing that you're not quite qualified, even though all of us have gone to the same school, have the same degrees and the same licenses. We have to spend half the time proving that we're credible architects."
"People guard their culture very closely," Mr. O'Neal said. "A lot of what is considered architecturally good is often considered to be out of the reach of a nonwhite or a black architect."
What optimism there is rests mainly in the future. The year-old World Studio Foundation in Manhattan hopes to award $50,000 in scholarships next year, principally for minority students to study design.
"The key is academia and education if you want to change things," said Mr. Travis, who teaches at the Fashion Institute of Technology and the Parsons School of Design. He designed Spike Lee's house in Brooklyn and is working on four residences for Wesley Snipes, who played the architect Flipper Purify in Mr. Lee's 1991 movie, "Jungle Fever," on which Mr. Travis served as the consultant.
Minority firms are coming to benefit from their own networks. Mr. Warren and three others have formed the Atepa Community Development Association, whose name means "master builder" in Swahili. It includes engineers and lawyers. "We know the future is not just in knowing other architects," Mr. Warren said, "but in knowing your colleague in another profession who can help you get your project through."
Mr. Barnes noted that he and his partner, Gabriel Hernandez, were chosen to design a sanctuary for a Seventh-Day Adventist congregation at Weeks Avenue and 175th Street in the Bronx because "they wanted someone who was culturally related to them."
"I think minority architects will do better in the future because the client base will be expanding," Mr. Barnes said. "And I don't think most majority firms are willing to go into a lot of areas that I have.
"The difference that used to be restrictive," he said, "will be to our benefit."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
In the Aftermath, a Builder Picks Up the Pieces

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WHEN the building and buying boom of the 80's dissolved in bankruptcies and foreclosures, it was the developers who, deservedly or not, took the heat for overbuilding and overpricing.
In Stamford, which had been transformed from a dowdy industrial town into a modern city, the fall was especially hard. A parade of companies that had moved into new buildings suddenly moved out, headed for cheaper business and housing costs in the South and leaving developers with empty spaces and deep financial troubles. 
 Two of the best known real-estate names in the area, Arthur Collins Sr. and Robert Rich, were especially hard hit. Their companies live on, however, although in much-diminished and reorganized form and with control having gradually passed to younger generations in the families.
"Bob Rich," Mr. Collins said, "was hit worse than I was." Mr. Rich had been designated by Stamford's Urban Redevelopment Commission to level the downtown and then build most of its office towers.
"He concentrated totally on Stamford," Mr. Collins said, "I was in Princeton and Greenwich as well, where the markets were stronger. But I made the same mistake by concentrating too much in a limited area, and at all costs I would never sign notes personally again."
"It's easy," Mr. Rich said, "to second guess. We had other projects, too, in Boston and Florida. But we had a mission in Stamford -- a pact with the city signed in 1960 -- and we followed through. The tragedy was not that we kept building but, that the city allowed so much more building, including what Collins built on the waterfront."
Three of Mr. Collins's Stamford buildings were foreclosed: 1010 Washington Boulevard, 60 Long Ridge Road and Nine West Broad Street. Large tenant bankruptcies, including those of Savin, the copier company; and Vestron, a video company, left enormous vacancies. As other leases began rolling over at up to 40 percent less than their original rents, the value of the buildings dropped below the mortgages.
One Collins residential complex, called Harbor House, was also foreclosed, while Harbor Plaza, a 725,000-square-foot office complex and marina overlooking Stamford harbor, was not affected.
It took five years for the Collins Development Corporation to negotiate a financial agreement with lenders and pay off overwhelming legal bills. And, Mr. Collins said, "it was painful to let go people who had worked for the company for years."
The former Collins Development, once housed in 12,000 square feet of offices overlooking Stamford harbor, is now called Collins Enterprises, occupying a modest 3,500 square feet of an office building it owns at 53 Forest Avenue in Greenwich.
In October, Mr. Collins, 65, a Princeton-trained architect, ardent yachtsman and hockey player, moved up to chairmanship of the business that he started in Greenwich in 1971. His son Arthur Jr., 39, became president, overseeing development and construction, and his other son Dwight, 37, became vice president in charge of the portfolio of rental properties. Arthur Sr.'s wife, Joan, manages sales, and Charles Collins, a nephew, handles construction.
"AFTER the 80's, smaller is better," the senior Mr. Collins said. "We're sticking with rentals now -- the acquisition and management of rental properties, and the future development of waterfront projects in other states."
Last year Collins Enterprises bought Greenwich Close and Winthrop House in Greenwich -- apartment buildings with 130 and 52 units, respectively, for a total of $13.5 million. Vacancies are rare, and rents, which could rise next year following renovations, range from $1,080 for a one-bedroom apartment to $1,580 for three bedrooms at Greenwich Close, and about $50 more at Winthrop House.
"We are interested in the entire Northeast," Dwight Collins said, "and we are actively looking for rental apartment properties in Boston and Philadelphia."
Knoxville, Tenn., has hired the Collinses to construct a mile-long stretch of boardwalks, marinas, shops, restaurants and, eventually, 150 condominium and 100 rental units along the Tennessee River. Completion is expected in about five years.
"Condos are going to be a difficult sell unless the locations are special or they are bargains," predicted the elder Mr. Collins. "Waterfront sites are special."
Arthur Collins Jr. has been involved since 1987 in a similar waterfront complex in Stamford called the Strand, approved by the Stamford Planning Commission in 1990. Development has been stalled by the real estate recession.
"Our option to buy the land from Northeast Utilities was recently extended," he said, but Northeast has stipulated that the option cannot be exercised for four and a half years, at which time the utility expects the market to have improved sufficiently to sell. The 14-acre project designed by Do H. Chung & Partners, was to cost $90 million, and was expected to redeem Stamford's South End from its hodgepodge of decaying industrial buildings.
When Northeast Utilities was looking for a Strand developer, the Stamford Partnership, a business organization headed by David Anderson, recommended Mr. Collins, "because he has a particular niche in waterfront development, and he has an excellent reputation here, in Greenwich and Princeton," Mr. Anderson said.
From 1984 to 1987, Collins Development spent $2.5 million on engineering, architectural and legal fees, land options and environmental studies for the Strand. In addition, Arthur Collins Sr. agreed to donate an additional $2 million in cash or construction to low-cost housing in the South End.
"HE is like that," said James Sandy, the Greenwich town planner. "He would do everything a town wanted. We imposed a million dollars in offsite improvements on his Greenwich Gables condominium complex, and he did them."
Construction at the 167-unit Greenwich Gables complex lagged after a brisk start in 1990, when 2,317-square-foot units were selling for $575,000. "The last 23 units are being built now," said Arthur Collins Jr. One-bedroom apartments and three-bedroom town houses will cost from $390,000 to $600,000.
Lyon Farm, a residential development in Greenwich, "was typical of Arthur Collins Sr.'s unique approach to development in the 70's," Mr. Sandy said, "with major perquisites for the community. He even built a covered bridge over a stream."
Lyon Farm has small clusters of a total of 191 single-family units, separated by open spaces. Part of the land was donated for a town park and another part is open space in perpetuity. Prices have increased from an original $100,000 to as high as $900,000.
"The elder Collins was not unique in his difficulties," Mr. Anderson said, "and it can happen again -- where the real estate and banking industries and government regulatory agencies go wrong. Too much money, loose regulations, overbuilding, and the banks start foreclosing on so many loans that they go under -- back to the F.D.I.C., to you and me."

HEADLINE: The World;
Latin Leaders Speak Gringo

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
IT'S being billed as a meeting of the hemispheres, but when President Clinton addresses Latin America's leaders this week in Miami, it will have more than a passing resemblance to an evening at the University Club. The Latin American leaders include alumni of Yale, Columbia and the University of Michigan. And they see the United States not so much as the overbearing behemoth of Latin lore, but as a place where they studied, whose language they share and whose values they are increasingly embracing.
 This does not mean that all of South America has gone yanqui; the new rapport with North America is growing, in large part, only among the elites. But that is still enough of change to make this first hemispheric summit meeting since 1967 unlike any other. 
 For a quarter-century of accelerating travel, study and work in North America seems to have shorn many of the continent's leaders of their suspicions about the Northern colossus.
 
A Common Language
 The two halves of the hemisphere now speak the same economic language -- that of free trade between free markets. And if they still have bargaining to do on how fast South America will be admitted to a hemisphere-wide free trade zone, at least they can do much of it in English.
 Until the mid-1980's, the Latin countries had a penchant for repressive dictatorships and economies run to benefit the cronies of the powerful. The United States, whose banks were pressing for repayment of billions of dollars in loans, was an all-purpose villain. Now, after Southeast Asia, Latin America is the world's fastest growing regional economy and the fastest growing market for United States exports. And civilian democracy is the general rule.
 "It's similar to all those exchange and scholarship programs that chipped away at the Iron Curtain; the Latin American students have learned different ways of running their economies and their politics," said William S. Reese, president of Partners of the Americas, a private Washington-based group that promotes educational exchanges between the Americas.
 So far, this transformation has been limited to the middle and upper classes. And because the region has the world's worst income distribution, one result may be to widen already yawning social, cultural and economic gaps. "It's all very nice that almost all the Cabinet has attended American universities," a minister in Ecuador said recently. "But lower down in the ministries, all the bureaucrats attended the National University. There they had Marxist professors who taught them to love state companies and to equate foreign investment with theft."
 But the middle-class embrace of the United States is clear in many places where France, Spain or Portugal used to be the preferred places to tour or study. Take Brazil. Over the last two decades, the number of Brazilians visiting the United States has increased 12-fold, to 700,000 this year. And since the early 1960's, the number of Brazilians studying at American colleges has increased tenfold, to almost 5,000.
 Overall, South America's share of United States tourist and business visas more than doubled in the five years that ended in 1993, when it reached 21 percent. The number of subscribers to CNN has tripled in three years to almost 2 million. Last year, when Magic Johnson retired from professional basketball, it was front-page news in soccer-crazy Brazil -- a tribute to the influence of satellite television.
 The United States business school degree is now the universally sought after ticket to success. "Applications from Latin Americans have been growing at the rate of 20 percent a year for the last five years," said Thomas P. Gerrity, president of the Wharton school of the University of Pennsylvania, which now has 1,020 Latin American alumni.
 Indeed, the ornate Spanish-style presidential palaces of Latin America are increasingly filled with leaders who mowed lawns during summer jobs in the United States. Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, the former Colombian President who became Secretary General of the Organization of American States in September, studied for a year at Roosevelt High School in Fresno, Calif. Ecuador's President, Sixto Duran Ballen, was born in Boston and graduated from Columbia University. President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru studied mathematics at the University of Michigan.
 Bolivia's President, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, grew up in the United States and speaks Spanish with an American accent. Brazil's President-elect, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, has lectured at Stanford and Princeton. And Mexico's new President, Ernesto Zedillo, earned a doctorate in economics from Yale. "The best U.S. investment in Latin America was not the Alliance for Progress, but the Fulbright scholars program," said Augusto Alvarez Rodrich, director of Peru Economico, the nation's leading business magazine.
 Having developed a global perspective and an insider's understanding of competitive capitalism, such people tend to return dissatisfied with crony capitalism, a system pockmarked by monopolies, state subsidies and high tariff barriers. But to say Latin America's elite soaked up American economics is not to say that they absorbed its civics lessons.
 Last year, a group of wealthy Colombian parents at Bogota's American school, the Colegio Nuevo Granada, sought to bar the children of American oil workers from admission.

HEADLINE: Countdown;
The Rage to Kill Those Who Kill

BYLINE: By TOM KUNTZ 

 BODY:
SENTIMENT in favor of capital punishment is sweeping the land. This week five executions are scheduled -- three in Texas, one in Missouri and one in Indiana -- meaning that if there are no last-minute stays (always a possibility) the nation will pass yet another milestone in the modern era of the death penalty. Since the Supreme Court allowed states to resume executions in 1976, in no calendar week have more than four executions taken place.
 With states like New York moving to bring back the death penalty and moves afoot to streamline the judicial process so the condemned can no longer drag out their appeals, it seems an appropriate time to ask, once again: Will all this killing do any good? Will it deter crime? Is it cost effective? Or are we simply talking about retribution here -- real Old Testament stuff? 
 The data presented on Page 3 are intended to provide some talking points for the debate.
 Comparing state homicide rates released by the F.B.I. this weekend with state-by-state death penalty numbers certainly doesn't prove the case for deterrence. In states with large numbers of executions, murder rates remain persistently high.
 Of course, the data don't necessarily disprove the case either, since a complex web of social, economic and demographic factors drive murder rates.
 The numbers also provide an intriguing hint that the resurgent faith in executions may be more ambiguous than it seems. In the 18 years since they resumed, 254 have been put to death -- a tiny fraction of those convicted of murder and less than a tenth of the 2,948 currently condemned to die. TOM KUNTZ

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE POLICY
Colliding Missions -- A special report.;
U.S. and Bosnia: How a Policy Changed

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times; The following article is based on reporting by Michael R. Gordon, Douglas Jehl and Elaine Sciolino and was written by Mr. Gordon.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
It was the Sunday after Thanksgiving when Anthony Lake sat down in his Massachusetts farmhouse to work on a confidential memo to President Clinton, conceding reluctantly that American policy in Bosnia had run into a brick wall.
For months, Mr. Lake, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, had been talking about the need to combine the threat of force with the effort of diplomacy to protect towns designated by the United Nations as "safe areas" in Bosnia and quell the fighting. Now Bihac, a Muslim town in northwestern Bosnia that the United Nations had promised to protect, was on the verge of falling to the Serbs. 
 In his three-page note, drafted with the help of Alexander R. Vershbow, his top aide for European affairs, Mr. Lake said Washington had failed to persuade Britain and France to support NATO air strikes to try to save the town. Instead of pressing further for bombings, Mr. Lake recommended that the United States concentrate on trying to secure a cease-fire and on stepping up its diplomacy.
"Bihac's fall has exposed the inherent contradictions in trying to use NATO air power coercively against the Bosnian Serbs when our allies have troops on the ground attempting to maintain impartiality in performing a humanitarian mission," he wrote. "The stick of military pressure seems no longer viable."
From his house overlooking a pasture full of cattle, Mr. Lake faxed the memo to the White House, which in turn faxed it to Mr. Clinton, who approved it. Still smarting from his setback inmidterm elections, the President was at his Camp David retreat and had been involved only episodically in the Bosnian issue.
The next day Mr. Lake's conclusions were formally embraced at a meeting of the President's top advisers that neither Mr. Clinton nor Vice President Al Gore attended, and American policy on the 32-month-old war in Bosnia reached an important milestone.
The threat of bombing raids to pressure the Serbs to go along with a peace settlement would be put aside for now. Having failed to stop the assault on Bihac because it could not bend the wills of Britain and France, the United States concluded that it was more important to re-establish unity in NATO. But to do so, the leader of the alliance had to take a back seat to its junior partners, Britain and France.
The story of how and why the allies failed to act in Bihac, pieced together from interviews with American, British and French officials, goes well beyond the Balkans. It is a tale of the changing dynamics within the 45-year old NATO alliance, which is still searching for a role in a world with no clear adversary such as that embodied for decades by the Soviet Union.
With the common enemy gone, it has become increasingly hard for the United States, Britain and France to find the point where their national security interests converge. The United States, unwilling to send troops into Bosnia until the fighting stopped, was unable to impose its will on European allies that do have soldiers on the ground there. Washington managed to ease the worst NATO dispute since the 1956 Suez crisis not by leading the alliance to a consensus, but by acquiescing to the British and the French.
Last February, in response to a mortar attack that killed 68 people in a Sarajevo marketplace, President Clinton successfully pushed the alliance to create a weapons-free zone around the Bosnian capital. This time, Mr. Clinton contacted only President Francois Mitterrand of France. But the French, the architects last year of the "safe area" policy, were now siding with the British, who had been forced to go along with the threat of air strikes last February, and the Europeans prevailed.
NATO's unity was preserved. But a solution to the long war in Bosnia seemed more elusive than ever, and the United States is now looking for ways to keep the Serbs from feeling they have a completely free hand.
 
The Rift
Shift on Embargo Strains Allies
 The low point in the dispute between the United States and Western Europe over Bosnia came three weeks ago. Frustrated by the Bosnian Serbs' refusal to accept an international peace proposal, and by the Western Europeans' unwillingness to use military pressure, Congress ordered a significant change: as of mid-November, the United States would no longer enforce the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government.
Though the move had been telegraphed in the Congressional record since August, and its importance was more symbolic than substantive, it led to bitter recriminations within NATO. The leader of the alliance took the extraordinary step of saying it would no longer share intelligence with its closest allies or use its ships to monitor the weapons ban on the Bosnians.
As the Americans and Western Europeans were squabbling, the fighting in Bosnia was heating up.
Long frustrated over being cut off from food and relief supplies, the mainly Muslim Bosnian Government troops in Bihac opened an offensive in early November to push out of the enclave. The Clinton Administration refused to condemn the attacks, reasoning that the Muslims were victims in the war and were trying to reclaim their own territory. But Foreign Minister Alain Juppe of France and Foreign SecretaryDouglas Hurd of Britain complained that the Muslims were now acting as aggressors.
The United States and Western Europe might simply have agreed to disagree on the wisdom and morality of the offensive, had the Muslims prevailed for more than a few weeks. But the Muslim breakout from Bihac was risky -- so much so that Croatian military leaders warned the Bosnian Government against launching the attack.
Bihac was near Krajina, the Serb-controlled area of Croatia, and the Croatian Serbs soon joined in the fighting. According to an American official, 2,000 to 4,000 Croatian Serbs joined some 10,000 Bosnian Serbs in the fray, using supplies from Serbia, despite an agreement by Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, to cut off all aid to the Bosnian Serb combatants.
"We saw no shortage of ammunition, no shortage of supplies on the part of the Bosnian Serbs as they conducted the Bihac counteroffensive," a senior Administration official said.
The Bosnian Government apparently had not calculated that the United States and its Western European allies would allow the Krajina Serbs to cross an international border in support of their Serbian brethren. The Serbs were also supported by Muslims loyal to a secessionist Muslim leader, Fikret Abdic.
The Croatian Serbs' intervention was decisive, and the Muslims were beaten back.
In a move that would set off alarm bells in Washington, the Croatian Defense Minister, Gojko Susak, signaled to Peter W. Galbraith, the American Ambassador to Croatia, that his Government planned to respond to the Serbian assault by entering the war. A cross-border triumph by the Croatian Serbs and Bosnian Serbs threatened the Croatian Government's ability to reclaim the third of its territory that fell to the Serbs in fighting there in 1991. Mr. Galbraith sent an urgent message to Washington on Nov. 11, passing on the Croatian warning.
The Clinton Administration feared that a Croatian Government offensive would lead to a wider war in the Balkans that could even prompt Serbia to join in.
 
The New Strategy
Making One More Exclusion Zone
 On Nov. 12, the day Washington stopped enforcing the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government, Defense Secretary William J. Perry and Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, met in Mr. Perry's office at the Pentagon. Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Mr. Lake, traveling with President Clinton in Asia, were represented by their senior aides.
Throughout the consultations on Bihac, Mr. Clinton was distracted by Asian economic issues, the push to win Congressional support for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and forging a relationship with Republicans in Congress.
The goal at the meeting in Mr. Perry's office was to draft a plan to keep the Serbs from taking Bihac and keep the Croats from joining the fight.
"Our No. 1 objective was to prevent the war from widening," said a senior Administration official who attended the meeting. "The only leverage we had was to apply an exclusion zone."
The plan seemed straightforward enough. Washington had won NATO approval for establishing zones free of heavy weapons around Sarajevo and Gorazde earlier this year. This would just be one more.
Tanks, artillery pieces and other heavy weapons would be forbidden within 12 miles of Bihac and would be subject to NATO air strikes if the Serbs violated the ban. Since the zone would include part of Croatia, new Security Council and NATO resolutions authorizing the move would be sought.
The next day, American ambassadors throughout Europe received an urgent message to begin emergency consultations with allies on the plan. Meanwhile, Washington sent a message to the President of Croatia, Franjo Tudjman, urging restraint.
But the plan proved to be a hard sell, and the Clinton Administration gradually shrunk the proposed exclusion area, trying to make it more acceptable to the allies.
Finally, it proposed a six-mile zone that would not include Croatian territory. That way, the Administration figured, the zone would not need a Security Council vote, with the risk of a veto by Russia, France or Britain.
But even the shrunken zone was too much for the Western Europeans to swallow.
For his part, Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Rose, the British commander of United Nations peacekeeping troops in Bosnia, refused to acknowledge that Croatian Serbs had joinedthe fighting, even though the United States shared intelligence with London and the United Nations indicating that they had done so.
Clinton Administration officials say they believe that General Rose and his French colleague, Lieut. Gen. Bertrand de Lapresle, commander of United Nations peacekeeping troops in all of the former Yugoslavia, have been taking their cues from their own Governments rather than from the United Nations, a charge the generals deny.
In their deliberations with the Americans, the British and French argued that the Serbs would content themselves with the retaking of lost territory around Bihac and would not threaten the civilians in the town. London and Paris were also concerned that the establishment of a new zone could prompt the Serbs to retaliate against their peacekeeping troops in Bosnia.
Some American officials argued that Britain and France wanted the Muslim army to suffer a resounding defeat at Bihac so that the Bosnian Government would give up its effort to reclaim land it has lost across Bosnia. Western European officials deny that that is their motivation, but suspicions of this sort contributed to a tone of sourness in the alliance touched off by the United States' decision not to enforce the arms embargo.
Indeed, tensions between the Western European allies and Washington became so high at one point that Mr. Juppe, the French Foreign Minister, suggested that the United States might be covertly supplying the Bosnian Government with arms in violation of the weapons embargo against Bosnian combatants. Peter Tarnoff, the Undersecretary of State for Political Affairs, flew to Paris and told Mr. Juppe that the charges were false.
The French Foreign Minister did not back down. "I take note of your position," he said coldly.
A senior Clinton Administration official observed: "This was a terrible time within the alliance to get a decision. It was directly tied to disenchantment within the alliance with the Americans. They saw us moving toward unilateral actions on the embargo. It greatly complicated our ability to get action."
With little support evident for the establishment of a weapons exclusion zone, the Administration prepared a fall-back plan. If the Western Europeans did not agree that the Serbs' advances to date warranted action, perhaps they could at least agree on what type of future Serbian attacks would justify NATO air strikes if the Serbs kept pressing toward Bihac.
Mr. Lake later outlined this plan in a classified memo to Mr. Clinton on Nov. 18.
The idea would be to get the Europeans to agree on measures that would be "triggered" if the Serbs moved beyond the reclamation of lost territory near Bihac, shelled Bihac with artillery or harmed United Nations peacekeepers, Mr. Lake wrote.
The possible response included the establishment of some sort of exclusion zone, air strikes on Serbian artillery positions in Croatia that were attacking Bihac, air attacks against Serbian surface-to-air radar missile systems in Croatia, hot pursuit of Serbian planes into Croatian air space and air strikes against Bosnian Serb forces attacking the town.
But this plan also had little appeal for the Western Europeans.
 
The Mixed Signals
As Allies Debate, Serbs Advance
 As Thanksgiving approached, the Muslim-controlled territory was dwindling by the day.
To stop Serbian bombing attacks, NATO launched a bombing raid on Nov. 21 against the Udbina airfield in Serb-held Croatia. But General Lapresle of the United Nations instructed NATO forces to avoid hitting approximately 15 Serb planes kept there so as not to unduly aggravate the Serbs.
Western European officials said that the strikes showed the alliance's resolve, but the Bosnian and Croatian Serbs appeared to have concluded that the West was afraid to take tough action and continued their assault.
In New York, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, helped assemble a last ditch "stabilization plan."
The United Nations Secretariat had complained that the weapons exclusion zone would not work because the 1,200 poorly armed Bangladeshi peacekeepers in Bihac would not be able to monitor the area. So a tiny sliver of territory less than four miles across and six miles long would be declared an "enforced safe area."
Under that plan, all the Bosnian Government troops in the area would leave or be disarmed. Only 500 Muslim policemen would remain to keep order in the town of 70,000. Nationalist Serb attacks would be deterred with wide-ranging air strikes at ammunition dumps and supply bases throughout Bosnia, not just the weapons directly threatening Bihac.
For two weeks, the Western Europeans argued that the Serbs would stop short of Bihac, but the Serbs were now on the town's doorstep. Pinprick air strikes, the Americans feared, would no longer keep them from overrunning the town.
Still, the Europeans made it clear they did not like the idea of wide-ranging air strikes. Soon after Ms. Albright outlined the plan in New York, Robert E. Hunter, the American Ambassador to NATO, presented it in Brussels, making it clear that the United States would not insist on the "strategic strikes."
On the day before Thanksgiving, to back up his ambassadors, President Clinton called Mr. Mitterrand, who the Americans calculated could play a pivotal role in persuading other Western European nations to go along with the plan. He asked for French support, telling Mr. Mitterrand that Bihac could fall in two days and that a Serbian takeover might prompt the Croats to enter the war. There could be thousands more refugees, more killing and an escalation of the war, he said.
President Mitterrand said he thought Bihac might not even last that long and that he needed to consult with his Foreign Minister and Prime Minister, who were traveling abroad.
On Thanksgiving Day, President Mitterand called back to offer only qualified support.
The French President said that Serbian artillery and troops were near Bihac and that they were not afraid of NATO planes. Mr. Mitterrand said that he was skeptical about the idea of some sort of exclusion zone but believed that some "limited measures" were needed, according to American officials.
"I appreciate that," officials quote Mr. Clinton as saying. He added that it was important to persuade Britain and other members of the alliance to go along.
Mr. Mitterrand reportedly said: "We must do what we can without waiting. Do you want a NATO decision?"
Mr. Clinton replied that it was important to move as quickly as possible, American officials said.
The stage for a NATO decision was finally set, but the alliance did not act.
In fact, although Mr. Mitterrand had voiced support for limited measures in the conversation with Mr. Clinton, the French Ambassador at NATO, Jacques Blot, argued that the new American plan would require more peacekeeping troops and hinted that Washington should supply them.
The Americans were angry that the French had not followed through, and French officials at NATO continued to complain that the Americans were demanding action but reluctant to expose their troops to the risk of Serb retaliation.
 
The Second Thoughts
Alienating Allies With No Gains

On the day after Thanksgiving, Mr. Perry and Mr. Christopher reviewed the maneuvering at a one-on-one lunch and concluded that the American demand for action was hurting the NATO alliance without tangible gains.
Mr. Christopher was scheduled to go to Brussels the following week to outline American thinking on how to expand the NATO alliance, and State Department officials did not want the trip to be overshadowed by reports of infighting over Bosnia.
Mr. Lake reached a similar conclusion. Two days later, Mr. Lake and Mr. Vershbow, his aide, drafted their memo for Mr. Clinton, noting that the American effort "to use NATO air strikes to prevent the fall of Bihac has only intensified trans-Atlantic frictions."
Mr. Lake recommended that the Administration put aside for now its push to win support for NATO air strikes to protect Bihac and focus instead on trying to arrange a cease-fire in Bihac and on diplomacy.
Mr. Perry was the first to articulate the new policy, appearing on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" two days later and proclaiming the Serbs' gains to be irreversible. Now that the Administration had given up on persuading the allies to use air strikes to save Bihac, Mr. Perry sought to justify the change in policy by arguing that air strikes were not that useful anyway.
The next day, a "principals meeting" of Cabinet-level officials was held. By and large, the officials accepted the conclusions in Mr. Lake's memo. But Ms. Albright, who took part in the meeting from New York via video monitor, was troubled. If the allies signaled that there would be no air strikes, would they not forfeit whatever leverage they had over the Serbs, she asked?
Mr. Lake said NATO warplanes would still be available for close air support, meaning they could protect United Nations peacekeeping troops and Sarajevo and Gorazde if the United Nations asked for such action.
Mr. Christopher said it was not realistic to assume that "strategic" air strikes were possible, meaning wide-ranging strikes through Bosnia. While such attacks should not be ruled out, he said, emphasizing that possibility would raise false expectations.
 
The New Policy
Going Back To the Future

Mr. Perry's disclosure of the new Administration approach came before the White House had time to devise a plan to pitch the new policy publicly. Critics said the United States was merely inviting further attacks by the Serbs and had abandoned its leadership role in the Western alliance.
Even some Administration officials wondered if Washington might have prevailed if it had made it clear earlier this year that its support for international peace efforts depended on the allies' support for air strikes to punish the Serbs if they spurned an accord.
Stung by the criticism, the White House insisted that Washington was simply beating a tactical retreat in the face of Western European objections. Mr. Perry, officials said, would explore the idea of establishing new weapons exclusion zones around other Muslim safe areas to deter Serb attacks when he met with Western defense ministers later this month.
But the larger issue was how the West would gain leverage over the Serbs without a credible threat of force.
Even advocates of the policy shift seem daunted by the task ahead. "The road will be very difficult," Mr. Christopher acknowledged on Friday.

HEADLINE: 'Nothing to Build On': Haiti Starting at Zero

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The ambulance for the only public maternity hospital in this capital city of 2 million people sits rusting on cinder blocks in the parking lot, its tires long gone. Fetid sewage water surrounds the hospital, clumps of garbage bobbing through the thick green algae. The hospital grounds are littered with broken and abandoned equipment: a battered sterilizing drum, a pile of old tires, a gurney with two wheels, a rusty boiler.
Inside the hospital, just one example of the overwhelming problems facing President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's new Government despite initial signs of hope, it does not get better. A half-dozen women, groaning and crying as they begin to go into labor, lie on a hallway floor because the beds are filled. 
 The birthing room has no equipment other than a half-dozen tables. The sterilizer has broken down again. There is no medication of any kind. There are not even swabs to take a culture. In the shabby room that serves as a laboratory, the refrigerator is not working, a microscope is broken and so is the X-ray machine.
The maternity hospital has no running water.
"Sometimes we have enough money for a water truck; otherwise we just walk around the neighborhood to a water source," said the lab attendant, gesturing futilely at the taped-up faucet in the sink and then miming carrying a heavy bucket of water. Even water is often a private, rather than a public resource in Haiti -- 39 percent of the population has no access to safe water -- and this is the way much of it gets delivered, even to hospitals.
"There is nothing to build on here," said Col. Lionel M. Nelson, an American Army doctor detailed to advise the Ministry of Health, as he shook his head in amazement and distress. "There is simply no infrastructure. This is a country starting at zero with three strikes against it. I don't see how they can make it."
It has been six weeks since President Aristide was delivered back to office in an American Army helicopter and three weeks since he assembled a Government. Thus far, he has won praise from American and foreign officials for his policy of reconciliation, a wary silence from the tiny, immensely wealthy, light-skinned elite who feared a revolution and -- at least for now -- a hopeful patience in the slums and shantytowns where people who must bathe in sewage hope to see their lives bettered.
"Aristide is back, and the sky has not fallen as many feared it would," said William L. Swing, the United States Ambassador, who has been intensely involved in the transition. "Overall the spirit is pretty good."
The Ambassador continued: "The President has made a lot of wise decisions. He's appointed a broad-based Cabinet. He's been an advocate of reconciliation in a country that probably rivals South Africa as a place of historical divisions. I think he's probably come back with a greater appreciation that he is now the President of the entire country and must reach out to them all."
In the hotels now, men with suits and briefcases come and go, speaking of guaranteed loan plans, replacing the hordes of sweating, blue-jeaned journalists covering the showdown with the old military Government. Bankers, foreign aid bureaucrats, businessmen and investors are ready, American officials estimate, to pump a half-billion dollars into this beleaguered country during the next year, although it is expected to take months before real effects are felt.
The American Airline flights from New York and Miami are filled with returning Haitians checking so much luggage it is a wonder the planes can take off. Their hand baggage is shrink-wrapped in heavy plastic so they cannot stuff in more on the way to the gate.
The army, the police and their thuggish plainclothes extensions -- Fraph, attaches, Tontons Macoute -- are no longer terrorizing the population, killing, beating, raping and stealing. That alone is a difference of night and day.
"People can sleep," said Colin Granderson, executive director of the United Nations Civilian Mission here, summing up simply what is an astonishing change.
"The situation has improved tremendously, no doubt about it," Mr. Granderson said. "The factional violence many people expected has not occurred, and much of the credit for that has to go to the President himself. Reconciliation is not just a hollow word."
President Aristide, still in a security cocoon, has become more visible in recent days, journeying to Jacmel to survey the damage of Hurricane Gordon, which sent mudslides across houses, villages and roads, killing about 800 people and demonstrating once again the lack of Government services. He delighted a crowd by saying the storm should be renamed "Attache."
He played host at the national palace -- the "house of the people," he calls it -- the other day for a group of some 500 labor union officials, many of them near tears as he hugged and greeted them. But they also clamored with requests and grievances. The President sternly lectured: "Discipline. Order. We must have democracy. But we can't have democracy without order and discipline."
But Haiti is a land like no other.
Born of a slave revolt, its 190 years of existence have been marked by what Alex Dupuy, a Haitian scholar at Wesleyan University, described as "a predatory state that preys on the population at large." There has never really been an ideal of a civil polity. Even the holiday celebrating Haiti's first ruler, Jean Jacques Dessalines, a black field slave turned rebel general, marks not his birth, but his assassination by mulatto rivals in 1806, two years after independence, beginning the important color line here.
Successive governments have taxed, stolen and extorted, but provided little in the way of basic services like roads, schools or even water. A symbol of the last Government is the road leading to the house of the former police chief, Lieut. Col. Michel Francois. Even the streets in the center of town here have crater-size holes, and the roads turn to dirt and mud -- the rich simply buy Range Rovers -- but virtually the only smoothly paved road in the country stretches for more than a mile directly to the chief's former house, the macadam abruptly stopping at the end of the property line.
Startling statistics abound. There have been 21 Constitutions and 41 heads of state, 9 declaring themselves leader for life and, with some overlap, 29 either overthrown or assassinated in office. Even before the coup, it was the poorest country in the hemisphere, with a per capita income of $370 a year; it is even worse now.
Two-thirds of the population is illiterate. Only 5 percent of eligible young people are in Government high schools. There are only six doctors per 200,000 people, but many of these connive to get assigned to hospital payrolls in the capital, doing little work because there is no equipment or medicine. Some 15 percent of the children die by the age of 5. Half the population is malnourished. Curable diseases like malaria and tuberculosis flourish.
"This place does not lend itself to a quick fix," said Colonel Nelson, the American Army doctor, part of a team of reserve officers attached to the 358th Civil Affairs Brigade. With civilian occupations like forestry, Federal emergency management, law, banking and even a Philadelphia deputy mayor for transportation, they have been mobilized to advise the new ministries. It is proving a daunting task.
"You see bed after bed of people dying who don't have to -- it just breaks your heart," Colonel Nelson said. "Eighty percent of the equipment in public hospitals is not working. No water for a maternity hospital? That's typical of every hospital I've seen."
Indeed, an early study by the Army War College warned of the difficulties of reconstruction, saying bluntly, "There is almost nothing to build on." Haiti, the study went on to say, has been "so degraded by poverty, illiteracy, malnutrition, disease, violence, corruption, overpopulation, rapid urbanization, deforestation and soil erosion as to raise serious questions about its continued survival as a society and as an independent nation-state."
In addition to the vast difficulties of turning the Government functional -- further hampered because office equipment, supplies and files were made off with in a final act of what an American official described as "rapine and pillage" -- there is an underlying fear of what will happen when the American troops, already moving out their equipment and about 200 soldiers a day, finally leave.
"There has not been enough disarmament, of the attaches and Fraph in particular," warned Mr. Granderson, the United Nations official. "There are smoldering fears that after the U.S. troops leave, these people will come out of their bolt-holes.
"Many Haitians are not convinced," he continued. "They have lived through periods of stability which didn't last before. There is a deeply ingrained streak of pessimism. There is an amount of confidence invested in the U.S. forces which, unfortunately, has not rubbed off on the U.N. peacekeepers who will replace them."
The guns, Prime Minister Smarck Michel said, are "a serious problem," adding, "The amount of automatic weapons we have seen in the streets the past three years does not conform to the number of weapons that have been gathered."
But of more immediate moment, the Prime Minister said in an interview in his office in an ornate Italianate mansion built in the 1950's by a police chief whose official salary was $200 a month, was that "everything has to be done, whether it's cleaning up the streets or putting toilets in the schools."
"Going from a predator to a servant doesn't conform to tradition," he said. "This is a world of misery, a world of hunger, of children not going to school, of bad roads. But with the time it takes to go through proper channels, the conditions of disbursement -- we may see nothing in help until April or May."
The old Government had left nothing in the offices but truckloads of garbage that had to be carted away, and when he took over, the Prime Minister said, "there were no vehicles, no typewriters, no computers and almost no pencils."

The women sat next to the delivery room door and waited for a doctor to let them in to deliver in one of four delivery beds. (Associated Press) (pg. 26)

HEADLINE: TRADE AGREEMENT ENDS LONG DEBATE, BUT NOT CONFLICTS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The enormous global trade agreement approved by Congress this week does not mean an end to trade conflicts, economists and Administration officials say, much as arms control does not mean an end to strife. If anything, the biggest trade accord in two generations will clear the way for new struggles over a different breed of trade barriers, which may prove more daunting than those it resolved.
The 22,000-page General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, known as GATT, dealt with many of the enormously sensitive political issues facing the international trading system, including the gradual reduction of tariffs on agricultural products and the protection of intellectual property rights, like copyrights and patents. 
 But the conflicts the Clinton Administration and others see ahead will involve a whole new generation of issues that mirror many foreign policy problems facing the United States today: questions of how countries act within their borders -- like labor conditions, environmental standards and human rights -- rather than simply how they interact with other states.
These were some of the most emotional matters brought up by GATT opponents in the debate that preceded Thursday's Senate vote. But many targets of these complaints, like China and Indonesia, have already told Washington that they consider these questions to be none of its business.
All of those issues are outside of GATT and many believe they should stay that way.
Talks have already begun, however, on another set of thorny issues that were left over when the GATT negotiations ended, including the movement of "cultural" products, like movies, across national borders and the opening of markets to foreign insurance companies, securities firms and banks. Those are also the subject of a number of bilateral negotiations, particularly between the United States and Japan.
These new issues are likely to be played out in new forums. For many reasons, this GATT, in fact, may prove to be the last sweeping global agreement of its kind. No one is eager to slog through another 12 years of talks with such a huge array of players, each with radically different interests.
And during the recent debate, members of Congress repeatedly expressed frustration that the expansion of the GATT was so vast, and its effects so unpredictable, that none of the experts and lobbyists who descended on Capitol Hill could come up with trustworthy estimates of how much the American economy would benefit, or how many American workers would lose their jobs because of increased foreign imports.
"In the end most everyone voted on an emotion about freer trade," one senior Clinton Administration official said on Friday. "No one wanted to look like an economic Neanderthal."
To make the next set of agreements easier to negotiate and more understandable, many believe the drive to liberalize commerce will continue largely on a regional basis, through accords in Asia, the Americas and Europe.
President Clinton has already begun down that road, pressing Asian leaders at a summit meeting last month in Indonesia to create a regional free trade area that will go beyond the minimum rules set out in the GATT accord. He will do it again starting on Friday in Miami, when he gathers the first summit meeting of leaders from Central and South America since 1967.
"It is difficult to negotiate with over 100 countries on things so politically sensitive" as labor rights or the environment, the United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, said today. "Regionally, you have a lot more leverage."
But the Administration argues that without rules set by GATT, it would not have the political backing to pursue a broader free trade agenda around the world. "To grow trade, we are going to have to create more and more credibility for trade," Mr. Kantor said. "If the rules are not fair, the playing field not level, we will not have the credibility among the American public that free trade is to our benefit."
The global trade pact Congress approved established the precedent that the common barriers to trade that countries have used for decades at their borders -- tariffs on imports, quotas on the amount of rice or the number of cars or VCR's that can enter a country, regulations that domestically made products need a certain percentage of "local content" -- must be gradually eliminated. Of course, even when the new agreement is fully enforced more than a decade from now, many such barriers will remain. Future arguments, however, will not be over whether they should fall, but how fast.
But opponents of the GATT agreement have complained, for example, that it would not allow the United States to stop the import of products made by child labor, by companies that pollute the environment, or that force companies to keep wages artificially low.
Few countries, however, are prepared to allow international trade inspectors to come into their factories and press questions like this: "Excuse me, how old is that little girl who is gluing the leather soles of those shoes?" or "Could you show us how you treat the chemicals coming out of this factory before you dump them in the river?" Or even: "Why do you imprison workers who demand to make more than 50 cents an hour?"
The chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Laura Tyson, said after the GATT victory: "Are these really international trade issues at all? Ralph Nader is willing to have the United States pay a higher price for goods because we eliminate imports from countries that don't adhere to environmental standards we consider to be acceptable. But he doesn't tell us the pricetag that consumers should be willing to pay."
If anything, the Clinton Administration has backed away from linking such domestic political issues to trade. The underlying message of its decision earlier this year to remove China's human rights record from the question of whether to renew its preferential trade status is that commerce is commerce, and connecting it to politics is just an invitation for America's competitors -- Japan, the European Union -- to move into markets while the United States stands on principle.
Moreover, getting 124 countries as varied as Malaysia and Sweden to agree on common labor or environmental standards would be next to impossible. President Suharto of Indonesia made it clear to President Clinton last month that he was not interested in talking about why his country throws labor leaders in jail. Singapore's founder, Lee Kuan Yew, has forcefully argued against Western interference in "Asian values," including a national right to economic development that supercedes most individual rights.
The result of such divisions is that the world's trading partners may determine that rather than trying to hit another global home run, they should try something a bit less ambitious.
C. Fred Bergsten, the president of the Institute for International Economics and a key participant in the past two Asian economic summits, contends that regional agreements, as long as they do not create warring trading blocs, can speed overall change. If Europe sees the Asians and the United States sign a regional economic agreement, "it is likely to want to match or better the terms." Fear of a closer alliance between the United States and the Pacific nations, he contends, was a major factor in persuading European countries to finish long-stalled negotiations on GATT last year.
But the doom of global trade agreements has been predicted before, and those predictions have proven wrong. "I thought they were over for good in the early 1980's," said John H. Jackson, a professor of law at the University of Michigan and one of the leading authorities on the workings of the GATT. "They seemed to be a mess, out of control. But there is something systemic that happens when you get so many countries together, and the issues rise to the top political level. I wouldn't be surprised if, after a number of years of stepping back, everyone decides they need to do this again."

Estimates are for the years running from 1995 through 1999. Figures are those of the GATT group and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. (pg. 32)
