HEADLINE: Seeing China Under Your Own Steam

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, former head of the Beijing bureau of The Times, is the author of the recently published "China Wakes: The Struggle for the Soul of a Rising Power" (Times Books).

 BODY:
MOUNT TAI is a sacred site in Asia, soaring into the clouds and teeming with Chinese pilgrims and sinewy peasant entrepreneurs straining and sweating as they haul ice cream up the 6,000 stone steps -- for sale at prices that climb as steadily and as steeply as the hillside. Yet while Chinese regard Mount Tai as one of the most famous places in their land, redolent with a history that goes back to visits by Confucius 2,500 years ago, it rarely appears on tourist itineraries.
It has been about 15 years since China opened up its doors to Western tourists, yet foreigners still crowd into just a few big cities, seeing standard sights, without ever meeting a peasant, even though three-quarters of the nation's 1.2 billion people live in the countryside. The tourism industry, in other words, has fostered a cocoon that allows Westerners to pass through China without ever quite stepping into it. Since returning to the United States after five years in Beijing, I have found that the most common query I get is not about Deng Xiaoping's health but rather about how to escape this cocoon.
What I tell people, to start with, is that it has never been easier to visit the "real China" beyond the tourist circuit. Independent travel can be frustrating, but with many hotels offering airport pickup and concierges arranging train and air tickets, few foreigners get irretrievably lost. Certainly it is hard to imagine a safer part of the world in which to roam about. While it is possible to take a regular tour of the main cities in China and then tack on a week of individual travel at the end, my recommendation is to go without a tour group if you are comfortable doing so.
The place to begin a self-guided two-week tour is in a Chinese-style courtyard hotel like the Lu Song Yuan or the Hao Yuan, in Beijing. Both hotels are built in the traditional courtyards that were once home to the aristocracy, and the 17-room Hao Yuan was the residence of the former Chairman, Hua Guofeng, until he was ousted by Mr. Deng at the end of the 1970's. Neither is convenient by Western standards -- the staff usually does not speak English and a request for a bucket of ice may take an hour to convey before it is understood and ignored. But the rooms are comfortable and the courtyards are full of the charms of China. On the other hand, if you place a premium on comfort and convenience, stay at the totally modern Palace Hotel, with its pair of gold Rolls-Royces to ferry you around the city. An alternative, also in the center of Beijing, surrounded by little shops and narrow alleys, is the Sara Hotel.
Any guidebook will tell you what to see in Beijing; my favorites are the Forbidden City, the Tibetan-style Yong He Gong temple and Tiananmen Square (including the Mao Zedong mausoleum; despite the rumors about wax, it really is Mao's corpse on display). You might also notice the high red walls of Zhongnanhai, an old imperial compound on the Avenue of Eternal Peace less than a mile west of Tiananmen. It is the new Forbidden City, the workplace and playground for today's Communist leaders. Visitors are not allowed beyond the soldiers at the gate.
Several Beijing hotels and shops rent bicycles for a dollar or so a day; they are one-speed contraptions but are usually functional, and in any case it is far safer to bike in Beijing than it would be in Western cities. Instead of sticking to the main streets, meander through the hutong, or back alleys, where residents live in one-story housing and share toilets with their neighbors. Rooms are so cramped that people often sit in their doorways, munching on watermelon or chatting with neighbors.
Almost everybody makes a side trip from Beijing to the Great Wall, but instead of going by bus, take a taxi and an interpreter. Your hotel can arrange an interpreter for $2.50 an hour or so, or you may simply run across an English-language student who is willing to accompany you for the day and interpret free of charge.
On the way back from the Great Wall, have the taxi driver take a dirt road randomly off the main route until you find yourself in the middle of a little village. You will find the peasants happy to talk to you, through the interpreter, and they'll be thrilled if you have brought a Polaroid camera and can take their photos.
AFTER a few days in Beijing, take the night sleeper train seven hours west to the much-overlooked city of Datong in Shanxi Province. Fifteen hundred years ago, Datong was the capital of the Northern Wei Dynasty, whose legacy is a spectacular cliff of carved Buddhas 10 miles outside the city. The Yungang Grottoes include 53 caves decorated with 51,000 statues and carved reliefs, yet what is most awe-inspiring is the scale of the sculpture: stone Buddhas that soar up to 55 feet high. To me these huge, serene statues in the middle of nowhere are as exhilarating as Europe's Gothic cathedrals, for the offer a similar mix of artistry and spirituality.
While modern Datong itself is a rather grim coal-mining metropolis -- offering a much more realistic slice of urban Chinese life than either Beijing or Shanghai -- it is also less than an hour's drive from the Great Wall. Unlike the reconstructed parts of the wall near Beijing, the wall near Datong is the original -- a crumbling, worn mound of rocks overgrown with shrubbery 2that extends endlessly toward the horizon.
After five or six days in Beijing and Datong, head south to Taian in Shandong Province -- again by train, the means of locomotion for most Chinese traveling between cities. One of your short rail journeys in China should be by hard seat, the cheapest class, which is how ordinary Chinese travel, but the nine-hour journey from Beijing to Taian is not the one to spend jammed in an uncomfortable railroad car as people spit on the floor and converse raucously about the large size of foreigners' noses.
Taian is the town at the base of Mount Tai, or Taishan as the holy mountain is called in Chinese. It is possible to check your luggage by the train station and take a small bag or backpack for the overnight trip up the mountain. Stone steps have been carved up the hillside, so it is not so much mountain climbing as stair climbing. Most people can manage the trek up, with plenty of time for breaks and photographs, in five or six hours. A hotel on the summit, Shenqi Guest House, has private rooms with bath and a decent restaurant; it also offers sleeping bags and rents jackets against the chill. An alarm wakes guests at dawn to see the sun rise and proclaim, as Mao Zedong did, that "The east is red."
Confucius climbed Mount Tai and came from a nearby town, Qufu, that is still dominated by the Kong family (Confucius is a European rendering; Confucius himself went by the name of Kong). Qufu is a typical country town, sleepy and gritty, yet it is chock full of temples and historic sites such as the family cemetery of 78 generations of Confucius's descendants. The town is an easy side trip from Mount Tai, or you can get back on the train for the daylong journey to Shanghai.
After several days of roughing it, you may enjoy the plush luxury of a place like the Garden Hotel, in the old French Concession of Shanghai. For the adventurous, the Chinese-run Red Flag Guest House, which used to accommodate only top party officials, now opens its bungalows to capitalists. A charming location and a sense of history and place are the rewards, but don't expect a concierge to arrange tickets or a maid to put mints on your pillow. Shanghai has some wonderful little privately owned restaurants and astonishing discos replete with Madonna-look-alikes, strobe lights and prostitutes who conduct their business with the help of cellular telephones.
The city also abounds with English speakers eager to ply their skills, and one or more of them will probably strike up conversations when you walk along the Bund, the historic riverfront district. Some are aiming to change money or act as paid tour guides, but others simply want to chat in English, and you may be able to find a terrific unofficial tour guide in this way. There are also con men on the waterfront, however: I once saw a pickpocket run down the Bund, chased by his victim and several onlookers; when a bus stopped on the main avenue, people inside jumped out to join the chase as well. The pickpocket was tackled, beaten up and then handed over to a policeman before the bus resumed its way.
After a couple of days in Shanghai take the two-hour, 20-minute flight to Guilin, a southern city in Guangxi Province that is the jumping-off point for daylong boat trips on the beautiful Li River. Three-day and four-day cruises on the Yangtze River in central China have become popular among foreigners as well, but the Li River is more scenic and eats up much less of a two-week vacation.
The Li River courses through spectacular rocky crags that are the inspiration for much of traditional Chinese watercolor landscapes. Children swim naked in the river as the boats pass, and peasants till the soil with water buffalo. The countryside is enchanting, so hire a taxi driver and an English interpreter for a half-day excursion to a nearby village, where you are likely to find mud-brick homes, a small elementary school with ramshackle desks, tiny backyard plots with pigs and chickens and flocks of little children who will make you feel like the pied piper. If you bring a few trinkets, someone may well invite you to a dinner of stir-fried vegetables and tofu with rice.
From Guilin, take a 60-minute flight to Guangzhou, the bustling southern metropolis also known as Canton. Ever since the Portuguese arrived in the 16th century, Guangzhou has been at the front line of interaction between China and the West, and it was partly because of intrigues among Western traders here that the Opium War broke out and Hong Kong was ceded to Britain. The free markets of Guangzhou are among the most vibrant in the nation, and the Cantonese have a national reputation as sophisticates and gourmets. Yet while the Cantonese make great food, they don't know where to draw the line with ingredients.
One interesting but depressing sight is the Qingping Market, where turtles, salamanders, snakes, dogs and just about everything else are sold to be eaten. Afterward, intrepid tourists may wish to go to a snake restaurant or rat restaurant in Guangzhou. Snakes, in particular, are regarded as a virtual health food, a Chinese equivalent of alfalfa sprouts.
For those on a two-week itinerary, it is time to move on toward Hong Kong for the flight back. If you do not have too much luggage, take a bus or taxi for a few hours to Shenzhen, the boom town next to Hong Kong. Fifteen years ago Shenzhen was just a sleepy farming town; now it is a dynamic industrial city with a stock exchange, glass-and-steel skyscrapers, pin-striped lawyers and hundreds of factories churning out televisions, shoes and toys for consumers around the world.
From Shenzhen it is easy to walk across the border into Hong Kong, with only brief formalities with Chinese and Hong Kong immigration officials. On the Hong Kong side, trains take everyone to the urban areas. Alternatively, express trains run direct from Guangzhou to Hong Kong and minimize problems for those burdened by lots of luggage. The overland route is worthwhile simply because it conveys the feel of an endless construction zone; Guangdong Province has the fastest-growing economy in the world, and everywhere you look buildings are going up. Westerners joke that the official local bird is the crane.
For those with an extra week, Tibet makes a delightful side trip from Beijing. But be sure to get out of Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, and visit smaller towns such as Shigatse, site of a beautiful monastery and the traditional headquarters of the Panchen Lama, second only to the Dalai Lama in the Tibetan hierarchy. As everywhere in China, it is fascinating to visit the nomads and peasants who make up the bulk of Tibetans. Rural Tibet is still one of the most remote places in the world. I once met a Tibetan woman who was puzzled when I asked her whether her village had electricity. It turned out that she had never heard of electricity.
Most flights to Lhasa stop over in Chengdu, in Sichuan Province, the potbelly of China, and Chengdu makes a terrific break for a day or two. It is a somewhat grimy, very typical Chinese city of narrow lanes, tiny family-managed restaurants and, in the outskirts, peasants toiling over doll-sized plots of land. Moreover, Chengdu has, for my taste buds, the best food in China. I once took two Americans to dinner at a hole-in-the-wall restaurant near the Jinjiang Hotel, and our table was soon laden with delicious spicydishes; there was more than the three of us could eat, yet the bill -- including beer -- was less than $5.
IN any case, wherever one goes in China, perhaps the most important thing is to spend time with the people.
In many cities, so-called English corners are set up one or more nights a week for local people to get together and practice English. Americans are hugely welcomed. Similarly, university campuses are a good place to meet English-speaking Chinese, and even on the streets you may meet someone who will invite you into a home for dinner.
In particular, spend at least a day in the countryside. My most interesting moments in China were spent in the villages, and the fascination was often mutual. On my first trip to China, in 1983, I was waiting for a train at a station in a rural part of Shandong Province, and so I sat down and began reading my guidebook. A few peasants gathered in front of me, watching me for entertainment, as if I were a movie. Then others approached, and soon dozens of them were sitting in a semi-circle around me, pointing and staring.
Soon nearly 100 peasants were sitting on the ground in front of me, the adventurous ones crawling in front of me to look at the cover of the book I was reading, and the episode ended only when the alarmed authorities led me to a small room and barred the audience from following. It was an encounter between two worlds, and I found it just as extraordinary as they did.
 
 
 
IF YOU GO
 In Beijing, an interpreter, official or unofficial, can negotiate to rent a regular taxi for the day for about $80 or a minivan (which are not allowed to pick up foreigners up at hotels) for $40. In other cities taxis should be a bit cheaper. Train travel is not expensive: a first-class train ticket from Shanghai to Guangzhou costs about $30.
Hotel prices are for a double room, calculated at the rate of 8.5 Chinese yuan (renminbi) to the dollar. The country code for China is 86.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Tours of West Africa

 BODY:
The rich cultural heritage of West Africa is the focus of two tour itineraries early next year.
Travel Plans International is offering two-week tours of Senegal and Mali, with departures on Jan. 18, Feb. 1, Feb. 15 and March 1. Highlights of the tour include the flower and basketry markets of Dakar; a tour of Goree Island, once a major West African slave-trading center; a day in Timbuktu, a nexus of the trans-Saharan caravan trade and a center of Moslem culture; the mud mosque in Djenne and tours of remote Dogon villages. 
 The tour costs $6,595 a person based on double occupancy, and includes economy class air fare on Air Afrique from New York. Also included is lodging at Sofitel hotels, meals, lectures and internal flights and land transportation. For more information, call Travel Plans International at (800) 323-7600 or (708) 573-1400 in Illinois.
Magical Holidays and the Museum for African Art offer a package tour to the Ivory Coast, including three days in Korhogo observing the dances and crafts of the Senufo people, and a visit to Bouake in Baule country to see weavers, dyers, potters and goldsmiths at work. The tour, from Jan. 23 to Feb. 4, costs $4,700 a person, double occupancy, of which $600 is a tax-deductible contribution to the Museum for African Art. Air fare from New York on Air France is included as are hotels, daily Continental breakfast and some lunches, guides and local transportation. For more information, write to the Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10012; or call (212) 966-1313, or Magical Holidays, (212) 486-9600.

HEADLINE: And Still the Stonington Fleet Will Fish

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA 

 BODY:
AT 9 A.M. on a cold fall day, the rain had stopped but wind still whipped the Stonington Town Dock. "Boy, it was pouring," said Arthur Medeiros, who'd been there four hours earlier when his 55-foot fishing boat, the Seafarer, went out for the day. Now he talked with others on the dock, including two men mending a giant net and Fred Calabretta of Mystic Seaport.
"How's the fishing, Arthur?" asked Mr. Calabretta. 
 "It's been good," said Mr. Medeiros, noting great improvement over last winter. "We've been worried about the regulations; we still are, but we've gotten into other specices, like squid. Everybody's giving it a good shot. They're not going to roll over and die."
Mr. Calabretta often stops by the dock to talk with local fishermen about everything from the weather to even more formidable forces the men face -- declining stocks of fish like flounder and increasing regulation. As director of the Mystic Seaport Stonington Fishing Oral History Project, he and an associate, Glenn Gordinier, have taped some 30 interviews with the men, their families and others involved with Stonington fishing, including a local clergyman. A Seaport photographer, Mary Ann Stets, has taken hundreds of photographs to accompany the project.
Fishing in Stonington "is a significant maritime activity in our own backyard. We're trying to get a record," Mr. Calabretta said. "And there's a certain urgency. Fishing here -- and throughout the world -- is in real trouble." He added, "People are the focus of this project, not gear. These are good, hardworking people. They're all after the same limited fish stocks, but they stick by each other."
Stonington has been a center of fishing since Colonial times. Today it has Connecticut's only sizeable commercial fishing fleet -- 18 draggers and 12 lobster boats. The local fishermen's association is headed by Mr. Medeiros, who after fishing for 46 years now has someone else run the Seafarer and considers himself semi-retired. Still, he comes to the dock every day, to check on things and help out. He's pleased that the Oral History Project is recording a way of life beset by changes and challenges. "It's very good for generations to come to know firsthand from fishermen and their families what it was like," he said.
Project interviews, taped mainly in people's homes, are being transcribed; they fill more than 500 pages so far. In them, the fishermen tell how much they love their hard, dangerous work; how they learned it (mostly from their fathers and uncles, who learned it from theirs), and how they remember the men who died doing it.
What they like about fishing, most of the men said, is that it lets them be independent -- and out on the water.Mr. Medeiros, in his interview, said, "It's a good feeling, doing what you like, being out in the fresh air. There's no timeclock or people standing over you." Another interviewee, John Rita, said, "I guess you could call it being free, just being your own person."
Many have fished since childhood. Mr. Rita, who is 44, said he loved to go fishing with his father during school vacations. "I'd hear him get up. He'd say, 'You want to go?' I couldn't wait. I used to run right downstairs," said Mr. Rita.
Mr. Medeiros said that growing up in fishing is the way to learn to do it. "This isn't a business that you advertise in the newspaper and get a man to come off the street. It takes years and years of experience," he said.
Many fishermen grew up in Stonington, now a gentrified place with expensive homes and upscale shops. But Mr. Rita noted that when he was young, "It was a small-knit community, where most were fishing people," and just about everybody walked to the grocery store, the barbershop and the dock. After school, Mr. Rita and his friends headed to the dock to meet returning boats -- and get paid ("$5, which was a lot") for doing chores like washing down engines.
Some Stonington boats go out for several days at a time; others make day trips. The latter "is more of a family-type life. I think it's a lot better," said Mr. Rita. He and his wife, Ann, who was also interviewed for the project, have three children.
Family concerns run through the interviews. Mrs. Rita -- daughter and sister-in-law of fishermen as well as the wife of one -- is a bookkeeper at the town dock. Budgeting is a constant concern. "If you're prepared, you can manage," she said, but "you can't collect welfare and you can't collect unemployment."
Another interviewee, Robert Berg, added that "to survive now, a guy's wife has to have a job where she gets Blue Cross." And Mr. Rita said, "You've got to provide your own retirement. Nobody's going to give you one." Many interviews cite those who've left fishing to get jobs with benefits.
The fishermen noted that even when they're not on the water, they're on the job -- checking their boats, fixing nets, doing all kinds of maintenance. "Christmas morning, after the kids open their gifts, we run down for a couple of hours and check everything," Mr. Rita said.
They know long hours and terrible weather. They know the risks, but don't dwell on them. They know loss. On the dock stands a granite memorial to fishermen lost at sea; it has 34 names now. Every summer the fishermen's association sponsors the Blessing of the Fleet, which is partly festive, with food and music, but also has solemn ceremonies, like the dropping into the sea of a broken anchor of flowers, to honor fishermen who have died. "My heart and soul go with that," said Mr. Medeiros, who knew almost all those whose names are on the memorial.
It is at the 1995 Blessing of the Fleet that Mr. Calabretta hopes to show the oral history for the first time. Tapes, transcriptions and photos will be kept at Mystic Seaport; about 40 photographs, with text from the interviews, will become a traveling exhibition.
The men and their families are clearly worried about the future. So are government agencies, which have imposed limits on catches of scarce species, like flounder, and have proposed such steps as a buy-back of fishing boats, to reduce the number working the waters. The agencies have also been requiring additional safety features on fishing vessels (which Mr. Rita called "more safety things we've got to keep buying"). Many fishermen said that it's increasingly difficult for them to earn a living -- and keep up with the paperwork.
Some have given up. John DeBragga, working on the net at the dock, no longer fishes. In his interview he said that regulations and paperwork drove him to take a job at the casino in Ledyard. "That was sad to hear," said Mr. Calabretta.
Most though are still trying. Mr. Rita, in his interview, spoke of the proposed government buy-back of fishing boats. "For somebody that wants to fish, that isn't what you want. You don't want to sell your boat. You want, somehow, for them to let you make a living, continue what you're doing. I don't want somebody to mail me the check. I want to get up in the morning and go fishing," he said.
Asked what he would tell young men considering going into fishing, Mr. Rita said, "The way things are right now, I would say it's a good period to hold, see what's going to happen."
Mr. Medeiros's son graduated from college and now works with computers. "He liked fishing, but fishing is questionable for the future," said Mr. Medeiros.
Mr. Calabretta noted that the fishermen are very supportive as their children seek other opportunities, but they're also a little disappointed. "They're proud of what they do," he said, and proud of following a long tradition. Now, "there's an impending break in this tradition."

HEADLINE: Tanks Take On New Role as Artificial Reefs to Attract Fish

BYLINE: By JENNIFER WEITZMAN 

DATELINE: MANASQUAN

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY is participating in a nationwide cooperative program between the Department of Defense, the National Guard and Federal and state environmental groups by taking outdated Army tanks and dumping them into coastal waters to form artificial reefs to create habitats for fish.
The program of using old war materiel is called Reef-Ex (for Reef Exercise), and officials say it will improve and extend the life of artificial reefs and rebuild the environment and economy of coastal states. 
 New Jersey's recreational fishing industry, with 125 miles of coast, is second only to that of Florida, with 1,100 miles of coast.
On a recent morning, four miles off Manasquan Inlet, a group of Army officials and environmentalists watched in awe from a charter boat as six M-60 main battle tanks, which saw extensive service in Vietnam, were pushed one by one by a bulldozer off a barge. They plunged with a huge splash into the water and sank 65 feet, coming to rest on the Axel Carlson and Sea Girt reef sites. They were the first of about 100 tanks destined for New Jersey.
Officials said that by the next day, small marine organisms like mussels and barnacles would find the tanks to be a good place to hide and would attach themselves to the steel plates inside and outside the open vehicles. These creatures will become food for the dozen species of fish the program hopes to attract, including sea bass, blackfish and lobsters.
The tanks are also expected to provide a safe breeding ground for juvenile fish to grow and survive, which in turn would attract more sports fisherman and divers to the area. Officials said they hoped that by this time next year, fishing boats would find the waters rich with fish.
The 40-ton tanks are certified to be environmentally safe by the Army Corps of Engineers and Federal and state environmental agencies. Army and Navy reservists, performing their two weeks of annual active-duty training, prepared the tanks by draining all fluids, removing transmissions, engines and hydraulic systems and steam-cleaning the tanks.
"We are pretty hopeful these will be good reefs for divers and will provide better access for people fishing," said Bruce Halgren, maritime fishery administrator of the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife. Mr. Halgren said that because the hulls of the tanks were so thick, about 12 inches of steel, they would last 50 to 100 years as reefs before dissolving in the salt water.
That compares with the 5-to-10-year life span of thinner items like old cars and ships used before.
Capt. William Higgins of the Defense Logistics Agency Headquarters Reserve Unit in Washington said he came up with the idea of creating artificial reefs from the excess tanks. The Department of Defense was faced with the task of getting rid of 3,500 tanks from its Anniston, Ala., Storage Depot. Rather than cut the tanks up for scrap and remove their firing power, which was initially estimated to cost $10,000 each, Captain Higgins decided it would be cost effective to have the tanks removed intact and dropped into the ocean.
With the advice of the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Marine Fisheries Service, Captain Higgins said, the best solution, both environmentally and economically, was to use the tanks as artificial reefs to stimulate fish growth.
"By taking obsolete but environmentally safe tanks, we can recycle them and improve our existing artificial reefs," said Maj. Gen. Paul J. Glazar, the Adjutant General for New Jersey. For each tank sunk, he said, New Jersey will generate tens of thousands of dollars during the life span of the tanks from increased fishing and diving.
New Jersey is expecting about 100 tanks to be distributed along the coast by next year. It is estimated that the entire program will generate $7 million in economic activity for New Jersey over the next half-century.
"We need to maximize the reefs because the fish need to be protected," General Glazar said. "We don't have the coral reefs other states and islands have, so we have been creating artificial reefs using chained tires filled with concrete, automobiles and excess rubble along the coast of New Jersey for several years."
"Also, the openings throughout the tanks will provide the fish with more places to hide and give scuba divers more interesting places to visit," General Glazar added.
Captain Higgins said the program would be run at minimal cost to New Jersey, as it is one of the nation's testing states. The Army, the Navy and the Coast Guard will use funds for training reserves to pick up the tab for moving the tanks, and the program will seek donations from local businesses and grants and funds from the Federal Government and the states involved to cover the cost of the barge.
William Figley, reef coordinator for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, said that fishing is a multimillion-dollar industry for the state and that its resources "can be there forever if we take care of it."
The fish population over the last few years has dwindled 30 to 50 percent throughout the North Atlantic, as determined by the National Marine Fisheries Service. There are more fishermen using better technology, resulting in an excessive amount of adult fish being caught. Housing developments in wetland areas and the pollution of rivers add to the depletion of the fish population.
Now the trend is to rebuild marine life by regulating how many fish can be caught and by developing new reef habitats. "The goal of the Reef-Ex program is to create enough habitats for the 12 species known in New Jersey," Mr. Figley said.
He added that the tanks were a small portion of the artificial reef project and that the project would take several years before a significant change could be detected.
The deliberate creation of artificial reefs in New Jersey first started in 1935 through the efforts of party boat and charter boat volunteers. Artificial reefs have historically developed along the Eastern Seaboard from natural disasters and shipwrecks.
The Reef-Ex program was instituted in Alabama this year when 100 tanks were dropped throughout the summer to create two major artificial reefs. Steve Heath, marine biologist with the Marine Resources Division of the Alabama Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, reported in The Mobile Register that a "tremendous number of fish" were seen around the first six tanks dropped in June.
He said, "The program has lived up to all our expectations, and we expect it to get better as the food web grows."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Washington-to-London Concorde Flights End

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

 BODY:
After 18 years, British Airways has discontinued service on the supersonic Concorde between Washington and London, and it will use the newly available airplane to increase its Concorde charter service from Kennedy International Airport in New York. The twice-daily Concorde service between New York and London is unaffected.
The thrice-weekly Washington service whisked travelers who paid $7,800 for a round trip between Dulles International and Heathrow Airports, traveling at up to 1,350 miles an hour so smoothly that they didn't spill their caviar and Champagne during the four-hour trip, but it fell victim to the economy, according to Margaret Vodopia, spokeswoman for British Airways. 
 Although the recession has ended, government agencies, diplomatic missions and international institutions like the World Bank that had cut costs during hard times decided to continue holding costs down, Ms. Vodopia said.
USAir will provide connecting service between National Airport in Washington and Kennedy Airport in New York for Washington-area passengers flying the Concorde between New York and London. There are two Concorde round trips a day between Kennedy and Heathrow at a round trip fare of $8,756. IRVIN MOLOTSKY

LENGTH: 2031 words

HEADLINE: For Arbitragers, the Game Is Afoot Once Again . . . but Rewards May Not Be as Sweet as in the 80's

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
LAST month's collapse of Conseco Inc.'s bid to acquire Kemper Corporation is the kind of event that professional speculators in takeover stocks dread. Many of these high-stakes investors, known in the business as risk arbitragers, bought Kemper stock at prices as high as $60 a share, hoping to make a killing by the time the deal closed at Conseco's offering price of $67.
But when Conseco withdrew its offer on November 21 because it couldn't muster the financing, Kemper's stock plunged, closing Friday at $40.25 a share. 
 To the "arbs," the Kemper blowup was just the latest in a series of mishaps that have unexpectedly roiled their complex calculations this year. But few are complaining. On the contrary, most are more upbeat than they've been since the fat years of the 1980's. "It's a very exciting time to be in the business," said Richard Nye, managing partner of Baker Nye and a 28-year risk arbitrage veteran.
Why so happy? After being tarred by the excesses of Ivan Boesky, the highflying arb who pleaded guilty to insider trading in 1986, and seeing their business dry up in 1990, many arbs now see things going their way.
The Republican victory in last month's elections saw the demise, or muzzling, of several powerful Democrats who were notorious among takeover investors for obstructing deals. Opportunities overseas are expanding as countries in Europe and elsewhere adopt more open takeover rules.
And domestically, the volume of takeover deals has approached record levels in the past two years and doesn't seem to be ebbing. Through November, $150.4 billion worth of deals were announced, involving 1,298 publicly-traded United States companies -- more than in any prior year, though the 1994 dollar volume may fall short of the $178.4 billion achieved in 1988.
"I feel comfortable that we are in pretty good shape for the next 12 to 24 months," said George Kellner, managing partner of Kellner, DiLeo & Company, a longtime investor in takeover stocks.
At a time when investors are uncertain about the direction of both the bond and stock markets, risk arbitrage has strong appeal. Because arbs focus only on the outcome of specific deals, their returns, in theory, are divorced from the vagaries of the overall market. Instead, arbs traditionally rank their performance against the money market, promising to deliver between two and three times the level of short-term interest rates.
A small and inbred club, arbs practice the select art of buying up the stocks of targeted companies after a takeover has been announced but while there is still some doubt about whether the deal will be completed. Their buying power offers less patient investors a way to get some cash out up front, while the arbs aim to make their profit when the deal is eventually consummated.
Notoriously secretive lest others follow their lead, arbs work either for Wall Street investment banks, risking the firms' capital, or for private investment funds with capital provided by institutions or wealthy individuals. Most rarely allow themselves to be quoted in the press.
It is virtually impossible to determine how much arb money is in the market at any one time because different players are moving in and out of deals on a daily basis. During the height of the 1980's takeover boom, estimates of total arb capital ranged from $10 billion to $20 billion. Today, arbs estimate the total to be a fraction, perhaps $4 billion.
Mr. Kellner, like most of his competitors, was reluctant to divulge how much money his firm manages, saying only that it is "well in excess of $100 million." But in a recent interview he added that he would like to raise about $100 million more.
Other arbs, too, said they were seeking more investment capital, while several who claimed they were not actively raising money coyly admitted that they wouldn't mind having more to play around with in the coming months.
"This year, risk arbitrage will continue to be one of the dominant styles that we believe will make money going forward," said E. Lee Hennessee, director of a group at Republic New York Securities that advises clients about investment partnerships known as hedge funds.
A major reason is the large number of takeovers being launched by corporations. Consolidations in industries such as defense, pharmaceuticals, financial services, entertainment, health care and computer software have resulted in a spate of deals, providing a wealth of opportunities for arbitragers.
THE 20-person arb desk at Bear, Stearns & Company is currently tracking 170 deals, twice as many as two years ago and even more than it followed during the 1980's, according to senior managing director Barry Cohen.
But while high deal volume broadens opportunities, it does not necessarily guarantee high profits. Risk arbitrage may reduce an investor's exposure to a downturn in the performance of the overall market, but it replaces market risk with the risks of specific deals.
Nevertheless, several arbs claim mouth-watering returns. Guy Wyser-Pratte, president of Wyser-Pratte & Company and a veteran arb who was brought into the family business started by his father in Paris in 1929, said his firm has registered an average annual pretax return on assets of 30 percent since July 1967. (Counting management fees, the actual pretax return to investors is closer to 25 percent.)
Such calculations smooth over the high year-to-year volatility of the past decade and minimize the impact of having to pay capital gains tax on all those short-term profits. Still, their record is respectable. The aggregate performance of the risk arbs tracked by Ms. Hennessee of Republic New York Securities vary from a 47 percent return in 1988 to 1.2 percent in 1990 to nearly 20 percent in 1991.
One of the reasons that the 1980's was a golden era for risk arbitrage is because most of the deals not only were completed but were bid up by successive suitors after a target company had been "put in play." Arbs could simply buy the targeted company's shares after the first bid was announced and ride the stock until the top bidder prevailed.
Before the 1980's, risk arbitrage was largely the preserve of investment banks like Goldman, Sachs & Company and Bear, Stearns. But the celebrated success and conspicuous wealth of Ivan Boesky spawned imitators and made arbitrage one of the emblems of the go-go 80's.
The party began to draw to a close after Mr. Boesky and several other prominent arbs, including Robert A. Freeman of Goldman, Sachs, pleaded guilty to insider trading. It ended in 1990, when deal financing dried up and new takeovers rapidly declined.
MANY arbs got clobbered when the stock market crashed in 1987, and after two separate bids for UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, collapsed in 1989 and 1990. Reeling from the losses, PaineWebber and the Blackstone Group shut down their risk arb departments. Smith Barney had trouble making up its mind, getting in and out of the business several times.
During the lean years of the early 1990's, the practice of risk arbitrage was difficult. Many arbs recast themselves, using their skills at assessing deals to buy the bonds of bankrupt or nearly bankrupt companies to reap profits from the reorganization.
Now such so-called vulture opportunities are drying up and investors are moving back into arbitrage.
But given the record number of deals this year, the risk arb business has not been as sweet as in years past. Many of the deals involve complex industries, such as telecommunications, health care and computers that are not easy to analyze. Unlike the 1980's, when cash was king, many acquirers have used their own stock to fund deals. That makes it harder for arbs to calculate what their returns will be.
For example, earlier this year, arbs playing the Viacom-Paramount takeover took hits when rising interest rates forced some private partnerships to unload their stock in order to cover their losses in the bond market. Because Viacom was using its stock to buy Paramount, the resulting fall in Viacom's share price cut into the profits of arbs waiting for the deal to close.
Rising interest rates also raised the cost of financing the arbs' stock holdings and shrunk profit margins after they had committed to deals.
In addition to blow-ups like the Kemper takeover, many deals have been delayed awaiting approvals from federal regulators on antitrust grounds -- an issue that never posed much of a problem during the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
TO arbs, time is money. A deal that closes in a month with a 10 percent gain represents an annualized return of 120 percent. But if the deal stretches out over six months, the effective annual return is only 20 percent.
Consequently, most arbs are fairly strong advocates of the free market. Mr. Wyser-Pratte railed against "the almost hysterical zeal of the Federal Trade Commission by what I would call the friends of Hillary gang." He blamed the commission for holding up pharmaceutical maker Eli Lilly's acquisition of distributor McKesson Corporation earlier this year.
But while antitrust worries have frustrated the arbs, they have also created opportunities. Software giant Microsoft Corporation is offering 1.336 of its shares for Intuit Inc., the maker of the Quicken personal finance program. That equals about $83 at Microsoft's current price. Yet, Intuit is only trading at $67.25 a share.
"This is a deal that the market thinks has a very serious antitrust problem," said one arb who requested anonymity. "If you have confidence that the deal is going to close, you are going to make more than $15 a share."
What can provide that kind of confidence is research and experience. Many of the successful arbs maintain a core of analysts who crunch numbers and assess the likelihood of deals reaching fruition. They also employ lawyers and consultants to brief them on the regulatory and legal angles of the deal.
"In a sense you are putting together the same kind of team that the corporations in the deals have done for themselves," said Peter M. Schoenfeld, vice chairman of Wertheim Schroder & Co., an international investment bank that trades for its own account as well as for outside investors.
The arbs see things getting easier in the months ahead. Deal volume will continue to be strong, they believe, as pending legislation affecting financial services, health care, entertainment and other industries encourages continued consolidation. Flush with cash and eager to earn fat fees, the commercial banks are increasingly willing to get back into the business of financing takeovers. In addition, falling stock prices will make potential targets more attractive while the low value of the dollar will continue to make American companies attractive to foreign buyers, who tend to pay cash.
The arbs also expect the new Republican majorities in both houses of Congress to ease antitrust fears. Senator Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio, a well-known gadfly who attacked many corporate takeovers, did not seek re-election and Representative John D. Dingell, who used his position as chairman of the powerful House Energy and Commerce Committee to challenge some deals, will be handing the committee reins to a Republican.
"There is no doubt in my mind that these folks are going to be behaving a whole lot differently," Mr. Wyser-Pratte said of the Clinton Administration.
Mr. Wyser-Pratte and others are also expecting an expansion in European deal activity as the continent emerges from recession. New rules adopted by the European Union strengthening shareholder rights have also made playing the risk arbitrage game more attractive.
"It's becoming more of a global market," said Mr. Schoenfeld, who maintains arb staffs in both New York and London.
But some of the veterans make it clear that they don't want things to get too good, either. If that happens, too much money might be drawn into the business, narrowing the spreads in the best deals and increasing volatility in others.
"We're not seeing the hot-money crowd, and that's good," Mr. Wyser-Pratte. "All that does is destabilize the sector."

HEADLINE: At Work;
Linking Gay Rights and Unionism

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
A CONFERENCE of gay trade unionists was just one of hundreds of events last June organized to coincide with the 25th anniversary of the Stonewall rebellion, the 1969 clash between the New York City Police and the patrons of a Greenwich Village gay bar that is generally regarded as the birth of the modern gay rights movement. But out of the Pride at Work conference, as it was called, a national organization has emerged. A leadership group of labor activists gathered in New York again late last month to formally ordain the National Gay/Lesbian/Bi/Transgender Labor Organization, the group's politically inclusive full title. Alas, no acronym dare speak its name, and so the group will be known as Pride at Work. It has a national mailing list of about 600 names.
It may not seem like the most propitious moment for an alliance between the two groups most likely to be marginalized by those who must now be obeyed in Washington. The Democratic debacle is attributed in part to Bill Clinton's support for gay rights and his attempt to change the military's discriminatory sexual orientation policies early in his term. There are undoubtedly those in the union movement, with strong ties to the Democratic Party, who would regard gay rights as a lavender albatross. Supporting those issues, the argument would go, is to risk further alienating the gay-shy electorate. 
 But as Pride at Work's organizers point out, they are not asking unions to do the right thing. Instead, they are trying to establish a power base that cannot be ignored, either in the political arena or when union locals are called on to support their gay and lesbian rank-and-file members who are being harassed at work. "We want to be recognized as part of the labor movement," said Flo Stern, a spokeswoman for the group. "We have to be visible wherever we are."
If the rank and file of the gay and labor movements would seem to have little in common other than an activist impulse, consider that neither group reflects its stereotype very faithfully. The liveliest segment of the labor movement is not in blue-collar industries dominated by workers who -- according to stereotype -- might be inclined to be hostile to homosexuality. The fastest-growing unions are those organizing white-collar and service industry workers. Some of those unions, especially the ones based in big cities, have a significant gay presence.
On the other hand, new research indicates that gay men and lesbians aren't all "guppies" and "dinks," which is to say, gay urban professionals and "double income, no kids" upwardly mobile couples without significant family financial responsibilities. A survey by a University of Maryland economist, Lee Badgett, revealed that both gay men and lesbians earn less on average than similarly qualified heterosexual men and women.
Pride at Work envisions itself as a kind of mediator between gay and labor concerns, promoting civil rights within the unions and the labor perspective within the gay community.
Part of the mission is to raise the consciousness of blue-collar workers who do fall into the stereotypical category, as well as to provide support for gay unionists in parts of the country where it is virtually impossible to be out of the closet.
The group can build on the history of informal gay activism within the union movement, and gay caucuses of varying degrees of formality exist at several unions. Pride at Work is doing within the labor movement what many gay people in general are doing these days: Coming out after a long period of cogitation in which they were open in every way except putting a name to it.
 
Labor Notes
 * In the week before Thanksgiving, the Association of Professional Flight Attendants observed the first anniversary of its strike against American Airlines, which, to the surprise of most observers, nearly shut the carrier down. The parties have been in arbitration since Oct. 17 and expect to be there until at least February. Reports of the airline's improved financial condition may give the union leverage to fight off concessions.
* Traffic accidents are the leading cause of occupational injuries. The Monthly Labor Review reports in its October issue that highway-related fatalities accounted for 20 percent of 6,271 fatal workplace injuries, based on statistics from the Labor Department's 1993 Census of Fatal Injuries. Homicide ranks second, at 17 percent of total job-related deaths. About half were of retail workers in grocery stores or restaurants who were killed during robberies or in the commission of some other crime. Roughly one victim in seven was done in by a "co-worker or personal associate."

HEADLINE: Yes, Even Now, There Are Pro-Clinton C.E.O.'s

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
IT is almost an oxymoron to combine the words "Democrat" and "chief executive officer." Yet there is a small, but hardy, band of Democratic business executives. And, despite the recent Republican sweep of Congress, they are standing by their man, President Clinton, though with some reservations and concerns.
More than any other Democratic Presidential candidate in recent times, Bill Clinton in 1992 reached out to business and business responded. From bankers on Wall Street to entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley, the Clinton-Gore campaign courted executives with the message that business had nothing to fear from a Democratic Administration. This effort had many goals: To lend credibility to the Clinton campaign, to tap into the deep pockets of business and to gain votes that had traditionally gone to Republicans. 
 And this effort paid off. More than 400 business leaders, nearly a third of whom were Republicans who had voted for President Bush, publicly endorsed Mr. Clinton. Now, two years and a bruising partisan setback later, feelings are softer. Many of these leaders say President Clinton has done a poor job of articulating what they claim are his many successful pro-business accomplishments -- and that the President should get that message out in a hurry.
The Clinton Administration is given high marks for a budget bill that began to rein in the deficit, for keeping interest rates low and the economy strong, for reducing unemployment and creating jobs, for Commerce Department trade missions that have been effective in promoting the sale of American goods overseas, for backing the North American Free Trade Agreement and GATT, for reducing taxes on small business and for supporting a whole array of regulatory initiatives that have cut red tape and spurred business development.
But, these business leaders say, these accomplishments have gotten little attention. "This Administration has a level of sophistication about business and many accomplishments," said Steven J. Green, chief executive of the Astrum International Corporation, which owns Samsonite luggage and Culligan water systems. "But it does a poor job of communicating what it has done well and an excellent job of communicating what it has not done well."
Some in the Administration say the midterm Democratic defeat should help business -- forcing President Clinton to focus more on centrist business issues of the type typically favored by executives and by the Republican majority in Congress.
"This is an opportunity for the President," said Kenneth D. Brody, a former Goldman Sachs partner and president of the Export-Import Bank. "There's an intersection with what the Republicans want and what the President wants. A lot of good things will get done. Beatings like this will have the President and his advisers focused on what the American people really want."
Just last week, Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker, appeared before the National Press Club in Washington to appeal for bipartisanship and for support for Mr. Clinton from the business community. "At this time," he said, "the Clinton Administration must regain the confidence it had originally gained from the business community, and which it subsequently lost. Whatever its shortcoming, I believe that the Administration is entitled to such support as a result of its economic policies."
If Democrats sniff opportunity in defeat, so do Republicans. Barbara Hackman Franklin, a former Commerce Secretary and a Republican fundraiser, said: "I'd like to see the G.O.P. capitalize on this victory and explain why business people are better off with us." As for fundraising for the Republican Party, Ms. Franklin added, "it's going to be a lot easier."
What follows is a midterm assessment by several prominent executives who voted for President Clinton.
 
Bernard L. Schwartz
Chief executive of the Loral Corporation, a New York-based military electronics manufacturer.
"I'm frustrated, but not disillusioned and I've not lost heart. The President is smart enough to read the election returns. He's delivered quite a lot. But the common perception is that government doesn't work. So he's got to skinny down his agenda and focus. He's also got to get people who are a little more seasoned and a little less idealistic on his team. I'd like to see a little more gray hair at the White House.
"This Administration has done a yeoman's job in helping the industrial base in a nonpartisan way. He's made good friends in the defense and aerospace industries. My advice is to stay the course -- we're only in the third or fourth inning, not the ninth. 1996? You tell me what the level of the stock market is in 1996 and the inflation rate and I'll tell you who will win."
 
Paul A. Allaire
 President of the Xerox Corporation, based in Stamford, Conn.
"There are a number of things Clinton has done that are positive for business. Clearly his approach to free trade is something we can feel very good about. The budget package helped produce a growing economy and created new jobs. And raising competitiveness to the forefront and acting to assure that our nation is more competitive is positive, too.
"Business would like to see the President and Congress working together so we don't get gridlock. We've had business, labor and government working together well. I don't think business leaders were very strong Clinton supporters in the beginning. Even though he's done a lot of things that business would say is good, business feels negative about other things -- like health care -- and that's colored their view."
 
Paul Montrone
Chief executive of Fisher Scientific International, a Hampton, N.H., scientific instrument supplier.
"Bill Clinton has been consistently supportive of the business community. But that's not kept a lot of business people from falling by the wayside in their support of him. Why? The answer is a combination of form and the people he has surrounded himself with that deal with the business community. [Commerce Secretary] Ron Brown has been a great business ambassador. But at the White House there are not a lot of players who understand how to deal with the business community and how to build alliances. They don't know what buttons to push and a lot of business people think he is too liberal.
"Bill Clinton's own thinking is pro-business. He needs to have some real solid business people close to him and follow their advice and lead. If that happens, it could possibly help in a major way. I'm hopeful."
 
Sanford R. Robertson
Chairman, Robertson, Stephens & Company, a San Francisco investment bank.
"I do a lot of business in Silicon Valley and he's been very good for us. He's lowered trade barriers to high-tech companies and cut red tape. Ron Brown has been terrific. The President has done a lot of things he hasn't gotten credit for.
"Business, however, was scared by health care. They saw the costs, and they didn't like the way it was handled. They saw the symbolism of big government. His support seemed to be O.K. until health care. Then it fell away fast.
"He can recover. But he's got to take the middle again and he's got to get to the middle fast. Maybe he can hop on the Dole capital gains tax cut proposal. He's on the right side in opposing the proposals on the new accounting treatment for corporate stock options. But Senator Phil Gramm has picked up the flag on that. If the President succeeds, there's a chance the Republicans will get all the credit."
 
Neil Bluhm
President of the JMB Realty Corporation, a Chicago-based real estate company.
"I was a supporter and still am. From a business perspective, he's done a good job. Frankly, I was surprised at the midterm elections. They can't be based on the economy because interest rates are way down and the President and his advisers were instrumental in getting that done.
"I'm in real estate and it's certainly a lot better environment. When Clinton came into office, everyone felt the U.S. was a second-rate power to Japan and Europe. People don't feel that way now.
"It must be that the public is fed up with big government and there are elements of the Democratic Party which are not responsive to that mood. Corporate America has downsized. It's gotten lean and mean. Now government has got to do the same and the liberal wing of the Democratic Party has got to understand that."
 
Steven J. Green
Chief executive of the Astrum International Corporation, a holding company based in Miami.
"This Administration truly understands the global changes in the economy and has been better at promoting business abroad than any other Administration I've seen. When people voted in Bill Clinton, they said that the system didn't work and they wanted change. But Clinton hasn't given them the perception that that's happening.
"The Republicans will probably get some benefit for supporting a capital gains tax cut. Every businessman earning over $200,000 a year wants it and will become a Republican supporter for it. If so, it will be difficult for the President to gain the momentum in the business community that he deserves -- especially if you look at what he's done for business.
"But the President has two years. In politics, that's a long time. Clinton is the master of escape. He's capable of pulling out of a tailspin. He's wounded and knocked down. But the referee hasn't counted to 10 yet. So I wouldn't give up."
 
Alan Patricof
Chairman of Alan Patricof & Company, a New York venture capital company.
"I'm an active supporter of Bill Clinton. And, from the standpoint of small business, a lot of good things have been happening. The No. 1 thing for small business is capital, and the regulators have made it easier for banks to lend and have cut paperwork. The Small Business Administration has been rejuvenated and has a new attitude -- they talk about small businesses as 'customers.' Small entrepreneurial business is now represented at cabinet meetings.
"A lot has been happening that's positive. But it seems like the P.R. isn't getting out for the good stuff. That's disappointing. I'm not jumping ship. The President has the right instincts and, if he acted on them, we could have an interesting Presidency. Maybe we will begin to see government work better. That was the clear message of the midterm elections. Congress had better start working better regardless of who is in the White House."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Newest Hot Spot? The Middle East

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis 

 BODY:
AMERICANS finally have a chance to bet on the emerging and burgeoning stock markets of the Middle East, thanks to Foreign and Colonial. In October, the London-based fund management group created the first investment fund registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission and devoted to this neglected area of the world, with assistance from Nomura Securities International, Paine Webber and JW Securities.
The Foreign and Colonial Emerging Middle East Fund Inc., as it is called, is a peanut-sized closed-end fund with a total initial capitalization of just $42 million, only 22 percent of which is currently invested. It finished the week trading in New York at $14.125, slightly down from its initial offering price of $15 a share. 
 A handful of British-run Middle East investment funds are already traded in London, with more reportedly on the way. But this is the first time Americans have seen such a beast. Foreign and Colonial won't keep its exclusivity long, however. Merrill Lynch will soon launch a second S.E.C.-registered fund aiming at Middle Eastern and African emerging markets. And Alliance Capital, another New York money management firm, plans an off-shore Middle East fund not open to American investors.
The Middle East, a region encompassing 19 countries with 319 million people, has gone relatively unnoticed by the fund managers swarming over the world's other emerging markets.
But now the Middle East offers greater political stability, new privatization programs, accelerating economic growth and, of course, Yasir Arafat's wobbly peace deal with Israel.
"Frankly, I expect the peace process to be a bumpy ride," said Omar Masri, the Lebanese-born investment manager of Foreign and Colonial. "What is impressive is the economic progress these countries are making and the performance of their stock markets. Most Middle East countries aren't affected by what happens in Israel."
So far this year, the Egyptian stock market is up 150 percent and Mr. Masri reckons the party is far from over when an estimated $25 billion worth of privatizations are expected in Egypt in the next few years. And wealthy Egyptians hold some $120 billion abroad. "Supply and demand are both there," he notes.
Tunisia's market has risen 45 percent so far this year. Markets are up 35 percent in Morocco, up 26 percent in Oman, and up 5 percent in Jordan. The region's market losers are Turkey, which has fallen 45 percent so far, and Israel, which is down 35 percent.
Other money managers and investment advisors in New York are also warming to the Middle East's markets. Kathy Lynn O'Donnell, executive vice president of Chase Global Markets, is enthusiastic about Morocco, where her firm actively deals in commercial bank debt. "It's a very attractive market," she says.
Douglas Dooley of J.P. Morgan likes a Moroccan brewery called Brasseries du Maroc and Cimenterie d'Agadir, a cement producer. He also points out that the Middle East's financial scene will become even livelier next year when war-torn Lebanon reopens its stock market. "There is still strong human capital there and a lot of offshore wealth," he said.
A major difficulty with investing in the Middle East is that while 13 countries currently have stock markets, only six -- Egypt, Jordan, Israel, Turkey, Morocco and Tunisia -- are fully open to foreigners. Oman is partly open, with foreigners allowed to deal in six of its 90-odd quoted companies, although this is expected to increase soon.
But Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are firmly closed to noncitizens, while only foreign residents may trade on the Kuwait market. Bahrain limits foreigners to four stocks, all of them banks.
Mr. Masri has divided the open markets into two groups. He plans to invest 65 percent of his Foreign and Colonial fund in what he calls the core markets of Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, Jordan and Oman, reserving the remainder for Turkey and Israel, since American investors already have access to country funds specializing in these two markets.
Among the stocks he likes on Casablanca's Marche de la Criee, as the Moroccan stock market is called, is S.N.I., a recently privatized financial conglomerate. In Egypt, he would choose the Suez Cement Company, which accounts for a quarter of market capitalization, as well as the Misr hotel group, which has properties on the Red Sea, safely out of range of fundamentalist terrorists. In Oman, he is looking at a power plant and a flour mill.
Some day, of course, one conspicuously missing stock exchange will open up to foreigners. Three times a week, Iraqis gather in a Baghdad bank to trade shares in Iraq's private industries and banks. But until the Security Council lifts sanctions, a Keep Out sign hangs for the rest of the world's investors on the door of the Baghdad stock exchange.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Wild Gambling And Deception Bring Big Losses

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
GAMBLING, gambling.
We used to think that it was the stock market where the big betting went on. But if this year has proven anything, it is that the really big swingers were playing the interest rate game. 
 Add Orange County, Calif., to the list of big losers. It has lost $1.4 billion in its investment fund, or about 18 percent of the money invested with it. It did this by borrowing like crazy -- roughly $2 for every dollar invested in it -- and using both derivatives and ordinary securities to bet on falling interest rates. By ignoring the fact capital was vanishing, the fund was able to pay yields of more than 7 percent a year.
It is true that Orange County used, and abused derivatives -- most of them issued by Government agencies like Fannie Mae. But other ways to gamble were also used. The county fund borrowed money at floating interest rates and used the money to buy five-year Treasuries. This is known as "playing the spread," and works as long as short-term interest rates remain lower than the coupon on the bonds. Now, however, some of those trades are losing money every day, but the county won't close them out for fear of having to recognize the losses.
The county says all of the securities will eventually be worth par value. True enough, but if interest rates keep rising it is possible that billions of dollars worth of them will pay zero interest for years before they mature. The county is still betting big on falling interest rates and could lose billions more.
The simple fact is that the Orange Country treasurer was gambling with the public's money. He bragged about yield and treated market value as irrelevant. What is needed is not Government regulation of derivatives but a law requiring public agencies to tell the truth by reporting the market value of their portfolios and calculating total returns.
Orange County joins a long list of others whose gambling was uncovered only after it failed, ranging from Gibson Greeting Cards to Mellon Bank. Many of them held on for the first year of the bond bear market, denying the reality and hoping it would turn around. An important question for the bond market now is how many more gamblers still are sitting on their portfolios, hoping to be bailed out before the truth emerges.
Stock market investors may be tempted to regard all this with a certain smugness. After all, stock prices have generally held up while bond prices have tumbled. But it is worth asking if there are other surprises awaiting.
"I didn't read any of that until the bond market melted down," observes Chuck Clough, the chief equity strategist at Merrill Lynch, speaking of the reports of derivatives abuse by fixed-income investors. He wonders if "the same may be true of leverage in the stock market."
It is clear that derivatives have made it a lot easier to gamble in stocks with little money down and have made it possible to shift risks around in a seemingly endless chain. Just where the risks have ended up, and whether those risk-takers could stand a bear market, is not knowable now.
In the bond market, even those who saw the dangers, and largely avoided them, have been stunned by the carnage. "We thought the market would turn slowly," said Jim Midanek, a portfolio manager with Solon Asset Management. "But markets don't turn slowly. They turn viciously."

HEADLINE: Profile;
As the Rules Change in Mexico, He's a Quick Study

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico

 BODY:
HE had just pulled off the deal of the year, swiping a sweet $1 billion joint venture with AT&T out from under his competitors' noses -- and in the process reshaping the future of telecommunications in Mexico. So how did Dionisio Garza Medina, the 40-year-old chairman of the Alfa group and scion of one of Mexico's most prestigious business dynasties, celebrate his coup?
He wolfed down a turkey sandwich and a Diet Coke at the AT&T offices in Mexico City, where the announcement was made, before he boarded a private jet to Alfa's headquarters in Monterrey to get back to work. 
 Mr. Garza may come from an old-line industrial family, but he represents a new kind of Mexican executive. Though he is steeped in tradition and belongs to a family so powerful it has been called the Rockefellers of Mexico, he has no time for the three-hour lunches that characterized the Mexican business style for so long -- and in some circles, still do.
Since becoming Alfa's chairman and chief executive in April, he has quickly recognized that global competition and open borders have changed the rules of Mexican business. In his first few months in charge of the diverse conglomerate, he has cut corporate costs by 40 percent, taken two of the four divisions public -- and, most notably, signed the deal with AT&T on Nov. 9 to form a joint venture that is sure to get a big piece of Mexico's long-distance business in just over two years.
Considering the vast potential for growth here, that could be a big prize indeed. For each 100 people, there are just 8 phone lines (compared with, say, 55 in the United States and 16 in Argentina), making Mexico one of the world's most desirable telecommunications markets.
The right to provide long-distance service now belongs exclusively to Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, but its Government-protected monopoly lasts only until 1997. Then the Government will spread the business around, and Alfa and AT&T are certain to get a big chunk of it.
It may seem odd that AT&T would choose a company like Alfa, with no experience in telecommunications, but what it clearly wanted was a partner that knows Mexico well, that knows the regulatory ins and outs. And Mr. Garza convinced AT&T that Alfa could offer exactly that.
"I think he is going to turn out to be one of Mexico's great entrepreneurs," said Timothy George, a friend of Mr. Garza's who is an investment banker at Morgan Stanley and who made the initial contacts between Alfa and AT&T.
Tall and lanky, given to white shirts and red ties that set off his pale skin and owlish glasses, Mr. Garza seems an unlikely magnate. But as a seasoned hunter, he knows the value of camouflage, of being able to overtake his prey -- whether quail or competitor -- by surprise. And for him, the hunt is not just a sport.
"I don't hunt for killing," he said. He keeps no prize bucks or trophies on his office walls. "Everything I hunt," he said, "I eat."
THIS hunter has been busy at Alfa. His rapid-fire moves have shaken up a company so battered by a brutal economic restructuring and family hardships -- including a 1973 kidnapping that ended in the murder of a Garza patriarch -- that it was in danger of losing its place as a force in the Mexican economy.
"When I took over, there was a feeling that Alfa had to do something," Mr. Garza said in an interview at Alfa's plush headquarters in Garza Garcia, a suburb of the northern industrial city of Monterrey. (Though the "Garza" in the town's name has no connection to the family, the Garza influence can be seen in the 13,000 jobs Alfa's companies provide in Monterrey.)
Mr. Garza Medina is reluctant to give details of his personal life because of his fears about kidnapping, but he did speak freely about the conglomerate where he has worked since graduating from Stanford University in 1975 with a master's in industrial engineering.
In many ways, Alfa's history over the last 20 years is a concise version of the broader Mexican story. In 1973, with a leftist president in office and political tensions mounting, Alfa was part of the increasingly unpopular northern conservative establishment. That year, leftist guerrillas kidnapped and murdered the head of the family, his great-uncle Eugenio Garza Sada.
The murder shocked the business community, and chaos seemed imminent. When President Luis Echeverria visited Monterrey after the killing, the family took out newspaper ads blaming him for encouraging the crime with anticapitalist rhetoric.
The family soon broke up its holding company, the Monterrey Group, into four businesses that could be managed -- and protected -- more easily. Alfa, one of the four, grew so fast in the mid- to late-70's that it soon became Latin America's largest privately owned company, with $2.49 billion in sales last year. (Three of its divisions are steel, petrochemicals and prepared foods; the fourth includes new businesses that Alfa is nurturing.)
Success came back to haunt Alfa, though. The company, which had borrowed heavily, was hit hard in Mexico's 1982 debt crisis. With a debt surpassing $6 billion at one point, Alfa could not make its payments and had to go for a loan to the Government it had castigated a decade earlier. Even so, it ended up signing over 45 percent of its stock to foreign bank creditors.
The past 10 years have been spent rebuilding -- restructuring the debt and investing billions in plants and equipment. The chairman at the time, Bernardo Garza Sada, was Mr. Garza Medina's uncle.
When Mr. Garza Medina took over, directors asked, " 'Where are we going to go from now?' " he said. "But nobody had it clear what alternative we should pursue."
When the Government privatized Telmex in 1990, the board considered bidding for it. But recalling the disastrous growth of the 70's, the members decided it would be wiser to complete the restructuring and invest any available cash in the core companies.
But now it's branching out, and with the Mexican Government still deciding the terms of the long-distance concessions, several companies have already formed teams to go after them: MCI with Banamex, Mexico's largest bank, and Sprint with Iusacell.
UNTIL the very morning of the Alfa-AT&T announcement, most analysts expected AT&T to pick Telmex. But Victor A. Pelson, an AT&T executive vice president, said company lawyers were concerned because Southwestern Bell owns 10 percent of Telmex; that could cause problems with United States regulators because regional phone companies are barred from long distance.
In addition, at a Mexico City news conference after the announcement, Mr. Pelson said an important consideration was "the management styles, the chemistry among managers, the things that make a real partnership work." And he said he had found that with Alfa.
"Management styles" can be taken as code words for cultural differences involving everything from decision-making to lunch -- issues that have derailed other ventures. One spectacular example was this year's breakup of Vitro, a Monterrey glass conglomerate (also headed by a member of the Garza family), and Corning.
Mr. Garza said he tried from the beginning to avoid cultural clashes. Alfa already has 15 international partners, perhaps more than any other Mexican company, and has learned a lot from them.
When he began negotiations with AT&T in June, Mr. Garza said, he made several points clear. "First of all, I didn't want a divorce," he said. "We were flexible, of course, but there were certain guiding principles. One was very, very important: We want to be an active partner in the management of the company."
Considering that he was negotiating with one of the world's most technologically advanced telecommunications companies, and that he himself has no experience in the field (he doesn't even use a personal computer), that was a tough stand to take.
The venture they worked out will be 51 percent owned by Alfa (in accordance with a Mexican law that prohibits foreign companies from owning the majority of a telecommunications company), but the partners have equal say in everything.
The deal "was one of the smartest hits of the year by any Mexican company," said Gabriel Szekely, a consultant in Mexico City. "They have forced a number of medium-sized companies, like Banamex-MCI, to reconsider whether they can be effective competitors." Telmex itself has been hurt; its stock dropped more than 10 percent after the AT&T-Alfa deal, but has since rebounded slightly.
FOR Alfa, the venture represents a jumping-off point. If it is a success, Mr. Garza said, "we'll be able to double the size of the company in the next several years." He has tried to focus investments on a few businesses with great potential.
"Already, our portfolio is very complex," he said. "Adding this $100 million company here and another $200 million company there would just add to the complexity, and I don't think that's good."
Maria de los Angeles Pozas, a researcher at the Colegio de la Frontera, who has written a book about the Monterrey business community that focuses on the Garzas, said the ascension of Mr. Garza Medina to both top posts represents the full return of the family to the Alfa helm. Because of the debt crisis, she said, Alfa had to go outside for a while for professional managers. But now, she said, "the company is back in the hands of the family."
That family realizes more than ever the importance of performance over paternity. Besides his Stanford degree, Mr. Garza also holds an M.B.A. from Harvard. He worked his way up the ladder at Alfa, although not from the bottom rung, starting as an executive in training in 1975. His last stop before the top: president of Sigma, the food division, and overall vice chairman.
And now that he and his wife, Balbina, have three sons, he keeps that in mind when planning the future. "The first priority I have in my life outside of here is my family," he said. "At times my boys ask me: 'What am I going to do?' I say whatever you want, but if they want to do it here or in any other company, I don't know what their position is going to be in 20 years."
Taking Alfa's companies public has brought $250 million in fresh capital, but it also brings closer the day when the family loses control. "It's not that I won a beauty contest and was put here," he said. "It's not that the family can do this or that. We have to be careful, if we want to have investors in the company, to run it as professionally as possible."
But the Mexican traditions that have played so big a role in the family's growth are not about to disappear in Mexico's newly open economy.
"I always tell members of the board I have a brother who is a priest and he needs the company to be profitable so we can donate the money he needs to run his parish," Mr. Garza said. "Then I tell them, 'If I don't do well, my brother is going to fire me before you do.' "
 
Dionisio Garza
 
 Born: Jan. 6, 1954; Monterrey, Mexico.
 
 Car: Chauffeur-driven, bullet-proof '94 Grand Marquis.
 
 Ideal vacation: A week in Paris.
 
 Family: Wife, Balbina; three sons, aged 6 to 12.
 
 Recent reading: "The Art of War," by the ancient Chinese philosopher Sun Tzu.
 
 Computer: Doesn't use one.
