HEADLINE: State's Quality of Life Has Dropped Sharply in Last 10 Years, a Study Finds

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 4

 BODY:
The social well-being of Connecticut declined sharply during the state's economic recession, erasing a substantial advantage Connecticut held over the rest of the nation in the 1980's, according to a report by a Fordham University research group.
The report, "The Social State of Connecticut," is the first study of a state by the Institute for Innovation in Social Policy at Fordham, which produces an annual assessment of the nation's social well-being known as the Index of Social Health. 
 In the Connecticut study, as in its national index, the institute used Census material and other data on factors including infant mortality, child abuse, health costs, crime and income disparities to reduce social health to a single figure ranging from 0 to 100, called the social-health index.
In 1984, Connecticut's index was 61.8, nearly 20 points higher than the national index, the institute reported. But it began declining the next year and by 1992, the last year for which data were available, it stood at 40.9, barely higher than the national index.
"Connecticut did better for a longer period of time," said the institute's director, Marc L. Miringoff. "The major decline for the country began in the late 70's and bottomed out in the early 80's.
"Obviously, the economy and its deterioration, particularly in manufacturing jobs, has been a major cause."
The Connecticut report was commissioned by the Legislature and a foundation, the Graustein Memorial Fund, to provide an up-to-date picture of the state's social health, comparable with the economic data readily available.
Policy makers, Mr. Miringoff said, need an overview of several factors so they can direct the state's resources where they can have the greatest impact, and his goal is to produce annual indexes that will enable officials to measure their progress.
Future reports on Connecticut, however, will depend on whether the Legislature and the foundation continue their support.
Looking back to 1970, the institute found that Connecticut has made progress in some areas. The state's infant mortality rate has decreased, though it remains high in poor cities, and the birth rate among teen-agers was lower in 1992 than in 1970.
The suicide rate among young people had worsened only slightly and had declined in the last two years for which data were available. And while housing remained expensive, the report found, the cost of single-family houses compared with personal income was no higher in 1992 than in 1970.
Health-care costs, however, had nearly doubled since 1980, and most important, from 1988 on, not only were more people in Connecticut unemployed, but more were out of work for longer periods.
The strains on family income during that time were accompanied by a sharp increase in reports of child abuse and of crime, Mr. Miringoff said, mirroring similar increases across the country.
The report also noted a small decline in the state's high-school graduation rate over the entire period, at a time when a growing proportion of jobs require higher education, and a widening of the gap in income between the state's wealthiest communities and its poorest.
Mr. Miringoff said the report's data allow policy makers to see what factors tend to rise or fall with each other over time as they make spending decisions. "A well-targeted dollar could touch two or three problems," he said.
Noting the effects of the recession and a shift in the work force from high-paying factory jobs to lower-paying service jobs, he continued, "It's easier to get at some of these problems through jobs rather than counseling children, for example.
"I would see the creation of stable, real jobs to be the most important single thing that we can do."

HEADLINE: U.S. Senators Step to Plate

 BODY:
Fearing a devastating blow to Florida's economy with the possible loss of spring training, the state's two United States Senators have urged the new chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee to make baseball's antitrust exemption a priority when Congress reconvenes next month.
"We urge you to take quick action in January to address legislation to repeal the antitrust exemption so that baseball can return to the playing field even if the dispute continues off the field," Senator Connie Mack, a Republican, and Senator Bob Graham, a Democrat, wrote in a letter to Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah Friday. 
 Hatch co-sponsored unsuccessful legislation with Senator Howard Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, in the last session aimed at bringing an end to the work stoppage. It called for the removal of the exemption in labor matters if the owners unilaterally imposed new work rules.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 650 words

HEADLINE: Keeping Score on the Budget

 BODY:
Under Democratic and Republican leaders alike, the Congressional Budget Office has used techniques for estimating deficits that were trusted by legislators and outside professionals. Until now, the C.B.O. has not abused that trust. But a Republican notion called "dynamic scoring" threatens that healthy bipartisan tradition and the budget office's reputation for refusing to adopt scoring techniques whose only virtue was to yield estimates that politicians wanted to see.
Under the budget laws, the practice of scoring takes on a huge importance. Those laws prevent Congress from passing bills that add to the deficit. Republicans propose cutting taxes and the deficit. Ordinary accountants say they cannot do both. Their response is to change the accounting method. 
 Republican critics condemn existing scoring rules as "static," presumably because the word sounds stodgy compared to their idea, which they label "dynamic." Indeed, many of these critics accuse the budget office of assuming that a 10 percent cut in the tax rate on, say, gasoline reduces tax collections by 10 percent.
That would be static. It would also be inaccurate -- which is why Congressional staffs do no such thing. They routinely estimate the impact of tax cuts on individual behavior -- estimating, for example, how a cut in gas taxes would encourage people to drive more, buy more gasoline and, therefore, pay additional taxes that offset part of the impact of the initial rate cut. There is, then, nothing static about Congressional scoring rules.
What Congressional staffs do not do, but some Republican leaders want them to do, is assume that a cut in gasoline taxes could boost overall economic activity -- not just gasoline sales -- enough to generate waves of new tax revenue. The idea is to make tax cuts take on a Reaganesque magic, becoming at once a gift to taxpayers and the Federal Treasury.
Put aside the fact that such supply-side nostrums proved foolish in the 1980's. It is nonetheless proper to ask why the C.B.O. should rule out by assumption a link between tax cuts and aggregate economic activity. There are three good reasons.
First, dynamic scoring would solve a nonexistent problem. Budget office estimates of revenue after tax cuts -- such as President Reagan's -- have typically been too high; dynamic scoring would enlarge the error.
Second, the budget office projects deficits only five years into the future; few economists believe that tax cuts -- on gasoline, capital gains or anything else -- could lift a $6 trillion economy very much in such a short time.
But the biggest threat from dynamic scoring is political. Economists have not settled upon reliable ways to do dynamic scoring. Tracing the loop from tax cuts through economic activity back to revenue collection is fiendishly difficult. If the idea were adopted, then, the head of the budget office would have a free hand to pick a technique that serves a favored political agenda.
A tax cut on capital gains could be made to look like a cash machine -- even though most economists would estimate otherwise. A Democrat-controlled Congressional committee predicts that the capital gains tax cut proposed in the Republican "Contract With America" would reduce tax revenues by $56 billion over five years; an adviser to the House Republicans, using a self-serving version of dynamic scoring, says the cut will raise revenues by more than $125 billion over the same period.
There is a responsible course of action. The budget office should retain its current rules because they have worked well and because they are reasonably free of political taint. But it should keep an open mind: if outside experts settle upon a reliable way to do dynamic scoring, then the budget office should certainly revisit the option. That way the decision to cut taxes would be driven by professional merit, not Republican fantasies.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Wireless Bidders Jostle for Position

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Forget Sotheby's and Christie's. The biggest auction of all time will get under way on Monday morning in the basement of a Postal Service building a few blocks north of the Capitol.
No fast-talking auctioneer will be present, no gavel, no paintings by Picasso or diaries by Da Vinci. Instead, the bidding will occur amid the quiet hum of computers. And the prizes will be invisible and untouchable: 99 licenses to use the radio spectrum for "personal communication services," a new family of wireless telephone and data services. 
 No winners will be quickly apparent in the auction, in which the total of the winning bids is expected to be somewhere between $3 billion and $15 billion. The Federal Communications Commission, which has organized the huge sale, is preparing for the bidding to last two to three months. Would-be bidders were required to make refundable good-faith deposits that ran as high as $118 million; 23 companies and alliances did so.
Both the opportunities and the risks are enormous. The 10-year-old cellular telephone industry now has 16 million subscribers and is growing by more than 40 percent a year; the new licenses will ultimately make it possible to add at least three competing services in every city.
But the required investment and the uncertainties are huge. Building a new national wireless network is expected to cost billions of dollars, and the competition in wireless services will be far keener as the number of rivals climbs in each market.
The Sprint Corporation, which has formed an alliance with three big cable television companies, and the AT&T Corporation are likely to lead the bidding. Craig O. McCaw, the billionaire who sold his cellular telephone company to AT&T, will also be prominent, along with all the regional Bell telephone companies.
Nothing quite like this has ever occurred before. In July and October, the F.C.C. held three smaller auctions for licenses to operate paging and interactive television services. Those auctions brought bids of more than $1 billion, but the licenses going on sale now are far more valuable and the bidding process will be far more complex.
"This auction represents the largest one-time launching of a start-up industry in America's peacetime history," Reed E. Hundt, the commission's chairman, said. "We don't want to focus on getting every last nickel. What we want is to focus on a technique that gets people to show the color of their money as quickly and continuously as possible."
The companies have been preparing their strategies in great secrecy. Sprint, for example, will be submitting bids over encrypted telephone lines from a sealed "war room" at a secret location somewhere in the Kansas City area. Security is so tight that visitors are blindfolded when driven to the site, which is filled with computers and has a conference room and food stockpiles.
Companies will be confronted with an auction in which they will be allowed to bid simultaneously for licenses across the country and to shift bids from one location to another. Each will be watching the others, since each bidder's move will be posted electronically, and each will be able to feint and parry through the many rounds of bidding.
In Washington, the F.C.C. has built a war room of its own. It has 20 bidding booths, each with a computer and a printer; they will be monitored electronically from a monitoring room. In a separate, locked room, 10 "telemarketing" people will accept and verify bids by telephone from around the country.
Because of the perceived risks, stock prices have slipped for many of the companies that have said they will take part in the bidding. Sprint shares, for example, closed at $29 on Friday, down from $33 a share at the end of October; those of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, which has formed a bidding alliance with three other big cellular operators, have dropped to $49 from $52. Shares of the Pacific Telesis Group, the San Francisco-based Bell company that is expected to bid fiercely for California licenses, have dropped to $28 from $30.
Indeed, several major telecommunication companies have decided to remain on the sidelines. The MCI Communications Corporation and Time Warner Inc. each decided to offer wireless services by buying capacity wholesale from other companies. Electronic Data Systems, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, pulled back as well.
"This is one of the most complex business propositions to evaluate," said Joseph W. Cece, president of Cablevision Lightpath, a subsidiary of Cablevision Industries, which plans to bid on licenses in Boston and Cleveland. "Is this a cellular clone? Is this a replacement for local telephones? Depending on how you define it, you can come up with radically different business models and valuations."
F.C.C. economists decided that a conventional auction would not work for the license sale, because the value of each license is tied to the values of the others. Many companies want to assemble nationwide or large regional wireless systems, so they seek to bid with a particular package of properties in mind.
Beyond that, some companies may want to switch their bidding to different markets if the prices become too steep in the market where they started.
"The key issue here is the great degree of interdependency between the licenses," said Evan Kwerel, a senior economist at the F.C.C. who first proposed a simultaneous bidding approach.
A necessity for a successful auction would be to have the maximum amount of information available to each bidder. Simultaneous bidding over many rounds, Mr. Kwerel argued, would allow bidders to learn from the earlier bids of their rivals and change strategy quickly if needed.
Still, the process will take time. To give companies time to analyze the results of earlier rounds, the commission will hold only one or two rounds of bidding each day.
To keep the action moving, the commission has ruled that new bids must be at least 5 percent more than the previous ones. Companies must also bid on at least some licenses in every round to stay in the game.
What will make the process particularly intriguing is that the companies will be able to switch their bids from city to city. A company might devote most of its early bidding toward a license in Chicago and then surprise rivals by switching its bid to the New York market near the end of the auction.
Most participants caution that the first round of bidding on Monday will provide little real hint of the ultimate results. But investors are already concerned about the prices that companies will end up paying.
"Wall Street has been extremely cautious or has downgraded companies that filed for the P.C.S. spectrum plans, the concern being that the prices could get very expensive," Frederick W. Moran, a telecommunications analyst at Salomon Brothers, said.
Not to worry, said Gary Forsee, senior vice president of Sprint, who is coordinating the auction strategy for Sprint and its partners, Cox Enterprises, the Comcast Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc.
"The concerns about high costs are ill founded," he said. "These are rational players who are going to make rational business decisions."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 9, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about the Federal Government's auction of licenses for wireless telephone and data services misstated the number of companies and alliances that made deposits to qualify for the bidding. It was 30, not 23.

Chart: "Auction for the Airwaves"
 Today, the F.C.C. will hold the first of several auctions for licenses to offer wireless personal communications services, or P.C.S., that transmit voice, data and images over the air.
 
ROUND ONE: MAJOR TRADING AREAS -- 99 LICENSES
 Up for sale are two licenses in each of 51 regions that the F.C.C. has defined as "major trading areas." Each license covers a 30-megahertz swath of the radio band, roughly comparable to licenses for cellular telephones. Three licenses have been reserved for technical "pioneers"; the remaining 99 are open for auction. Bidders were required to make advance deposits based on the number of regions in which they may seek licenses.

These smaller licenses will be auctioned in several rounds beginning next year.

HEADLINE: Many Questions, but Too Late

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5

 BODY:
If anyone blew the whistle on Robert L. Citron, the Orange County treasurer who was forced to resign today, it was one of his biggest backers, Peer Swan.
Mr. Swan, president of the Irvine Ranch Water District Board, may have been the first of the roughly 170 local agency heads who invested $7.8 billion in the fund, to ask questions before the county disclosed last week that it faced an investment loss of $1.5 billion. In retrospect, he says, it was already too late. 
 "People here should have paid more attention," Mr. Swan said in an interview late last week. "We knew we were highly leveraged. But it had been a winning strategy for so long."
Indeed, it was not until October, months after interest rates began their sharp climb this year, that Mr. Swan began demanding details about the fund's liquidity and the precise impact of rising rates.
Worried that the rising rates were ravaging the portfolio, Mr. Swan, who says he voted for Mr. Citron in June, asked the county in late October to begin returning his $400 million investment in chunks of $50 million a week. Mr. Swan agreed to stop withdrawing the money in November when the county administrator agreed to scrutinize Mr. Citron's activities more closely and answer some questions. When those answers were not forthcoming, Mr. Swan asked to withdraw the remaining $300 million.
"We found out that some of the things Citron told us weren't the gospel," Mr. Swan said. "He had told us in October that the fund had more than $1.3 billion in cash and we found out it was more like $400 million."
That means Mr. Citron did not have enough cash on hand to live up to redemption policies required by law. Of the $7.8 billion pool, about $4.7 billion came from Orange County agencies, including 31 school districts, that are required to invest with the treasurer. The remaining $3.1 billion belonged to "discretionary" investors, including the Irvine water district. Others in this category included the Orange County sanitation, transportation and toll road agencies, and several city governments. By law, they are entitled to refunds of their entire principal within 30 days of a request.
Some financial experts say Mr. Swan and his fellow managers among the local districts should have put the brakes on Mr. Citron sooner. Enraptured by their high returns, they failed to heed public warnings by a handful of state lawmakers and outside experts about the dangers of the fund's aggressive approach, these experts believe.
"The 170 directors were hooked on a yearly fix from Citron that allowed them to finance projects that they otherwise would not have had the money for," said John Moorlach, a certified public accountant who tried to unseat Mr. Citron in a heated campaign in June. The risks of the fund's strategy, including its partial reliance on derivatives, was the central issue in the campaign.
Some state legislators had been calling for the resignation of Mr. Citron, who has not been available for comment since the loss was disclosed last week.
Mr. Citron leveraged $7.8 billion pooled by local agencies into an investment portfolio valued at about $20 billion by borrowing and investing heavily in high-risk securities tied to the prospects of lower interest rates. While the fund returned an average of 10 percent annually in the last 15 years, its investments lost value sharply this year as interest rates bounced up. Mr. Citron was forced to put up more collateral against borrowings, creating a liquidity problem.
Liquidity in the fund, according to Standard & Poor's, which put the county on its credit watch on Friday, had declined to $450 million by late November from $1.2 billion on Sept. 1. Mr. Swan estimates that the fund has as little as $320 million today because of calls for more collateral.
Mr. Swan said his request for a withdrawal was not motivated by an immediate need for the money. Instead, he merely intended it as a tool to pry the county into appointing an investors' committee to oversee management of the fund. "We talked with him about forming one since early in the year, after interest rates started to rise," said Mr. Swan, who is treasurer of the Pacific Scientific Company and sits on the board of the Southern California Bank.
Mr. Citron provided monthly reports on the asset value and interest earnings of the fund, but Mr. Swan said there was no way to tell, for example, that a third of the assets were tied to declining interest rates. In October he asked for details on the fund's liquidity, the interest it was paying on some holdings and the adequacy of its collateral.
"We knew he was leveraged two times," Mr. Swan said. "We were surprised that he had leveraged the portfolio up by almost three times."
At the same time, another investor, the Orange County sanitation district, pushed for a review committee. With $400 million in the fund, the sanitation district set aside $25,000, and prepared to bring in an outside consultant to study the damage of rising interest rates to the portfolio.
"The next thing we knew," Mr. Swan said, "the county administrative officer had stepped in to oversee Citron and had brought in an outside adviser and law firm." That action "gave us confidence that the problems would be taken care of."
Behind Mr. Swan's request was the fear that the treasurer intended to impose a penalty fee on investors who withdrew their funds. And last Tuesday, a week after Mr. Swan asked to withdraw, that is exactly what Mr. Citron's office did.
It imposed a 20 percent penalty, and asked investors not to withdraw. Most agreed, though they privately questioned the legality of such an action. Two days later, to stop rumors circulating in the municipal bond market that the fund faced a cash-flow crisis, Orange County announced the paper loss of $1.5 billion.
Mr. Citron could have hedged against rising interest rates in February to minimize the losses, Mr. Swan said, but he did not. "By the end of March, he was locked into his position," he said. "He had sold off some of the derivatives at a $6 million loss in March and taken heat for it in the campaign, so he couldn't get rid of any more."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Some Losses But Revival of Rally Is Seen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar declined against most leading currencies yesterday as dealers took profits after a monthlong rally.
But the dollar stopped short of falling though the critical level of 100 Japanese yen and held steady above 1.5710 German marks, which traders said indicated that the outlook for the dollar remained positive. 
 "It has been kind of quiet," said Lizbeth Goldberg, assistant vice president at Hypobank. "The dollar is just recuperating a little bit but the next move will be higher."
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 100.36 yen from 100.61 yen on Friday. It slipped to 1.5714 marks from 1.5798 marks.
Traders said the dollar would probably continue on an upward course that began early in November. The currency has been stronger since the United States entered the markets late in October to buy dollars for marks and yen. It was further bolstered when the Federal Reserve sharply raised short-term interest rates on Nov. 15.
Some investors are confident that inflation, which erodes the value of dollar-based assets like stocks and bonds, is being held in check. "That is why the dollar continues to rally," David Durst, vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company, said.
In New York trading yesterday, the market was focused on reports that Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen was planning to resign. Mr. Bentsen called the reports premature, but he stopped short of denying them outright. The decision to intervene in the currency markets is a task of the Treasury Department.
"Bentsen's resignation has been expected for a long time," Mr. Durst said. "But I don't think it will be viewed as negative."
After the markets closed in New York, firmer reports indicated that Mr. Bentsen would step down within a day or two, and would be replaced by Robert E. Rubin, head of the Administration's National Economic Council.
Dealers said that the British pound came under pressure as the House of Commons prepared to vote today on a proposed fuel tax. The vote was seen as a test of Prime Minister John Major's credibility, but was not a formal confidence vote.
"It is not that the Government is at risk of collapsing," said Amy Smith, an analyst at the consulting firm I.D.E.A. "But it would further damage Major's image and I don't think they want that political implication."
In New York trading, the pound fell to $1.5575 from $1.5596 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Panel on Trimming Programs Takes Aim at Social Security

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 --
The staff of the committee appointed by President Clinton to remedy imbalances in the Government's health and retirement programs proposed today three possible solutions that involve the politically unmentionable subject of Social Security.
One option would be to raise the normal retirement age to 70; another would accelerate previously scheduled increases in the retirement age to lift it to 67, and a third would raise the threshold for full benefits to age 68 in a way that the full effect would be felt only by people 40 years old or younger. The third option would also reduce benefits for the more affluent. 
 But it is not certain that the bipartisan, 32-member commission itself will accept any of these possible solutions in preparing its report for the President by Dec. 15. Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, and Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican, the two heads of the panel, are expected to produce their own package of recommendations this Friday. The commission's interim report in August concluded that current budgetary imbalances would mean that Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security would entirely consume the Federal budget by 2029 if the system were not changed.
The commission is scheduled to meet in open session on Friday to receive the panel's proposals, and on Dec. 14 it will conduct its final meeting before going out of business at the end of the year. Mr. Danforth and Mr. Kerrey are trying to muster the needed 20 votes to recommend one package to the President, a prospect that remains uncertain.
The goal of the commission is not to find ways to balance the budget, but to keep the section of the budget that goes to entitlement programs from growing above the 3 percent of the gross domestic product it now consumes. Medicare and Medicaid have been two of the fastest growing portions of the Federal budget. Social Security is currently in surplus, but it is projected to begin drawing down that surplus in 2012.
The commission is made up of 11 Republican and 11 Democratic members of Congress and 10 unelected members. One member is Representative Dick Armey of Texas, who has been elected Republican majority leader. He, like other Congressional leaders and President Clinton, has declared Social Security to be off the table when it comes to discussions about cutting Federal spending.

HEADLINE: BENTSEN IS POISED TO LEAVE CABINET, OFFICIALS CONFIRM

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen plans to announce his resignation this week, senior Administration officials said tonight, ending months of speculation about the tenure of the Cabinet's most prominent member.
Robert E. Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, will be nominated to replace Mr. Bentsen, the officials said. 
 Mr. Bentsen, 73, will not leave immediately, the officials said, although he may not stay until Mr. Rubin goes through the Senate confirmation process. If Mr. Bentsen leaves before then, Deputy Treasury Secretary Frank N. Newman would become the Acting Treasury Secretary.
Mr. Rubin, 57, is also a senior adviser to Mr. Clinton and a former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, the New York investment bank.
Administration officials said today that Mr. Bentsen, who represented Texas in the Senate from 1971 to 1993 before moving to the Treasury post, had told Mr. Clinton before Election Day that he was not prepared to stay in office through 1996 and believed that a replacement should be chosen before the next round of budget struggles begins in earnest this winter. The two men engaged in a series of discussions about the timing of Mr. Bentsen's departure.
The likely candidate to replace Mr. Rubin on the National Economic Council, Administration officials said tonight, is Erskine B. Bowles, the White House deputy chief of staff. A former investment banker in North Carolina, Mr. Bowles first came to work for the President as head of the Small Business Administration and recently moved to the White House.
Rumors of Mr. Bentsen's departure have swirled periodically for more than a year. Other speculation had Mr. Bentsen replacing Secretary of State Warren Christopher, although Mr. Bentsen never tried to feed or squash that rumor.
The speculation increased this fall when Mr. Bentsen bought a large house in Houston, where his children and grandchildren live. Former President George Bush lives in the same neighborhood.
Mr. Bentsen has long spoken to his associates of returning to Texas at the end of 1994, when the Senate term he gave up to take the job would have expired.
Even Administration officials accustomed to putting the best possible face on bad developments were unable to portray Mr. Bentsen's departure in a good light today. The resignation of one of the most prominent members of the Democratic Party's moderate wing would be a political setback for a President trying to stem the sense of drift that has followed last month's electoral drubbing.
"If you could only have one person on your side in an economic debate, most people would have chosen Secretary Bentsen," said Gene Sperling, a deputy assistant to the President for economic policy.
Mr. Bentsen also has more influence and experience in working with Congressional Republicans than any other senior Administration official. Unlike other Administration officials with experience in the House, like Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, Mr. Bentsen also served in the Senate, including working on the minority side when the Republicans controlled that chamber from 1980 to 1986.
Administration officials emphasized today that Mr. Bentsen was not leaving because of personal or policy differences with his colleagues. But Mr. Bentsen has expressed frustration to associates during the last two years about long and rambling meetings at the White House that seldom started on time.
Mr. Rubin is well known in currency markets and foreign capitals, two audiences that any Treasury Secretary must impress.
Officials said that Mr. Rubin would not retain his position as head of the National Economic Council, because of the council's role as an honest broker in interagency debates. His likely replacement as head of the council, Mr. Bowles, has a reputation within the Administration as a pro-business Democrat who likes to talk about the importance of entrepreneurship to the economy. "He fits kind of well into the Rubin-Bentsen mold," one Administration official said.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has an outside chance of beating out Mr. Bowles for the job.
Mr. Bentsen told reporters before a speech this afternoon on trade policy that the rising speculation about his departure during the last month was premature. "When I have more information, I'll let you know," he said.
Mr. Bentsen's press secretary, Joan Logue-Kinder, declined to comment today on Mr. Bentsen's recent discussions with the President. But she did say that "he has had a number of successes, and the main things that were of uppermost interest to him he has accomplished."
She cited Congressional approval of a global free-trade accord last week and a bill two months ago that will allow more interstate banking. She also cited Congressional approval last year of the President's budget plan and the North American Free Trade Agreement, which will gradually eliminate trade barriers with Canada and Mexico in the next decade.
By contrast, the next two years are likely to be much more difficult for whoever is the Treasury Secretary. Most economists, including those in the Administration, expect the Federal Reserve's interest-rate increases to begin slowing the economy next year, while Republican control of the House and Senate will make it much more difficult for the Administration to push through legislation.
Mr. Bentsen has tended to avoid partisan confrontations with Congressional Republicans. Mr. Rubin led the Administration's attacks this autumn on the Contract With America, the election platform used by many House Republicans.
People who know both men said that Mr. Rubin was less likely than Mr. Bentsen to defend the status quo. For instance, they said, Mr. Rubin is more likely to favor tax law changes than Mr. Bentsen, who wrote many of the current tax laws when he was chairman of the Finance Committee from 1987 until last year.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said, "Their politics are somewhat similar, but I think Rubin is more interested in innovation."
Mr. Bentsen has told associates in the past that he planned to leave Government and go back into business at the end of this year. He has never said what industry he might enter, but he made a fortune estimated at up to $70 million when he ran a Texas insurance company during the 1960's. He represented a south Texas district in the House from 1949 to 1955 and represented Texas in the Senate from 1971 until early last year.
Speculation about Mr. Bentsen's departure began late last year when several long-time aides, who had served him in the Senate and followed him to the Treasury, submitted their resignations within a few weeks of each other. Although the resignations appeared coincidental, they also reflected the officials' frustrations in dealing with the Treasury bureaucracy after years on a relatively small Senate staff.

HEADLINE: Republicans All for One, and the One Is Gingrich

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Representative Newt Gingrich was unanimously chosen today to be Speaker of the House by ecstatic Republicans chanting "Newt, Newt, Newt," and he told them that the way to get rid of bad Federal programs was simply not to provide any money for them.
Nominated for the post by Republicans who called him "a revolutionary" and a "visionary," Mr. Gingrich, a Georgian, talked for an hour about the America he would like to help fashion and the hard work ahead for the House. He gave his fellow Representatives an eight-item reading list that included titles as diverse as the Federalist Papers and Mary E. Boone's "Leadership and the Computer." 
He was occasionally overcome and had to pause because his boyhood ambition is one step from realization, awaiting a Jan. 4 House vote that is no more than a formality. Accepting the nomination from his majority party, Mr. Gingrich compared the gray, rainy day to March 4, 1933, when Franklin D. Roosevelt was inaugurated in the depths of the Depression and assured the nation, "We have nothing to fear but fear itself."
"I think we're in that tradition," he said. "I think we want to say to the nation that we have nothing to fear but fear itself, that we can reach out together as a family, all Americans, and we can dramatically improve our quality of life, the economic opportunity and the safety of virtually every American between now and the year 2000."
He reminded Republicans that while they had broken a 40-year tradition in winning control of the House, not since the 1920's had Republicans controlled the House for four years in a row. He said their work now would influence whether that achievement could be duplicated.
But as he concluded his speech in the ornate caucus room of the Cannon House Office Building, named for Joseph Cannon, the last Speaker who used, and ultimately lost, the degree of control he seeks to exert, Mr. Gingrich said:
"The real success isn't a Republican re-election. The real success isn't even a balanced budget. The real success is no law.
"The real success is the morning we wake up on a Monday and no child has been killed anywhere in America that weekend, and every child is going to a school their parents think is worth attending, and across the country there is a smaller, more customer-friendly Government doing what governments should do, and every American has a chance to create a job or find a job, and across the planet freedom is winning and civility and decency are driving barbarism out of our lives."
It was largely a day for oratory, and the only hint of new policy came when he discussed the work the Republicans would do on spending bills. He said they had the opportunity "to begin decisively changing the shape of the Government." He said it was not necessary to repeal the authority for specific programs: "We simply have to not pay for them."
He did not specify which programs or how deep a set of cuts he intended. Nor would Representative Bob Livingston of Louisiana, his choice to head the Appropriations Committee, who said of the impending cuts: "Don't be surprised if it's a lot. We have long knives."
After anointing him as the party's candidate for Speaker against Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democrats' minority leader, the Republican caucus elected Representative Dick Armey of Texas as its majority leader. Mr. Armey, who promised fast action on the party's "Contract With America," its campaign manifesto, also had no opposition.
Another Texan, Representative Tom DeLay, won a three-way race for the No. 3 position, that of majority whip. He got 119 votes to 80 for Representative Robert S. Walker of Pennsylvania and 28 for Representative Bill McCollum of Florida.
The only discouraging words of the day came from Democrats who held a news conference to denounce Republicans as mean-spirited for dismissing more than 3,000 white- and blue-collar employees on Capitol Hill and not giving them severance pay.
Representative David E. Bonior, Democrat of Michigan, calling Mr. Gingrich arrogant and hypocritical, said: "Why are you firing over 1,500 hard-working people less than a month before Christmas without even considering giving them their due compensation? Why are you firing an additional 1,800 people who are not political appointees, who are not partisan in any way, some of whom have worked here for both the Democrats and the Republicans the past 20 or 30 years?" They include janitors, clerks and carpenters, who owe their appointments to Democrats but can be replaced in the new regime.
He accused the Republicans of professing to care about working people but then showing no regard for their circumstance. "This is not a workers' agenda, it's a boss's agenda," he said.
Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, had no estimate of how much money was involved. "They may be re-hired, they may not be rehired," he said. "There is no assurance that anyone will be back. They don't know whether their agency is still going to exist, whether it will be someplace else, or whether Newt Gingrich might have some friends who need jobs that may be coming in and taking their employment. There is no protection."
At the Republican caucus, Mr. Gingrich was nominated by Representative Henry Bonilla of Texas, a former television newscaster and executive, who called on the Georgian to lead Republicans not only against the Democrats, but in "doing battle with the liberal media." He said Mr. Gingrich was "a visionary, a revolutionary, a believer in basic values."
Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut called him "the most visionary thinker in American politics today," the appropriate leader when "evolution is too slow and revolution is too costly."
In his speech, Mr. Gingrich at times resembled the history teacher he had been before going to Congress. He offered the reading list, half historical, half futuristic, with a couple of extra-credit supplements, saying, "I think ideas really matter."
"I think that a political party willing to learn will be more capable of delivering a better America than a political party that thinks it already knows it all," he added.
He, too, complained about the news media, saying his wife, Marianne, had "endured more from the media and from the process than anybody should have to, for me to be here." A spokesman for Mr. Gingrich said the Congressman meant that his wife, like many congressional wives, suffered when her husband was attacked in print.
Mr. Gingrich laid out an imposing agenda, saying that when the House meets on Jan. 4, it would be "the longest opening day in history," with votes on nine measures, starting with a bill that would impose on Congress the same laws covering working conditions and similar matters that apply to other Americans.
After the first 100 days, he said, the House would take three weeks off. He urged the Republican members to spend one week with their families and the other two with constituents, before returning to deal with the budget resolution and with spending bills.
And he promised to support efforts by Republican freshmen "to sell at least one office building." The building they have in mind is a 433,000-square-foot structure that the F.B.I. once used to store files. It is known as House annex No. 2, but it also bears the name of a former House minority leader who later became President: Gerald R. Ford.

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
Ascendance of an Improbable Leader -- Richard Keith Armey

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Here is how Newt Gingrich says someone can tell that a "revolution" is truly at hand. When he and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas had to leave an important meeting of Republicans on Friday, they left Representative Dick Armey and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi in charge.
Mr. Gingrich of Georgia, the next Speaker of the House, told this anecdote to a gathering of conservatives here, and the audience cheered wildly. 
 Mr. Armey, a 54-year-old former economics professor from Texas, is widely perceived as farther right and more hot-headed than Mr. Gingrich -- and as an improbable leader. He used to sleep in the House gym to save money; he has implied that Hillary Rodham Clinton was a Marxist, and, upon meeting her, he said, "The reports on your charm are overstated, and the reports on your wit are understated."
But today, Mr. Armey, whom the Almanac of American Politics dismissed as "hardly likely to be a power in the House," was crowned during a jubilant ceremony on Capitol Hill as the first Republican majority leader in 40 years.
Like Mr. Gingrich, Mr. Armey is eager to rise above his Dennis-the-Menace reputation and show that he can be constructive.
"We didn't win power; we gained responsibility," Mr. Armey told the sixth annual Conservative Leadership Conference on Saturday night. "We do not view ourselves as a temporary strike force. We view ourselves as a permanent presence."
Whether Republicans maintain that presence will depend in part on how Mr. Armey, who is beginning his sixth term in the House, conducts himself in the 104th Congress.
In an interview in his Capitol Hill office, Mr. Armey, a former marathon runner with a 6-foot-3-inch frame and a sunny demeanor, volunteered that his days of defiance were over.
Being a member of a "repressed minority" -- House Republicans -- had forced him to be uncharacteristically confrontational, he said. Those were the bad old days, when he did things like acidly hiss on the House floor to Democrats that "your President is just not important to us," a remark that disturbed even his fellow Republicans.
"I was just trying to fight for some turf to stand on," he explained.
Then he smiled. "Now I own the playing field."
As majority leader, he will serve as Mr. Gingrich's commander in the field. His first duty: within 100 days, to engineer votes on the 10 items in the "Contract With America," the Republican's campaign agenda, including a balanced budget amendment and term limits.
He calls the contract merely the "shakedown cruise of the counter-revolution," predicting a far more drastic paring down of Government once the Republican ship is under full sail.
He and Mr. Gingrich are expected to work well together. They are not personally close, but they share a similar background and many goals. Earlier this year, they fused their considerable powers of positive thinking to convert the Republican "minority mentality" into a "majority mentality." They forged the contract together -- sharing a deep commitment to such items as eliminating welfare payments to unwed teen-age mothers -- and helped usher in the new order on Nov. 8.
"They have managed to put aside two pretty formidable egos to form a very good working relationship," said Ed Gillespie, a spokesman for the House Republicans. "As Newt says, 'Armey put aside my ego, and I put aside Armey's.' "
As a public speaker, Mr. Armey appears less grandiose and less polished than Mr. Gingrich, but is more of an ideologue. And while Mr. Gingrich likes to theorize about the big picture -- renewing civilization, the future of the solar system -- Mr. Armey tends more toward the here and now. But their construct is the same: to transform the welfare state into what they call an opportunity society.
Although he is a central figure now in his party's establishment and was unchallenged for majority leader, Mr. Armey first came to Washington 10 years ago with the air of the citizen-legislator that the Republican contract promotes. Chairman of the economics department at North Texas State University in Denton, Tex., he was watching the House proceedings on C-Span one night in 1984 when he turned to his wife and said, "Honey, these people sound like a bunch of darn fools." She said, "Yeah, you could do that."
Beating the incumbent Democrat in his suburban Dallas district, Mr. Armey made news during his first term by sleeping on a cot in the House gym to save money. When evicted, he repaired to his office couch.
He now rents a house in Maryland, where he lives with his second wife, Susan. They have five grown children from previous marriages. He will use the limousine and driver that come with the job of majority leader only to get around Washington; to and from work, he will continue to drive his red pickup truck, which sports a "Jimmy Buffet for President" bumper sticker. He is an avid fisherman; among his angling companions is Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas. Mr. Thomas's wife, Virginia, is on Mr. Armey's staff.
The son of a grain dealer, Richard Keith Armey was born on July 7, 1940, and grew up in Cando, N.D. He was the first in his family to attend college, graduating from Jamestown College in Jamestown, N.D., and went on to earn an M.A. from the University of North Dakota and a Ph.D. in economics at the University of Oklahoma. He was raised in the Church of the Brethren and later became a Presbyterian. Today, he said, "I am officially Presbyterian, but I probably enjoy the Baptist Church more."
Like Mr. Gingrich, also a Baptist, he did not serve in the military. "I slotted in between Korea and Vietnam," Mr. Armey said. "I turned 18 in 1958 and registered in a small rural county in North Dakota. I never applied for a student deferment, but I ended up getting one. By the time I was 24, I had a wife and baby, and that was 1964. By that time, I think I was effectively out of the pool."
To Mr. Armey, America's chief problem is big government.
"Government is too big and in its excessive size does too much of the wrong thing in the wrong way," he said. "Fat weakens muscle." His most notable achievement as a legislator was writing a bill that depoliticized the process of shutting down obsolete military bases.
Although his role as majority leader requires him to represent his party, he makes no secret of his own conservative agenda.
During his first campaign in 1984, Mr. Armey pledged to phase out Social Security, still a long-term goal. And he wants to repeal the ban on assault weapons enacted as part of this year's crime bill, and the Brady law, which imposes a five-day delay on handgun purchases.
A strong opponent of abortion, he argued against including abortion coverage in any health care plan, saying, "Are we going to be so fem-centric that we're going to condone the self-indulgent conduct of the body of a woman who has already demonstrated" that she was "damned careless with it in the first place?"
He also favors amending the Constitution to allow for voluntary school prayer. In underscoring that prayer be voluntary, he said, "No child should be made to pray -- any more than a child should be made to sit through class with condom instruction."
He added, "We would like to experiment with prayer in schools now that we've had 30 years of your experiment with condom distribution."
Addressing the conservative meeting in Washington, Mr. Armey told the story of Charlie, a janitor he knew who was mentally retarded but kept his building clean and safe. When Congress increased the minimum wage "to make Charlie better off," Mr. Armey said, he was fired because his employer could not afford the higher wage. When Mr. Armey next saw him, Charlie was on welfare and using food stamps.
"That kind of compassion that beguiled the country into accepting a minimum wage and denied this man his dignity, his freedom and his fundamental, God-given right to work at a job commensurate with his abilities is very painful to watch," Mr. Armey said. "And I do not intend to watch that kind of misguided compassion during a Republican majority."

HEADLINE: Bethlehem Journal;
A City Prepares for Life After Steel

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 2

 BODY:
This is a city of caldrons and creches, of blast furnace fires at the steel plant and twinkling holiday lights, of grit-coated factory windows and impeccably kept 200-year-old homes.
But the fires that shaped the backbone of American cityscapes -- the mighty I-beams that went into Rockefeller Center and the Citicorp building, the Golden Gate Bridge and the George Washington Bridge, the Supreme Court building in Washington and the new stadium in Cleveland -- will soon be extinguished. 
 "No more furnaces here," said Curtis H. Barnette, the chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.
Bethlehem and steel have long been intertwined, much as Kentucky and bourbon, Wisconsin and cheese, Winston-Salem and cigarettes. But come next year at this time, Bethlehem Steel will no longer make steel in Bethlehem; it will not make jumbo beams anywhere at all. Here it will shape smaller beams from steel imported from Steelton, Pa., but the company will turn most of its attention to steel it makes in Indiana for cars and in Maryland for ships.
Left behind in Bethlehem will be a huge industrial carcass, a monochromatic, rust-brown horizon of columns and pipes, brick walls and tin roofs that was doomed by competition and declining demand.
Left behind, too, will be thousands of people who worked at the plant, many of them descendants of those who have worked there since the furnaces were turned on 90 years ago.
For these people, making steel has been flesh-baking, often terrifying work. But it pays well; the steelworkers earn $30,000 to $100,000 a year. It is also gloriously proud and male work.
"You felt you were doing important things," said Gary Ward, the president of Local 2592 of the United Steelworkers of America. "We built the infrastructure of America."
Guillermo Lopez Jr., a millwright at the plant whose father also worked for Bethlehem Steel, said he had noticed a plaque on a wall at Madison Square Garden. It said the steel came from Bethlehem. "It made my hair stand up," he said.
Mr. Ward said: "We're not going to do that anymore. Imports are. Mini-mills are. Bethlehem is getting out of it. It doesn't make sense."
But Mr. Barnette said the demand for the jumbo beams was shrinking even as competitors, notably foreigners and efficient mini-mills that make steel from scrap, muscled into the market. The result, he said, is a plunge in the price he gets for beams, to $356 a ton from $475 a ton in 18 months. Losses there and from earlier struggles in the long-ailing American steel industry resulted in $2.2 billion in losses for Bethlehem Steel in the first four years of the 1990's. With the industry rebounding, Mr. Barnette said that this year, at last, he expects a small profit.
The chief remnant of Bethlehem Steel that will remain in Bethlehem will be the city's tallest building, the company's 21-story headquarters on the North Side. But even there, the company has retrenched. It has taken in boarders, renting half the space to other companies.
Most people here seem conditioned to the company's withdrawal. From a World War II peak of 31,600, employment has been ebbing for years, to 3,600 now. Elizabeth Kovach, a company spokeswoman, said it would drop to 1,900 next year, when the last furnace goes cold.
Mayor Kenneth Smith said: "The community has been through the worst of it. It was a great way to grow in the 20th century. I don't think we're ever going to have anything that strong again. But I'm very respectful of their current decisions."
Mayor Smith is a moderate Republican and 1961 graduate of Lehigh University, the only other institution of note among the multiethnic neighborhoods and church steeples on the South Side. With the demise of the jumbo beams, he harbors some hope for the less polluting, less hazardous production of jelly beans by Just Born, a thriving confectioner with more than 200 employees here.
Just Born and other new businesses, along with the university, the smaller Moravian College in the heart of the North Side, tourism and well-heeled settlers from New York and New Jersey, have given the economy enough lift that Mr. Smith expects Bethlehem Steel's latest contraction to reduce the city's tax revenue by just 2.8 percent, or $970,000, in 1996, the year after the shutdown.
Getting by is one thing, however; getting a new identity is another. "There are groups that want industry, groups that want tourism and festivals, groups that like the conservation aspect," Carl F. DiCello, the city's development director, said.
And there is another school of thought shared mostly by some North Side historic preservationists who consider the 20th-century intrusion of steelmaking a blot on the image of the older, Moravian Bethlehem of Christmas lights.
The conflict boiled over last month when the fellow in charge of maintaining the North Side's standards of 18th-century urban decor wrote a letter to the steelworkers union, whose locals occupy a quite pedestrian brick building on the North Side.
He asked the union to remove the bright red jumbo beam, about 30 feet long, that it installed a decade ago as a monument to its members' work. The ensuing brouhaha was overwhelmingly pro-beam, so the order was withdrawn. "The beam will stay," Mayor Smith said. "It's a symbol to many people of what their fathers and grandfathers had come here for."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The huge steel plant in Bethlehem, Pa., employed more than 31,000 people during World War II. Next year the last furnace goes cold. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fund Head Resigns in California

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Under mounting pressure from state and county officials, Robert L. Citron, the manager of a public investment pool in Orange County, Calif., resigned as county treasurer after disclosing that his aggressive strategy caused $1.5 billion in potential losses for local governments, county officials announced today.
The announcement was made by Ernie Schneider, the chief administrative officer of Orange County, who also said the Securities and Exchange Commission had been gathering information during the weekend on the investment pool, made up of $7.8 billion from about 170 municipal agencies. 
 In Washington, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the S.E.C., said, "There is an ongoing investigation, and I can't comment on that."
The disclosure of Mr. Citron's resignation came at an emergency meeting of the Orange County Board of Supervisors, a panel of five elected officials who oversee the county government. Though the S.E.C. has little authority over county and state investment pools, which are not registered with the agency, it has the right to investigate whether any antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws have been violated.
In an unusually risky approach for a local government, Mr. Citron, who has been the county treasurer for 24 years, borrowed heavily to leverage the $7.8 billion in public funds into an investment portfolio valued at $20 billion.
For as much as a decade, Mr. Citron managed to generate returns of about 10 percent annually, in part by investing in volatile instruments known as derivatives, whose returns are linked to bonds, currencies and other securities and in this case were dependent on falling interest rates.
But the biggest problem this year was not the use of derivatives per se, but simply that Mr. Citron, using borrowed money, bet so heavily that interest rates would continue to fall.
When interest rates started rising in February, the fund's returns began to slide. And Mr. Citron was required to put up more cash as collateral to cover borrowings, leading to a liquidity problem that was disclosed last week.
The board of supervisors disclosed that management of the fund would be taken over by Matt Raabe, the county's assistant treasurer. In addition, Orange County last week hired Capital Market Risk Advisers Inc., a Wall Street advisory firm, which is scheduled to make recommendations by Dec. 15 about the best way to salvage the fund's losses.
In disclosing the resignation, the county released a letter from Mr. Citron. "After much thought and soul searching and with much regret, I have decided for the benefit of the county of Orange to resign from my elective office of Orange County treasurer-tax collector," he wrote. Mr. Citron has not made public comments since the loss was disclosed.
This week, Assemblyman Curt Pringle of Garden Grove in Orange County is expected to introduce state legislation that would restrict government officials from taking such risks with taxpayer money. It would also require that municipalities have a better sense of the value of their investments.
Separately, Moody's Investors Service said today that it was placing under review the ratings of the issuers that have funds invested in, or obligations secured by, the county's investment pool. Another credit rating agency, Standard & Poor's, put the county on its credit watch on Friday.
Some securities experts say the fund's losses boldly underline the need for tighter regulation of the municipal bond market. "This is a wake-up call to everyone in the muni market," said James Lynch of Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory in New York.
The S.E.C. chief disclosed that he had discussed the situation in Orange County with Gov. Pete Wilson of California. "I offered to work with his people in the state and to co-ordinate with the S.E.C. anything that he will be doing in the state," Mr. Levitt said.
He acknowledged that proving fraud could be difficult, particularly if the public agencies that invested in the fund did so willingly out of a desire to extract the largest possible return for their money.
The new Republican chairman of the House Banking Committee said today that he planned to look into the situation early next year after the Congress convenes.
"I expect a very serious review of the Orange County situation," said Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, who will take over as the committee's chairman in January. "These kinds of incidents underscore the need for public accountability."

HEADLINE: Bankers Trust and U.S. Set Pact On Disclosure of Derivatives' Risk

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
In the first big Government action against a seller of the financial instruments known as derivatives, the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday that it had reached a settlement with the Bankers Trust Company that requires the bank to increase the disclosure of risks its customers face.
At the same time, two other Federal agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, are expected to reach a joint settlement against Bankers Trust in the next few weeks. 
 Taken together, these actions will substantially expand the Government oversight of derivatives, which are financial instruments with a value linked to the performance of an underlying asset or index, like a Government bond, a stock or an index of stocks. The outline of new requirements for Bankers Trust could become a de facto standard for the entire industry.
Under the new guidelines, Bankers Trust will have to detail the risks of certain volatile derivatives before they are bought. After the purchase, the bank has to report the value of those derivatives to the customer every day. Before yesterday, the bank made such information available only if it was requested by the customer.
The derivatives market, which until now has been largely unregulated, has made headlines all year because of the sharp losses attributed to these complex financial instruments.
As interest rates fell in 1992 and 1993, many companies, mutual funds and investors sought to profit from the surging bond market by using derivatives along with other financial innovations like mortgage-backed securities and reverse repurchase agreements, a form of leverage.
When rates rose sharply this spring, some of these investors found they did not fully understand the risks of their complex strategies. A fund managed by Orange County, Calif., faces losses of at least $1.5 billion because it borrowed money to invest, in part, in a volatile form of derivatives known as inverse floaters, bonds with an interest rate that declines as other rates go up.
Bankers Trust has been among the nation's most prominent dealers of derivatives. Several companies, which mainly use derivatives to reduce the interest cost on money they borrow, suffered major losses on derivative deals with Bankers Trust after rates rose. The bank has been sued by the Procter & Gamble Company and the Gibson Greetings Inc. It settled with Gibson last month in an agreement that was seen as a loss for the bank.
The Federal Reserve's action is called a written agreement, the second-strictest form of disciplinary action, which is rarely applied to the nation's largest banks. Unlike the more common memoranda of understanding, written agreements, which essentially are formal promises by the bank to take certain actions, are made public and can be enforced in court.
In choosing a strong and public response, the Fed appears to be signalling that it has found disturbing practices at Bankers Trust, though it did not detail any specific rule violations in the agreement. The Fed also seems to be asserting that it has the power and the will to supervise derivatives activity of banks without new legislation covering the market from Congress.
"They want to send a message that there is no legislation needed, so they need to act in a determined way," said Michael Bradfield, former counsel to the Federal Reserve Board and now a lawyer with Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Washington.
Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who is set to become chairman of the House Banking Committee, praised the Federal Reserve's action.
"What's been established is a new standard for industry practices that by contract applies to Bankers Trust, but, in effect, could well apply to all banks and potentially all market participants," said Mr. Leach, who has proposed legislation of his own to establish a new derivatives regulatory agency.
The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission are negotiating a joint consent agreement with Bankers Trust, people familiar with those negotiations said. Such an agreement would probably include a promise by the bank to follow certain practices, similar to its agreement with the Fed. It may also agree to pay a fine.
Officials of both regulatory commissions declined to comment on any actions related to Bankers Trust. A Bankers Trust spokesman said the bank is cooperating with regulatory investigations, but declined to comment further.
It remains unclear, however, how much effect the new Government interest in derivatives will have on the business and whether the Government will choose to go further. Bankers Trust agreed to a variety of rules for improved disclosure related to the risks of derivatives, but it was not forced to pull back from any part of the market.
Charles S. Sanford, the chairman of Bankers Trust, said in an interview that the bank had decided to adopt more stringent standards to prevent further lawsuits by clients.
"No one ever likes to have dissatisfied customers," he said. "We don't think we did anything wrong before, but we are saying 'let's make sure we don't have any misunderstandings.' "
Still, all the agencies are taking a tougher stance than they did earlier this year, when they said the existing regulatory oversight of the derivative market was enough.
Mary L. Shapiro, chairwoman of the commodity futures commission, said today that the agency was reviewing the broad exemption it granted two years ago to swaps, the most common form of derivative. The agency is considering if it should regulate more closely derivatives activities by smaller institutions, municipalities or mutual funds.
Similarly, the S.E.C. appears close to asserting that some forms of derivatives are securities and therefore fall under its jurisdiction. Derivative dealers have argued that derivatives are private negotiated contracts with customers, not securities, which are defined as standardized financial instruments that can be easily traded.
In addition, the two commissions are negotiating with each other to divide the jurisdiction of derivatives between the two agencies, people familiar with those discussions said.
The Bankers Trust agreement with the Fed only applies to what the agreement calls leveraged derivatives, which are contracts that rise or fall in value at a more rapid rate than the underlying market. Leverage is used to take more risk in search of higher reward from investments. Bankers Trust said that at its peak, about 5 percent of its revenues came from such leveraged derivatives. Last year, about a third of the bank's profits came from all forms of derivatives.
The agreement represents a shift by Bankers Trust. When clients began complaining earlier this year, the bank in effect called them sore losers because they had bet incorrectly that interest rates would not rise. While the bank still insists that its descriptions of the terms of its deals were legally sufficient, it now says it needs to do more.
Under its agreement with the Fed, Bankers Trust said it would try to make sure its customers understand the nature and risks of any leveraged-derivative deal, providing each client with a long list of disclosure information. In the past, it only provided some information on request.
Similarly, for some of the most volatile derivative deals, Bankers Trust said it would now tell clients what their positions were worth each day instead of waiting for the customer to ask for that information.
Bankers Trust also agreed to several steps to improve its internal training, supervision and controls on leveraged derivatives. The bank has suspended six employees it says violated internal rules in connection with selling leveraged derivatives. In the agreement yesterday, it said it would notify the Fed if it returned these employees to their previous duties.
Gibson, Procter & Gamble and other customers have complained that their positions dropped in value farther and faster than they thought possible and that by the time they found out that they were losing money, it was too late to take action.
Bank stock analysts suggested that these restrictions, in fact, may not hurt Bankers Trust, in particular because all companies will be forced to follow them.
But some swap dealers complained that the rules are too tough and said that other banks would not comply unless forced.

HEADLINE: Union Official at Javits Center Is Accused of Having Mob Ties

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
In his first move to clean up the corruption that officials say has driven business away from the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, a special investigator yesterday accused a carpenters' union official of being a Mafia family's "acting agent" at the center.
The investigator, Kenneth Conboy, filed administrative charges to remove the official, Anthony D. Fiorini, the union's top representative at the center, on the grounds that he aided the Genovese crime family in its activities at the center for more than three years. While not specifying how Mr. Fiorini is to have helped the crime group, Mr. Conboy suggested that he had helped Mafia members and their associates find jobs at the center while discriminating against carpenters' union members. 
 Exhibitors have complained about shakedowns and excessive labor costs in dealing with the carpenters and other unions at the glass-enclosed center ever since it opened in 1986 as the city's major site for trade shows and fairs. In part because of the center's high labor bills, many trade-show organizers say they have moved their exhibitions to other cities -- a trend that tourism officials say has drained millions of dollars from New York's economy.
Aides to Mr. Conboy described yesterday's action as just the opening shot in a broad investigation into possible corruption in the carpenters' union, both at the Javits Center and elsewhere.
Mr. Conboy, a former Federal judge in Manhattan, also charged that Mr. Fiorini in 1984 and 1985 had physically threatened a union member who complained about illegal practices by union officials and had allowed a contractor to hire nonunion employees in violation of the union's collective bargaining contract.
Under a court order, Mr. Conboy was appointed in March to monitor the activities in the 30,000-member New York District Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners. His assignment was part of a settlement of a Federal civil racketeering suit brought against officials of the union in 1990 by the Justice Department. At that time, Federal prosecutors in Manhattan described the Javits Center as a hiring hall for mobsters and former convicts.
Mr. Fiorini, 34, who is the district council's representative at the Javits Center, did not return two telephone messages left for him yesterday at his office in the center at 34th Street and 11th Avenue.
Frederick W. Devine, the president of the district council, described Mr. Conboy's investigation as "a witch hunt by someone who is trying make a name for himself on the union dues of members." The court agreement requires the district council and the carpenters' international union to pay Mr. Conboy and his staff $80,000 a month until March 1997.
Mr. Devine said in an interview that Mr. Conboy had raised no objection to Mr. Fiorini's appointment in April when he notified him of his intention.
In a report in October, Mr. Conboy said the day-to-day hiring decisions at the center for some 100 carpenters who install and dismantle exhibits were made by Mr. Fiorini and Lenard J. Simon. Mr. Conboy asserted that both men had little experience as carpenters but had extensive connections to mobsters.
According to the report, Mr. Fiorini is a brother-in-law of Liborio Bellomo, the street boss of the Genovese crime family, and Mr. Simon is a brother-in-law of Ralph Coppola, a convicted arsonist with mob ties.
Mr. Devine said that Mr. Simon's job as a union representative ended in October after he helped negotiate a collective bargaining agreement with the center's management.
Mr. Conboy in his charges yesterday said that Mr. Fiorini referred "a small pool of favored individuals" for lucrative carpenter jobs at the center.
The complaint said that Mr. Fiorini since August 1991 was "the acting agent of the Genovese organized crime family of La Cosa Nostra at the Javits Center, and knowingly associated with members and associates of the Genovese crime family and other families of La Cosa Nostra, including Liborio (Barney) Bellomo and Ralph Coppola."
Asked about the charges that Mr. Fiorini was linked to organized-crime figures, Mr. Devine said, "If Conboy has proof he's a member of organized crime, why doesn't he take it to a government agency for prosecution?"
An administrative or civil hearing for Mr. Fiorini was set for Feb. 1. Mr. Conboy will in effect act as the prosecutor, and the charges will be heard by a three-member panel. The panel will consist of one member designated by Mr. Conboy and one by Mr. Fiorini, with those two appointees selecting the third.
The most stringent penalty the panel can impose is the expulsion of Mr. Fiorini from the union. Or it could recommend his removal as a union official.
Any action the panel takes can be appealed by Mr. Fiorini to Charles S. Haight Jr., the Federal District Court Judge in Manhattan, who approved the settlement between the union and the Justice Department.
Mr. Fiorini can remain in his post at the center until the charges are resolved.

HEADLINE: El Salvador Suffers Split Among Left

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Five years ago, the Salvadoran guerrilla movement carried out a military offensive with such discipline and organization that it ultimately forced the Government to accept many of its demands.
But in its new incarnation as a political party, the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front has become so splintered by animosities and differences over fundamental goals that it seems unlikely to survive the peace, many of its most important leaders say. 
 While the front's leaders squabble and much of its membership loses heart, its opponents on the right retain control of the Government and now find themselves in position to whittle away at the agreements made to end the war.
"There no longer is a Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front," said Joaquin Villalobos, leader of one of the five leftist rebel groups that came together to form the front in the early 1980's.
Facundo Guardado, a renowned guerrilla commander and now a prominent member of another group, said, "We are people who shared something that is over."
To end the civil war, the Salvadoran Government, under pressure from the United States, its principal supporter, agreed to a number of fundamental reforms in peace accords that took effect in 1992. The guerrillas then turned in their weapons in exchange for promises that they could take part in electoral politics.
It was in the transition from a rebel coalition to a political party that the former guerrillas seem to have foundered.
While the coalition always presented itself as unified, its leaders now say that it was a common enemy rather than shared ideology that held it together.
The divisions became evident in the election campaign this year. A dispirited and disorganized left saw the rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance, or Arena, retain control of the presidency and legislature and increase its number of local offices. The center party, the Christian Democrats, also lost heavily, leaving the right with much more power than before.
In trying to regroup, the left has not been able to agree on political or economic programs. The former guerrilla commander, Mr. Villalobos, now completely rejects socialism and is trying to take his group into a coalition with center and even rightist organizations.
One of the other groups retains the name Salvadoran Communist Party, and looks forward to making the government socialist. In between the extremes, other former rebels admit that they are still searching for policies on which they can agree, and which will be acceptable to voters.
The conflict within the Salvadoran left mirrors the turmoil in the left throughout Central America as socialism and rigid party structures are called into question.
In Guatemala, leaders of the region's remaining armed insurgency are negotiating a peace with the Government after three decades of war. In Nicaragua, the Sandinista party is staggering with a conflict between hard-liners like former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra and reformers.
In El Salvador, the debate has become quite personal, with leaders of the groups calling each other traitors to the causes for which they fought during the war.
Many members of the Marti Front find it frustrating that having achieved such profound changes in El Salvador's political system, the front is now in too much disarray to take advantage of them.
Looking back over what they achieved in the negotiations ending the civil war, Mr. Guardado said: "We forced the military out of politics. We've started agrarian reform. We made them reform the Constitution, the police, the judicial system, and even make elections much more fair."
But, he added, all of this is still incomplete, and could be reversed because, as he put it, "the left has come apart."
In coming apart, the Marti Front has left many angry dissidents who assert that while leftist leaders quarrel, Arena will be able to undo the reforms it accepted when it was confronted by a rebel army.
"Arena only gave in because it was forced to by a powerful left," said Horacio Castellanos, the editor of a new newspaper staffed in part by former members of the Marti Front.
"Now that the political opposition is tearing itself to pieces, there is very little outside control over Arena," Mr. Castellanos said.
Indeed, influential members of Arena contend that it is resistance from the less extreme members of the party, rather than pressure from the left, that is obliging the Government to honor the promises that ended the war.
