HEADLINE: Homes Data Help Push Bonds Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday amid revived investor concern over continuing strong growth that could accelerate inflation. Municipal bond prices outperformed government securities despite the potential $1.5 billion loss reported last week by Orange County, Calif.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell about 6/32 to 95 7/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.92 percent from 7.91 percent on Friday. 
 A report that showed a 1.3 percent surge in the sales of new homes in October weighed down Government securities. The Commerce Department report suggested that six increases in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve have not pushed mortgage rates high enough to slow the housing industry.
Prices of short-term Treasury bills fell sharply yesterday in anticipation of an interest rate increase. Bill rates were up an average 15 basis points in secondary market trading. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
At its regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the Treasury saw rates jump to their highest levels since early 1991.
In the municipal market, analysts continued to weigh the impact of the Orange County investment fund's troubles. Yesterday's trading offered few clues.
Robert J. Froehlich, director of research at Van Kampen & Merritt, said the market was waiting for more details to be released after an emergency meeting of the county's board of supervisors .
Late yesterday, the resignation of the Orange County treasurer, Robert L. Citron, was announced.
Mr. Froehlich noted that so far the two largest participants in the county's investment fund, the transportation and water agencies, have both agreed to stay in the fund. "If there is a mass defection," he said, "then those paper losses will turn to actual losses." The county's $7.8 billion investment pool represents contributions from 170 municipal agencies.
Of the $7.8 billion, approximately $4.7 billion is from Orange County agencies required to invest their money with the treasurer, including the school districts. The remaining $3.1 billion is from voluntary or "discretionary" investors, including the county transportation, toll road and sanitation agencies, as well as cities like Irvine and Huntington Beach. The money borrowed by the school districts is also part of the discretionary portion.
James Lynch of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, said: "Right now potential sellers of these bonds will hesitate to sell because they don't know how it will all unfold and are afraid they will sell too cheap. Buyers hesitated because they want to be sure they are buying at the lowest price."
Peter B. Coffin, head of an investment advisory firm with the same name in Boston, said there was not a lot of activity for Orange County bonds, but he said the situation could give many retail traders an excuse to sell other issues.
Elsewhere, traders said South Africa was expected to sell its first post-apartheid bond issue in international markets early this week.
The Government plans to sell $500 million in five-year global notes through a group led by two investment banks, Goldman, Sachs & Company and the Swiss Bank Corporation.

HEADLINE: Light Trucks' Sales Lift Auto Makers' Records

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The sound of breaking records has itself become something of a broken record in Motown, as, month after month, sales of light trucks have topped past performances.
November was no exception, the auto makers reported today. All three domestic auto makers set November records for sales of pickups, mini-vans, and sport utility vehicles. The General Motors Corporation sold 167,687 light trucks in the United States during the month -- 13 percent more than its previous record November, which was in 1978. 
 With one month to go in 1994, the auto makers have already sold more trucks than they sold in all of 1993. And several auto makers, including the Honda Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Corporation, reported that they had already surpassed their total 1993 sales of cars and trucks.
For the industry, sales climbed 5.4 percent over a strong November last year, to 1.16 million. While car sales edged up 1.4 percent, to 665,187, light truck sales rose 11.2 percent, to 501,428.
In sum, the auto makers appeared on track to sell more than 15 million vehicles this year, for the first time since 1988, when they sold 15.5 million. In 1993, they sold 13.9 million. The industry's best sales year was 1986 when it sold more than 16 million cars and light-trucks.
"Sales were better than we thought," said David M. Garrity, auto industry analyst for Smith Barney in New York. "I was very much impressed with what the Big Three were able to do."
In particular, Mr. Garrity said, he had expected G.M. to suffer in the month because of truck shortages. That it did not, he said, may indicate that G.M. has worked out some of the components-supply problems that have been dogging it.
Not that dealers are happy with their inventories. Indeed, the auto industry's second-ranked broken record for 1994 would have to be dealers' lamentations on this subject. "We can't get enough to sell," said Tom Ward, general sales manager at Main Motor Sales in Anoka, Minn. "It's not just me, either. There's a shortage in general, and more buyers than product."
Mr. Ward sells Cadillacs, Geos, and Chevrolets. He said he has not received a single 1995 Cavalier subcompact in two months, and he usually sells up to 15 of them monthly. G.M. has had trouble increasing production at the Lordstown, Ohio, plant that makes the car.
But, he said, the shortages have helped him sell some cars customers normally spurn, like Chevy's rear-wheel-drive Caprice sedan.
But some dealers worried that interest rates were beginning to bite into sales. "Truck sales are up, but the interest-rate increase hurt our new-car sales," said Glenn Gardner, vice president and general manager of Rice & Holman Ford in Mount Laurel, N.J. "They started strong, but new car sales went soft in the last two weeks of the month," after the Fed raised short-term interest rates by three-quarters of a point.
Industry officials and analysts remained divided on the effect of rising interest rates.
Thomas J. Osborn, the director of sales and marketing operations planning for the Chrysler Corporation, said that rates would have to climb much higher, perhaps into the teens, before they would begin to cut into sales. But Joel Pitcoff, the Ford Motor Company's market analysis manager, said that some people might be buying now to avoid paying higher rates later.
"Some of the apparent strength may be pull-ahead from people who expect interest rates to continue to go up," Mr. Pitcoff said.
Mr. Garrity argued that banks' eagerness to make loans would cause them to continue offering good deals to consumers, like letting them borrow with less money down. Further, he pointed out, consumer confidence, like the employment rate, remains strong.
The seasonally adjusted selling rate for all cars in the month was 8.9 million, compared to 8.7 million in November a year ago, and 8.8 million in October. The rate for trucks was 6.6 million, compared to 5.9 last year, and 6.5 in October.
Ford said today that it intended to continue reporting sales on the third working day of the month. G.M. has announced that, starting Feb. 1, it would report sales on the first day of the month, and Chrysler has said it would follow G.M.'s lead.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "U.S. Vehicle Sales in November" shows rates for all vehicles sold in the U.S., Car and Truck sales in the U.S. and U.S. market share for cars and light trucks. (Sources: Company reports: Department of Commerce)

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Finding Rent Help After Brain Surgery

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Two brain surgeries saved Joyce B.'s life. Nothing, it seemed, could stave off her brush with financial ruin.
With a steady job, health insurance and grown children and friends for support, Ms. B. was in as good a position as any to confront her illness when it struck. But even before she had fully recovered from her second operation, she was thousands of dollars in debt and facing an eviction notice. 
 Her case, though bleak, is not uncommon, charity officials say. For many regular New Yorkers with regular jobs, the loss of income due to illness often means wrenching financial hardship.
In July 1993, Ms. B., 52, a widow with two children, went to her doctor complaining of excruciating headaches. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed an aneurysm on the left side of her brain. Further tests revealed a second one deeper in her brain.
Needing major surgery, she took a disability leave from her job as an assistant payroll manager at the Lord & Taylor department store on Fifth Avenue. Doctors at New York Hospital corrected the first aneurysm but were unable to reach the second. In October, she flew to Miami, where doctors at Jackson Memorial Hospital finished the job.
Until the second operation, Ms. B. had managed to survive on the twice-monthly state disability checks that amounted to barely a third of her salary. "I managed to maintain things up until October," she said. "That's when things started backing up on me."
Though insurance paid more than $50,000 for her operations, it did not cover other expenses, like X-rays and air fare to the hospital in Florida, which left her in debt. Her children helped pay the phone and utility bills, but the rent on her apartment in Corona, Queens, was left to her.
She had fallen three months behind when the first eviction notice came last December, just after she returned to work. "It came before I really put myself back together," she said.
She went to court to delay her eviction and then turned to friends for help in paying her creditors.
"My friends gave me enough to satisfy them," she said. "But I was already in arrears and I had to worry about that and about paying back my friends." Ms. B. applied for government help, but her salary made her ineligible.
She struggled for another six months. Last July, nearly overcome with hopelessness, she called the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of the charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. "To be honest, I didn't think there would be anybody out there to help me," she said. "But I was at the point of desperation. I thought I would ask, and if they said no, they said no."
She reached Judith Milone, who handles rent-assistance appeals for the federation. "Her situation was so compelling, to have gone through two brain surgeries," Ms. Milone said. "But she is really quite typical. Most of the people we help are working people who lose time at work either because of illness or stretches of unemployment." Ms. Milone asked Ms. B. to submit proof of her situation.
"Taking to Judy on the phone gave me a glimmer of hope," Ms. B. said. "And sure enough, it came through." A few weeks later, Ms. B. picked up a check for $830, enough to cover one month's rent and to give her time to get back on her feet.
"I have so much to be grateful for," she said. "After going through these two surgeries and surviving and then to seek help and be provided with it. We have a tendency to take so many things for granted. I had never been put in a situation like this before."
Ms. B. is still struggling to keep up with the rent and pay all of her debts, but she said she has a new-found optimism knowing that there are people willing to help. The Neediest Cases Fund collects donations for seven organizations that benefit struggling New Yorkers. The Times pays all the costs of running the appeal, now in its 83d year, so all contributions go directly to the charities.
Ms. Milone said she hopes Ms. B. gives New Yorkers the courage to ask for assistance. "I hope her story encourages other people to seek out the help they legitimately need," she said.

HEADLINE: Pension Gap Increases to $71 Billion

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The shortfall in money that companies set aside to pay for Americans' pensions climbed to $71 billion last year.
"Millions of Americans still are in danger of not getting their pensions," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said today. "Underfunding has gone up to $71 billion from $53 billion in 1992 and $27 billion in 1987." 
 The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said underfinanced single-employer pension plans at the end of 1993 had assets of just $316 billion to pay $387 billion in benefits.
The announcement came just four days after Congress approved legislation requiring companies with pension deficits to reduce their underfinancing by more than two-thirds within 15 years. Mr. Reich said President Clinton would sign the bill on Thursday.
"This is not yet a crisis," Mr. Reich said of the gap. "But if it had not been addressed, somewhere down the line it would have been another savings and loan crisis."
"With Congressional passage of the Administration's pension reforms, we can now begin to reverse the trend that posed a risk to workers and retirees, the pension insurance program and, ultimately, American taxpayers," he said.
Officials emphasized that the vast majority of plans covered by the guaranty corporation were fully financed, with assets of $603 billion to cover $518 billion in benefits.
But Mr. Reich, who is chairman of the Pension Benefit board of directors, said underfinancing is a serious problem affecting nearly eight million workers and retirees, primarily in the steel, auto, tire and airline industries.
About 75 percent of the underfinanced plans are sponsored by financially healthy companies, the agency said. But about $18 billion of the underfinancing is in plans covering about 1.2 million people that are sponsored by businesses with below- investment-grade bond ratings.
People in underfinanced plans are at risk because the Pension Benefit coverage is limited to just $30,681.84 this year, often less than the benefit promised. The annually adjusted payment will be $30,886.32 next year.
The agency said most of increase in underfinancing in 1993 was a result of low interest rates, which reduced pension plan earnings. But it added that even if rates had not fallen, underfinancing, which has grown over the last decade, would not have improved significantly.
"Pension underfunding has been chronic and persistent and will not go away by itself," said Martin Slate, the agency's executive director.
The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation guarantees basic pension benefits of 41 million American workers and retirees participating in about 66,000 plans.

HEADLINE: Sales of New Homes Rose 1.3% in October

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Despite higher borrowing costs, sales of new homes rose 1.3 percent in October, their fourth consecutive monthly increase, the Commerce Department said today.
The strong gain in sales, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 726,000, surprised many analysts who had expected a decline in sales. 
 Today's report included an upward revision in the September sales figure, to a 5.6 percent jump and a rate of 717,000. Previously, the Commerce Department said September sales had risen just 2.6 percent, to a rate of 703,000.
The report provided further evidence that the economy continues to be robust, defying efforts by the Federal Reserve to rein in growth with higher short-term interest rates.
"It suggests that the national economy is doing very well and that overall improvements in the economy are offsetting higher interest rates," said Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders.
The new-homes sales report said the only region where fewer homes were sold in October than in September was the Northeast, where they plunged 33 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 63,000. The Northeast is the smallest market of the four principal regions for which sales figures are compiled.
By contrast, sales jumped in the West by 14.4 percent in October, to a rate of 230,000 a year. In the Midwest, sales of new homes rose 8.3 percent, to a rate of 117,000, and in the South they gained three-tenths of 1 percent, to a rate of 316,000.
The pattern of strong sales for new homes was the same as for existing homes. The National Realtors Association said a week ago that sales of existing homes gained five-tenths of 1 percent in October, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.91 million.
The gains in housing, however, "won't continue indefinitely," Mr. Carliner of the builders' trade group said. "The trend from now on will be downward."
The housing market has shown great resilience in the face of the Fed's six increases in short-term interest rates this year. The increases have sharply pushed up mortgage rates.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said the average rate for a 30-year mortgage loan last week was 9.23 percent, down slightly from 9.25 percent a week earlier but still much higher than a year ago, when rates were below 7 percent.
Housing prices, however, have not accelerated.
The average sales price in October was down to $151,600 from $154,700 in September. The median sales price, at which half the homes sold were cheaper and half were more expensive, rose modestly to $130,500 from $129,300.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gasoline Prices Off on Signs A Cleaner Grade Won't Sell

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices fell again yesterday on concern that areas that had volunteered to use a cleaner grade of gasoline would balk at the higher costs.
Silver and lumber also declined, pushing the Commodity Research Bureau index down 0.68 point, to 227.03, a five-month low. 
 The Energy Department estimates that reformulated gasoline will cost at least 5 cents to 7 cents more a gallon than the usual grades.
So far, 28 counties in Pennsylvania and one in New York that had volunteered to use reformulated gasoline starting Jan. 1 now say they can meet air-quality standards without the new fuel, and traders are concerned more counties will follow.
"It's the uncertainty that hurts the markets," said Tom Knight, director manager of East Coast products trading at the Fina Oil and Chemical Company. "Who's to say in the anti-tax environment in the Northeast that this won't spread?"
Gasoline for January delivery fell 1.25 cents, to 49.36 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. So far, gasoline is down 12.5 percent over the last three trading sessions.
January crude oil fell 14 cents, to $16.85 a barrel, an 11-week low, while January heating oil gained 0.01 cent, to 47.01 cents a gallon.
On other commodity markets, silver dropped to a 12-month low as higher interest rates appear to be keeping inflation low and choking off demand from investors. Silver for March delivery fell 12 cents, to $4.645 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange, while February gold was unchanged at $379 an ounce.
Precious metals rallied in September amid concern that a stronger American economy would generate inflation. Since then, silver prices have fallen 19 percent as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to slow growth and as inflation failed to pick up.
Elsewhere, lumber fell its daily trading limit amid concern that rising interest rates will push up mortgage costs, slowing demand for new homes. Lumber for January delivery fell $10 to $317 for 1,000 board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Mortgage rates are currently at their highest in three years, with the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage from Freddie Mac at 9.23 percent last week.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
From the optimists' ball, a consensus that happy days are indeed ahead.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
AN increasingly optimistic outlook for growth in advertising spending brightened even further yesterday as two leading industry forecasters presented rosy predictions for 1995 and beyond.
At the opening session of the 22d annual Paine Webber media conference, Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at McCann-Erickson U.S.A. in New York, and John Perriss, chairman at Zenith Media Worldwide in London, increased their projections for total advertising spending in the United States and overseas. 
 The changes, which included higher final estimates for 1994 ad spending, reinforced data from the last nine months indicating that Madison Avenue's five years of recession might finally be ending.
"The economic climate will be very good for advertising again," Mr. Coen told an audience at the McGraw-Hill Building in Manhattan, because "there's a widening and broadening of demand across a lot of marketing categories" like appliances, automobiles, cigarettes, furniture and packaged foods.
"I am now convinced we are back on track," he added, "and advertising will grow faster than the economy for a decade." As one reason for his confidence, he cited signs that short-term promotional spending -- temporary retail price cuts, for instance -- was "drying up" in favor of long-term traditional ad spending.
And Mr. Perriss said: "Everywhere in the world we see key indicators, with one or two exceptions, moving favorably to advertising. I have been very pleasantly surprised."
The forecasts come after spending increases by big advertisers in fields like consumer electronics, drugs and computers, as well as robust revenue gains among national media like network television and magazines, and increases in classified-ad linage in local newspapers.
Advertising results are "going in the right direction and for the right reasons," said Alan J. Gottesman, the Paine Webber analyst who is the host of the media conference, which continues through Friday. "And it's going to be sustained," he added, referring to the strong growth.
The presentations by Mr. Coen and Mr. Perriss echoed each other -- something that was significant because Mr. Perriss usually sees the glass as half-empty while Mr. Coen sees it as half-full (or even three-quarters.)
"This is an historic year," Mr. Perriss said, laughing. "For the first time ever, I'm in danger of being more bullish than Bob Coen."
Mr. Coen for the second time increased his 1994 estimate for ad spending in the United States, to $149 billion, up 7.9 percent from $138.1 billion in 1993. In June he estimated 1994 domestic ad spending at $148 billion, and last December, at $146.8 billion.
National ad spending in large media outlets, Mr. Coen said, would end the year up 9.6 percent, compared with an increase in the projected gross domestic product of perhaps 6 percent. That would represent the largest such outpacing of economic growth by ad spending since 1982.
For 1995, he said, ad spending in the United States would total $159 billion, up 6.7 percent from his most recent 1994 estimate of $149 billion. In June, he forecast that 1995 ad spending would total $157.7 billion.
For 1994 ad spending overseas, Mr. Coen estimated a figure of $172.9 billion, up 7.2 percent from $161.3 billion in 1993. That would result in total worldwide spending this year of $321.9 billion, up 7.5 percent from $299.4 billion last year.
For 1995, Mr. Coen estimated ad spending overseas at $186.7 billion, up almost 8 percent from his most recent 1994 estimate of $172.9 billion; in June, his forecast for 1995 was $181.9 billion.
All this would result in total worldwide ad spending next year of $345.7 billion, up 7.4 percent from his recent 1994 estimate of $321.9 billion.
Mr. Perriss, who heads Zenith, the media services division of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., said his prediction for worldwide spending growth in 1994 represented his "most bullish forecast since 1988." He predicted a gain in major media of 6.4 percent, compared with the gain of 5.5 percent he forecast in July. (Mr. Perriss, like Mr. Coen, makes forecasts twice a year.)
And as long as Western nations are "determined to control inflation," Mr. Perriss added, "there is a growing optimism for world 'ad-spend,' a trend that continues through to 1997."
Declines in spending for advertising in Japan have bottomed out this year, he said, and spending next year in countries like China, Denmark, Germany, Greece, Ireland and Singapore should remain strong. Mr. Perriss mentioned Central and Eastern Europe, Latin America and Southeast Asia as areas of expected strong year-to-year gains over the next three years.
In the United States, according to Mr. Perriss, ad spending for major media will grow 4.7 percent in 1995 and 5.4 percent in 1996.

HEADLINE: Companies Rediscovering Indonesia

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia

 BODY:
General Motors is back in Indonesia, selling the Opel Vectra sedan made at its new assembly plant outside Jakarta, the first G.M. plant in Southeast Asia.
G.M. is one of many American companies that have discovered or rediscovered Indonesia, lured by the prospect of its 5 to 7 percent economic growth, abundant natural resources and a population of 200 million, the world's fourth largest. 
 The company first entered what is now Indonesia in 1930 and by the early 1960's controlled more than 40 percent of its modest automobile market. Then, in 1964, as Indonesia swung politically leftward, the auto maker and other American companies were forced to leave the country. Now it is starting over in a nation in which about 90 percent of the vehicles are Japanese.
"It's very easy to give up market share, but you pay in blood to get it back," said Leonard L. Brownfield, the president of the General Motors Indonesian venture. But he said G.M. had no choice but to come back. "It's not hard to see where all the hot economies are," he said.
Indonesia's commercial prospects were highlighted when President Clinton and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, here to attend an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting, announced on Nov. 16 the signing of 17 agreements involving about $40 billion worth of business for American companies in Indonesia. The United States Government has also designated Indonesia as one of 10 big emerging markets for promoting American exports.
Big energy projects and the development of transportation and communications represent particular short-term opportunities for investors. In the largest agreement announced during President Clinton's visit, Exxon will join Pertamina, the Indonesian national oil company, in developing a huge offshore natural gas field. Exxon's investment could exceed $35 billion.
Other American companies are aiming at Indonesia's emerging middle class of consumers. While they represent only 10 percent of the population, that is still more people than live in Australia.
Citibank recently opened the first drive-up automated teller machine in Indonesia. Amway has begun to peddle perfume and honey-glycerine soap. A crowded McDonald's in central Jakarta operates 24 hours a day. Procter & Gamble, Avon and Levi Strauss are also doing business here.
Indonesia, once chary of foreign investment, is now worried about losing out to China, Vietnam and other countries. So the Government has been gradually liberalizing laws that severely restricted foreign investment and imports. In June, it allowed foreign companies to own 100 percent of their businesses in Indonesia for the first 15 years. Previously, most foreign ventures required an Indonesian partner.
The list of other activities closed to foreigners is shrinking. In June, foreign companies were finally allowed to engage in the business of providing roads, telecommunications networks, ports and other public works. Still, enough restrictions remain to make Indonesia a daunting place to do business. For example, foreigners are not allowed to own retail stores. And Amway is hampered by a law that requires police permits for any gathering of five or more people. The company holds 1,200 such meetings a month with distributors and customers
Corruption is also said to be commonplace in Indonesia. Some American business executives say the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act passed by Congress, which prohibits American companies from paying bribes, has put them at a disadvantage in winning contracts. During Secretary Brown's visit, an American lawyer said he was involved in three cases in which American telecommunications companies had to pass up joining multinational consortiums because of the act's restrictions.
Indonesia's economy was dominated until recently by the petroleum industry, in which American companies like Mobil, Atlantic Richfield and Caltex, a joint venture of Chevron and Texaco, have long been active. And since 1967, Freeport- McMoran of New Orleans has extracted copper and gold from one of the world's largest mining operations in Irian Jaya.
But outside natural resources, American businesses have not been that active in Indonesia, though the ban on their activities here was lifted in 1967 after President Suharto took power.
"Indonesia for some reason has not been discovered by the American public and the business community," said Louis A. Clinton, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Indonesia and head of Freeport-McMoran's activities here.
Japan has been the most active investor in the manufacturing and consumer sectors. Indonesia is the largest recipient of Japanese foreign aid, receiving $1.15 billion in 1993. Much of that is thought to go toward contracts with Japanese companies. By contrast, American foreign aid to Indonesia amounted to only $94 million last year.
From 1967 through 1993, Indonesia's Government approved a total of $13.6 billion in direct foreign investment by Japanese companies. The next largest investor was Hong Kong, at $5.5 billion. Total investment approved from American companies was $3.3 billion.
These statistics from Indonesia's Investment Coordinating Board, however, do not reveal the extent of American investments because they omit sectors like oil and natural gas or banking. Moreover, analysts say only about 30 percent of approved investments are actually made.
But American investment in Indonesia is rising. Approved investment rose from $154 million in 1990 to $922 million in 1992 before falling back to $445 million last year.
Major opportunities lie in road building, electric power and telecommunications and other projects. Indonesia plans to spend more than $50 billion on these projects by the end of the decade.
The General Electric Company and Mission Energy, an affiliate of the SCE Corporation, are among the partners in a company that will build Indonesia's first privately owned power plant. California Energy will build, own and operate a geothermal energy power plant.
In telecommunications, AT&T already makes digital switches in Indonesia. Nynex, Bell Atlantic, Motorola and GM Hughes Electronics are working on other deals ranging from wireless to more conventional telephone services. With fewer than 2 phone lines per 100 people, one of the lowest ratios in Southeast Asia, Indonesia expects to install millions of lines by the end of the decade.
The public works projects and other expansion also provide opportunities for construction companies like Fluor Daniel Inc. of Irvine, Calif., which has been in Indonesia for nearly 25 years. And Indonesia has become a low-cost manufacturing base for shoemakers like Reebok and for the toy maker Mattel.
American banks and other financial institutions can benefit from the huge need for the financing of such projects. Maarten J. Hulshoff, chief executive and general manager of Citibank Indonesia, said all his bank's customers were "seriously planning to at least double capacity in the next three years -- you can understand what that means for the banking business."
In the automobile industry, car imports, which were banned until 1992, are now allowed, but with tariffs of 200 percent. An assembly plant is required for auto makers to compete in Indonesia, so they have set up 16 automobile plants to serve a market that can afford about 300,000 vehicles, an amount that one plant could produce.
And various Indonesian taxes, like import duties and luxury taxes, keep prices high. The Opel Vectra that General Motors began selling last week has a base price of about $45,000, twice its price in Europe.
Americans doing business here warn that Indonesia's commercial laws are not yet fully in place, which makes lobbying and personal contacts essential.
Sometimes those relationship reach up to the top. President Suharto's children control vast business empires that win many big Government contracts. American companies often end up with these companies as partners. Waste Management Inc. operates a chemical waste treatment and disposal site in partnership with Bimantara, a company controlled by one of the President's sons. General Motors' partner is the President's half brother.
"The legal system does not protect the businessman as they expect in the United States," said Harvey Goldstein, chairman of Harvest International, a company that advises on doing business in Indonesia. "The three most important factors in doing business are relationships, relationships, relationships."

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: Amy M. Spindler 

 BODY:

A Film Message
Designers are slowly learning how to wield their political clout, but few have had an opportunity to send a message more pointedly than Tracy Reese does with a cameo appearance in "White Man's Burden," a film produced by Quentin Tarantino and Lawrence Bender and expected to be released early next year. 
 Directed by Desmond Nakano and starring Harry Belafonte and John Travolta, the movie creates a world of societal reversal, in which whites are a mistreated minority. "Blacks are in control of big business," Ms. Reese said, "and Harry Belafonte treats whites as physically and mentally inferior, common stereotypes, the same kinds of things you hear today in people's private opinions."
His wealthy wife, played by Margaret Avery, plans a charity runway show to benefit poor white children, and Ms. Reese's Afrocentric clothes designed last fall for Magaschoni Inc. are the featured attraction, with Ms. Reese taking a bow at the end.
"The message of the movie is that everyone is equal," she said. "That's the moral of the story. We've heard it all before, but it's going to be interesting to see the roles played out this way."
 
Documenting an Innovator
Modern women may be, by now, taking for granted what Claire McCardell (1906-58) brought to fashion. But the fashion industry is in the throes of enshrining her.
On Wednesday, the Parsons School of Design will open its exhibition of her work, titled "Claire McCardell: Redefining Modernism."
"My message here is the cultural currency her clothes have is still extrememly high," said Kohle Yohannan, 26, the exhibition's curator, who was briefly married to Mary McFadden. "She packs a wallop for young people, and that is where popular culture really validates good design. Museum work is now becoming cross-polinated and cross-generational. My message will make sense to the teen-age hip-hop group right through to the Smithsonian."
The exhibition, at the Parsons exhibition gallery at 2 West 13th Street(Fifth Avenue), will run until Jan. 12 and includes family photos and McCardell's Coty award, along with the clothes she created that revolutionized American fashion in the 1940's and 50's.
Mr. Yohannan said he has collected pieces by McCardell never before seen in New York, many from her family's collection right from her closet in Frederick, Md., where she grew up. He is also working on a book about the designer.
The current interest in McCardell's work is due to the fact, Mr. Yohannan said, that "our economy is pointing toward fashion that makes sense." For instance, he said, McCardell always put pockets in her clothes, and hooks, eyes and zippers were "unapologetically placed." He added, "She used utilitarian fabrics before the war restrictions even asked for them."
 
Jewelry by Trigere
At her corner table at Le Cirque last week, Pauline Trigere was wearing more pieces of jewelry than there were flowers in the vases. Le Cirque is, after all, the home turf of many of her clients, who have waited patiently for her to resume business since she closed her fashion house 16 months ago after a throat operation. So what better place to display her jewelry collection?
She held up a ring, a little bird perched upright on her finger, a diamond dangling from its beak. "French men descend to kiss the hand," she said, demonstrating how well the bird behaves under those circumstances. "But American men pull your hand to their lips," and the bird becomes a dangerous object.
Ms. Trigere decided to create a small line of bibs made of gold chains to wear under suits, pretty sheer dickeys with jewels strewn across them and glittery pave bracelets, earrings and pins, partly because her clients still have plenty of the clothes she designed, she said.
"Maybe it's my mistake," she said. "They can still wear it after 15 years."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Club Owners' Labor Chief Resigns

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 5

 BODY:
No one knows when striking baseball players and the club owners will resolve their prolonged labor dispute, but if they ever reach a settlement, they'll do it without the man who served the past three years as management's chief labor executive.
They'll also apparently have to do it with something other than the owners' recent tax proposal. "We don't believe it provides a framework in which we likely will get an agreement," Donald Fehr said in his first public characterization of the owners' proposed luxury tax on payrolls. 
 Earlier in the day, Richard Ravitch, who in a life of diverse roles also ran for the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York, announced that he was resigning as president of the Players Relations Committee, effective with the expiration of his contract at the end of this month.
The move came as no surprise, given the increased role the owners have taken in these fruitless negotiations and the ill-fated history of the position Ravitch has held. Labor agreements have often been reached and work stoppages ended with the chief labor executive replaced by another member of management in the key negotiating role.
Ravitch's resignation and Fehr's view of the tax proposal came on a day when the union's executive board convened a three-day meeting at the Atlanta Merchandise Mart. Seventy-eight players, far more than are on the board, from 27 teams were on hand for the union's effort to formulate a counterproposal to present to the owners' negotiators in Rye Brook, N.Y., on Friday.
If the two sides do not have an agreement, or are not on their way to settling their differences, the owners will meet Dec. 15 in Chicago, where they would be expected to approve an impasse-implementation strategy.
Ravitch, 61 years old, was not at the last round of talks, held in Leesburg, Va., this past Tuesday and Wednesday. On Tuesday he attended a board meeting of Olympia & York, a real estate enterprise, then called Chuck O'Connor, the chief management labor lawyer, and was told nothing that required his presence was happening.
It was at an earlier bargaining session, Nov. 10 in Rye Brook, that John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox replaced Ravitch as the owners' point man in talks with the players. If it had not been obvious before then that Ravitch would not remain beyond expiration of his contract, it became obvious that day.
"I never expected this would last as long as it did," Ravitch said today by telephone from New York. "I never expected to stay more than three years. I have not wanted to leave sooner because I did not want in any way to impair efforts to make the necessary changes in baseball. We're hopefully down to the final stages of negotiations and no one can make the decisions but the owners. No one can make them on their behalf. They're sufficiently informed. I don't feel I'm letting them down in any way."
Fehr said he was not surprised at the development. "His contract was over and there seemed to be no realistic reason to think he would stay on," Fehr said. "The owners' position in these negotiations have been driven by the owners, not by their employees. My guess is it will have very little effect."
In today's union meeting, said a person who was there, Fehr told the players that Ravitch had not been a significant player for a long time.
Ravitch was hired under a $750,000-a-year contract in November 1991. His primary role was to develop a new economic system that the owners would try to sell to the players. But before he embarked on that venture, he joined Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers and Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox in May 1992 in trying to induce Commissioner Fay Vincent to relinquish his authority in labor matters.
In his first months in the job, Ravitch studied the history of baseball negotiations and concluded that commissioners had long undermined the owners' bargaining position.
Vincent, who had been instrumental in ending the owners' lockout in 1990, declined to budge on labor, only to be forced out of office by the owners in September 1992.
In a more positive move, perhaps his most impressive effort, Ravitch worked for more than a year and succeeded in getting the owners last January to adopt a plan under which they would share a greater portion of their revenue.
In a statement, Selig said that Ravitch had been "instrumental in helping the clubs recognize the seriousness of the economic problems of the industry and then create a solution to resolve those problems."
The revenue-sharing plan, however, was contingent on the players agreeing to a salary cap. It has been nearly six months since Ravitch presented the salary-cap proposal, but the only way the owners will get it is to implement it unilaterally.
Ravitch's tenure has had its rocky moments, aside from the inability to forge an agreement with the players. His relationship with Fehr became strained, and Ravitch and Selig, the acting commissioner, have not had a good relationship for much of their association.
It was not known whether they would have agreed to a contract extension, but it seemed to be a foregone conclusion that Ravitch would leave Dec. 31.
In a letter to Selig, Ravitch said personal and business reasons did not make it feasible for him to consider an extension.
"This was never anything more than a temporary assignment," Ravitch said. "I have other things I want to get on to."
He said he had no other job lined up. "One of the problems I had faced," he explained, "was I was so visible in this I couldn't talk to people about the future without it leaking. I'm looking at a whole series of options. I'm not going to rush to make decisions."
He ruled out politics. "When I ran for mayor and I got 5 percent of the vote, I decided I wasn't going to run for office again," he said.
At a news conference after the players' first session, players were asked about the possibility of union members going back to work in spring training even if the players remained on strike.
David Cone said he didn't think that would be a problem. But when asked whether he thought there would be repercussions against such players, the Kansas City pitcher said: "This isn't the place to talk about violence. Repercussions will come down the line. It won't necessarily be violence, but the stigma of knowing you were one of the guys who crossed the line, the stigma of knowing you're going to carry that label the rest of your career, maybe the rest of your life."

HEADLINE: Orange County, Calif., Makes Bankruptcy Filing

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Orange County, Calif., plagued by disastrous losses in its investment fund, announced today that it had filed for bankruptcy protection to keep nervous lenders and investors from draining the fund and compounding its problems.
The filing by Orange County, one of the wealthiest in the country, is by far the largest bankruptcy case involving a unit of government and the first involving a large American county. 
 The bankruptcy filing has implications far beyond the 187 school districts, cities and county units that have invested $7.8 billion in the fund and may have to make cutbacks in programs. It may also cause Wall Street firms to demand higher interest rates or to pull back on lending to local governments, particularly in California, which relies on its 58 counties to finance many of its government programs.
"Under the circumstances, filing for bankruptcy might be the most rational solution," said Peer Swan, president of the Irvine Ranch Water District, who asked to withdraw its $300 million from the fund last month. "Everyone needs to cool off. We needed to stop the clock."
The bankruptcy filing comes five days after Orange County officials disclosed that the fund faced $1.5 billion in losses because of an aggressive investment strategy used by Robert L. Citron, the county treasurer, who resigned on Monday. Mr. Citron depended on heavy borrowing and the purchase of financial instruments known as derivatives, whose returns were based on the performance of fixed-income securities and counted on interest rates to fall.
The fund's value started declining in February when interest rates began to climb.
According to investors in the fund, a bankruptcy filing became necessary after several Wall Street brokerage houses refused to renew $1.2 billion worth of short-term loans that came due today. The loans were part of the $12 billion borrowed by the fund to enable it to expand the $7.8 billion in public money into an investment portfolio valued as high as $20 billion.
County officials said after the filing that state services provided by the county, like health care programs and welfare, would continue, as well as fire and police protection and paramedic services. But some local agencies, including those for parks, libraries and possibly schools, face cutbacks, said David Kiff, a spokesman for Thomas F. Riley, chairman of the Orange County board of supervisors. Mr. Kiff said the state would also have a role in sorting out the fiscal situation.
One lawyer close to the situation, who spoke on condition of anonymity, predicted that agencies invested in the fund might also be forced to file for bankruptcy.
Bankruptcies by a municipality are extremely rare, according to officials at the National Association of Counties in Washington. Moreover, no government bankruptcy has ever involved as much money as is at stake in Orange County.
Mr. Riley emerged from a meeting late this afternoon to announce that the county was seeking protection under Chapter 9 of the Federal bankruptcy code so it could face its fiscal problems "in an orderly manner."
Rumors early in the day that Orange County was considering bankruptcy "threw the municipal bond market into chaos," said Robert Froehlich, director of research at Van Kampen Merritt in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill. While there was little activity in California bonds because of the uncertainty, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded bonds fell about a point in the early afternoon on reports that the county might file for bankruptcy. But the prices of the contracts recovered in late trading, with the average yield to maturity falling to 6.92 percent from 6.96 percent on Monday.
Moody's Investors Service Inc., the rating agency, said today that it would suspend ratings on all Orange County bonds other than those backed by a bond insurance company.
In an unusually risky strategy for a municipality, Mr. Citron borrowed money for the fund for years, often investing it in what are known as reverse repurchase agreements. Several brokerage houses lent Orange County about $12 billion by taking as collateral fixed-income securities that would be bought back at a specific date. Because of a general decline in the market, cashing in the $1.2 billion in fixed-income securities would result in a loss of about $70 million.
The county has some cash -- about $400 million in the fund, another $400 million in investments coming due within the year and at least $450 million in property taxes due before year-end, Mr. Swan said. But the county's fund would be hard-pressed to meet its obligations if all its lenders refused to roll over the repurchase agreements.
Experts in the field said Orange County would have been better off finding an alternative to outright bankruptcy, like establishing a supervisory body to oversee its investments.
"It makes little sense for a municipality to actually carry out a bankruptcy threat," James Spiotto, a municipal bankruptcy expert at Chapman & Cutler, a Chicago law firm, said before today's filing. "It reminds me of the scene in 'Blazing Saddles' where the guy puts the gun to his own head and says: 'Take one more step and I'll shoot.' "
Indeed, since 1937, shortly after the Federal law allowing local governments to file for bankruptcy was passed, fewer than 500 cases have been filed and many of the largest were never completed.
Nearly all the filings have involved tiny municipalities or districts, with the average default in cases through the 1970's less than $2 million. By far the biggest previous bankruptcy in which tax-exempt bonds were used was a project of the the Washington Public Power Supply System, which was unable to complete construction on two of five nuclear power plants. It defaulted on more than $2 billion in debt.
In 1991, Bridgeport, Conn., tried to enter bankruptcy protection but the case was dismissed when a Federal judge ruled that the city was able to pay its bills. Bridgeport had no more than $200 million in outstanding debt.
An attempt in 1991 by the school district in Richmond, Calif., was also dismissed before it could take effect, as was a 1983 case involving the San Jose, Calif., school district. In that case, teachers and other employees ended up renegotiating a salary contract. All government bodies in those cases continued to pay interest to bondholders.
The Orange County bankruptcy is expected to allow the investment fund to delay payments to the towns and school districts that have money in the fund. It may also free the fund from having to meet any margin calls from its Wall Street lenders, although there are general provisions in the bankruptcy code meant to exempt the type of short-term borrowing that the fund used.
Chapter 9 of the bankruptcy code is restricted to political subdivisions of a state. The law was tightened in October by the Bankruptcy Reform Act, which says such a filing would be legal only if authorized by a state law.
There are relatively few precedents regarding Chapter 9, said Bennett J. Murphy, a bankruptcy lawyer and partner in the Los Angeles firm of Latham & Watkins. "It is a portion of the bankruptcy code that is a mystery even to experienced bankruptcy lawyers," he said. "There is very little developed case law."

LENGTH: 1349 words

HEADLINE: Choice for Treasury Wins Praise As Clinton Loses Elder Statesman

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton today accepted the resignation of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, one of the few elder statesmen in the Administration, and said he would name as the successor Robert E. Rubin, a former investment banker who is an ally of Mr. Bentsen and now mediates economic policy at the White House.
For Mr. Clinton, the effect of Mr. Bentsen's departure is more political than economic, since Mr. Rubin has been at the center of the Administration's policy-making for two years as a quiet consensus-builder serving as chairman of the National Economic Council. [Man in the News, page B10.] 
 Indeed, in that White House role, the 56-year-old Mr. Rubin has been one of Mr. Bentsen's closest associates in pressing the Administration to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
But the loss of Mr. Bentsen, a Texan who served in the Senate for more than two decades before joining the Clinton Cabinet, deprives the President of one of his most experienced political hands, an adviser on issues that ranged far beyond economic policy. It also leaves the White House without one of its most persuasive voices on Capitol Hill, particularly with leaders of the new Republican majority there.
Wall Street and many in Congress praised the quick selection of Mr. Rubin, who has demonstrated effectiveness as head of the economic council, created by Mr. Clinton to act as an arbiter among competing interests in economic policy.
While steering clear of the limelight, Mr. Rubin has been a central figure in every economic initiative of the last two years, particularly in the battles over the North American Free Trade Agreement and most recently the world trade pact. He is not expected to encounter much opposition in Senate confirmation hearings early next year.
In an interview at his office today, Mr. Bentsen said he had long planned to return home to Houston at the end of his fourth Senate term, which would have expired next month had he not joined the Cabinet.
"It's a terrific time to be going out, with the economic numbers this good," said the Secretary, sitting amid photographs that trace his political career to the time he escorted President Harry S. Truman on a campaign swing through Texas.
Mr. Clinton's aides said that the 73-year-old Treasury Secretary first expressed a desire to resign in September and that the President was unable to persuade him then to remain.
Some also speculated that he had viewed the present as a narrow window in which to leave: the country's economic performance is strong; the new, Republican-controlled Congress has not yet convened and begun to battle with the White House over the Federal budget and the Republicans' proposed tax cuts for the middle class, and the Republican chairmen-designate on Capitol Hill have not yet been able to renew the Congressional investigations on the Whitewater affair, a matter in which a number of the Secretary's subordinates at Treasury have been under scrutiny.
"I loved having you here every day, and I'm really going to miss you," Mr. Clinton told Mr. Bentsen at a brief ceremony in the White House Rose Garden this morning.
The President said Mr. Bentsen had promised to be "part of a seasoned kitchen cabinet" that will allow the White House to retain some experienced voices. Another adviser experienced in the ways of Washington, David R. Gergen, left the White House as counselor to the President earlier this year and will quit his temporary post at the State Department at the end of this month.
"I don't think the President talked about a kitchen cabinet lightly," one White House aide said today.
Until Mr. Rubin is confirmed by the Senate, Deputy Treasury Secretary Frank N. Newman, formerly a top official at the Bank of America, will serve as Acting Secretary.
White House officials said tonight that Erskine B. Bowles, a deputy White House chief of staff, remained the leading candidate to succeed Mr. Rubin as the Administration's coordinator of economic policy.
But they said Mr. Clinton was reserving a final decision about whom to appoint to that job until later this month, when he hopes to fill a series of vacancies within the White House staff.
Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Rubin have much in common: Both made millions in the private sector, Mr. Bentsen in insurance, Mr. Rubin at the Wall Street investment firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company. Both are noted for their loyalty to Mr. Clinton. And early in the Administration both managed together to convince the bond market -- perhaps now the most important constituency on economic policy -- that the White House commitment to deficit reduction was real. That, in turn, kept interest rates low enough to allow the economic recovery to gain steam.
But they are personality opposites. The gregarious Mr. Bentsen commands any room he enters, with his gravelly voice and an ease that bespeaks a life of constant and usually successful campaigning. "The sun always shines on Bentsen," the Treasury Secretary said in the Rose Garden this morning.
Mr. Rubin is more soft-spoken, self-effacing and cerebral, an excellent listener and an intense but gracious questioner.
He cannot, however, match Mr. Bentsen in political shrewdness or in favors owed on Capitol Hill; almost no one could.
In recent months Mr. Clinton has consulted Mr. Bentsen on the timing of the military venture in Haiti and the decision to back away from the health care initiative, a proposal that Mr. Bentsen had warned early on was overambitious. And last month the President relied on him to save the day when the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade seemed headed to defeat in the Senate. In the end it was Mr. Bentsen, along with Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, who met the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, in the Watergate Hotel and cut the deal that saved the 124-nation accord.
In his new post, Mr. Rubin will be headed for many more encounters with Congressional Republicans than he has experienced in the past. He said recently, only half in jest, that he had spent his professional life getting to know Democrats in Congress -- he has long been a big fund-raiser for the Democratic Party -- and that the moment had come "to get to know a few more faces."
Mr. Bentsen said today that he expected Mr. Rubin to make the transition easily. "Anybody who can deal with the egos of Wall Street," he said, "can deal with the egos of Congress."
The departing Secretary also said he doubted that Mr. Rubin would make many changes at the Treasury Department, although others there said they suspected that the department's young chief of staff, Joshua L. Steiner, who burst into the limelight earlier this year when he disavowed his own diaries at a Congressional hearing on the Whitewater affair, might be moved aside.
Mr. Rubin will face some challenges that Mr. Bentsen was lucky enough to sidestep. He will have to lead the Administration through the political quicksand of debate on a middle-class tax cut advocated by the new Republican Congressional majority. Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Rubin have both been quick to say that Mr. Clinton can support such a cut only if a way is found to pay for it.
Attuned to the markets, Mr. Rubin is expected to hew to his reputation as a deficit hawk, warning that any increase in the budget deficit would lead to soaring interest rates. But many Democrats suspect that this position could come under attack from Mr. Clinton's political advisers as the 1996 election nears and pressure builds to show that the middle class is sharing in the prosperity reflected by economic statistics.
In the interview at his office today, Mr. Bentsen suggested that the Administration still had not learned how to communicate its economic successes to Americans. He said the rout of Democrats in the elections last month was a result of "a great product and a lousy sales pitch."
But in the next breath he said the country's biggest problem was that "middle-income job holders have not seen their incomes expanding."
"That," he concluded, "has to be addressed."

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
A Quiet Team Builder: Robert Edward Rubin

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The Administration's invisible man is coming out of the shadows.
For two years, Robert E. Rubin has been the glue holding together the Clinton economic team, working behind the scenes to build consensus, much as he did while amassing a fortune as co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the New York investment bank. 
 But if his selection today by President Clinton to become Treasury Secretary goes through, he will face a very different challenge, as the Administration's most prominent economic spokesman, its emissary to Congress and liaison to the financial world.
Associates of Mr. Rubin in New York and Washington today were full of praise for his intellect and policy acumen. Any doubts they expressed had to do with how well he will handle the increase in visibility.
One associate noted that during Mr. Rubin's 12 years on the management committee of Goldman, Sachs, he almost never testified before Congress or came to Washington to push the firm's agenda the way many leaders of Wall Street habitually did.
"He was uncomfortable; he hated it," said an associate of Mr. Rubin who insisted on anonymity.
Some business executives are wondering how he will make the transition. "Bob is strong on policy, has good ties to the business community, and the challenge now is going to be how skillful he will be as a spokesman and lobbyist," said Jerry Jasinowski, a former Commerce Department official in the Carter Administration who is now the president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
Yet people who know Mr. Rubin say that it is a mistake to equate his reticence with a lack of political skill. "People sometimes associate aggressive behavior and being vocal as being politically sophisticated, and that's not necessarily so," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative.
In an interview this afternoon, Mr. Rubin was characteristically cautious in describing his political experience before joining the Administration. "I did have a fair bit of experience and had a fair number of relationships going back a ways."
Members of Congress portray Mr. Rubin as much better connected. He gave informal advice over the years to a succession of prominent Democrats, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York. And with peak earnings at Goldman, Sachs in 1992 of $26.5 million, he was also one of the most important Democratic fund-raisers in New York City.
"Because he was very interested in politics, and because he was very generous, he met everybody," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York.
But Mr. Rubin has less experience in dealing with Republicans. Some liberal Democrats blame the pro-business policies that he has overseen for hurting their party in last month's elections.
Administration officials predicted that Mr. Rubin's appointment would not result in any immediately discernible shift in economic policies because he and Mr. Bentsen collaborated closely. "I don't really foresee changes," said Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency and the nation's top bank regulator. "We've all been part of a team."
Robert Edward Rubin was born in New York City on Aug. 29, 1938, and grew up in Miami Beach, the son of a real estate lawyer. He graduated from Harvard College, summa cum laude in economics, and spent three days at Harvard Law School before dropping out to study at the London School of Economics. He later graduated from Yale Law School and spent two years at the New York law firm Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton. He joined Goldman in 1966 and traded stocks, bonds, commodities and foreign currencies as he worked his way up through the ranks.
That experience may help in office. Mr. Bentsen sometimes upset financial markets and sent the value of the dollar plunging with off-the-cuff remarks about exchange rates. Mr. Rubin is likely to say less, said G. William Miller, who was a Treasury Secretary under President Jimmy Carter. "He tends to be cautious in public statements," Mr. Miller said. "He's not a gunslinger at all."
Mr. Rubin's success as an impartial mediator as the head of the National Economic Council in many ways mirrored his job as head of Goldman, Sachs. In the White House, Mr. Rubin held his personal ambition in check while promoting teamwork, qualities prized at Goldman.
As a member of Goldman's management committee and later one of its two co-chairmen, Mr. Rubin presided over a period of tremendous success that was tarred by one high-profile embarrassment.
In 1987, Robert M. Freeman, who succeeded Mr. Rubin as head of Goldman's prestigious risk arbitrage department, was charged with insider trading. The firm paid Mr. Freeman's legal expenses and weathered an extensive investigation, which ended in 1990, when Mr. Freeman pleaded guilty to one felony count of insider trading.
Although Mr. Rubin was responsible for overseeing Mr. Freeman's department, he was never implicated in the insider trading.
Mr. Rubin drew criticism just after his arrival in Washington when it was disclosed that he had sent farewell letters to hundreds of Goldman clients saying he was "looking forward to working with you in my new capacity." Critics maintained that the letters gave at least an appearance of a conflict of interest.
But Mr. Rubin said he was merely being polite, and his former colleagues say that during his time in the White House he has been scrupulous about keeping his distance from both the firm and its clients.
Mr. Rubin lives in a hotel here, frequently traveling to New York on weekends to visit his wife, Judy, who loves the city and has not wanted to move. He has two grown sons, one of whom plans to move to Washington in June when his wife becomes a clerk at the Supreme Court.
Mr. Rubin frequently works in his office from 7 A.M. until 9 P.M., and seldom goes on official trips.
At a news conference today, he said, "Last night my wife, Judy, and I had dinner and we talked about how serving in this Administration has not been an easy way of life for us -- it involved a lot of personal disruption -- but how it has been a great opportunity to work on many of the critical issues at an important moment in our country's history."

HEADLINE: Lima Journal;
In the Macho World of Peru, 8 Women Muscle In

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Two women are running for President and six for Vice President in elections early next year -- the first time in Peru that women have been selected as candidates for such high office.
No one expects the tickets with women on them to defeat President Alberto K. Fujimori, who the polls indicate is comfortably ahead as he seeks a second five-year term. But some Peruvians see the women's candidacies as a sign of progress in a country of 23 million where many people still think of women as the property of their husbands. 
 The surge in the nominations of women began with the feud this year between Mr. Fujimori and his now-estranged wife, Susana Higuchi, which led to her own short-lived campaign for the presidency.
"The reason we see so many women candidates in this race, especially for Vice President, is that there is a new notion among politicos in Peru that women are now more prone to vote for women candidates than in the past, and this idea is the direct result of Susana Higuchi's high-profile campaign as a woman," said Mirko Lauer, a political analyst.
Before Ms. Higuchi was forced to drop out of the race in October because she lacked the required signatures, local polls indicated 10 percent support for her, 41 percent for Mr. Fujimori and 23.5 percent for Javier Perez de Cuellar, the former United Nations Secretary General who has selected a woman as his running mate, as have five other male candidates.
In addition to accusing her husband's Government of corruption and of ignoring the plight of the poor, Ms. Higuchi asserted that Mr. Fujimori had no respect for women. But the two women still in the running for the presidency, Mercedes Cabanillas and Lourdes Flores, are not focusing on women's issues.
Like their male counterparts, they are using their candidacies to try to convince voters that Mr. Fujimori, who disbanded Congress and assumed one-man rule in 1992, should not be re-elected because he has not done enough to help the poor or to return Peru to true democratic rule.
Mrs. Cabanillas, 46, a former senator and Education Minister from the center-left American Popular Revolutionary Alliance, has called for the decentralization of government to better address the needs of Peru's provinces, expanded economic development and more social programs.
Miss Flores, 35, a congresswoman and lawyer from the conservative Popular Christian Party, said that while she was concerned about women's rights, she was offended that many people expected the issue to be at the top of her agenda.
"The question I am asked most often is, 'Why aren't you married?' " Miss Flores said. "People tell me that if I want to win, I should project a more motherly image. Well, I'm not a mother and I am still very happy. I want to be more like Margaret Thatcher, a strong leader on all the issues."
Mr. Lauer said: "These women are not really running as women. They are running as any other politician would. Neither of these women has a feminist platform, and they are not putting forward feminist demands. They are running within the macho context."
Elena Maria Delgado, a business executive who was chosen as the second vice presidential candidate for Alejandro Toledo, an economist who is rising in the polls, has urged women to shake off past notions of their role in society.
"Machismo exists today because women allow it to exist," she said. "They raise their sons in a machismo way where their daughters do all the housework and their sons can rest on the couch and take it easy. We need to change our attitudes and not raise little machistas."
In Peru, there is a First Vice President, who becomes head of state if the President dies or is incapacitated, and a Second Vice President, who is third in line to power. There are two women running for First Vice President and four for Second Vice President -- none of them on Mr. Fujimori's ticket.
Most of the women chosen as running mates have little or no political experience. But Mrs. Cabanillas and Miss Flores have been leaders in their parties for some time, and in recent years women have begun to assume more visible roles in Peruvian society. Women now head labor unions and prominent businesses, and they also have leadership positions in two of Peru's guerrilla organizations, the Shining Path and the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru.
The withdrawal of Ms. Higuchi has not appreciably helped the candidacies of Mrs. Cabanillas or Miss Flores. A survey taken after Ms. Higuchi dropped out showed Mr. Fujimori with the support of 44 percent of the voters, Mr. Perez de Cuellar with 22 percent, Mr. Toledo with 9 percent, Mrs. Cabanillas with 4 percent and Miss Flores with 2 percent.
But Violeta Vermudez, head of Manuela Ramos Movement, a leading feminist group, said the women's candidacies will force the presidential campaign to focus on women's issues that have long been ignored in Peru, including political representation, domestic violence, employment discrimination and health care.
"The mere presence of all these women running for office is having a dramatic impact on the psyche of all women in Peru," Ms. Vermudez said. "It's an inspiration. It's empowering."

HEADLINE: U.S. Shutting 1,274 Farm Field Offices

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The Department of Agriculture will close nearly one-third of its field offices and hopes to save $3.6 billion in a vast reorganization announced today. In Washington it might have been a budget cutter's dream, but few down on the farm were happy about the changes.
Under the reorganization signed into law by President Clinton in October, 1,274 of the department's 3,700 offices around the country will be closed and consolidated with nearby ones. Many of these offices are in counties where farming has given way to urban and suburban sprawl. 
 "The U.S.D.A. is too large," Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, said this afternoon at a news conference in Washington. "We cannot justify the presence of field offices where the farm population does not exist."
The changes could take 11,000 workers off the Federal payroll in the next five years, Mr. Espy said, and farmers would have "one-stop shopping centers" for help with water conservation, erosion-abatement and other technical services, as well as help with loans, crop subsidies or crop quotas. In many states those services are now offered at different locations.
The Secretary said staff cutbacks would be realized through attrition and buyouts rather than dismissals.
In most of the heavily affected states, the shrinkage of the offices parallels a shrinkage in farms. Virginia, for example, now has only 42,000 farms, down from 136,000 in 1954, said James W. Pease, an agricultural economist at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University. Similarly, the number of farms in Georgia now dropped to 43,000 today from 73,000 in 1974, said Mike Hammer, deputy state agricultural statistician.
Nonetheless, in a host of rural communities, farmers said they viewed Mr. Espy's announcement as just one more affliction, joining nature's pests, droughts and floods in the catalogue of unwelcome events.
The Agriculture Department offices, these critics said, were the best evidence that farmers had a friend in the Government, the only human face of the sprawling Federal bureaucracy that often determined their fate.
"I'm not angry, just resigned," said Carlton Tate, a 78-year-old rancher in Dahlonega, Ga.
Mr. Tate's local office of the Agriculture Stabilization and Conservations Services and Soil Conservation Services will close and be consolidated with the one in Gainesville, 20 miles away. "The large farmer who doesn't really need their help will make that drive," he said, "but the small farmers like me who really need the help won't have much time to do that."
Robert E. Hall, a 41-year-old farmer who grows corn, soybeans and wheat on 500 acres outside Heathsville, Va., said the closings would turn his half-mile trip to the local farm office into a 40-mile one. He visits the office three or four times a year.
Mr. Hall said he feared that the envisioned savings to the Federal Government would prove illusory while the increase in his own fuel costs and time getting services would not. "We need to be working in the fields, not running errands," he said.
Still others saw the reorganization as so much politics, in which offices in the districts of powerful lawmakers were untouched while those in the districts of less powerful officials were axed.
Jeanette Perry, the program assistant in the Winder, Ga., office of the Agriculture Stabilization and Conservation Services, said that her office in was already a one-stop shopping center for Barrow County's 400 farmers and that its services would now be split and put in three offices in other counties.
"We don't have any political pull in our county," Ms. Perry said, "but they do in those other counties."
Jim Loftus, a spokesman for the Agriculture Department in Washington, disputed such assertions, saying it was politics in the past that had kept the department from streamlining its services and consolidating the offices that had been sown like so many seeds over the years, starting with the Depression-era assistance programs.
Mr. Loftus said Mr. Espy had achieved bipartisan support from Congress for the reorganization by including a plan to eliminate "hundreds of pages of forms" that farmers must now use to get Federal financial and technical assistance.
The list of closings and consolidations released today showed that Georgia, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia were among the hardest hit. In Georgia, 193 offices are to be consolidated into 92. In Texas, more than 100 offices will be closed, leaving the state with 220. Tennessee will lose 51 of its 123 offices, while Virginia will have its 111 offices reduced to 54.
Just north of Houston, in Montgomery County, time and progress have converted what was once a rural agricultural area to a Houston suburb with three agriculture department offices that the Montgomery County Judge said were little used. All three offices will now be closed, Judge Alan Sadler said, because there is "virtually no agriculture here."
Representative Jack Kingston, Republican of Georgia, said farmers had generally been supportive of the closings, especially in his state, where Agriculture offices proliferated in the 1940's and 1950's.
In those days, Mr. Kingston said, Senator Herman Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, headed the Senate Agriculture Committee and steered "more than our proportionate share of offices" to the state. Many of the offices slated for closing are now in suburbs of Atlanta and Savannah, where there are no longer any farms, he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Agriculture Department announced yesterday that it would close nearly one-third of its 3,700 field offices in an effort to save $3.6 billion. Farmers like Robert E. Hall, above, who grows corn, soybeans and wheat on 500 acres outside of Heathsville, Va., said the closings would create hardships. (Dean Hoffmeyer for The New York Times)
