HEADLINE: Gains in Productivity Reported for 3d Quarter

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
American businesses improved their productivity during the third quarter of this year while keeping wages in check and inflation at bay.
A revised report released today by the Labor Department showed non-farm productivity up at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.9 percent in the July-to-September period, higher than the 2.7 percent initially reported. 
 "Productivity is the most important silver lining of this recovery," said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. "In 14 quarters of recovery, productivity has risen a little more than 2 percent per year, half a percent faster than the productivity gains should have been, given this relatively weak recovery in our economy."
Mr. Roach said increasing productivity "reflects the positive benefits of corporate restructuring and re-engineering and a significant response to extraordinary competitive pressures."
The Labor Department said productivity -- output per number of hours worked -- rebounded from a 2.1 percent decline in the second quarter. The decline in the April-through-June period was the first since a 2 percent decrease in the January-through-March period of 1993 and the steepest since a 3.7 percent plunge in the first quarter of 1989.
The report showed also that unit labor costs, which represent about two-thirds of the cost of a product, were unchanged, the best showing since a 2.4 percent decline in the last quarter of 1993. A modest one-tenth of 1 percent increase was reported initially.
"Normally at this stage of the business cycle unit labor costs are not rising 0.8 percent year over year; they're up 6.1 percent," Mr. Roach said. "We are really in a rarefied zone of sharply diminished cost pressures, and in my opinion there's nothing but good news out there on U.S. inflation."
Investors watch closely for any signs of inflation, which can devalue long-term holdings. The Federal Reserve has pushed up short-term interest rates six times this year in an effort to stem inflationary pressures.
Many economists say labor costs have remained in check because workers fear losing jobs if they demand higher wages or more costly benefits.
Unit labor costs were held down despite an inflation-adjusted 3 percent increase in hourly compensation, compared with seven-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. Hourly compensation rose 6.1 percent in the first quarter.
The Labor Department said output was up 4.2 percent at an annual rate, higher than the 3.9 percent reported earlier.
The increase in productivity among manufacturing businesses slowed, rising 3.6 percent in the third quarter after increases of 5.6 percent in the second quarter and 6.4 percent in the first. Manufacturing output was up 5.7 percent, compared with a 7.2 percent second-quarter increase.
Nearly 20 percent of American business sector employment is in manufacturing.
Total business productivity, including farming, was up 3.5 percent, more than the 3.1 percent first reported. That compares with a 2 percent drop from April through June.

Orange County's Bankruptcy
 
The municipal bond market was roiled after Orange County, Calif., sought bankruptcy. The wealthy county's filing threatens to raise borrowing costs for other local governments. And some Wall Street firms may face losses and lawsuits. [Page D1.]
 
Other local governments face problems with risky interest-rate investments. But Orange County's troubles may be on a different scale: its $20 billion investment pool is bigger than most and its investments were far more aggressive. [D1.] 

The bubble burst for some municipalities, utilities and school districts as the bankruptcy filing locked up their funds. [D17.]
 
Who wrote California's law allowing extra borrowing by counties? Orange County's former treasurer, Robert L. Citron. [D17.]
 
Investor demand for insured bonds is likely to increase as a result of Orange County's bankruptcy filing. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Kmart Signs Store Lease Near Macy's

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
In a city where some of the most prominent landmarks bear names like Tiffany's, Saks and Bergdorf Goodman, another is on the way: Kmart.
For years a staple of suburban retailing, the discount chain signed a lease yesterday for what would be the company's largest store this side of Alaska, on West 34th Street a half-block from one of New York City's most famous department stores, Macy's. 
 The store, one of 2,350 in the Kmart chain, will take up about 140,000 square feet of space at One Penn Plaza (which is actually one-fifteenth the size of the unarguably large Macy's). And in its first foray into Manhattan, Kmart is adding a decidedly New York sensibility: the store will be vertical and largely underground, taking up four levels of the 57-story skyscraper, three of them below the surface.
The store, which is expected to be open for the 1995 holiday shopping season, would lead directly onto the concourse level of the Long Island Rail Road at Pennsylvania Station, meaning that suburban commuters could find a touch of home as soon as they arrived for work.
Although the idea of such a huge mass-market discount store in Manhattan may strike some as an incongruity, it is only the latest in a move toward suburbanlike shopping that has seen a dozen or more so-called superstores opening in Manhattan since 1991 in Chelsea, at Union Square and on 34th Street.
Among Manhattan's new superstores are several Barnes & Noble bookstores; the clothing stores Today's Man, T. J. Maxx and Daffy's; Bed, Bath and Beyond; Toys "R" Us and the department store Bradlees, which last month opened a store with more than 150,000 square feet just south of Union Square, the only new retail outlet bigger than the planned Kmart.
Manhattan's Kmart will offer 100,000 items, with everything from prescription drugs to best-selling books. The only larger Kmart is in Anchorage.
"Suddenly, it has occurred to a lot of retailers that people in Manhattan may not be so different from people in the suburbs or the rest of the country," said Peter Siris, a retail analyst for UBS Securities. "They are saying let's give Manhattan a shot."
No state and city subsidies or tax abatements were offered to lure the giant retailer. As America becomes saturated with discount outlets like Kmart and Wal-Mart, high-rent urban centers like Manhattan have become more attractive. The Manhattan move is part of a larger strategy by Kmart to tap fresh markets in the face of flagging earnings and sharp cost cutbacks. Because of aggressive openings in recent years, Kmart officials said they now have at least one store in each of the most populous 50 metropolitan areas.
Kmart, which had been searching for a Manhattan site for five years, acknowledged that the move represents a gamble on what it calls its most expensive location ever, though it declined to disclose its investment or financial details. In fact, Kmart is entering an already crowded retail arena. Both Sears, Roebuck and J. C. Penny have been negotiating for the space occupied by the Abraham & Straus store between 32d and 33d Streets on the Avenue of the Americas. Federated Department Stores, owner of A.& S., has said it wants to sell that store.
Nonetheless, Joseph E. Antonini, Kmart's chairman, said the company was expecting sales to be the largest of any of its stores.
"This is a win-win deal for everyone," said Peter L. Malkin, a co-owner of the building with Harry B. Helmsley and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. "Kmart will have access to the hundreds of thousands of people who work and shop in the 34th Street-Herald Square area, attend events at Madison Square Garden and ride the Long Island Rail Road and Amtrak. New York City will benefit from the 500 or more jobs created by the store, and the sales tax and other taxes generated, estimated at over $125 million in the initial term of the lease."
The property owners said that accumulating the needed square footage in a building that was not designed to accommodate a single large tenant was difficult. "Obtaining possession of the former F. W. Woolworth store, even though it was only 5,448 square feet, was the key to the puzzle," said Daniel E. North, the Helmsley-Spear Inc. executive who negotiated the deal for the owners.
Twenty-seven additional spaces were assembled. Leases with existing tenants had to be canceled and shops relocated, Mr. North said.
R. H. Macy & Company, which operates the world's largest store with a total of 2 million square feet less than a block away, had no comment yesterday.
In addition to the kinds of merchandise offered, and Kmart's more mass-market orientation, Kmart differs from Macy's in that it buys huge volumes of merchandise that are distributed from a central point, allowing the discount store to greatly shave traditional retail markups.
Mr. Antonini said that he did not think one store would hurt the other. Both Kmart and Macy's have "their core customers," he said. "Together, we'll bring more people to the hub."
Indeed, the new Kmart is expected to give a stimulus to 34th Street, which had historically been one of the world's busiest shopping strips but had lost some of its luster in recent years. "This is an extremely important development for New York," said Walter Loeb, a retail analyst and publisher of the Loeb Retail Letter. "It revitalizes another part of the city."
New York seems to be a bet more retailers are making, largely because of the improving economics of doing business in Manhattan. Faith Consolo, managing director of Garrick Aug, a Manhattan brokerage that specializes in retail space, said the chain superstores have been attracted by falling rents, large blocks of empty retail space, declining crime rates and a surge in tourism bringing new shoppers to the city.
She sees a clear place for a discounter like Kmart. "This is the value-oriented 90's," she said. "People in the city want the kind of choices this store will provide, and not have to go to the suburbs to find them."
Kmart officials say they had trouble finding a site in the past because they found real estate to be prohibitively expensive. Manhattan's landscape is also a new experience for the chain, with its one-story stores surrounded by large parking lots.
But Kmart has gradually been taking over buildings constructed for other uses in urban centers around the country. It opened a two-story store two years ago in a former Bloomingdale's in Fresh Meadows, Queens, and it has performed in the top 10 percent of Kmarts. The chain currently has a total of four stores in the five boroughs.
"Our heritage and culture has been one-story," Mr. Antonini said.
He added that a furious cost-cutting drive has increased profit margins sufficiently so that Kmart can move into areas formerly considered uneconomical because of high taxes and other costs.
The Kmart that opened on Thanksgiving weekend at Co-op City in the Bronx posted the highest opening days sales of any Kmart ever.Kmart also has two stores on Staten Island, both opened 20 years ago, and is looking for more in other boroughs.
At the same time, Kmart has closed 110 stores in other markets, mainly small ones in less profitable locations. By the end of February, the company expects to come up even in openings and closings, said Mary C. McGeachy, a spokeswoman for Kmart.
Kmart, which has taken cost-cutting steps like ordering workers to shut off office lights, has suffered from declining earnings over seven quarters. And in the third quarter of this year, net income fell sharply.
Yesterday, around 34th Street, there was a variety of unofficial views on Kmart's chances of success.
"I like everything about Kmart, the prices are beautiful," said M. Powell from Brooklyn, entering the Sports Authority on Seventh Avenue, a new sporting goods superstore partly owned by Kmart.
Others were skeptical. "Kmart is not a store I shop in," said Steve Zito, a Long Islander entering Macy's. "It's the low end."
One advantage Macy's is unlikely to sacrifice is its lure as a special shopping attraction. Rheyma Baldwin, who lives in the Poconos, said she had taken a bus to New York especially to visit Macy's. "I love everything here," she said. "They have unique things from all over.
"And," she added, "we have Kmarts in Pennsylvania."

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeking To Lift Cloud Over Rapport With Moscow

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Stung by Moscow's opposition to their proposal to expand NATO, Clinton Administration officials acknowledged today that relations with Russia had sunk to their lowest level in years.
Eager to ease the tension, Administration officials said that high-level contacts had opened this week and that Vice President Al Gore would seek to mend fences next week in Moscow. 
Several officials said they were surprised by the bitterness of the attack against NATO's expansion that President Boris N. Yeltsin made on Monday in Budapest, saying the Russian leader was not merely playing to his domestic audience but was underlining important differences between Moscow and Washington.
"We obviously have some very serious problems about how we are going to deal with Russia over the next months and couple of years about the future of Europe," said a senior Administration official.
Another official said, "Clearly, we're going through a rougher patch in our relations with Russia than we had in 1992 or 1993."
The differences were underlined at a NATO meeting last week in Brussels when Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev angered and embarrassed the United States and other Western nations by refusing to sign documents that spelled out Moscow's plans to cooperate with what NATO calls the Partnership for Peace, a loose association with former Soviet-bloc countries.
Tensions are also running high over Bosnia, with Russia joining France and Britain in opposing the Administration's calls -- now renounced -- for air strikes against the Serbs. Russia also blocked a Security Council resolution last Friday that would have tightened the embargo against the Serbs.
Experts see other reasons for worsening relations, including Russian fears that Washington is bullying Moscow and that the Republican landslide victory last month will mean more hostility.
Many Russians also protest that the West is trying to dictate economic policies to turn Russia into a capitalist replica of the West. Those tensions were aggravated on Tuesday when the International Monetary Fund warned that it might not issue $12 billion in planned loans to Russia because its economic program was not strict enough in reducing its budget deficit and slashing inflation. Russian legislators had already complained that the economic plan was far too harsh.
"I would say we're seeing the worst relations since 1984," said Dimitri Simes, a Russia expert who is president of the Nixon Center on Peace and Freedom in Washington. "We're seeing a fundamental worsening of the relations, which reflects not domestic Russian circumstances, not the Republican Congressional victory, not Bosnia, but trends in Russia that once again make it a serious power with nationalist interests and an increasingly assertive manner."
Washington and Moscow will not be able to patch up relations until they reach agreement over President Clinton's proposal to enlarge NATO, Administration officials say. The plan, endorsed by NATO, is to spell out for Eastern European nations next year the conditions for joining NATO as part of a gradual expansion.
Viewing expansion as an anti-Russian move, Mr. Yeltsin reacted bitterly in Budapest, saying, "Why are you sowing the seeds of mistrust?"
According to Administration officials, their strategy will be to explain to the Yeltsin Government that widening NATO will advance Russia's goal of stability in central Europe.
But some officials acknowledge that such an explanation might not placate the Yeltsin Government, which is worried that it is being left out of the new security structure that NATO is developing.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher spoke with Mr. Kozyrev this week to reassure him. Vice President Gore is to meet with Mr. Yeltsin and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin next week as part of semi-annual talks in which senior official discuss economic, environmental and other issues. But Mr. Gore will no doubt discuss NATO, Administration officials say. So will Defense Secretary William J. Perry, who is due in Moscow next Thursday.
While their talks will seek narrow difference, these officials also intend to make clear that Washington is firmly committed to expanding NATO, a senior Administration official said.
Several officials sought to play down down the differences between Moscow and Washington, noting that both nations continue to cooperate in the Mideast, Ukraine and North Korea. They also point to Russia's acceptance of international peacekeepers in Nagorno-Karabakh, the region of Azerbaijan that is immersed in civil war.

HEADLINE: ORANGE COUNTY'S BANKRUPTCY: THE TEMPTATIONS;
The Search for Municipal 'Cowboys'

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Are there other Orange Counties out there?
The answer, experts say, is a qualified yes. While the bankruptcy of Orange County in California has gotten the attention, there are clear signs that similar problems exist elsewhere in the country. Dozens of local governments have already posted multi-million-dollar losses from ill-fated interest rate bets. 
 "There's probably more than one cowboy out there like Orange County," Peter Jordan, a managing director at Fitch Investment Services, said.
Orange County seems in a league of its own. The county's $20 billion investment pool is bigger than most and its investments were far more aggressive. Still, with nearly 80,000 state and local government agencies having billions in public dollars to invest, the lure for higher yields tempted many into making investment decisions that have come back to haunt them.
The securities creating most of the problems at municipalities around the country are mortgage-backed derivatives. These are tailor-made securities created by dividing pools of mortgages into newly repackaged instruments, some of which move in the same direction as interest rates, some in the opposite direction.
In all cases, though, their central attraction is that they take simple interest rate swings and accelerate the moves.
Best of all from Wall Street's point of view, these derivatives are highly profitable products for brokers to sell to local officials, who, many now say, did not fully understand what they were buying.
"All major Wall Street firms sold this stuff and anyone who now says they didn't handle derivatives is not telling you the truth," said Guy Cecalla, publisher of Inside Mortgage Securities, an industry newsletter.
About $200 billion of the $700 billion of mortgage-backed derivatives outstanding, Mr. Cecalla estimated, were particularly risky.
"Once the safer ones were sold," Mr. Cecalla said, "there were more volatile ones left over. Those are the ones that were sold to many of these municipalities. The fact that school systems ended up buying this stuff is inconceivable. Why would anyone in their right mind touch this stuff, if you understood its downside risk?"
Across the country, these kinds of mortgage-backed derivatives have already led to financial pain. A Texas junior college faces a potential loss of $22 million; a Chicago city college has $96 million invested in an asset that cannot be sold. An Indian tribe lost $5 million. San Diego's investment fund, which has about a quarter of its $3.3 billion fund in derivatives, has lost 10.7 percent of its value, county treasurer Paul Boland said yesterday.
All this comes atop large losses that many local governments are facing simply because of the general decline in bond prices this year. Cuyahoga County, Ohio, for example, paid off 80 other investors in a $1.8 billion fund, absorbed the rest of the losses itself and recently said it must cut its operating budget next year by at least $11 million.
A Texas state investment fund holding cash for 1,300 schools, utilities and local governments said yesterday that its estimated losses have escalated to $70 million.
"You can throw darts at a map of the United States," said Joe Mysak, editor of the Grant's Municipal Bond Observer newsletter, "and wherever one hits, there will be losses."
One of those darts hit Auburn, Me., where $16 million of the city's $43 million operating budget is invested in mortgage-backed derivatives that are now worth only $10 million. This money, invested by the town's former finance director, is earmarked to run the city and its schools.
"We are going to have to cut back on services and some capital items," Patricia Finnegan, the acting city manager, said.
Should state and local treasurers, often lacking the skills of more sophisticated corporate managers, be able to invest such huge sums of taxpayer dollars with so little oversight, disclosure and accountability?
"You look at some of the municipal finance managers," said Barry Barbash, director of investment management for the Securities and Exchange Commission, "and you have to question how much expertise they have. It raises some real questions and there will be some real inquiries by Congress."
Derivatives are securities linked to underlying assets -- stocks and bonds or financial indexes. The gain or losses of the derivatives depend on the performance of the asset. Derivatives can result in losses that investors may never have imagined.
The Government Finance Officers Association, a trade group that helps local municipalities, issued a warning earlier this year about derivatives, saying they should be approached with "extreme caution."
"We had a number of our members," said Betsy Dotson, a spokeswoman for the association, "saying that they had gotten a lot of cold calls from brokerage houses and they were promised a lot of things by these brokers."
Besides Wall Street firms, a large number of the municipal derivatives sold came from a small group of Houston firms, some of which are now being sued by disgruntled local governments. The Houston brokers involved in many of the problem situations are: the Government Securities Corporation; Hart Securities Inc.; MGSI Securities Inc., and Westcap Securities L.P.
Some states have already banned the use of derivatives by public agencies. Colorado approved investment guidelines in 1993 that prohibit the use of long-term and volatile bonds, as well as derivatives.
In the New York area, the legislature in Albany prevents state and local governments from investing in derivatives. No such rules exist in New Jersey, but state officials in Trenton say that no problems with derivatives or major investment losses have cropped up.
Fortunately, most municipal finance officers are conservative investors. "I don't think that you are going to see a great deal of these heavily leveraged situations," said Richard Larkin, a managing director at Standard & Poor's Rating Group. "I'm not so naive to think we won't see more. But I think it is a handful who will get into trouble."
Still, S.E.C. commissioner Richard Y. Roberts said, no one can anticipate what problems may arise.
"I've got my fingers crossed," he said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Under a Troubling Cloud" lists three municipal entities that have been downgraded or are under review by Moody's Investors Service because of real or "paper" losses from derivatives investments. (Source: Moody's Investors Service) (pg. D17)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Keycorp Will Take $100 Million in Charges

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Keycorp, the latest Midwest banking casualty of rising interest rates, said today that it would take $100 million in charges against its earnings in the fourth quarter and next year's first quarter.
The nation's 11th-largest banking company said the charges would reduce its vulnerability to rising rates, which squeezed profits on its fixed-rate loans and complicated its merger with the Society Corporation earlier this year. 
 "With all of the things that have happened to our company in the last 10 months, with the merger and rapid loan growth, we got ourselves in this situation," Robert Gillespie, company president, said.
Keycorp joins other major banks that have warned Wall Street that 1994 or 1995 earnings could be reduced because of rising interest rates. Those banks include Banc One of Columbus, Ohio, and PNC Bank and Mellon Bank of Pittburgh.
"There are only a couple of companies that we can find that need to restructure their balance sheet, and most of them have done it already," said a Paine Webber analyst, Thomas McCandless. "PNC is the exception."
Keycorp's shares slipped to a 52-year low of $23.625 after the company disclosed the charges, but they later rebounded to close at $24.625, up 62.5 cents for the day.
Keycorp said the $100 million in pretax charges stemmed from the planned sale of about $1.5 billion in low-yielding United States Treasury and Federal National Mortgage Association securities. Derivatives aren't involved, Mr. Gillespie said.
The company said the charges are expected to produce 1994 net income that is 4.2 percent less than Wall Street's mean earnings estimate, and 5.8 percent below 1995 mean earnings estimates. The Cleveland-based company still expects to report record 1994 net income.
The charges from selling low-yielding, longer-maturity securities "will likely result in a pretax loss of up to $100 million spread over the remainder of 1994 and the first quarter of 1995," said Jim Wert, Keycorp's chief financial officer.
Because of the actions, the company expects to recognize a fourth-quarter charge of $25 million to $35 million, or 7 cents to 10 cents a share.
Keycorp was expected to earn 94 cents a share in the fourth quarter, based on the mean estimate of 24 analysts surveyed by Institutional Brokers Estimate System.
The charges will trim 1994 earnings to between $3.45 a share and $3.50, compared with a Wall Street mean estimate of $3.60 a share.
The remaining charges of $65 million to $75 million will likely be recognized in the first quarter of 1995, said Victor Riley Jr., chairman and chief executive.

HEADLINE: Boitzenburg Journal;
20 Castles for Sale (With 65 Handyman Specials)

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOITZENBURG, Germany

 BODY:
Like scores of central European villages, this one is dominated by an imposing castle from which the surrounding region was once ruled. The Boitzenburg castle is an imposing mass of towers, gables, steeples and cornices that has been owned by a series of noble families from the time it was first occupied in 1271.
Set on a 24-acre plot in a forested landscape that has changed little over the centuries, it is surrounded by streams and ponds and has more than 150 rooms. It is also one of 20 castles in eastern Germany that have been put up for sale. 
 They range from palatial mansions worth millions of dollars to several that may be had for just one mark, the equivalent of about 65 cents. The sale is being run by the agency charged with selling off property that formerly belonged to the Communist Government of East Germany.
Hundreds of bidders have already submitted offers, and the privatization agency has sent out more than 6,000 copies of its lavishly illustrated catalogue, which is titled "Fairy Tales for Sale." Bids will be accepted until Dec. 14, and the Government hopes to complete the sale of at least some castles within a few months.
"Price will not be the deciding factor," said Elke Schicktanz, an official of the privatization agency. "We are looking for offers that provide solid, long-term, economically feasible proposals for how the properties will be used."
Miss Schicktanz said that the largest number of bids so far had come from Germany, but that of the offers from abroad, most had come from the United States.
"Americans have capital, initiative and flexibility," she said. "They realize that each of these castles is a unique historical and architectural treasure. Chances to buy properties like these don't come along very often."
In recent decades, the Boitzenburg castle was used as a vacation resort for officers of the East German Army. It is in good structural condition, and some of its most famous features, like the richly decorated stucco ceiling in the "hunter's room," which was created in 1630, remain intact. But much of the original floor plan has been altered, and many rooms have been spoiled with tasteless wallpaper and cheap linoleum.
About 1,500 people live in the village of Boitzenburg, and many of them hope that whoever buys the castle will help revitalize a region stricken by unemployment and the dashed hopes of prosperity that followed German unification in 1990.
"People have mixed feelings," said Gabrielle Macher, who runs the local public library. "A hotel or a conference center would be nice, but we don't want mass tourism or something that will ruin our peace and quiet. Maybe someone could turn it into a clinic or a retirement home, or even something cultural, like a center for exhibitions or concerts."
Not all of the 20 castles now for sale offer as many possibilities as Boitzenburg. Thirty miles west of here, in the isolated village of Zernikow, a brick manor house that was once home to a medieval order of knights is in an advanced state of decay. Although there were apartments on the second floor as recently as a decade ago, the challenges for a buyer would be considerable. By one estimate, renovating the property would cost $3 million and upkeep would run to $65,000 a year.
Near the manor house on a recent afternoon, a farmer laughed when asked what he thought a future owner might do with it. "Tear it down, I guess," he said. "I can't imagine that anyone would actually buy it."
Although the Government has not placed price tags on either property, officials are hoping to get at least $10 million for the Boitzenburg castle. They would sell the Zernikow manse for one mark to a bidder with an imaginative plan and the money to execute it.
Other castles now for sale are spread across the entire territory of the former East Germany. Among those for which the most offers have been received are several in southern Thuringia and Saxony, regions that border on the wealthy western states of Hessen and Bavaria.
Many of the castles are registered historical landmarks, and new owners will have to work with preservationists when planning renovations.
"It's a shame that these monuments have to be sold to private owners, but I can't see any other solution," said Sibylle Badstubner-Groger, an art historian who works with groups seeking to preserve German castles. "Local communities can't afford to renovate or maintain them, and neither can state governments. We would welcome new users, especially if they keep the buildings at least partly open to the public.
"You can come up with all kinds of fantasies for these places. How about a small museum, with a few apartments upstairs? There are plenty of rich art collectors in western Germany and the United States who don't have a really outstanding place to display what they own. Why not buy a castle that's a work of art in itself?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Germany hopes to get at least $10 million for this castle in Boitzenburg, one of 20 that are up for sale as part of a privatization plan. (Stephan Doblinger/Paparazzi, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Greenspan's Comments Send Bond Prices Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of longer-term Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, indicated to Congress that the central bank would be raising interest rates again. Prices were also pulled lower by worries about the bankruptcy filing of Orange County, Calif., which faces big losses in its investment fund.
In testimony before the Joint Economic Committee, Mr. Greenspan said the economy was continuing to grow briskly despite six interest-rate increases by the Fed already this year. And he said that he expected inflation, which is running at about 3 percent, to begin rising soon. 
 Mr. Greenspan did not say specifically that the central bank would raise interest rates, but his comments were interpreted as a clear signal of intent. While most analysts are expecting the Fed to raise rates, but are debating when, the comments added to concern in an already nervous market.
Mr. Greenspan's comments seemed to dispel any notion that the Orange County situation would slow a plan to raise rates. The county filed for bankruptcy protection because it faces $1.5 billion in losses in its investment fund. The potential losses stem from a strategy of heavy borrowing, the purchase of of often-volatile financial instruments called derivatives and a bet that interest rates would fall, even as they began to rise this year.
In an effort to calm the nerves of investors and play down Orange County, Mr. Greenspan said, "I don't consider it as something that gives me great concern." He added that the situation was being closely studied by regulators.
Treasury prices at the close of New York trading were mixed, with the 30-year bond down 14/32 , to a price of 9517/32 for a yield of 7.89 percent, up five basis points from Tuesday's session. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The shorter end of the Treasury market was buoyed by what appeared to be a flight from stocks and the municipal market.
Traders said prices of municipal bonds having nothing to do with Orange County fell sharply, with the yield on the Bond Buyer muni bond index jumping to 7.06 percent, from 6.92 percent on Tuesday.
But it was much harder to tell what happened to Orange County municipal bonds and to those of the school districts and other units that invest in the county's fund. There appeared to be little trading in those bonds, as investors decided to wait on developments in the bankruptcy case. But Bloomberg Business News reported that some traders said some Orange County paper was being offered at 50 cents on the dollar, apparently without many takers.
Many investors decided quickly yesterday that Orange County would not be the only municipality to show losses because of aggressive investing in risky products, like derivatives, or because of heavy borrowing. James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International, said Texpool, the $3.7 billion Texas investment pool, reported that it had paper losses of $70 million. "It fueled more fears that there are probably many more agencies in trouble," Mr. Hale said.
Chris Leary, a senior vice president and portfolio manager for SunAmerica Asset Management, said there were many shifting winds in the market yesterday. "We appeared to be unwinding from flattening trades," he said, "where people sell short maturities to buy long maturities." He said short maturities were the beneficiaries of a flight to quality stemming from the confusion surrounding Orange County. He said Treasury bills were also volatile.
John C. Mooney, portfolio manager on the muni side at SunAmerica, said there were many bids out yesterday, with yields on general municipal paper rising 15 to 20 basis points.
"Investors were mostly testing waters for reaction when they put bids," Mr. Mooney said. "There is so little known about municipal bankruptcy.".
Mr. Hale said he had not heard any specific talk about unannounced buying by the Fed. "While Orange County's bankruptcy obviously upset the markets," he said, "the fear is that they are not alone in having complex derivative problems." But he said he thought the Fed would want to insure adequate liquidity in the banking system to keep rates from moving higher.

HEADLINE: ORANGE COUNTY'S BANKRUPTCY: THE OVERVIEW;
Orange County Crisis Jolts Bond Market

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The sudden plunge of Orange County, Calif., into bankruptcy shook the market for public borrowing across the country yesterday, threatening to make it more expensive for many localities to borrow. It also left some Wall Street firms facing the potential of big losses.
And it served as a warning of how rapidly new and popular financial strategies can sour, leaving an apparently prosperous county unable to pay its bills. 
 Orange County, a suburban area south of Los Angeles that is more than twice the size of Long Island's Nassau County, filed for bankruptcy late Tuesday, after heavy borrowing and risky investments in its investment pool turned into big losers as market interest rates rose.
The investments had been made by a county desperate to get additional profits on its investments to pay for government services. But the fund, with about $8 billion invested in it -- and with borrowings of about $12 billion -- now faces a loss of at least $1.5 billion. And local governments that invested in the fund may also be unable to pay their bills, raising the possibility of additional bankruptcy filings.
"The bankruptcy filing by Orange County will have a far greater and far longer impact than just missing a payment on their debt," said Richard Larkin, a managing director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, a bond rating agency.
The county said late yesterday it was able to meet all its payrolls. "The county has use of all its finances," said Bruce Bennett, the bankruptcy lawyer at Stutman, Treister & Glatt who is handling the case, adding that it did not need judicial approval to make the payments. "We are clearing all checks. Welfare checks went out today."
But the municipal bond market -- one of the largest in the country, with more than $1 trillion in outstanding issues -- was shaken. Traders said the bonds from most California issuers were quoted at sharp drops in prices -- with yields about 40-hundredths of a percentage point higher than Tuesday's level -- but there was no activity in them.
"There is no market in California issues," said Austin Tobin, president of the Delphis Hanover Corporation, which prices municipal bonds. "There probably won't be one for a couple of days."
The decline was felt in municipal bonds across the country, with the yield on the Bond Buyer municipal bond index leaping to 7.06 percent yesterday from 6.92 percent on Tuesday, while the rates on taxable Treasury bonds rose much less.
Much of the decline represented buyers pulling back in fear that other counties might have similar problems. It seems unlikely that any county invested quite as recklessly as did Robert L. Citron, who was forced to resign as the Orange County treasurer on Monday, but other governments took lesser risks.
"More losses will come out," said Joe Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer, a New York publication that follows the municipal market. "The municipalities will blame Wall Street and the tight financial situation they are in."
The Wall Street exposure stems from billions of dollars in loans that firms made to Orange County's investment fund and to the possibility of lawsuits from the county stemming from the risky investments it made. It used those investments to bet on lower interest rates, both through conventional bonds and more esoteric investments, including derivative securities, whose rates fall when market interest rates rise. No such suits have yet been filed, and Wall Street firms have said they have no liability.
Still, there is a risk of suits. "The more complicated and the fancier these so-called investments are, the more the question of appropriateness comes to the fore," said Felix Rohatyn, a partner in the investment banking firm of Lazard Freres and a former chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was formed in 1975 to help New York City after it was unable to pay its bills. "How can you allow taxpayer funds to be gambled with in this manner?" Mr. Rohatyn asked. "That is just inconceivable to me."
The largest of the investment banks to deal with Orange County was Merrill Lynch, whose shares fell $1.25, to $35, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Merrill Lynch said its $2 billion in loans to the county were fully collateralized.
The restrictions on local investment policies have often dealt with the credit quality of the investments. But in this case, that was not a problem. The issue was losses stemming from changes in interest rates.
J. Chester Johnson, president of Government Financial Associates, an adviser to local governments, noted that cities and states were forced to disclose more financial information after the New York crisis. Now, he said, investment policies would have to be disclosed, and rules would be adopted to limit the riskiness of investments.
At a Congressional hearing yesterday, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, voiced caution about the need for legislation on the derivatives market.
"The trouble with legislation," he said, "is that it is very likely in this type of market to become rapidly obsolete, and could very readily become counterproductive to the required flexibility that we need to address the types of problems that we are addressing."
The Orange County fund had borrowed heavily to speculate on interest rates staying low or declining. As the rates have risen this year, the county's losses mounted, but until last week, the county maintained that there was no problem.
So unaware were local officials of the mounting losses that in June four education authorities with money in the fund -- the Orange County Board of Education, the Irvine Unified School District, the Newport-Mesa Unified School District and the North Orange County Community College District -- borrowed a total of $200 million solely to invest in the funds. Those borrowings were underwritten by Rauscher, Pierce Refnes, whose officials did not return telephone calls yesterday. Those notes will come due next June.
The fund had obtained higher yields than were generally available in the market through a variety of techniques, including borrowing to buy more securities. On Tuesday Wall Street firms began refusing to roll over those loans. That forced the bankruptcy filing, which the county said would stop the investment banks from seizing its collateral.
Whether the filing will accomplish that is not clear. Investment banks said they still had the right to sell the collateral, and it seemed likely that issue would end up in court.
The county tried on Tuesday to get the Securities and Exchange Commission to intervene to stop investment banks from seizing the collateral, but the agency declined.
Orange County's bonds had been rated AA by both Moody's Investors Service and S.& P., a very high investment grade rating. Yesterday, S.& P. cut its rating to CCC, a low junk-bond rating. Moody's suspended its rating.
It is not yet clear if bondholders in Orange County will suffer any losses. But it is clear that the county and many of its agencies will have to deal with lower income. That is likely to mean cuts in government spending, because tax increases are very hard to get in California, as a result of Proposition 13, which holds property taxes in check.
"You can pin this almost 100 percent on Proposition 13," said Dale Scott, a San Francisco financial adviser to local governments.
"The only reason people are out there trying to turn two dimes into a quarter is they can't finance basic needs anyway else," he added. "The Music Man comes in and says, 'I can get you 10 percent when everyone else gets 5 percent,' and he's a hero."


GRAPHIC: Many American investors are suffering from Orange County's decision to file for bankruptcy protection. The aftershocks are hitting them where it hurts -- in their pocketbooks.
 
Orange County's bondholders
Chart: "Millions of Losers"
The county has sold well over $500 million of tax-exempt bonds, which are generally bought by individuals, and hundreds of millions of dollars of taxable debt. Nobody knows whether the county will continue to make payments on its debts -- or even if if, legally, it can. And some kinds of bonds, such as those backed by insurance, may fare better than others.
Moody's Investors Service, which had given the county's debt high marks, suspended its ratings. Standard & Poor's cut its ratings on $1.6 billion or Orange County's debt to "speculative." The county's bonds are clearly worth less now than before the bankruptcy, but how much less remains uncertain, because the bonds did not trade yesterday.
 
Other bondholders
Some 180 cities, school districts, sewer agencies and the like invested in Orange County's ill-fated investment fund and now can't get their money out. These agencies sell bonds, too, and Standard & Poor's said it might lower the credit rating on more than $800 million of their debt.
In fact, all California bond issues suffered yesterday, as did the entire municipal bond market. The most actively traded issues, as measured by the Bond Buyer Municipal Index, lost $10.50 for every $1,000 of face value.

Portfolios with the most money in Orange County debt of all kinds, according to CDA/Spectrum's Bondwatch:

Allstate Insurance Company: $45 million
 
Mutual funds
Bond funds that specialize in California debt fell 1.6 percent yesterday, according to Lipper Analytical Services. Hardest hit was Alliance Municipal California, which dropped almost 2.5 percent -- but many funds did not report their prices. California funds are owned almost exclusively by residents of that state, but some national funds may also own some affected bonds.
Early estimates showed a number of funds with big positions in the affected bonds, but fund companies say their exposure may be less than it appears. For example, Franklin California Tax Free Income, which looks like one of the bigggest holders, reports that only 0.16 percent of its $12.6 billion portfolio is in direct obligations of Orange County.
 
What investors should consider
Zane Mann, editor of the California Municipal Bond Advisory newsletter, suggests that bondholders sit tight. "If you don't sell, even the downgrading doesn't mean anything," he said.
For mutual fund investors, "It's tough luck," said Richard Lehman of the Bond Investors Association. Because mutual funds must mark their portfolios to market every night, investors in those funds have already lost money. But he, too, recommends hanging in until the picture becomes clearer. That way, "they may get a recovery," he said. "If they get out in the interim, they will take a hit." Leslie Eaton (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: ORANGE COUNTY'S BANKRUPTCY: THE PEOPLE;
Shock and Confusion In Offices and Streets

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif., Dec. 7

 BODY:
It was easy money. As the California economy crashed all around them, local governments here in Orange County enjoyed what sometimes seemed a guilty pleasure: building, expanding and improving with the profits of a risky, high-wire investment fund.
While other cities around the state were making painful cutbacks, Huntington Beach built a children's addition to its library. 
 The City of Orange, which invested $28 million of its $125 million portfolio in the fund -- $8 million of it borrowed money -- used its profits to keep down fees and property taxes. "If you can make a two-point spread on $28 million, you're doing quite well," said David Dixon, the city manager, referring to extra return on the risky investments.
But the bubble burst on Tuesday. After years of high profits from its investment fund, Orange County declared bankruptcy when it was unable to roll over $1.2 billion in loans to its investment fund. Thus, it became the largest municipality ever to file for Federal bankruptcy protection. The action fended off creditors but also locked up funds invested by cities, some utilities and, most painfully, by school districts, which had been required by law to deposit their entire budgets into the fund.
At the Irvine Unified School District, with $106 million in the fund -- the most of any district -- officials were cloistered in meetings today, and only their secretaries, turning away a reporter, reflected the level of their pain.
"He is secluded," said the secretary to Paul Reed, the district's financial officer. "Let's just say he is secluded. We don't know, really, what all this means, and he's just trying to get some answers."
At the Anaheim City School District, not far away, Mel Lopez, the superintendent, said the questions were straightforward and frightening.
"All the school districts have a payroll to meet on Friday," he said. "If they don't allow us to withdraw from the fund at all, we don't know what we will do."
His district, with 18,000 students from kindergarten through the sixth grade, is the largest elementary school district in the county, with an annual budget of $71 million.
"We thought we were pretty solvent and we were pretty smug about our financial picture," he said. As of today, the district has stopped every purchase order that is not essential to the schools' survival and has rescinded job offers to new teachers.
"We are not spending any money, even for new books," Mr. Lopez said.
Don Watson, the city treasurer in Huntington Beach, said that city, too, had put a halt to spending. "Now we have to make a close watch on everything and not spend on anything we don't have to," he said.
One concern now, he said, is whether the city will be able to keep any new tax revenues it collects or whether those revenues will be impounded to make payments on the county's debt.
But officials of larger communities appeared less alarmed. "Don't panic" were the watchwords around the county, said Paul Brady Jr., the city manager of Irvine. Like officials in other larger cities, he insisted that day-to-day operations would not be affected because the investments represented discretionary capital and because the city's portfolio was diversified.
But he said long-term prospects were more uncertain.
"We are truly in the dark along with everyone else," he said. "We are getting bits and pieces of information and are all speculating, just like everybody else. Nobody really knows the whole picture. It's too big."
Even with all the uncertainty, the investment fund has its defenders.
Here in Irvine, a pristine, meticulously planned city that has risen on open farmland over 20 years, "It's been wonderful for us, " Mr. Brady said of the fund.
He said Irvine had increased its earnings by $8.5 million over the last 15 years by investing in the fund, sometimes borrowing millions to augment its investment. The profits paid for a senior center, built roads and parks and financed municipal improvements.
At the moment, Mr. Brady said, the city has $209 million in the county's investment pool as well as $315 million invested elsewhere.
At gasoline stations and shopping centers, the only places where people can be seen on the streets in this futuristic city of industrial parks and corporate headquarters, the bankruptcy touched off sparks.
"I think it's just typical of the respect that your average politicians and government officials have for your working people that pay the bills," said Bob King, a newspaper delivery man with a stack of copies of The Orange County Register bearing two-inch-high headlines reading simply, "BANKRUPTCY."
Tony Comella, an electronics salesman, glared at one of the newspapers. "You have all these legal minds and all this staff," he said, "and yet they ran it to the point here they have to declare bankruptcy."
And Helen Uldrich, who is retired from her job at a Christian broadcasting station, paused in her shopping to declare: "I'm shocked. Sometimes they tell us everything is O.K. when it isn't."

He insisted that daily operations would not be affected, despite investments in the Orange County fund, because the city's portfolio was diversified. But not all citizens were comforted. HEADLINE: GREENSPAN HINTS AT FURTHER RISES IN INTEREST RATES

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
In an unusually clear signal that the Federal Reserve will continue raising interest rates, its chairman, Alan Greenspan, said today that inflation might rise soon and that the economy was continuing to grow briskly.
The Federal Reserve has sought with six rate increases since February to brake economic growth in an effort to forestall inflationary shortages of goods and skilled workers. Mr. Greenspan told members of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee that "there is very little evidence throughout this economy of any degree of slowdown," 
 Producers of consumer goods face rising raw material prices and other expenses, he added, warning, "With demand for their output strong, finished-goods producers may soon attempt to pass on their higher costs."
Mr. Greenspan warned that if the Federal Reserve allowed inflation to rise now, Americans would begin to expect rising prices. "It is these expectations that make an inflationary process, once begun, difficult and expensive to reverse," he said.
When asked at a routine news conference today, Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, challenged Mr. Greenspan's prediction of rising prices. "At this point we don't see any inflationary pressures within the economy," she said. "We see continued growth, strong growth, very low inflation."
While Ms. Myers refused to discuss interest-rate policy, Clinton Administration officials have begun to chafe privately about the Federal Reserve's aggressiveness in raising rates this year.
Mr. Greenspan did not say explicitly that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates further. Like most Federal Reserve chairmen, he usually limits his public statements to careful generalities, avoiding language that could affect financial markets unduly. His unusually candid statements today coincided with a monthly report by the Federal Reserve concluding that the economy continued to grow in November at about the same pace as in previous months.
Labor Department statistics have not yet shown high inflation -- the prospect of which has so alarmed the Federal Reserve this year. Consumer prices rose only 2.6 percent in the 12-month period through October, and the pace of increases slowed in September and October. Producer prices actually dropped by half a percentage point in September and again in October.
But the monthly report, compiled by the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks, found that producers were beginning to pass along their rising costs to consumers.
The Labor Department is scheduled to issue November figures for producer prices on Tuesday and for consumer prices on Wednesday.
When asked explicitly today whether the Federal Reserve would raise rates at the next meeting of its top policy committee on Dec. 20, Mr. Greenspan responded that he did not know. But he then volunteered that private economists' forecasts and changes in financial markets had indicated that short-term interest rates, which the Federal Reserve controls, would continue to climb next year.
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, urged Mr. Greenspan not to be "the Grinch that stole Christmas" and added, "Let's hope that you're all not going to be Ebenezer Scrooges."
Financial industry economists have been divided over whether the Federal Reserve will act again on Dec. 20 or wait for the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee's subsequent meeting on Jan. 31. But interest rates have already risen for short-term Treasury securities to an extent that suggests a consensus is developing among private investors that the Federal Reserve will act again on Dec. 20.
Mr. Greenspan has the personal authority to push up interest rates between meetings.
The Federal Reserve has already raised rates six times this year. It has increased its target for the Federal funds rate, which banks pay to borrow money overnight, by a total of 2.5 percentage points, to 5.5 percent. The less important discount rate, which banks pay the Federal Reserve for short-term loans, has climbed by 1.75 percentage points, to 4.75 percent.
Any action at the Dec. 20 meeting would be likely to add fuel to the debate that followed its three-quarter-point rate increase last month. While inflation hawks worried that the move might not have gone far enough to damp down rising prices, other economists, along with some Democrats, business executives and organized labor worried that the Federal Reserve was hitting the brakes too hard.
Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said that further interest rate increases could be risky. "They haven't reached the threshold for a recession in 1996 yet, but as you reach 7 percent on the Federal funds rate, the risk rises," he said.
Some business executives have suggested that basic changes in the American economy -- like growing international trade, the spread of new technologies and the shrinkage through layoffs of many big American companies -- have reduced the risk of inflation from brisk economic growth.
Executives of the Ford Motor Company said today that they saw no danger of inflation for this reason. Edward E. Hagenlocker, the president of Ford's automotive operations, said the auto maker was holding the line on its raw materials prices, urging its suppliers to contain costs by increasing productivity.
"Because of the strong productivity in the manufacturing sector, I don't see inflation, so from my perspective I don't see the need for another rate increase," Mr. Hagenlocker said in a briefing with reporters. He said expanding production capacity in the auto industry would keep auto makers from raising prices, although he refused to discuss Ford's own pricing plans.
But Mr. Greenspan took issue today with the idea that the American economy's susceptibility to inflation had changed much. "There is a significant element of truth in these arguments, but these developments are evolutionary, working slowly and incrementally over time," he said, later adding, "If we ignore experience, we would be taking unacceptable risks of higher inflation, economic and financial instability and ultimately subpar economic performance over time."
Two Republicans at today's hearing, Senator Connie Mack of Florida and Representative Jim Saxton of New Jersey, were mildly critical of the interest-rate increases. But Mr. Mack also said that he would seek legislation next year to change the Federal Reserve's mandate.
The current Federal Reserve goals of holding down unemployment and maintaining moderate long-term interest rates would be eliminated under the legislation, leaving a single goal of fighting inflation. Mr. Mack said that the Federal Reserve should have a target of limiting consumer price inflation to 2 percent, and Mr. Saxton said that he completely agreed that controlling inflation should be the Federal Reserve's sole job.
Mr. Greenspan said that he favored such legislation in principle, although he preferred a more vaguely worded inflation target, given the Labor Department's periodic revisions in how it calculates the Consumer Price Index. But Mr. Greenspan also cautioned that he could not speak for the Federal Reserve Board. It endorsed such a narrowing of the Federal Reserve's goals two years ago, but since then President Clinton has nominated two governors to the board, both of whom favor multiple goals.

HEADLINE: ORANGE COUNTY'S BANKRUPTCY: THE RULES OF THE GAME;
A Strategy's Creator Also Drafted the Law

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7

 BODY:
No one took advantage of a section in California state law allowing extra borrowing by counties as much as Robert L. Citron, the Orange County treasurer whose risky investment strategy drove the county into bankruptcy court on Tuesday. And who wrote the law? Mr. Citron.
In 1979, Mr. Citron, who was then the head of the state association of county treasurers, drafted a change in state law on counties' investments. The change allowed county treasurers, with permission from their boards of supervisors, to borrow money through so-called reverse repurchase agreements, or repos. Those instruments allow the purchase of securities with borrowed money, using the securities themselves as collateral. 
 The change was introduced into the Legislature by Chester Ray, a former Assemblyman from Orange County.
Having cracked open the gate, Mr. Citron drove right through it. In Orange County, Mr. Citron managed to buy $20 billion of securities with a down payment of about $7.8 billion, the amount invested by local government units. But when interest rates started rising this year, he found his large portfolio falling further and further behind, and county officials disclosed last week that its value was down 20 percent. Mr. Citron resigned on Monday.
"Many county portfolios are operating at a 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6 percent loss because the market is down," said Terry Brennand, a lobbyist for the treasurers' group. "I don't know any county with a 20 percent loss, or any that were that leveraged, that much on margin, that much at risk."
The state law also accounts for why the losses did not come to light for so long. The law, which was intended to insulate day-to-day investment decisions from interference by local elected officials, left Mr. Citron to set strategy without supervision. Apart from the requirement that the county's five-member board of supervisors approve the use of repos, the board had no specific authority over Mr. Citron's portfolio, said David Kiff, spokesman for Thomas F. Riley, the chairman of the Orange County board.
And aside from monthly statements on interest income and the net asset value of the fund, the 187 local government units that invested in the county fund had little solid information on Mr. Citron's investments.
In the most recent annual report, dated Sept. 26, Mr. Citron painted a rosy picture of the investments. "We have constructed a well-balanced portfolio that we believe can withstand the impact of current interest rates," Mr. Citron wrote.
Mr. Citron was not alone in his power: With the exception of three appointed county treasurers who answer directly to their boards of supervisors -- in Los Angeles, Sacramento and Santa Clara counties -- all elected county treasurers in California operate independently, said Barbara Coates, president of the county treasurers' group.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Rises Again

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing rose $11.62 billion in October, the 23d consecutive monthly gain, as retail sales remained healthy heading into the holidays, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Robust consumer spending has continued to help economic activity, even though the Fed has made borrowing costlier by raising interest rates six times since February. The Fed's aim is to cool the growth rate and contain inflation. 
 So far, however, the combination of higher debt and higher interest charges is showing little evidence of reducing economic activity, although the consumer borrowing figures released today come from a month before the Fed's last rate increase on Nov. 15.
Today's report showed installment credit totaled $891.581 billion during October. In September, consumer credit rose a revised $10.333 billion. Initially, the Fed said consumer credit increased by $10.567 billion in September.
The Fed said that the annual rate of consumer borrowing ran at 15.8 percent during October compared with a 14.3 percent pace in September.
By category, credit-card borrowing increased by $4.886 billion in October, auto borrowing rose by $2.907 billion for the month and other types of personal loans climbed by $3.827 billion. The Fed's report does not track home equity loans.
Before today's report, a survey showed, economists expected an $11.1 billion increase in consumer credit in October.
Many analysts believe the economy, buoyed by strong Christmas sales, is growing at more than a 4 percent annual rate in this year's final quarter. In October, for example, retail sales increased 1.1 percent, the fifth consecutive monthly gain. Excluding autos, sales also advanced a solid six-tenths of a percent during the month, according to Commerce Department figures.

HEADLINE: German High Court Bans Energy Subsidy on Utility Bills

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 7

 BODY:
It is called the coal penny, or Kohlepfennig, and for two decades this surcharge on German electricity bills has subsidized the country's unprofitable coal industry, becoming a symbol of German insistence on maintaining costly energy production and mining jobs at consumers' expense.
But today, Germany's high court ruled that the surcharge was unconstitutional. In a decision that will force Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government to increase taxes and possibly slash employment in the coal industry, the court ruled that the coal penny was a hidden tax and that the Government had to budget it as tax by moving it off consumers' bills and onto Government ledgers. 
 Economics Minister Gunter Rexrodt said that although the ruling would result in new taxes, "through the disappearance of the coal penny, the taxpayers in their role as electricity users will be relieved of some burden."
Still, it creates political problems for Bonn, with the tax increases expected to run more than $4 billion a year. The German people already pay high tax rates to support extensive social welfare programs, plus more than $400 billion to date to rebuild the formerly Communist east. And in January, tax rates are to go up 7.5 percent because the costs of restoring the east have been even higher than expected.
The coal penny was an 8.5 percent surcharge on all electricity bills, providing the billions to protect jobs in the Ruhr Valley, the cradle of German industrial might.
But over nearly three decades, employment at the deep anthracite mines -- where the coal cannot compete in price with open-pit mines in Poland and the United States -- has fallen from 530,000 to 90,000. Financial analysts who cover the industry say many of these underground coal mines should eventually be closed.
Some of the analysts said today's decision would give the Government an excuse to reorder national energy policies, away from what has essentially been a regional subsidy to a plan based more on energy security.
Officials of the miners' union, however, said they already had an agreement with the Government for subsidies to run through the year 2000.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Avis Says Costs Force a Rental Rate Rise

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 7

 BODY:
Avis Rent A Car System Inc., citing higher fleet costs and recent interest rate increases, said today that it was raising its daily, weekly and weekend rental rates by as much as 6 percent across the country.
Avis, the nation's second-largest rental company behind the Hertz Corporation, said the new rates would be effective Jan. 6. 
 Daily rates will rise $2, weekly rates $10 to $20 and weekend rates $1.
On a typical midsized car in Chicago, Avis said the daily rate would rise $2, to $59.99, and the weekly rate would increase $12, to $215.99. In San Francisco, the daily rate will rise $2, to $46.99, and the weekly rate will jump $20, to $195.99.
"As fleets convert to the 1995 models, the industry is experiencing tremendous cost increases," James Collins, executive vice president of Avis, said in a statement. "This is the third year in a row that car makers have boosted pricing for the industry. At Avis, the average monthly cost of our cars has risen 50 percent in past two years, with 15 percent price increases for 1995 cars.
"On top of this, interest rates are also going up. In a highly leveraged business such as rent-a-car, the impact of a 1 percent increase in interest rates is major.
"The car rental industry remains in a fiscal crisis. Keen competition has kept industry pricing unrealistically low for years -- and now companies cannot absorb additional increases."
In September, Hertz raised rental car rates by 8 to 10 percent nationwide to offset higher fleet costs and interest expenses.
A spokeswoman for Avis predicted further rate increases in 1995. "I think this is just the start," she said. "With these enormous cost increases, we just can't absorb them."
In addition to the higher leisure rates, Avis said it would negotiate price rises as corporate contracts came up for bid. The company estimated it would get a 5 to 8 percent increases in corporate rates.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Poverty rates have actually fallen, a new book argues.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
HAVE you had your fill of charge and countercharge swirling around the authors of the "The Bell Curve," who assert that I.Q. is destiny? Are you ready for something equally subversive from the frontiers (or the fringes -- take your pick) of social science?
Consider the work of Dale Jorgenson and Daniel Slesnick, economists with impeccable academic credentials (Harvard and the University of Texas, respectively) and no apparent ideological bone to pick. They argue that properly measured, poverty rates have actually fallen sharply in the two last decades. 
 Almost none of their fellow poverty researchers agree. But the work -- much of which has been published in peer-reviewed scholarly journals -- does expose the Achilles' heel of research in standard-of-living trends in general, and poverty in particular. It is very difficult to measure the consumption of people at the bottom of the economic pecking order. And it is even more difficult to compare the material needs of say, a mother with two teen-agers in Minnesota with those of, say, a retired couple in San Diego.
The official poverty rate measure was developed in the mid-1960's. At its heart is an estimate of how much food individuals of varying ages need to live a healthy life, and an assumption that an income three times as large as the basic food budget would put people above the poverty line. The Government then uses survey data on incomes to measure the percentage of Americans who do not make the cutoff.
Even a cursory look, though, makes it clear that the poverty rate calculation is conceptually flawed. It makes no distinction between the needs of a 3-month-old and a 14-year-old or between a rural family in a cold climate and an urban family in the subtropics.
By the same token, it draws no distinction between income and purchasing power: A welfare mom living on $400 a month is treated identically to a graduate student who earns $400 a month at a part-time job and borrows an additional $1,500 from her parents. Nor does it tackle the problem of income from the underground economy, presumably a major source of sustenance for the very poor.
But most specialists still think the Government's measure is good enough for examining trends in poverty, in contrast to absolute rates. The fact that the poverty rate was 9.9 percent in 1971 may not prove much. Adding the fact that 11.3 percent of Americans were officially poor in 1991 does, however, strongly suggest that times were growing harder for low-income families.
Or does it? Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at the University of Chicago, raised doubts a decade ago. He argued that trends in measured income for the bottom few percent of the population diverged from consumption in the 1970's because of the rapid growth of in-kind subsidies for the poor: food stamps, Medicaid and the like.
Now Mr. Jorgenson and Mr. Slesnick are taking aim at the other weak link in the calculation, the Government's simplistic method of calculating the cost of living for people of differing ages, sex, household sizes and location. By their numbers, for example, the average family of four headed by a female needs just 62 percent as much income as an average family of four headed by a male, largely because the female-headed households contain fewer adults and more young children. The Census Bureau, by contrast, assumes the female-headed household needs 99 percent as much.
Since virtually all of the growth in low-income families has been in female-headed households, it should thus be no great surprise that the Jorgenson-Slesnick calculations show poverty falling steadily through the 1980's. Indeed, they estimate that the percentage of Americans in poverty in 1990 was just half as large as in 1970.
What should one make of this? As much to the point, what will Newt Gingrich and the New Republicans, who want to cut welfare costs, do with it?
The focus on income rather than consumption has certainly been misleading -- and is now probably unnecessary since better data on consumption are available. And the use of food costs as a proxy for living costs will always make the poverty index suspect. But the core of the controversy is the assumption of equivalency scales for different sorts of families. Mr. Jencks (among many others) is deeply skeptical that female-headed households can, in reality, "live on air."
What Mr. Slesnick and many of his critics do agree about, however, is that the traditional measures of poverty will always be open to challenge. "We've pushed cash comparisons too far," Mr. Jencks argues.
He, for one, would prefer to go back to basics, saying: "Are people eating well? Are they going to the doctor when they're sick? These are the sorts of questions that really matter."

HEADLINE: Guide for Last-Minute Shoppers and Shippers

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
IN the United States, there are Santa's helpers who deliver presents on Christmas Day. They don't sit in department stores or slide down chimneys, but they will come dressed in red suits.
They are Postal Service carriers. The Postal Service is the only mail service that will deliver a package on Christmas Day -- but only if it is sent by Dec. 23 by Express Mail. 
 Here's how it works: If a package is sent Express Mail from one major metropolitan center to another on Dec. 23, the Postal Service guarantees delivery on the 24th. If the destination is far from a metropolitan center, Express Mail will take two days. On Christmas Day, the mail carrier will arrive, most likely in a red suit, said Larry Dozier, a spokesman for the Postal Service.
Neither Federal Express nor the United Parcel Service will do this.
Mail services and catalogue houses have different deadlines for guaranteed delivery of Christmas gifts by Saturday, Dec. 24. The blithe spirit who wants to send gifts at the last minute should take note or he may find himself the family Scrooge.
At the Postal Service, after Express Mail -- the fastest service and the only guaranteed one -- there is Priority Mail, with delivery in two to three days. For early birds, parcel post takes seven to 10 days for delivery. Neither Priority Mail nor parcel post is guaranteed.
Mr. Dozier suggests senders "use strong tape, a strong secure box, wrap in brown paper, and put a name, a complete address, including the apartment number, and a ZIP code. Don't use string and twine, because that can damage our machinery." He also suggests that people put the address inside the package, too, in case the address on the outside gets smudged.
Federal Express has two services for domestic delivery, overnight and two-day delivery, and as many deadlines as there are cities.
For a package sent overnight on the 23d, delivery is guaranteed on the 24th, provided the customer meets the deadline and pays the regular Saturday $10 surcharge. A second-day delivery requires a package to be sent on the 22d, for delivery on the 24th, with the same $10 Saturday surcharge. If you don't want to pay the $10 surcharge, send a package on the 22d for delivery overnight on the 23d.
Information about a city's Federal Express deadline, is available by calling (800) 463-3339.
U.P.S. guarantees its next-day air delivery service in the United States. If a package is sent Dec. 23, it will arrive the 24th. But U.P.S. does not guarantee second-day air service if it is sent after Dec. 8. Ground service is never guaranteed, but from New York to California, the normal time in transit is six days. At Christmas, delivery time is never normal.
 
Deadlines for Catalogues
 Catalogue houses can usually guarantee delivery only of in-stock merchandise. On the telephone, a customer service representative can probably tell via a computer whether or not an item is in stock. Here are some catalogues that will accommodate last-minute shoppers, listed in order of deadlines. (Alacrity, however, is encouraged.)
* Hearthsong -- (800) 325-2502 -- sells children's toys and books from Berkeley, Calif. Its deadline is Dec. 15 at 10 P.M., Pacific standard time, for guaranteed delivery by Dec. 23 via regular U.P.S. For delivery by Federal Express on the 23d, the deadline is the 20th at 10 P.M., Pacific standard time.
* The Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan -- (800) 447-6662 -- has two deadlines for domestic packages. To ship by U.P.S., MOMA guarantees delivery by the 23d if the item is ordered from the catalogue by Dec. 16 at midnight, Eastern standard time. To ship by Federal Express, MOMA charges an extra $20, and orders must be placed by Dec. 20 at midnight, Eastern standard time. Delivery is on Friday, the 23d.
* At L. L. Bean -- (800) 221-4221 -- in Freeport, Me., Dec. 19 is the deadline for Dec. 23 arrival, via regular-carrier economy Federal Express. Order by the 21st for arrival on the 23d by standard Federal Express, and you'll pay more. Should the order be placed on the 22d, it may or may not arrive on Saturday the 24th, since not all ZIP codes have Saturday delivery, said Nikki Kayser, a customer service representative. "There's a priority Federal Express," Ms. Kayser said, "but only certain areas are served by that."
* Calyx & Corolla -- (800) 800-7788 -- in San Francisco guarantees delivery of fresh flowers, plants and dried arrangements by the 24th, if the order is placed by Dec. 22 at noon, Pacific standard time. All orders are shipped Federal Express.
* The deadline for ordering from Williams-Sonoma, Pottery Barn, Hold Everything, Gardeners Eden and Chambers -- all (800) 922-5507 -- in San Francisco, is Dec. 23 at noon, Pacific standard time. Delivery by Federal Express is the next day. Large furniture items cannot be shipped overnight.
* Hammacher Schlemmer -- (800) 543-3366 -- in Chicago has a deadline of Dec. 23 at noon, Eastern standard time, for delivery by the 24th via Federal Express.
* At the Sharper Image -- (800) 344-4444 -- with headquarters in San Francisco orders must be placed by Dec. 23 at 6 P.M., Pacific standard time, for Federal Express delivery on the 24th.
